column2: Pedro Rodríguez filled in for Barcelona’s missing star forwards by scoring three goals in 10 minutes in a wild 5-2 win at Getafe.

PUCCI--Umberto. 1930-2013 R.I.P. Our first Christmas apart in 49 years. Richard
McGUIRE--Muriel Margaret. Merry Christmas Mom. Remembering you, missing you, loving you always. Sissy

MACHOL--Betty F. Kurzman 12/24/1921 - 8/10/2012 The table is set, plates are full the wine sparkles yet the taste is bittersweet as we in unison raise them to wish with all our hearts, that together today we could all be celebrating your 92nd birthday. Marking of yet another year passed without the generous, sincerely tender loving words you spoke in which we hold in our hearts as incentives to conduct, by which we honor your memory. Each birthday's coming and going will be a seal of love everlasting that abides in my heart, not just this day special, but always on all days. Erwin
GOLDSMITH--Marc Sandy. Dearly missed. 12/17/72- 12/26/11. Love, Mom, Dad, Ama & Fae
GLICKSMAN--Albert, Aly - Dearest husband, Happy Anniversary on the 24th, Merry Christmas on the 25th, and Happy Birthday on the 26th. Love Fran

WILSON--Robert W.,The Metropolitan Opera mourns the death of one of our most generous and passionate supporters, Robert W. Wilson. Mr. Wilson served as a Managing Director on the Met Board. He was uncompromising in his devotion to opera and support of the Met, encouraging other donors to increase their giving through a series of challenge grants. Mr. Wilson was also dedicated to the preservation of historic Met performances, helping to fund the restoration of tapes and recordings of hundreds of historic Met broadcasts. He was one of the initial financial supporters of the Met's chair-back subtitling system that was transformative for the understanding and appreciation of opera. We offer our sincere condolences to his family, friends, and many admirers. Ann Ziff, Chairman Kevin W. Kennedy, President Peter Gelb, General Manager James Levine, Music Director The Board of Directors of the Metropolitan Opera Association

SILBERSTEIN--Doris M.,88, on December 22, 2013. Beloved wife of the late Richard. Loving mother of Laura and husband Joseph Nolan, David and wife Susan, and Samuel. Cherished grandmother of Nicole Madonna Rosario and husband John, Nathaniel Silberstein and wife Maeva, Emily Silberstein, and Paul Nolan. Loving great- grandmother of Elias Rosario. Dear sister of Adrian Ettelson. She was the center of our family and we will greatly miss her.

SCHNEIDER--Leona (Berman), formerly of New Jersey, Wantagh, NY and Indianapolis, IN on December 23, 2013. Wife of the late Milton Schneider. Mother of Toby Raich and her husband Stephen, and the late Lawrence Schneider and his surviving wife Patty. Grandmother of Rebecca Raich and William Raich. Sister of the late Harold Berman. Companion of the late Morris Lefkowitz. Graveside services at New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY on Friday, December 27 at 1:00pm. In lieu of flowers, remembrances may be made to Hadassah. Schlossberg-Solomon Chapel "Family Owned" www.Schlossberg Chapel.com info@schlossbergchapel.com 781-828-6990

SCHACHNE--David. With profound sadness, the Board of Directors, Administration and Staff of the Gurwin Jewish Nursing & Rehabilitation Center mourn the loss of our esteemed board member and Treasurer, David Schachne. David was a strong advocate for the creation of our Center and remained a devoted leader for more than two decades. Together he and Dorothy dedicated the Schachne Pavillion touching the lives of so many. His valuable counsel and leadership through the years helped to make the Gurwin name synonymous with excellence in caring for the elderly and those in need. Most of all he was a gentleman, sincere in his desire to make our community a better place for all. We express heartfelt condolences to his beloved wife, Dorothy, his children Sydney and Jay and the entire family. Lawrence Simon, Chairman Bert E. Brodsky, President Herbert H. Friedman, Exec VP

SCHACHNE--David Irwin, 88, founding partner of Fairfield Properties. David I. Schachne, son of Pauline and Abraham Schachne, died peacefully at his home in Commack today. He is survived by his beloved wife Dorothy of 66 years, sons Sydney and Jay, daughters-in- law Lesly and Andrea, grandchildren Brian, Heather, Seth, lan, and Elana, sister Doris, as well as many nieces, nephews, and cousins. David had a full life. At age 18, he enlisted in the army and fought in the Battle of the Bulge where he was wounded and received a Purple heart. He graduated from NYU with a degree in accounting. After many years as a practicing CPA he developed an interest in real estate, subsequently becoming a founding partner in Fairfield properties where he enjoyed working until his final days. Mr. Schachne's philanthropies extended to Flatbush Park Jewish Center, Yeshiva University where he was bestowed an honorary doctorate of humanities, Wurzweiler school of social work, Brookdale hospital, Gurwin Jewish Geriatric Center, Jinsa, Shaare Zedek hospital In Israel, Jinsa, and Cancer Care. Because he believed In doing what he could to improve the human condition and to relieve pain and suffering of his fellow man he actively served on the boards of these Institutions. Above all, Mr. Schachne embodied the true essence of "Tzadik", a righteous man who loved life, his family and friends. For all who knew him and loved him he will live forever. Shiva will be observed at his home in Commack.

SCHACHNE--David. The Board of Trustees, Administration, Medical Staff and Staff of the Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center mourn the loss of David Schachne, Chairman Emeritus of the Finance Committee and dedicated supporter of the hospital. Brookdale's Schulman and Schachne Institute for Nursing and Rehabilitation is named in his honor. Our sincere condolences to his wife Dorothy, sons Sidney and Jay and the entire Schachne family. Alexander Rovt, Ph.D., Chairman Board of Trustees Mark E. Toney, President and CEO

SANDAK--Gerald. The Rosenthal family and staff of Rosenthal & Rosenthal offer our deepest sympathy on the passing of Gerald Sandak, former Senior Executive Vice President. Our condolences to his wife, Gee, his daughter Barbara, and son, Mitch and their families. Jerry will be truly missed by everyone.
REISEN--Mitzi. Beautiful, Spirited Mother and Grandmother will be Remembered for her wit Spunk and companionship.

POOR--J. Sheppard, Died December 15. A life-long resident of Locust who, after attending Williams, graduated from Harvard Business School. He was a WWII Navy pilot; a banker in New York, Paris and London, and always an avid sailor. He was the beloved husband of the late Lee and father of Avery, Penelope and Deborah. A service will be held in the spring.

PALESTINE--Victor R.,"Dick," age 97, of New Bedford, died December 22, 2013 surrounded by his loving family at his longtime home in New Bedford. He was the husband of Shirley G. (Ganzer) Palestine for the past 63 years. Born in Mount Vernon, NY, a son of the late Jacob and Sarah (Workman) Palestine, he spent his youth in New York, moving to New Bedford in 1948. A graduate of Lehigh University, class of 1938, he was a Veteran of the United States Army having served as a Captain during World War II. He then became owner-operator of the former Gro-Togs Inc. in New Bedford for many years, retiring in 1968. After retirement, he earned his Masters Degree in Psychology from Yeshiva University, Class of 1974 and became a practicing psychologist in New Bedford for over 20 years. Surviving in addition to his wife: daughter: Jane Jamieson and husband Frederick of Waban, MA, son: Samuel G. Palestine and wife Maryann of Boynton Beach, FL, grandchildren: Sarah Palestine, William and Peter Jamieson, and many nieces and nephews. He was brother of the late Lester, Julius, Herbert, Marc, William, Bella, Flora, Jean, and Rita. A Memorial Service will be held Friday, December 27, 2013 at 11:00am in Tifereth Israel Synagogue, 145 Brownell Ave., New Bedford, MA 02740. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to the Rabbi's Discretionary Fund at Tifereth Israel Synagogue, or Community Nurses and Hospice, 62 Center St. Fairhaven, MA 02719. Burial private. Directions, tributes: www.waring-sullivan.com. Services in the care of Dartmouth Funeral Home, Dartmouth.

MARSHALL--Mildred P. Milly Marshall died peacefully in her apartment at Essex Meadows on December 19. She was born June 5, 1921 in Memphis, the youngest of the three Puryear girls, belles of Memphis society. Her father, a prominent attorney, died when she was eight, and she was raised through the Depression years by her mother. Graduating from the Hutchison School in Memphis, she went to Vassar College on a scholarship, graduating in 1942 with an economics major. She went to Washington during World War II to work as Assistant to the Rubber Director in the Office of Price Administration. A year later in Washington she married a handsome Navy lieutenant, Bob Marshall (Princeton '40), who would remain the focus of her life for the next 64 years. Milly and Bob moved to Bronxville, NY in 1950 and were pillars of the community for more than 50 years. Milly taught Sunday School at Christ Church, was on the board of the Bronxville Junior League, helped her three children, Bob Jr., Sara and Nancy, with their homework while herself studying at Union Theological Seminary, where she also served on the board. Inspired by a lecture at Union that challenged the audience to improve city schools, Milly rounded up a half-dozen mothers to take suburban students in to Harlem every Wednesday afternoon to a tutoring program that had just been started. With Milly providing crucial early leadership, the East Harlem Tutorial Program has grown from an organization with a $30,000 budget when she started to a $10 million enterprise today. Drawing on her experience caring for her older sister Narnie as she died, Milly became a board member of Concern for Dying, an early proponent of living wills. Later in life, Milly pioneered again, as one of the first to obtain a Masters in Health Advocacy from Sarah Lawrence College. She helped organize Jansen Memorial Hospice in Tuckahoe and became an active volunteer for the Cancer Support Team in Rye. Milly was a member of Nondescript, Little Forum and the Field Club in Bronxville, the Cosmopolitan Club in New York and the Ausable Club. Never one to flaunt her accomplishments or intelligence, Milly was known and cherished by all for her Southern graciousness, sparkling humor and sincere empathy for everyone she met. To her dying day, she never complained or said a mean word. Everything and everyone was "the best," " the most fun," "the nicest," "the most delicious." She loved people, and they loved her. The family will host a memorial service at Christ Church, Bronxville, on January 25, 2014. Memorial gifts may be sent to East Harlem Tutorial Program, 2050 Second Avenue, New York, NY 10029.

KENNER--Eugene, on December 21 at age 91 in Rye NY. Beloved husband of Barbara (Berg) Kenner. Devoted father of Sharon Heiman, Brian Kenner, Todd Kenner and Andrea Kinnard. Adoring grandfather of ten and a great-grandchild. Loving uncle and great-uncle. Predeceased by late wife Rhoda (Daum) and former wife Elaine (Greenberg). An admired and respected CPA, he retired as a partner from Lipsky, Goodkin. He was a model of generosity and kindness to all who knew him. Service December 23, 12:30pm, Ferncliff Cemetery, Hartsdale.

KELLERMAN--Joan. The Board of Directors, residents and staff of the Hebrew Home at Riverdale deeply mourn the loss of Joan Kellerman. Joan, who was a beloved RiverWalk resident, was a warm and caring woman who will be missed by her family and all who had the privilege of knowing her. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the entire Kellerman family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion. The Hebrew Home at Riverdale Daniel Reingold, President and CEO

KARR--Christy, 93, of Agawam, MA died December 19, 2013. He was married to the love of his life, Elizabeth Flanagan. Known as "Dear Old Dad" by his children, Christy Jr. (wife Peggy), Richard (wife Ellen) and Elizabeth (Liz) Rodbell (husband Mitchell). Loved by his grandchildren, Danielle, Joanna, Emily, Ryan, Hannah, Sarah and Luca his great-grandchild. He graduated Brown University and served in WWII as a Navy Lieutenant. His career included management positions in the steel industry and then was President of AAIM a consulting firm until he retired at 84. He loved football, music and politics but most of all his family. Funeral services will be held in Brockton, MA on Saturday. A Memorial service will be held at Liz Rodbell's home in NYC on January 9th at 6:00pm. For full obituary, visit www.Russellpicafuneralhome.com

HAGAN--William A. Jr.,of Garden City, NY on December 23, 2013. Beloved brother of Mary Ellen Boyrer. Cherished Uncle of William Boyrer, Francois Hagan and Andre Hagan. Also survived by many dear friends at the Garden City Golf Club. In repose at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd. Manhasset, NY on Thursday 3-5pm and 7-9pm. Funeral Mass: Friday, 11:15am, at St. Mary's Church in Manhasset. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Henry Viscardi School, 201 I.U. Willets Road, Albertson, New York 11507.

GOTTESMAN--Barbara, 86, died peacefully at home on December 21st, 2013. A lifelong New Yorker, Barbara and her late husband, Bertram cherished time in Manhattan enjoying the arts and a wide circle of friends. Barbara was the loving mother to daughters Deborah Schwarz, Pamela Auer and son Jeffrey (Rhonda) Schwarz. Passionate, generous, smart, and stylish, Barbara was a voracious reader, avid traveler, and a huge supporter of the arts. She was very successful in the New York real estate world at BJ Gottesman Company for many years. Along with Deborah, Pamela and Jeffrey, Barbara leaves eight grandchildren: Eric McGregor, David McGregor, Alison McGregor, Jason (Heather) Auer, Gregory Auer, Julia Auer, Adam (Amber) Schwarz, Amy Schwarz. The funeral will be held at Weinstein Memorial Chapel, 1652 Central Park Ave., Yonkers, NY at noon on Friday, December 27th, 2013. Burial will follow at Mount Pleasant Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY.

GIAMBELLI--Mary. We are deeply saddened by the loss of our dear friend, owner of Giambelli's 50th Ristorante with her late husband Francesco. She was generous, kind and loved by all who knew her. May she rest in God's eternal peace. WeiserMazars LLP

FOX--Jean, a lifelong new Yorker, died at home in Manhattan on December 13th, 2013, two weeks before her 98th birthday. She was a champion of social justice, an advocate for senior tenants rights, and a devoted wife for 66 years to Sidney Fox, predeceased in 2010. Survived by her two sons, Terry and Paul; her daughters-in-law Susan and Franne; her grandchildren, Avra, Aaron, and Sydney; her grandson-in-law Jose; and her great-granddaughter Matilda; along with her caregiver of many years, Leanne Ford.

CLINCH--Wayne M.,62, on December 15, 2013 at Southampton Hospital after a brief illness. Carolyn Gay, his beloved wife was with him when he passed. Resident of Montauk, NY and formerly of Brooklyn Heights, he retired 2010 as Managing Director of Marsh & McLennan in New York following a 30 year career as an insurance broker. Also survived by loving sister, Betsy, nieces and nephews. Mass and interment was December 19th in Montauk. Donations may be made to St. Therese Church, 67 South Essex St., Montauk, NY 11954 or Montauk Library, PO Box 700, Montauk, NY 11954.

CAREW--Raymond, 73, of Garden City, NY, died on December 21st. Beloved husband of Alexandre, loving father of Michael. Treasured brother of Cyril (Una), James (Mary Ann) and sister, Marie Heaney. Predeceased by his brother, William (Josephine). Adored uncle of many nieces and nephews. Visiting December 26th, 2-4 and 7-9pm at Fairchild Sons Funeral Home, 1201 Franklin Ave Garden City. Mass of the Resurrection on December 27th l0am at St. Joseph's R.C. Church, Garden City. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory may be made to either Covenant House, Times Square Station P.O. Box 731 New York, NY 10108-0900 or St. Luke's Education Foundation, Inc. 608 E. 139th Street Bronx, NY 10454.

BRONFMAN--Edgar M. We had a dream for Jewish life at New York University. You made it come true. We shall always be grateful. Naomi B. Levine, Past Chair Dr. Susan Dickman Rabbi Andy Bachman Cindy Greenberg David Rittberg Rabbi Yehuda Sarna

BRONFMAN--Edgar M. The Collegiate School community mourns the passing of Edgar M. Bronfman. His contributions to Collegiate were significant; his impact on the world was immeasurable. We extend our deepest condolences to the entire Bronfman family. George R. Bason, Jr. '72 President, Board of Trustees Dr. Lee M. Levison Headmaster

BRONFMAN--Edgar M.,Z"L. Mariana and Eduardo Elsztain mourn the passing of great leader and friend, Edgar M. Bronfman. We extend our deepest condolences to his family. His contribution to the Jewish People is immeasurable and will forever be remembered. May his family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem.

BRONFMAN--Edgar M. The Hebrew Charter School Center is deeply saddened by the loss of a true friend and inspiration, Edgar M. Bronfman, Sr. We are forever indebted to him for enthusiastically supporting our mission to educate children across America in the language and culture of Israel. We offer our sincerest condolences to his wife, Jan Aronson, and his children, grandchildren, and great-grandchildren. Sara Berman, Chair, Hebrew Charter School Center

BRONFMAN--Edgar. Together with the global Jewish community, The Wexner Foundation mourns the death of Edgar Bronfman, of blessed memory. Edgar was a rare and wise leader, a giant in the field of Jewish philanthropy as he was in business. He was a treasured colleague and friend to our chairmen, Abigail and Leslie Wexner. Edgar and Les shared a long and enduring commitment to Jewish life, Jewish learning and to supporting Jewish leaders. Edgar Bronfman's legacy shall endure in the vast communities he has inspired and influenced. May Edgar's family be comforted among all who mourn in Zion and Jerusalem. Leslie and Abigail Wexner, Chairmen Rabbi B. Elka Abrahamson, President Larry S. Moses, President Emeritus The Wexner Foundation

BRONFMAN--Edgar M. The Aleph Society mourns the passing of Edgar M. Bronfman, Sr., father of our esteemed benefactor Matthew Bronfman. A visionary philanthropist and leader, he was an ardent supporter of Jews and Israel. The legacy of his loving-kindness continues through the good deeds and the grace of his children and grandchildren. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Adin Steinsaltz

BRONFMAN--Edgar M. The American Society for Yad Vashem mourns the passing of the Chairman of its International Board. Mr. Bronfman championed Holocaust remembrance and education and became an early supporter of Yad Vashem. He was instrumental in winning the fight for financial restitution of Holocaust victims and their heirs. Our sincerest condolences to his wife, Jan Aronson, his children Samuel II, Edgar Jr, Matthew, Holly, Lev, Adam, Sara Igtet, and Clare, to his brother Charles, his sister, Phyllis Lambert, and to his extended family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Leonard Wilf, Chairman

BRONFMAN--Edgar, Sr. The Board and Staff of the American Friends and of the Israel Museum mourn the death of Edgar Bronfman, Sr. one of the early founders of our Samuel and Saydie Bronfman Archeology Wing. Heartfelt condolences to Jan, Charles, Matthew and the entire family. Ninah Lynne President, AFIM Board Stephen S. Lash Co-Chairman, AFIM Board Judy Steinhardt Co-Chairman, AFIM Board James S. BRONFMAN--Edgar M.,Sr. The Trustees, Faculty and Staff of the Mount Sinai Health System are deeply saddened by the passing of Edgar M. Bronfman, Sr., an outstanding philanthropist and dedicated member of the Mount Sinai Boards of Trustees from 1957 to 1985. The generosity of Mr. Bronfman and the Samuel Bronfman Foundation made a significant, enduring impact on our institution, in particular naming the Samuel Bronfman Department of Medicine. We are deeply grateful for Mr. Bronfman's support and extend our heartfelt condolences to our Trustee Charles Bronfman and the entire Bronfman family. Peter W. May, Chairman of the Boards of Trustees Kenneth L. Davis, M.D., President and CEO Dennis S. Charney, M.D., Anne and Joel Ehrenkranz Dean, Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai and President for Academic Affairs Valentin Fuster, M.D., PhD, Physician-in-Chief, Director, Mount Sinai Heart, Zena and Michael A. Wiener Cardiovascular Institute, Marie-Josee and Henry R. Kravis Center for Cardiovascular Health and Richard Gorlin, M.D./ Heart Research Foundation Professor of Cardiology Mount Sinai Health System

BRONFMAN--Edgar. The Officers, Board, and staff of World ORT mourn the tremendous loss of Edgar Bronfman. The dear friend and dedicated leader of the Jewish people, Edgar, has provided invaluable wisdom, and boundless dedication to some of the world's largest Jewish organizations, impacting the lives of Jews around the world. As the longtime president of the World Jewish Congress, Edgar fought for Jewish rights worldwide. For the past 30 years he also devoted his efforts to teens and college students connecting them to their Jewish heritage and to Israel. World ORT extends our deepest condolences to his wife, children, brother, sister and grandchildren. May his memory be for a blessing. Dr. Jean de Gunzburg, World ORT President Mauricio Merikanskas, Chairman of the Board of Trustees Conrad Giles, Deputy President Shmuel Sisso, Director General and CEO World ORT

BRONFMAN--Edgar M. My deepest sympathy in the hour of bereavement to his lovely wife and family. Edgar was a lasting and old friend. My heart and thoughts are with his family. He will be very much missed. Elaine Sargent

BRONFMAN--Edgar M. The students, staff and Advisory Board members of the Bronfman Center for Jewish Student Life at New York University mourn with great sadness the passing of our founder, mentor and guide, Edgar M. Bronfman Sr. A great man with deep concern for the Jewish People and its global welfare, Mr. Edgar Bronfman's passion for pluralism, inclusiveness, and Torah study inspired thousands of Jewish youth, catalyzing a generational renaissance. Mr. Bronfman's bold and generous ambitions for the future of the Jewish community will continue to be fulfilled, though we will miss his presence. We remain eternally grateful. Steven M. Cohen, Dorothy Tananbaum, Rabbi Yehuda Sarna

BRONFMAN--Edgar M. The Foundation for Ethnic Understanding mourns the passing of our generous supporter, a tireless advocate for human rights and racial harmony. Heartfelt sympathy to the entire family. Rabbi Marc Schneier, President Russell Simmons, Chairman Ken Sunshine, Secretary

BRONFMAN--Edgar M. New York University mourns the passing of Edgar M. Bronfman Sr., founder of the Bronfman Center for Jewish Student Life at New York University. A visionary leader, businessman and philanthropist, Mr. Bronfman's generosity provides an enduring gift to the thousands of students, parents and alumni inspired by the Center bearing his name. We extend our deepest condolences to the entire Bronfman family and pledge to uphold his legacy. Martin Lipton, John Sexton

BRONFMAN--Edgar. The Anti-Defamation League mourns the loss of Edgar Bronfman, a long-time friend of the League and Honorary National Vice Chair. Edgar was for many years Chair of our Liquor Industry Division, Chair of our New York Appeal and one of our most significant benefactors. We remember with pride that we honored Edgar for his leadership here in New York and on the national level. He was the moving force behind the settlement with Swiss banks for restitution for Holocaust survivors. His decades of strong advocacy on behalf of the Jewish community here at home and around the globe earned him a place in the pantheon of outstanding Jewish leaders. He will be fondly remembered for his leadership, his integrity and his abiding commitment to the Jewish people. Barry Curtiss-Lusher, National Chair Abraham H. Foxman, National Director

BRONFMAN--Edgar M. Hillel: The Foundation for Jewish Campus Life joins the many sorrowful voices in the global Jewish community and sends it heartfelt condolences to the family of our dear friend Edgar M. Bronfman. A legend not only in business, but also in philanthropy, Edgar was essential as the founding chair of Hillel's International Board of Governors in the transformation and renaissance at Hillel. His good deeds have touched the hearts and souls of hundreds of thousands of Jewish students. He was an exemplary Jewish leader and humanitarian. A giant among men in all that he did. A man of courage and integrity with a generous spirit, wisdom and kindness. His legacy will be carried on in the many Jewish lives he has inspired. Our condolences go to Jan, Charles, Matthew, Adam and the rest of the Bronfman family. May they be comforted among the other mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. May his memory be a comfort and blessing. Randall Kaplan, Chair of Intl Board of Governors; Sidney Pertnoy, Chair of Intl Board of Directors; Eric D. Fingerhut, President and CEO, Hillel Intl.

BRONFMAN--Edgar M. Taglit-Birthright Israel, Birthright Israel Foundation, NEXT, a division of Birthright Israel Foundation, and their officers and professionals, mourn the passing of Edgar M. Bronfman, one of this generation's most pre-eminent and dedicated Jewish leaders. Awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom in 1999, he will be remembered for his passionate advocacy for the rights of the Jewish people, for supporting Jewish identity for future generations and for demonstrating by personal example the power of one individual to help create a better world. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife, Jan Aronson; his brother and our founder, Charles R. Bronfman; his sister, Phyllis Lambert; and his entire immediate and extended family. He will forever be remembered as an exemplar of leadership for the Jewish people. Gidi Mark, CEO, Taglit-Birthright Israel; David Fisher, President, Birthright Israel Foundation; Morlie Levin, CEO, NEXT

BRONFMAN--Edgar. The Board of ELEM/Youth in Distress in Israel mourns the passing of Edgar Bronfman--a great philanthropist and supporter of Israel and its youth. Our deepest condolences to the Bronfman Family. Lenore Ruben, President, ELEM/U.S.A.

BRONFMAN--Edgar M. Beit Hatfutsot, The Museum of the Jewish People, mourns the loss of Edgar M. Bronfman benefactor and Honorary Chairman of its American Friends, and offers heartfelt condolences to the grieving family. Edgar Bronfman was steadfastly dedicated to celebrating diverse expressions of Jewish life while affirming the unity of the Jewish people; facilitating exploration of Jewish identity and meaningful engagement by transmitting the stories and ethics of our ancestors; empowering young Jews with pride in their heritage. His commitment and passion for Jewish history and peoplehood will endure and continue to inspire us. Irina Nevzlin Kogan, Chair, Beit Hatfutsot Judith Stern Peck, President, AFBH Sam E. Bloch, Chairman, AFBH Shula Bahat, CEO, Beit Hatfutsot of America

Bronfman--Edgar. The Trustees and Governors of Skowhegan School of Painting & Sculpture extend condolences to longtime Trustee Jan Aronson and the Bronfman family on the passing of Jan's beloved husband Edgar, a visionary philanthropist and great friend to artists.

WILSON--Robert W. The Whitney Museum of American Art is greatly saddened by the loss of our beloved and outspoken Trustee Robert W. Wilson. Bob served on the Board for 35 years in many capacities including Vice Chairman, Vice President, Chairman of the Investment Committee and longtime member of the Executive Committee. He passionately believed in the risk-taking mission of the Whitney and was one of the Museum's most beneficent supporters in its 82 year history. His giving was always focused on motivating others to donate with equal generosity, evidenced by his $25 million challenge grant to the Museum's current capital campaign. Bob loved conservation of cultural legacies in all its manifestations and in 2000 spearheaded the funding for the Whitney's first Conservation Department. We will greatly miss his honesty, forthrightness, wicked sense of humor and willingness to call a spade a spade. He was a singular man; the hole he leaves will never be completely filled. Flora Miller Biddle, Honorary Chairman Leonard A. Lauder, Chairman Emeritus Robert J. Hurst, Co-Chairman Brooke Garber Neidich, Co-Chairman Neil G. Bluhm, President Adam D. Weinberg, Alice Pratt Brown Director

WILSON--Robert W. The Board and Staff of The New York Landmarks Conservancy mourn the passing of our longtime friend and benefactor Robert W. Wilson. Though not religious himself, Bob understood the importance of saving religious institutions for their architecture, history and community programs. Through the years, his extraordinary support of our Sacred Sites Program helped restore more than 120 religious institutions across the State. We will be forever grateful for his immense good works. Lloyd P. Zuckerberg, Chair Peg Breen, President
WILSON--Robert W. We greatly mourn the loss of a truly exceptional friend. Paul LeClerc & Judith Ginsberg

WILSON--Robert W.,The Wildlife Conservation Society mourns the death of the great philanthropist, Robert W. Wilson. Bob Wilson supported WCS for more than four decades. His strategic thinking and financial investment transformed WCS from a New York-based institution with a small conservation program into a global conservation authority with its foundation and roots in the New York cultural landscape. He dispatched a team to evaluate our overseas programs and helped us to build our capacity, encouraging others to match his generosity. He inspired us to grow our programs and their influence. His support created institutional momentum that will carry us well into the future. His investment in WCS resulted in protection of wild species and the preservation of wild places around the world - resources of both global significance and importance for local people. Bob Wilson will be remembered as a great and transforming conservationist. WCS extends its sympathies to his family and friends.

WILSON--Robert W. Together with the philanthropic community, the partners of Anchin Block & Anchin LLP mourn the passing of Robert W. Wilson, who has been a client of our firm for over thirty years. As well as being an astute businessman, Bob was a pioneer in the field of philanthropy. In addition to giving the majority of his fortune to charity, his leveraged techniques were transformative to the institutions and the causes he supported, and have forever changed philanthropic giving. Richard Schneidman and the Partners of Anchin Block & Anchin LLP.

WILSON--Robert W. The Trustees and staff of The New York Public Library deeply mourn the passing of one of the greatest champions and most generous supporters of the Library in its long history. From the time that he made his first gift to the Library in 1966, Bob developed a visionary and monumental philanthropy that has helped the Library expand access to our research collections in many ways. He was one of our first supporters to recognize the importance of electronic applications for libraries, and he significantly underwrote the conversion of our card catalog to electronic form. With his subsequent support, the Library has been able to open extraordinary numbers of research materials to scholars and people everywhere both on-site and online, to add important archives and other primary source materials to the collections, and to preserve these invaluable holdings for future generations. We will all miss his great friendship and lively spirit. We offer our deepest sympathies to his friends and family. Neil L. Rudenstine, Chairman; Samuel C. Butler, Catherine Marron, Elizabeth Rohatyn, Marshall Rose, Chairmen Emeriti; Anthony W. Marx, President; Paul LeClerc, Vartan Gregorian, Presidents Emeriti

WILSON--Robert W. A unique, innovative and philanthropic man, died December 23, 2013 in New York City. He is survived by his brother William Wilson II, his nephew William Wilson III, and his niece Karen DeFiore. Born in Detroit, Michigan in 1926, he graduated magna cum laude, Phi Beta Kappa from Amherst College and received a master's degree in economics from the University of Michigan. He worked for a number of investment firms in the 50s and 60s and in 1969 started his own hedge fund. He was an astute investor and soon gained a reputation as Wall Street's premier short seller. Before retiring in 1986, he had been able to parlay an initial stake of $15,000 from his mother into an immense fortune and then spent the latter part of his life giving it away. He was an ardent conservationist, with the goal of preserving natural and man-made wonders. His philanthropy in that field was transformative for many of the institutions he supported. Ever the astute businessman, he was a pioneer in leveraged philanthropy, which, through the use of many unique and innovative programs, challenged the recipient organizations to achieve unique benchmarks, which strengthened and improved them far in excess of his contributions. His philanthropy was diverse, touching on many of his other interests: the arts, education, and policy reform, to name a few. Bob was cultured and well-read, with an insatiable appetite for newspapers and news journals. He loved fine restaurants and wine, and was passionate about opera and traveled all over the world to hear his favorites performed. He enjoyed movies and good jokes, and was delighted to email a long list of friends the latest and greatest anecdotes he had discovered. Bob was, no doubt, a man with the courage of his own convictions, albeit one who was willing to listen with an open mind to a new idea. Endowed with a brilliant mind, decisive and direct, he was always his own man. Throughout his career, he served on numerous boards and never hesitated to express his own strongly held opinions, no matter how controversial. Bob used his intelligence and his fortune to make the world a better place. That is his legacy. A memorial service for Bob will be announced at a later date.

VOZICK--Michael "Mike", 77, on December 21st, 2013, the Winter Solstice. Beloved brother to Bettina, Alexandra, and David, brother in-law to Paul Levinson, Michele Vozick, and Paul Hans. Cherished uncle to Molly and Simon Vozick-Levinson; Ben Isaac, Marc, and Zachary Thacher; Jesse, Julie, and Eric Vozick. Adored son of the late Ida and Hyman Vozick. An irreplaceable presence in the lives of countless friends and an invaluable teacher and colleague to many in the CUNY system and beyond. A tireless activist in pursuit of justice and equality for all oppressed people; a revolutionary thinker and eternal believer in the power of collective thought and action; a scientist, poet and deep spirit in touch with the Earth. From his historic work as a founder of San Francisco State's Experimental College in the 1960s to his devoted advocacy for adjunct professors' rights in recent years, Mike spent his life making a difference. He never stopped believing that a better world was possible, whether he was being arrested in the "Desegregate Route 40" Freedom Rides, protesting the Vietnam War, cheering on Occupy Wall Street, or sporting his signature "WAGE PEACE" button on the streets of New York. He leaves behind an unforgettable legacy of love, light, and humor and the inspiration of a mind that was thinking, questioning, confronting, and imagining to his very last day. Rising Turtle, supporting the Earth; Earth, supporting Rising Turtle. Rise on, Mike. A celebration of Mike's life will be held at noon on Thursday, December 26, 2013, at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue and 91st Street.

STIER--Eleanor, 88, died December 18 at home in Greenwich Village, where she resided more than 55 years. Born in Mount Vernon, NY she earned a BS cum laude at Columbia University and an MSW at Columbia's School of Social Work. An education policy analyst, she worked for 26 years at the Community Service Society and was a charter member of the Educational Priorities Panel, which monitored the NYC Board of Education's spending practices and helped reallocate funds from administration into classroom services. She was the longtime co-chair of the Education Committee of the Women's City Club of NY, which honored her contributions in May 2013. Predeceased by her brothers, Sidney and Joseph L. Stier, and her lifetime partner, Barbara Reach. Survived by her beloved niece and nephew, Audrey Adams-Doppelt (Neil) and Lawrence Stier (Ritann); adored great-nieces, Dr. Sarah Steinberg (Peter) and Dr. Rachel Adams; cherished great-great-nephews, Charles and Henry Steinberg; and many friends.

STEINBERG--Arnold, 92, of Parkland, Florida, died on December 24, 2013. Beloved husband of Lillian for 70 years. Loving father to Stuart, Meryl, and Jeffrey. Father-in-law to Fran, Ken, and Kay. Grandfather to Jennifer, Alison and Hasty, Michelle and Jonathan, Benjamin and Kira, Andrew and Valerie, Hyebin, Samantha, Melissa, Josh, and Courtney and Nick. Great-grandfather to Sadie, Etta, Austin, Jasper, and Skye. Brother to Gladys, Joyce, and the late Myron. He was the revered patriarch of the Steinberg & Pokoik Real Estate Family business for 70 years. His devotion to both family and business were unsurpassed. He was a member of the Seawane Club for over 50 years and served as its President. A member of Temple Israel of Lawrence for over 50 years and a great supporter of Israel. A proud American who served his country in WWII in the Pacific. He will be greatly missed by his loving family, friends, and the real estate community. Visitation: Thursday night, December 26th, 7-9pm. Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76th St., New York City. Graveside Funeral: Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Queens, NY Friday, December 27th, 1pm.

SPITALNY--William H.,died peacefully at home three months shy of his 99th birthday. He was the adored and adoring husband of Mickey, his wife for 69 years. He will be forever loved and in the hearts of his children Susan Jill Baten (Mickey) and Richard M. Spitalny (Dianne) and grandchildren Melissa, Amanda, Blythe, Beth and Dara and great-grandchildren Lainie, Cas, Zachy and Cecilia. A graduate of Michigan University's Law School, 1st Lieutenant in the Army, President of Independent Printing, Automatic Data Processing Board member, he was an extraordinary man whose kindness, generosity, intellect and wit gave us all a lifetime of unconditional love and support. It will always be a privilege and a blessing to be his family. Services Friday 10am. Westchester Reform Temple Scarsdale, NY.

SEIDENBERG--Barbara Balamut, died on December 23, 2013. Born on February 12, 1938, in Brooklyn, New York to the late Ralph and Dorothy Balamut, Barbara was a woman of valor. She lived life to the fullest, overcoming the continued health obstacles constantly thrown her way. Unfortunately, she could fight no longer and died peacefully in her sleep, in her own home. Predeceased by her husband Paul, Barbara is survived by her beloved grandchildren, Ryan, Ben, Jeremy, and Emma Seguljic, and children, Wendie and Jim Seguljic, Teresa and David Seidenberg. Donations can be made to: The Rogosin Institute, Development Office- HT 230, 505 East 70th Street New York, NY 10021.

SCHACHNE--David I. The Board of Trustees and staff of CancerCare were saddened to learn of the passing of David I. Schachne, husband of Dorothy, an esteemed and devoted member of our Board of Trustees. Our condolences to Dorothy, their children and grandchildren and the entire Schachne family.
REISEN--Mitzi. Beautiful, Spirited Mother and Grandmother will be Remembered for her wit Spunk and companionship.

LISS--Stanley, 97, died peacefully December 19, 2013. He is survived by his devoted and loving wife of 73 years, Ruth Schlesinger Liss, his son Robert Liss, a psycho-analyst, writer, and basketball coach who resides in San Francisco, and his grandson, David Liss. Stanley Liss was born in New York City on November 22, 1916, the first son of Jack and Fannie Hecht Liss, followed by Seymour and Teddy. After moving to England, he matriculated at The London Polytechnic School, and studied at The London School of Economics. He then became a partner in Jack Liss and Sons Company, an innovative import/export business in New York and London, known for introducing the notion of half-sizes in women's dresses, and for stressing the importance of exemplary ethics in business. Stanley was an outstanding athlete. In 1936, when Hank Luisetti was revolutionizing basketball by shooting with one hand, Stanley responded intuitively to the smaller English ball by doing the same. Only an injury prevented him from representing England in the 1936 Olympics. The loving tributes of his family, friends and associates uniformly described Stanley as the quintessential model of the perfect gentleman.

KLEIN--David, The Juilliard community mourns the death of David Klein, an active member of this nation's art world and the husband of Heidi Castleman, a distinguished member of the School's viola faculty. An engaged and knowledgeable supporter of the arts, his presence added immeasurably to the quality of life of our students. Our condolences go to his beloved wife Heidi and the members of his family. Joseph W. Polisi, President Ara Guzelimian, Provost and Dean Adam Meyer, Associate Dean

GOULD--Eveline, R.N. Adored, cherished mother, wife, grandmother, sister, aunt, counselor and friend. She was a beautiful, insightful person who touched the lives of so many. She will remain in our hearts forever.

BRONFMAN--Edgar M. Taglit-Birthright Israel, Birthright Israel Foundation, NEXT, a division of Birthright Israel Foundation, and their officers and professionals, mourn the passing of Edgar M. Bronfman, one of this generation's most pre-eminent and dedicated Jewish leaders. Awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom in 1999, he will be remembered for his passionate advocacy for the rights of the Jewish people, for supporting Jewish identity for future generations and for demonstrating by personal example the power of one individual to help create a better world. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife, Jan Aronson; his brother and our founder, Charles R. Bronfman; his sister, Phyllis Lambert; and his entire immediate and extended family. He will forever be remembered as an exemplar of leadership for the Jewish people. Gidi Mark, CEO, Taglit-Birthright Israel; David Fisher, President, Birthright Israel Foundation; Morlie Levin, CEO, NEXT

BRONFMAN--Edgar. The Jewish Museum mourns the loss of Edgar Bronfman, a true leader and philanthropist. His memory and impact continue to live on at the Museum through the Edgar M. Bronfman Education Center. Established on the occasion of Edgar's 60th birthday, the Center provides a range of programs for children, families and school groups. We extend our condolences to his wife Jan, children Adam, Clare, Edgar Jr., Holly, Matthew, Samuel, and Sara, to his brother Charles, sister Phyllis and to the entire family. Robert Pruzan, Chairman Claudia Gould, Helen Goldsmith Menschel Director

BOURAS--Nicholas J. A member of the greatest generation and a brother in Christ, fell asleep in the Lord on December 22, 2013, while surrounded by his loving family and friends at his residence in Summit, NJ. He was 93 and was blessed to have lived a wonderful life. Mr. Bouras enlisted in the United States Army Air Corps in 1942. By the end of 1945, he attained the rank of Major and flew 44 combat missions in the European theater as the lead navigator and bombardier of 36 B-26 bomber aircraft. In 1946, the President of the United States awarded Mr. Bouras the Distinguished Flying Cross and the Air Medal with seven oak leaf clusters. His assignments included the Headquarters 9th Air Force, 386th Bomb Group and the Headquarters 9th Air Division, 552nd Bomb Squadron. After his honorable discharge from the military, Mr. Bouras returned to his position with the United States Steel Corporation, where he remained for twenty years. In 1960, he and his late wife, Anna K. Bouras, embarked on an entrepreneurial career that led to the creation of one of America's leading manufacturers of fabricated steel components for the commercial real estate industry. For nearly 40 years, his privately owned company supplied steel to contractors who helped transform New York's skyline. In 1970, this impact on the skyline began with the construction of World Trade Center Tower 4 and was followed by the construction of headquarter buildings for Hearst, Bloomberg, Bear Sterns, and Goldman Sachs, as well as the Time Warner Center. His company also supplied steel for the construction of professional sports stadiums and arenas, which included the Yankees, Giants, Patriots, Ravens, Redskins, Celtics, 76ers, Wizards, and the Devils. In 2007, Bouras Industries ceased operations with the sale of four companies and over 700 employees. Mr. Bouras' business achievements enabled him to positively impact the lives of thousands of people in need, including those in pursuit of higher education, as well as numerous non-profit institutions throughout the world. He exhibited extraordinary commitment to his local parish, Holy Trinity Greek Orthodox Church, which he helped found and served on the Parish Council for over 40 years. His support of the Ecumenical Patriarchate, the Greek Orthodox Archdiocese of America, Hellenic College, Orthodox Christian Mission Center, and numerous philanthropic causes typified his enduring generosity for humanitarian projects. A 25 year member of the Archdiocesan Council and National Council of the Order of St. Andrew the Apostle, Archon Vice Commander Bouras was central to expanding initiatives of these important institutions. His philanthropy empowered the Order of St. Andrew to develop a multifaceted domestic and international strategic plan to secure religious freedom for the Ecumenical Patriarchate, the spiritual center of the world's 300 million Orthodox Christians located in Istanbul, Turkey. Mr. Bouras is the recipient of numerous awards and honors, including an Honorary Doctor of Humanities from Hellenic College, the Ellis Island Medal of Honor, the Alpha Omega Council Lifetime Achievement Award, the Hellenic Heritage Achievement Award from the American Hellenic Institute, the Entrepreneur of the Year Award from Ernst and Young, the Humanitarian Philanthropic Award from the Cyprus Federation of America, the Athenagoras Human Rights Award from the Order of St. Andrew the Apostle, and the Republican Senatorial Medal of Freedom, the highest honor the Republican members of the U.S. Senate can bestow. Born in Pontiac, MI, and raised in Chicago, Il, Mr. Bouras was an alumnus of Northwestern University. Mr. Bouras is survived by his sister-in-law Tina Kariotis and brother-in-law John Mathrusse; nieces Susan Tseng (Greg), Pamela Kariotis (James), Elizabeth Smejda (Karolus), and Georgeane Valos (John); nephews James Mathrusse (Jiemin) and Robert Kariotis; grandnieces Katie and Emma; and grandnephews Matt, Brian, Andrew, and Rocco. United States Presidents, world business leaders, and Veterans have had the distinct honor and pleasure to know and serve with Nicholas J. Bouras, who so distinguished himself in faithful service to his country, fellow man, and his beloved church. Funeral services will be held at Holy Trinity Greek Orthodox Church in Westfield, NJ as follows: A Viewing will take place on Friday, December 27, 2013 from 2pm to 8pm with Trisagion (Memorial) services every hour with Hierarchical Trisagion at 7pm. Funeral services will take place on Saturday, December 28, 2013 at 9am. Burial to follow at Fairview Cemetery in Westfield, NJ. Note: please send flowers to the church. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to St. Anna Greek Orthodox Church in Flemington, NJ and/or Holy Trinity Greek Orthodox Church in Westfield, NJ. Ser vices are being handled by Higgins and Bonner Echo Lake Funeral Home in Westfield, NJ. Condolences can be sent to the family at www.higginsandbonner.com

BOHRER--Harry, 90, on December 23, 2013. Beloved father of Margaret Beauregard, Jeffrey, Nat and Seth Bohrer, and Clifford Stanley. Dear brother of Moe Bohrer and Claire Abner. BAUM--Judith Jaffe. Dear sister of Susan Bloomenstein, sister-in-law of Richard Bloomenstein. Wonderfully caring aunt of Laura and Ellen, died suddenly on December 20, 2013. An all- around New Yorker with a warm and loving heart; Judy, we will love you and miss you forever.
BAUM--Judy. From Brooklyn to Manhattan and beyond, the best Best Friend ever. With much love, Mina, Elizabeth & John Greenstein
BARANKER--Anni. (nee Lobenberg), age 99. Beloved mother of Jane and Karen. Oma to Naomi, Ilana and Avi. Oma Anni to Dahlia and Lily. She will be missed deeply by us all.

BALDWIN--David S.,M.D. The distinguished physician and scholar died at the age of 92 in his sleep on December 23 at his home in New York City. Dr. Baldwin was born in Rochester, New York, where he trained at the University of Rochester School of Medicine. For half a century, this tireless pioneer in the origins of hypertension and nephritis practiced internal medicine at his office in Manhattan while teaching generations of aspiring doctors at Bellevue Hospital and New York University Tisch/Langone Medical Center as a Professor of Medicine. Dr. Baldwin was married for 68 years to Halee Jean (Morris) Baldwin, who survives him. He also leaves four loving sons and three daughters-in-law, Neil (Roberta), Andrew (Susan), Daniel (Nancy) and James; seven grandchildren, Nicholas, Allegra, Seth, Laura, Matthew, Joshua, and Julia; two great-grandchildren, Levi and Emily; as well as countless grateful patients and their families. Funeral services will be private.

WILSON--Robert W. The Whitney Museum of American Art is greatly saddened by the loss of our beloved and outspoken Trustee Robert W. Wilson. Bob served on the Board for 35 years in many capacities including Vice Chairman, Vice President, Chairman of the Investment Committee and longtime member of the Executive Committee. He passionately believed in the risk-taking mission of the Whitney and was one of the Museum's most beneficent supporters in its 82 year history. His giving was always focused on motivating others to donate with equal generosity, evidenced by his $25 million challenge grant to the Museum's current capital campaign. Bob loved conservation of cultural legacies in all its manifestations and in 2000 spearheaded the funding for the Whitney's first Conservation Department. We will greatly miss his honesty, forthrightness, wicked sense of humor and willingness to call a spade a spade. He was a singular man; the hole he leaves will never be completely filled. Flora Miller Biddle, Honorary Chairman Leonard A. Lauder, Chairman Emeritus Robert J. Hurst, Co-Chairman Brooke Garber Neidich, Co-Chairman Neil G. Bluhm, President Adam D. Weinberg, Alice Pratt Brown Director
COHEN--Israel, el pasha. LOVE LASTS Grace, Ellen, David, Romy, Oliver, Sylvie, Nathaniel and Ezra

WILSON--Robert W. The Trustees and staff of The New York Public Library deeply mourn the passing of one of the greatest champions and most generous supporters of the Library in its long history. From the time that he made his first gift to the Library in 1966, Bob developed a visionary and monumental philanthropy that has helped the Library expand access to our research collections in many ways. He was one of our first supporters to recognize the importance of electronic applications for libraries, and he significantly underwrote the conversion of our card catalog to electronic form. With his subsequent support, the Library has been able to open extraordinary numbers of research materials to scholars and people everywhere both on-site and online, to add important archives and other primary source materials to the collections, and to preserve these invaluable holdings for future generations. We will all miss his great friendship and lively spirit. We offer our deepest sympathies to his friends and family. Neil L. Rudenstine, Chairman; Samuel C. Butler, Catherine Marron, Elizabeth Rohatyn, Marshall Rose, Chairmen Emeriti; Anthony W. Marx, President; Paul LeClerc, Vartan Gregorian, Presidents Emeriti

WILSON--Robert W.,World Monuments Fund pays tribute to Robert W. Wilson, visionary philanthropist whose generosity helped to secure the planet and its great cultural legacy. WMF Trustee since 1989, Robert Wilson helped the organization grow, placing targeted support behind critical preservation work the world. His Wilson Challenge to Conserve our Heritage created a global incentive for individuals and governments to invest in the conservation of monuments of outstanding significance. After a successful career in the financial sector, Wilson focused his life on using his wealth for the benefit of others present and future. WMF trustees, staff and worldwide partners will remember his wry humor, his penetrating intelligence, and his warm humanity. Nearly 200 sites around the world, preserved through the Wilson Challenge, will stand as a permanent legacy to his bold leadership. We regret his parting, but revere the example that he set.

HESS--Glen E.,born February 4, 1942, passed away December 20, 2013. He was preceded in death by his first wife, Victoria (nee Vala). He is survived by his wife Linda (nee Pollitt); his two children Gretchen (John) Trofa and Gregory (Meghan) Hess; his eight grandchildren Kristen, Jenny, Melissa, Becky, Libby Trofa and Joe, Will, Katie Hess; his mother-in-law Victoria Vala Dvorak, brother-in-law Alden (Karen) Vala, and nephew and niece Jason and Sally Vala. Glen was born and raised in the LaGrange area, where he was a founding member of the LaGrange Park Little League. He graduated from Riverside Brookfield High School in 1960, Cornell University in 1964 and Harvard Law School in 1968, where he was a member of the Harvard Law Review. He started his legal career as a corporate and securities lawyer with Kirkland & Ellis in Chicago, becoming partner and serving as a member of the Firm Committee for 22 years. He launched K&E's New York office in the early 1990s. A former member of the Board of Directors of Alpharma, Inc., Glen provided trusted counsel to many companies, including S.C. Johnson & Son, Hershey Corporation, AON Corporation, and FMC Corporation. He loved spending time with his family, enjoying 39 years of marriage to his high school sweetheart Vicki. Glen's other passions included the Chicago Cubs and golfing and fishing with friends and family. Visitation 4 to 9pm Friday, December 27 at Hallowell & James Funeral Home, 1025 W. 55th St., Countryside, IL. Family and friends are asked to gather for an 11am funeral service Saturday, December 28 at Grace Lutheran Church, 200 N. Catherine Ave., LaGrange, IL. Interment Private. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be given to PSP.org or a charity of your choice. Funeral Info 708-352-6500.

BROOKS--Stan, Senior Correspondent for 1010 WINS News Radio, passed away peacefully at home on December 23, 2013. Stan was the loving and adored husband of the late Lynn (Schwarz) Brooks, founder of Big Apple Greeter. Stan was born in Bronx, NY on January 24, 1927 to Herman Brooks and Mildred (Goldstein) Brooks. He was the brother of the late Alan Brooks. Stan attended DeWitt Clinton High School, City College of New York, and Syracuse University, where he received a Bachelor's Degree in English. Stan worked as a reporter and editor for Newsday for 11 years before becoming Assistant News Director of WINS in 1962. In 1965, as News Director, Stan led the transformation of WINS from a rock-and-roll station to the first-ever all-news radio station in the United States. Among the many highlights of his distinguished reporting career were coverage of the Attica Prison riot, Chappaquiddick, Vietnam War protests, civil rights demonstrations, the 1968 Democratic National Convention, and the attacks on the World Trade Center. Stan continued to work at WINS until shortly before his death. Stan was much beloved and admired by colleagues, friends, and family alike. He is survived by his sons, Rick, George, and Bennett, three daughters-in-law, seven grandchildren, two great-grandchildren, and six nieces and nephews. A funeral service will be held on Friday, December 27, 2013 at 1:30pm at the Riverside Chapel, 180 W. 76th St, NYC. In lieu of flowers, donations will be gratefully accepted by Big Apple Greeter, 1 Centre St, New York, NY 10007.

BRONFMAN--Edgar M.,Sr. The leadership and staff of the USC Shoah Foundation mourn the passing of our longtime friend and colleague, Edgar Bronfman, Sr. As a world leader, philanthropist, humanitarian, and staunch advocate for the Jewish people, and as the USC Shoah Foundation's Honorary Board Co-Chair for nearly two decades, Edgar was an inspiration and mentor to all of us helping to give voice to more than 50,000 survivors and witnesses of the Holocaust. His legacy of service and the impact of his efforts to stand against hatred and injustice and to expose evil around the world will be felt for generations to come. We extend our deepest sympathies to the entire Bronfman family. C. L. Max Nikias, President, University of Southern California; Steven Spielberg, Founder, USC Shoah Foundation; Robert J. Katz, Chair, Board of Councilors, USC Shoah Foundation; Stephen Smith, Executive Director, USC Shoah Foundation

BRONFMAN--Edgar M. Hillel: The Foundation for Jewish Campus Life joins the many sorrowful voices in the global Jewish community and sends it heartfelt condolences to the family of our dear friend Edgar M. Bronfman. A legend not only in business, but also in philanthropy, Edgar was essential as the founding chair of Hillel's International Board of Governors in the transformation and renaissance at Hillel. His good deeds have touched the hearts and souls of hundreds of thousands of Jewish students. He was an exemplary Jewish leader and humanitarian. A giant among men in all that he did. A man of courage and integrity with a generous spirit, wisdom and kindness. His legacy will be carried on in the many Jewish lives he has inspired. Our condolences go to Jan, Charles, Matthew, Adam and the rest of the Bronfman family. May they be comforted among the other mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. May his memory be a comfort and blessing. Randall Kaplan, Chair of Intl Board of Governors; Sidney Pertnoy, Chair of Intl Board of Directors; Eric D. Fingerhut, President and CEO, Hillel Intl.

BOURAS--Nicholas J. A member of the greatest generation and a brother in Christ, fell asleep in the Lord on December 22, 2013, while surrounded by his loving family and friends at his residence in Summit, NJ. He was 93 and was blessed to have lived a wonderful life. Mr. Bouras enlisted in the United States Army Air Corps in 1942. By the end of 1945, he attained the rank of Major and flew 44 combat missions in the European theater as the lead navigator and bombardier of 36 B-26 bomber aircraft. In 1946, the President of the United States awarded Mr. Bouras the Distinguished Flying Cross and the Air Medal with seven oak leaf clusters. His assignments included the Headquarters 9th Air Force, 386th Bomb Group and the Headquarters 9th Air Division, 552nd Bomb Squadron. After his honorable discharge from the military, Mr. Bouras returned to his position with the United States Steel Corporation, where he remained for twenty years. In 1960, he and his late wife, Anna K. Bouras, embarked on an entrepreneurial career that led to the creation of one of America's leading manufacturers of fabricated steel components for the commercial real estate industry. For nearly 40 years, his privately owned company supplied steel to contractors who helped transform New York's skyline. In 1970, this impact on the skyline began with the construction of World Trade Center Tower 4 and was followed by the construction of headquarter buildings for Hearst, Bloomberg, Bear Sterns, and Goldman Sachs, as well as the Time Warner Center. His company also supplied steel for the construction of professional sports stadiums and arenas, which included the Yankees, Giants, Patriots, Ravens, Redskins, Celtics, 76ers, Wizards, and the Devils. In 2007, Bouras Industries ceased operations with the sale of four companies and over 700 employees. Mr. Bouras' business achievements enabled him to positively impact the lives of thousands of people in need, including those in pursuit of higher education, as well as numerous non-profit institutions throughout the world. He exhibited extraordinary commitment to his local parish, Holy Trinity Greek Orthodox Church, which he helped found and served on the Parish Council for over 40 years. His support of the Ecumenical Patriarchate, the Greek Orthodox Archdiocese of America, Hellenic College, Orthodox Christian Mission Center, and numerous philanthropic causes typified his enduring generosity for humanitarian projects. A 25 year member of the Archdiocesan Council and National Council of the Order of St. Andrew the Apostle, Archon Vice Commander Bouras was central to expanding initiatives of these important institutions. His philanthropy empowered the Order of St. Andrew to develop a multifaceted domestic and international strategic plan to secure religious freedom for the Ecumenical Patriarchate, the spiritual center of the world's 300 million Orthodox Christians located in Istanbul, Turkey. Mr. Bouras is the recipient of numerous awards and honors, including an Honorary Doctor of Humanities from Hellenic College, the Ellis Island Medal of Honor, the Alpha Omega Council Lifetime Achievement Award, the Hellenic Heritage Achievement Award from the American Hellenic Institute, the Entrepreneur of the Year Award from Ernst and Young, the Humanitarian Philanthropic Award from the Cyprus Federation of America, the Athenagoras Human Rights Award from the Order of St. Andrew the Apostle, and the Republican Senatorial Medal of Freedom, the highest honor the Republican members of the U.S. Senate can bestow. Born in Pontiac, MI, and raised in Chicago, Il, Mr. Bouras was an alumnus of Northwestern University. Mr. Bouras is survived by his sister-in-law Tina Kariotis and brother-in-law John Mathrusse; nieces Susan Tseng (Greg), Pamela Kariotis (James), Elizabeth Smejda (Karolus), and Georgeane Valos (John); nephews James Mathrusse (Jiemin) and Robert Kariotis; grandnieces Katie and Emma; and grandnephews Matt, Brian, Andrew, and Rocco. United States Presidents, world business leaders, and Veterans have had the distinct honor and pleasure to know and serve with Nicholas J. Bouras, who so distinguished himself in faithful service to his country, fellow man, and his beloved church. Funeral services will be held at Holy Trinity Greek Orthodox Church in Westfield, NJ as follows: A Viewing will take place on Friday, December 27, 2013 from 2pm to 8pm with Trisagion (Memorial) services every hour with Hierarchical Trisagion at 7pm. Funeral services will take place on Saturday, December 28, 2013 at 9am. Burial to follow at Fairview Cemetery in Westfield, NJ. Note: please send flowers to the church. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to St. Anna Greek Orthodox Church in Flemington, NJ and/or Holy Trinity Greek Orthodox Church in Westfield, NJ. Ser vices are being handled by Higgins and Bonner Echo Lake Funeral Home in Westfield, NJ. Condolences can be sent to the family at www.higginsandbonner.com

BLASENHEIM--Shirley Katz, died in Colorado Springs, CO, on December 17, 2013. She was 92 years old. Born and raised in the Bronx, NY, she also lived for many years in Putnam Valley and then Yonkers, NY, and later in Wellington, FL. She passionately loved her immediate and extended family, her friends, the theater, the cinema, politics, travel and gracious living. She studied drama at the New Theatre School in New York in the late 1930s and served as an elected member of the Putnam Valley School Board of Education in the mid-1950s. Her beloved husband Matthew E. Blasenheim predeceased her in 2003. She is survived by her daughter, Nancy Bailey of W. Palm Beach, FL; her son Prof. Peter Blasenheim of Colorado Springs, CO; her grandchildren Alexis Khoury of Astoria, OR, Jon Khoury of Colorado Springs, CO, Michael Khoury of Columbia, MD, and eight great-grandchildren.

KLAUSMAN--Bernard: Dad, you are loved and missed by your ONLY children, Michael and Joel on your 100th birthday.

WILSON--Robert W. The Board of Trustees, Auxiliary and staff of Brooklyn Botanic Garden extend our sincere sympathy to the family and friends of former Garden Trustee Robert W. Wilson. Bob was an important Garden advisor and generous supporter of BBG for more than 40 years, and served as an active Trustee and Board Committee member in the 1970's. His legacy at the Garden endures in new gardens and greenhouses created from his challenge grants over two capital campaigns. We mourn the loss of his leadership and his true commitment to conserving the natural world. Scot Medbury, President Frederick Bland, Chairman Frances Mendlow, Auxiliary President

WILSON--Robert W. The Board of Directors and staff of the American Civil Liberties Union mourn the passing of Robert W. Wilson, a true friend who was committed to justice and freedom for all. Known as a visionary investor, Bob was also a visionary philanthropist. Through the Robert W. Wilson Charitable Trust, he established the Legacy of Liberty Challenge, inspiring thousands of ACLU supporters to pledge over $200 million in legacy gifts. By inspiring others - and through his own extraordinary philanthropy - Bob made a lasting difference to the issues he cared about. He was passionate about criminal justice reform, and the need to provide justice to those who are imprisoned. A member of the ACLU for more than four decades, Bob gave a voice to those who have been silenced, and hope to those who had long given up on the system. The ACLU is forever grateful for the deep impact Bob has made, and we take comfort in knowing that his commitment to justice lives on through his legacy. Anthony D. Romero Executive Director

STIER--Eleanor. The Board of Trustees and Staff of the Community Service Society are saddened by the death of Eleanor Stier on December 18, a long time respected member of the staff of the Community Service Society. She earned a bachelor's degree and Master of Social Work at Columbia University's School of Social Work. Eleanor Stier had a distinguished 26 year career as a caseworker and public policy analyst at our organization, including serving as the Director of Education. She was a member of the Educational Priorities Panel and a long time co-chair of the Education Committee of the Women's City Club of New York, where she was honored for her contributions. Our condolences to her family, her beloved niece, nephew, great nieces, and great-great nephews.

STEINBERG--Arnold. The partners and employees of Steinberg & Pokoik are deeply saddened by the loss of the last of our founding partners, Arnold Steinberg. He was a known dynamo and leader in the real estate industry in New York and extraordinarily well respected. Our heartfelt sympathies go out to Arnold's wife, Lillian, his children, Stuart (Fran), Jeff (Kay) and Meryl (Ken), grandchildren and great-grandchildren who all loved him and will remember him always. Arnold will be sorely missed by many.

STEINBERG--Arnold. The Board of Governors and the members of the Seawane Club, record with sorrow the loss of our longtime member and former club President Arnold Steinberg. We extend heartfelt sympathy to his wife Lillian and family. Paul Kotcher, President

STEINBERG--Arnold. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Arnold Steinberg. He leaves behind a loving family that will carry on his legacy of exceptional philanthropy. We extend our condolences to Arnold's wife, Lillian; his children, Stuart (Fran), Meryl (Ken), and Jeffrey (Kay); his grandchildren; his great-grandchildren; and the entire family. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; John S. Ruskay, Executive VP & CEO

STEINBERG--Arnold. Tiger J, LLC mourns the passing of our dear friend Arnold Steinberg; father of our Chairman, Jeff Steinberg and grandfather of our Chief Business Officer, Andrew Steinberg. Our love and heartfelt sympathy is with you and your family always.

SPITALNY--William. The members of Brae Burn Country Club mourn the passing of our esteemed founding member, William Spitalny. Our sympathy is extended to his entire family. Len Shendell, President William Schultz, Secretary

SHAPIRO--Theodore, 84 years old, died on December 25, 2013. Loving husband of Judith (Kreisberg). Devoted father of Kathy Simon (Scott), Hilary Shepard (Tim Brown) and John (Geri). Cherished grandfather of Matti, Alix, Cassidy, Scarlett, Jake, C.J., and Adam. Beloved brother of Leona Brodner. Also survived by many nieces and nephews. He attended Drake University where he was an avid football player. Then he went into the US Navy where he served in Korea as a frogman. He then attended Brooklyn Law School. He was a member of the US Polo Association, NY Jockey Club and the owner of CIAO.

SCHACHNE--David I. The Board of Trustees and staff of CancerCare were saddened to learn of the passing of David I. Schachne, husband of Dorothy, an esteemed and devoted member of our Board of Trustees. Our condolences to Dorothy, their children and grandchildren and the entire Schachne family.

ROTTER--Walter. UJA-Federation of New York mourns with sadness the passing of Walter Rotter, beloved father of Steve Rotter, a member of the UJA-Federation Board of Directors and Real Estate Executive Committee. Walter leaves behind a loving family whose generosity strengthens our ability to serve those in need. We extend our condolences to Walter's children, Steve (Robin), Ellen (Steven Silver), and Michael; to his grandchildren; great-grandchildren; and the entire family. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; John S. Ruskay, Executive VP & CEO

PHELPS--Stowe. The Children's Aid Society mourns the death of Stowe Phelps, the husband of our marvelous Chairman Emeritus Charlton Phelps, on December 24th, and expresses deep condolences to Charlton and their two lovely and loving daughters, Fia and Meredith, a long-term and valued Trustee of the Society. Stowe will be missed. Mark Edmiston, Chair; Richard Buery, President and CEO; Edgar Koerner, Chair Emeritus; and the Trustees and Staff of the Society

PHELPS--Stowe Catlin. Born April 15, 1917, died peacefully at home on December 24th, 2013. He had lived "Many Very Good Years" to quote the title of his memoirs. On June 24, 1944 he married Charlton Yarnall Jacobs of Philadelphia. They had two daughters: Sophia Yarnall Payne of Fort Worth, TX and Meredith Phelps Rugg of New York City. Stowe had a varied, creative career that included acting on Broadway, working at CBS television and writing and producing documentary films. He spent many years on the Board of the Third Street Music School Settlement and was an active member of The Century Association. Music was central to his life and he was the oldest living Whiffenpoof. He loved golf and enjoyed his many years as a U.S. Senior. His family was all important to him and in addition to his wife and two daughters he is survived by his son-in-law Peter Rugg, five grandchildren and seven great-grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to: The Third Street Music School Settlement, 235 E. 11th St, New York, NY 10003 or The Fishers Island Sea Stretcher, c/o FIFD Box 222, Fishers Island, NY 06390 or The Century Association Foundation, 7 West 43rd St, New York, NY 10036. There will be a memorial service soon in 2014.

MADDEN--Peter Hammond, died on December 21, 2013 in Rye Brook, New York. He had been unwell for some time, according to his sister, Christina Madden Whitman of New York City. Mr. Madden was born in Greenwich, CT. on November 21, 1940 to the late James Madden and the late Mrs. H. Adams Ashforth, and lived in both New York City and Greenwich. He graduated from the Hotchkiss School in 1958 and with the Yale class of 1962, where he participated on the crew team. He then went to Law School at the University of Virginia, graduating with an LL.B. degree in 1965, served his time in the United States Army, and then worked for some years for the law firm of Davis Polk & Wardwell in New York. He was predeceased by an older brother, Michael Jay Madden, and is survived by his sister, Mrs. Whitman, and a niece, Elizabeth Whitman. Funeral services will be private.
LEWIS--Miriam B.,93, Deceber 20, 2013. Devoted aunt of Judy Thorpe, loving cousin of Marcia Ezra and Robert Friedland, soulmate of Joseph Fuchs. A cultured and generous New Yorker.

KIRSCHENBAUM--Harriet Benwitt, died on December 25, 2013. She lived a life full of grace and laughter. Predeceased by her husband Bob. Harriet is survived by her children, Ben, Roger and Leslie; by her daughter-in-law, Adrienne; and by her grandson, Peter. A graveside service will take place on Friday December 27 at Mt. Pleasant Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY at 11:15am.
KIRSCHENBAUM--Harriet. Caring, considerate and thoughtful; a wonderful wife, mother, grandmother plus a true friend to the Fleder family.

KASS--Herbert D.,passed away on December 25th. Beloved husband of Barbara, loving father of Arden (Juan), Marshall (Nikki) and Jenny. Brother of Donna Carter and the late Charles Kass, adored Pop Pop of Izzi, Jillian, Leo and Gaby. Service will be held at Gutterman and Musicant, 402 Park Street, Hackensack, NJ on December 27th at 10am.

HAMLEN--Cyrilla Page, on December 21, 2013. Beloved wife of the late Joseph R. Loving mother of Mary. Devoted grandmother of Olivia and Cordelia. Funeral Mass: St. Thomas More Church, 65 East 89th St, New York, Saturday, December 28 at 2pm.

GROSINGER--Kathy. It is with great sadness that the associates of LeFrak mourn the passing of our colleague and friend Kathy Grosinger. Her kindness, loyalty, diligence and integrity will be missed by all. To her family and friends we extend our deepest and most sincere condolences and our prayers.

FEDDER--Sara "Susie", 94, on December 25, 2013. Susie was an elegant and accomplished woman with a sharp wit and a great sense of humor. She loved reading, the TCM channel and always had a strong opinion about everything. She never missed a Broadway show, adored shopping at Loehmann's when the labels were removed. It was fun. Susie loved a challenge and could take on the guys at a poker game. She adored animals, especially dogs, who were always a part of her family. Susie is mourned by her daughters Nancy and Marilyn, her daughter in-law Sandy, her son-in-law Gary, her adored grandson Jack and the many other family members and friends whose lives she touched. Susie we love you. You and Floyd truly made the world a better and kinder place.

DRENTTEL--William. Designer and publisher William Drenttel died December 21, 2013 at Connecticut Hospice after a long illness. He was 60. Born in Minneapolis, Drenttel grew up in Southern California and graduated in 1977 from Princeton University. He was a co-founder of Drenttel Doyle Partners, Winterhouse and Design Observer, a longtime trustee of Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum, and a member of the Art Directors Club Hall of Fame. He is survived by his wife, Jessica Helfand and their two children, Malcolm and Fiona. A memorial service is planned for early March.

DONOVAN--John Molloy, a former partner at Salomon Brothers died peacefully at his home on December 24, 2013 from complications of advanced Parkinson's disease. He is survived by his wife of 56 years, Patti; his children Richard, Mary-Joan Buckley, and William; his grandchildren Kaitlyn Donovan, Will Buckley, Patsy Buckley, Aidan Donovan and Maureen Donovan. He was predeceased by his parents Thomas and Mary and his brother William. Born in New York, NY he attended Incarnation School in Washington Heights and Power Memorial High School. He went on to attend Colgate University where he played football and was a member of the Theta Chi fraternity. He graduated from Colgate in 1952 and was fondly known by his classmates as Duke. As an alumnus he was a member of Colgate's President's Club, a Maroon Citation recipient, a Wm. Brian Little Award recipient for distinguished service to the university and a member of the James B. Colgate Society. Following college he joined the US Navy and served on the USS Haynesworth as an officer during the Korean Conflict. Upon completion of his military service, Mr. Donovan enrolled in New York University's MBA program and earned a masters degree in 1957. His professional career started at Crucible Steel in Pittsburgh, PA. He went on to take a position at Mellon Bank, Pittsburgh, in its Municipal Sales and Trading department. He moved back to New York in 1962 as part of Mellon's expansion of its New York Municipal presence. Several years later he joined Lehman Brothers as a municipal sales person. In 1970 he joined Salomon Brothers Municipal Sales and Trading Department where he served as a sales manager. He was made a partner in 1979. He later left the sales and trading group to head-up the Municipal Finance Department, which he ran until 1987. During his time at Salomon Brothers, Mr. Donovan worked on many important public projects including the New York City fiscal crisis in the early Seventies where his efforts along with others staved off bankruptcy and fiscal collapse for the city. Mr. Donovan completed his career at Dean Witter Reynolds as the head of Municipal Finance, where he worked until his retirement in 1992. In retirement, he spent his time between his homes in Short Hills, NJ; Quogue, NY; and Hobe Sound, FL. He was a long time member of Canoe Brook Country Club in Summit, NJ; Westhampton Country Club in Westhampton Beach, NY; and Loblolly Pines in Hobe Sound, FL. Mr. Donovan served as the President of the Loblolly Bay Association during which time it merged with Loblolly Pines to form Loblolly. A Funeral Mass will be celebrated at St. Rose of Lima Church, 50 Short Hills Rd, Short Hills on Monday, December 30th at 11:15am. Interment at Quogue Cemetery, Quogue, NY will be on Tuesday at noon. Relatives and friends are invited to visit at Bradley, Smith & Smith Funeral Home, 415 Morris Ave, Springfield on Sunday, December 29th from 3 to 8pm. In lieu of flowers, donations in Mr. Donovan's memory may be made to St. Patrick's Cathedral at saintpatrickscathedral.org. For further information or to send a condolence, please go to bradleyfuneralhomes.com.
