BOHRER--Harry. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Harry Bohrer, whose dedication to helping those in need will live on through his children, Margaret Beauregard, Jeffrey, Nathaniel (Betsy), Seth (Susan), and Clifford Stanley. We extend our condolences to Harry's siblings, Moe and Claire; his children; grandchildren; great-grandchildren; and the entire family. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; John S. Ruskay, Executive VP & CEO

BLASENHEIM--Shirley Katz, died in Colorado Springs, CO, on December 17, 2013. She was 92 years old. Born and raised in the Bronx, NY, she also lived for many years in Putnam Valley and then Yonkers, NY, and later in Wellington, FL. She passionately loved her immediate and extended family, her friends, the theater, the cinema, politics, travel and gracious living. She studied drama at the New Theatre School in New York in the late 1930s and served as an elected member of the Putnam Valley School Board of Education in the mid-1950s. Her beloved husband Matthew E. Blasenheim predeceased her in 2003. She is survived by her daughter, Nancy Bailey of W. Palm Beach, FL; her son Prof. Peter Blasenheim of Colorado Springs, CO; her grandchildren Alexis Khoury of Astoria, OR, Jon Khoury of Colorado Springs, CO, Michael Khoury of Columbia, MD, and eight great-grandchildren.

KLAUSMAN--Bernard: Dad, you are loved and missed by your ONLY children, Michael and Joel on your 100th birthday.

STEINBERG--Arnold. New Alternatives for Children mourns the passing of Arnold Steinberg, father of longtime boardmember Meryl Sherman. Our heartfelt sympathy to the entire family. Robert Friedman, President; Arlene Goldsmith, Executive Director

SHULMAN--Betty. The congregation of Shaaray Tefila records with deep sorrow the death of our longtime cherished member. Heartfelt condolences are extended to her daughter Susan, son Neal, and their loved ones. May her memory be for blessing. Rabbi Jonathan A. Stein Michael Starr, President

ROTTER--Walter. The Officers and Directors of MJHS express our condolences on the passing of Walter Rotter, beloved father of Steve Rotter, a Member of the MJHS Hospice and Palliative Care Board of Directors. It was our honor to care for Walter on our hospice program, if only for a brief period of time. We extend our sympathies to Walter's children, Steve (Robin), Ellen (Steven Silver), and Michael; to his grandchildren; great-grandchildren; and the entire family. Ronald B. Milch, Board Chairman; Eli S. Feldman, President and CEO; Shmuel Lefkowitz, Board Chairman, MJHS Hospice and Palliative Care.

ROTH--Charlotte (Spector) (Kelem), died peacefully in her Mamaroneck home with her husband Robert Roth by her side. She is survived by her husband, Robert Roth, her children and stepchildren, Jamie Keshet, Roger Kelem, Thomas Kelem, Jean Roth, John Roth, Martin Roth, Richard Roth, and grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Services will be held at Fox Funeral Home, 2080 Boston Post Rd., Larchmont, NY 10538, on Sunday, December 29 at 10am. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to UNICEF at www.unicefusa.org. For more info: www.JJFFH.COM

PIETRONUTO--Joseph A.,age 85, of Pelham Manor, died on December 21, 2013. Born January 28, 1928 to Pasquale and Antoinette Pietronuto. Joseph served as Sergeant in the U.S. Army in South Korea during the occupation of Japan from 1946-48. He went on to having a career as an Allstate agent in the Bronx for more than 40 years. He is the beloved husband of Catherine (Marricco). In addition to his wife he is survived by his loving sons, Michael, Robert and Richard (wife Andrea) Pietronuto. He is predeceased by his son, Joseph Pietronuto and daughter in law, Anita. Also survived by dear brother, Louis Pietronuto (wife Catherine), eight grandchildren and one great-grandchild. To honor Joseph's life family and friends will gather on Sunday from 2 to 5pm at Coxe & Graziano Funeral Home, 767 E. Boston Post Rd., Mamaroneck. 914-698-5968. Funeral Mass on Monday 10:30am at Our Lady of Perpetual Help R.C. Church followed by entombment at Ferncliff Cemetery. For more information or to place an online condolence; www.coxeandgraziano.com
MILLER--Sara (Sukie) Unobskey. Dearest classmate. Witty, wise, wonderful and forever in our hearts. Fieldston Friends

MADDEN--Peter Hammond, died on December 21, 2013 in Rye Brook, New York. He had been unwell for some time, according to his sister, Christina Madden Whitman of New York City. Mr. Madden was born in Greenwich, CT. on November 21, 1940 to the late James Madden and the late Mrs. H. Adams Ashforth, and lived in both New York City and Greenwich. He graduated from the Hotchkiss School in 1958 and with the Yale class of 1962, where he participated on the crew team. He then went to Law School at the University of Virginia, graduating with an LL.B. degree in 1965, served his time in the United States Army, and then worked for some years for the law firm of Davis Polk & Wardwell in New York. He was predeceased by an older brother, Michael Jay Madden, and is survived by his sister, Mrs. Whitman, and a niece, Elizabeth Whitman. Funeral services will be private.

HAMILTON--Robert Alexander, Jr. died peacefully at his home surrounded by his wife and family in Surfside, Florida on December 19th. Bob was born to the late Pauline and Robert Hamilton, Sr. at home in Ridgefield Park, New Jersey on January 24, 1917. He was predeceased by his wives, Polly Thacher Hamilton and Geraldine McKinney Hamilton and his stepson John McKinney. Bob is survived by his wife, Frederica Tubb Hamilton, his daughters Gale Hamilton and Toni Doggett, his stepchildren, Patricia Driscoll, Thomas McKinney, Sharon Beyers, Kevin McKinney, and Michael McKinney as well as nine grandchildren, nine great-grandchildren and by his long time loyal friend and family manager, Joseph Galluccio. He graduated from Duke University in 1938 before going on to own and manage a successful construction Company, R.A. Hamilton Corporation in Hackensack, New Jersey. Bob was a member of The Reading Room, The Rover Boys, DOCA, and Skeeters. For twenty-five years he served on the Board of Directors of Hackensack Hospital. He was a member of the Surf Club and Indian Creek Country Club of Miami Beach Florida for the last 50 years. He will be remembered for his love of travel, an excellent round of golf and a successful day at the race track. There will be a memorial service at a later date. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Hackensack Hospital in Hackensack, New Jersey.

GROSS--Beatrice, died peacefully in Boca Raton, Florida on December 24, 2013. She was 97 years old. Her beloved husband, Harry, predeceased her in 2001. She is survived by her daughter, Stacy Sussman of Syosset, NY; her son, Lynn Gross of Aurora, Colorado; her brother Arthur (and wife Dorothy) Okun, of Hewlett, NY; her grandsons Josh (and wife Lola) Spitzen of Ceritos, CA; Dan (and wife Jennifer) Spitzen of Penn Valley, PA; and Matt Sussman of Redwood City, CA; and her three great-grandchildren Noah, Deker and Remy Spitzen. A private graveside service will be held on Sunday, December 29, 2013 at 11 am followed by Shiva at the home of Stacy Sussman on Sunday and Monday, December 29 and 30, beginning at 1pm.

DRENTTEL--William. Designer and publisher William Drenttel died December 21, 2013 at Connecticut Hospice after a long illness. He was 60. Born in Minneapolis, Drenttel grew up in Southern California and graduated in 1977 from Princeton University. He was a co-founder of Drenttel Doyle Partners, Winterhouse and Design Observer, a longtime trustee of Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum, and a member of the Art Directors Club Hall of Fame. He is survived by his wife, Jessica Helfand and their two children, Malcolm and Fiona. A memorial service is planned for early March.

DiSALVO--Lisa Merians, Devoted mother and wife, died suddenly on December 25th at Englewood Hospital in Englewood, NJ. She was 58. Daughter of Isabel and the late Sidney Merians of Alpine, NJ, Lisa was born in Manhattan and raised in New Hyde Park, Long Island. She later lived in New York City before moving to Tenafly, NJ, where she resided for the past 22 years. A retired Vice President of Creative Services at Viacom Enterprises, Lisa was instrumental in the creation of many hit television shows such as The Cosby Show, Roseanne, and A Different World. A lover of the arts, Lisa most recently served as a docent at The Metropolitan Museum of Art in Manhattan, where she specialized in providing guided student tours ranging from Greek and Roman antiquities to American art. She received a B.A. in English from Washington University in St. Louis, MO. Lisa is survived by her loving husband, Joseph; her daughters, Madeleine, Rachel, and Sara; her mother, Isabel Merians; and her sisters Melanie and Valerie Merians. A memorial service will be held on Monday, December 30th, at 1:30pm at Gutterman and Musicant Funeral Home, 402 Park Street, Hackensack, NJ. A shiva will follow at the DiSalvo's home. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made in her honor to The Docent Program at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

CAFFREY--Jeanne (nee Quinn), Beloved wife of Philip. Loving mother of Patricia Caffrey, Maureen Ayres, Cathleen Murphy and Philip Caffrey Jr. Devoted grandmother of Matthew and Kevin Murphy, David Ayres, Katheryn and Krisanne Caffrey, Melissa Sipes, and Keri Ayres. Loving sister of Ruth Lennon. Reposing at the Horne Dannecker Funeral Home, 445 West 43 Street, Sunday 2-9pm. Mass at St. Michael's Church, 424 West 34 Street, Monday 10am. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to St. Michael's Church in Jeanne's memory.

BERTELS--Rev. Henry J.,S.J., on December 26, 2013. Many years at the Pontifical Biblical Institute Library in Rome and more recently at the Fordham University Library. Reposing at the Murray-Weigel Hall Chapel, 515 East Fordham Rd., Bronx, NY, on Sunday, 3-5pm and 7-8:30pm. Funeral Mass in the Murray-Weigel Hall Chapel, Monday at 11:30am. Interment at the Jesuit Cemetery, Auriesville, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the New York Province, Society of Jesus, 39 East 83rd St., NY, NY 10028. For information, contact Farenga Bros., Inc., Directors (718) 654-0500.

BARR--Lenore. December 26, 2013. Widow of Irving Barr. Beloved sister of Faith Wolitzer. Loving mother of Kathie and Arnold Kaplan, Jackie and Eliot Morrison, Susan and David Currier, Alan and Burta Barr. Cherished grandmother and great-grandmother. Services Sunday 12:30pm, Riverside Cha-pels, Great Neck, NY.

ZIMMERMAN--Sylvanus Arnold III, died November 11, 2013. He was born January 28, 1920. He graduated from Blair Academy and then Princeton University in 1942. He then served in the Army in the Pacific. After four years in the Army, he then entered Harvard Law School and graduated with the class of 1948. He then served under Arthur T. Vanderbilt, the chief justice of the New Jersey Supreme Court. He then worked for Wallace and Tiernan, until joining Avon Products as General Counsel. He was there for twenty five years before retiring to his home in New Vernon, NJ. He is survived by his wife Jeanne Marshall Zimmerman of seventy years. Also surviving are his three children, Dr. Sylvanus Arnold Zimmerman IV, Sally Marshall Zimmerman of Sonoma, CA and Todd Kilpatrick Zimmerman of Connecticut, and his grandson, Sylvanus Arnold Zimmerman V, a lawyer.

YARNELL--Philip, passed on December 23rd, 2013. Born April 19th, 1924. Cherished husband of Roberta for 67 years. Beloved father of Madge Leone and Gary (Laurie) Yarnell. Loving brother of Marvin Yarnell. Adored grandfather of Jason, Matthew, Nikki and Adam. Your strength and generosity were the heart of our family.

WILSON--Robert W. Timothy Cardinal Dolan, Edward Cardinal Egan and the Board of Trustees of Inner-City Scholarship Fund mourn the loss of our dear friend Robert W. Wilson. His extraordinary support of needy children attending Catholic schools in the Archdiocese of New York made an enormous difference in thousands of young lives. Mr. Wilson's vision for creating the Catholic Alumni Partnership will assist Catholic elementary schools in New York and across the nation and will be a blessing to Catholic education for generations to come. We will be forever thankful for his immense generosity.

WILSON--Robert W.,The Wildlife Conservation Society mourns the death of the great philanthropist, Robert W. Wilson. Bob Wilson supported WCS for more than four decades. His strategic thinking and financial investment transformed WCS from a New York-based institution with a small conservation program into a global conservation authority with its foundation and roots in the New York cultural landscape. He dispatched a team to evaluate our overseas programs and helped us to build our capacity, encouraging others to match his generosity. He inspired us to grow our programs and their influence. His support created institutional momentum that will carry us well into the future. His investment in WCS resulted in protection of wild species and the preservation of wild places around the world - resources of both global significance and importance for local people. Bob Wilson will be remembered as a great and transforming conservationist. WCS extends its sympathies to his family and friends.

WILSON--Robert W. Together with the philanthropic community, the partners of Anchin Block & Anchin LLP mourn the passing of Robert W. Wilson, who has been a client of our firm for over thirty years. As well as being an astute businessman, Bob was a pioneer in the field of philanthropy. In addition to giving the majority of his fortune to charity, his leveraged techniques were transformative to the institutions and the causes he supported, and have forever changed philanthropic giving. Richard Schneidman and the Partners of Anchin Block & Anchin LLP.

WILSON--Robert W. The Rainforest Alliance mourns the loss of Robert Wilson, a true friend and advocate for the planet, its wildlife and natural resources. Mr. Wilson's generous support and challenge grants over the years leveraged additional millions to transform the way that land is managed and businesses interact with the natural world. His spirit and generosity will be truly missed and we extend our condolences to his friends and family. Daniel Katz, Chairman Tensie Whelan, President
WILSON--Robert W. BAM mourns generous donor, unique individual, and BAM supporter for 30 years. Karen Hopkins, President

WILSON--Robert W. The Byrd Hoffman Water Mill Foundation and RW Work pays tribute to our long time supporter and former Board member. A visionary philanthropist whose generosity helped secure the archives and cultural legacy of the artist Robert Wilson, as well as bringing several of the artist's theater works to New York City. He was devoted to helping others within the arts, libraries, education and conservation. A close friend to Bob, the Board and staff, his unique perspective and honesty was greatly admired. The Byrd Hoffman family hopes to honor his example and deeply regrets his passing.

WELLS--Wayne, 89, of North Palm Beach and St. Louis, died peacefully in North Palm Beach after a long illness on December 23. An avid Cardinals fan, he attended spring training, keeping stats on his beloved team. He also loved Iowa, good restaurants, the arts, travel, his friends and family. Mr. Wells was born on a farm in Cantril, Iowa, and served in the Navy. He graduated from the University of Iowa and quickly became a partner at Arthur Andersen & Co in New York City. He also worked at Deering Milliken, Mohawk Data Sciences, General Dynamics, and Alltype Fire Protection. He served on the Vestry of The Church of St. Michael & St. George. He is survived by his wife of 58 years, Jean Burchell Wells; his brothers Van and Dwight; his children Jeffrey (Serena) of New Canaan, Linda of Manhattan, Jennifer of Novato, and David (Anne) of Darien, along with eight grandchildren and countless friends. He was predeceased by his brother Donald. Hismemorial service is on January 11th at the Lost Tree Chapel.

WILSON--Robert W. A unique, innovative and philanthropic man, died December 23, 2013 in New York City. He is survived by his brother William Wilson II, his nephew William Wilson III, and his niece Karen DeFiore. Born in Detroit, Michigan in 1926, he graduated magna cum laude, Phi Beta Kappa from Amherst College and received a master's degree in economics from the University of Michigan. He worked for a number of investment firms in the 50s and 60s and in 1969 started his own hedge fund. He was an astute investor and soon gained a reputation as Wall Street's premier short seller. Before retiring in 1986, he had been able to parlay an initial stake of $15,000 from his mother into an immense fortune and then spent the latter part of his life giving it away. He was an ardent conservationist, with the goal of preserving natural and man-made wonders. His philanthropy in that field was transformative for many of the institutions he supported. Ever the astute businessman, he was a pioneer in leveraged philanthropy, which, through the use of many unique and innovative programs, challenged the recipient organizations to achieve unique benchmarks, which strengthened and improved them far in excess of his contributions. His philanthropy was diverse, touching on many of his other interests: the arts, education, and policy reform, to name a few. Bob was cultured and well-read, with an insatiable appetite for newspapers and news journals. He loved fine restaurants and wine preceded by a good martini, and was passionate about opera and traveled all over the world to hear his favorites performed. He enjoyed movies and good jokes, and was delighted to email a long list of friends the latest and greatest anecdotes he had discovered. Bob was, no doubt, a man with the courage of his own convictions, albeit one who was willing to listen with an open mind to a new idea. Endowed with a brilliant mind, decisive and direct, he was always his own man. Throughout his career, he served on numerous boards and never hesitated to express his own strongly held opinions, no matter how controversial. Bob used his intelligence and his fortune to make the world a better place. That is his legacy. A memorial service for Bob will be announced at a later date.
van Straaten--William. Art dealer/publisher, 76, died December 23, 2013, peacefully at home in Denver, CO.

VAN PRAAGH--Felicia (Flicka), passed away early Christmas morning at the age of 79. She is survived by her loving husband Ian, her three children Cecily, Ian and Giles, their spouses Alex, Anne and Stacy and five grandchildren Helen, Louisa, Sam, Emma and Claire. Flicka was a gallant force in the lives of many. She headed up international adoption for many years at Spence-Chapin where she placed in excess of 500 children. Flicka was the fifth generation of her family to be born in Manhattan. She and her husband Ian raised their family on the Upper West Side and in St James on Long Island. She will be remembered for her generosity, selflessness and practicality. She will be sorely missed by family and friends alike.

TOEPFER--Susan J.,Mother of Kate and Nick, and wife of Lorenzo Carcaterra, died on Christmas Eve after a long battle with lung cancer. Susan was a passionate reader, lover of theater and film, and devoted mother, wife, and friend. Her great love of art, life, and entertainment drove Susan as she rose through the ranks of the New York Daily News and People Magazine before founding her own publication, Quick & Simple Magazine, through Hearst. She later returned to her roots as the Entertainment Editor for More Magazine. She once wrote, "waitress money in pocket, typewriter in hand, I came to New York from Ohio to make my living as a writer." More than that, she lived a life rich in love, laughter, friendship, and new experiences. Everyone who knew her was better for it, and she will live on remembered by those who loved her most.

STEINBERG--Arnold. New Alternatives for Children mourns the passing of Arnold Steinberg, father of longtime boardmember Meryl Sherman. Our heartfelt sympathy to the entire family. Robert Friedman, President; Arlene Goldsmith, Executive Director

SLOVINSKY--Flora Berta, 85, died peacefully in Chula Vista, CA on December 18, 2013, surrounded by her children, Claudia, Gustavo and Nicole. She was born on January 14, 1928 in Argentina and was married to Manuel Slovinsky for 58 years. Seeking better opportunities, they came to the US in 1957. Flora is already greatly missed by her children and grandchildren, Maya, Eli, Daniel, Chloe and Kevin and sons-in-law, Andy and Jeff.

SHAPIRO--Harold N.,mathematician and polymath, died on December 12 in Teaneck, NJ. He was 91. Dr. Shapiro was Professor Emeritus at New York University's Courant Institute of Mathematical Sciences, where he taught for over 50 years. A distinguished number theorist, he was omnivorously interested in mathematics and its applications. In the early 1960s, he briefly left NYU to found Systems Research Group, a consultancy for industry and government. There, he used mathematical models to solve problems in space rocketry, computer science, oil production, ship scheduling, and bond trading, among many other fields. Born on October 2, 1922 in the Bronx, NY, he was the loving son of Isaiah William and Julia Shapiro, and the devoted brother of Raymond E. Shapiro, a toxicologist. He attended City College and then Princeton University, where he received his Ph.D. at the age of 24 under the direction of Emil Artin. Throughout his teaching career, Dr. Shapiro supervised 41 doctoral dissertations and many master's theses. His care for his students extended beyond the classroom and lasted long after the awarding of their degrees. His publications include more than 60 articles and one book, Introduction to the Theory of Numbers (1983, reprint 2008). In 1979, he received the Townsend Harris Medal for outstanding achievement by an alumnus of City College. An engaging lecturer and storyteller, he was a walking library of anecdotes from the history of mathematics. He also painted, wrote poetry, loved music, collected art, and was quietly philanthropic. Having studied Latin, Russian, and modern Greek, he spoke French, German, and Spanish, which he learned at 85 years old. He is survived by his four children, 10 grandchildren, one great-grandchild, and by Ruth Shapiro, his loving wife of 65 years.
SCHOTTENFELD--Milton, Adored father, grandfather. Forever in our hearts, his wit, warmth and zest for life will be deeply missed.

SACKS--Bernice, died December 26, Manhattan, age 89. Cherished by so many extended family and friends. Singer, dancer, patroness of the arts, humanist, political mind, the empress of West 70th Street. She was and remains the spiritual mother to a broad flock and the center of our compass. A memorial service will be held at a later date to be announced. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made in her name to WBGO Jazz Radio.

RHEINSTEIN--Frederic, age 86, died on December 22, 2013 in Los Angeles, CA. Born in New York City on November 5, 1927, he attended Exeter and Princeton University Class of 1949. He worked for NBC-TV as a stage manager for "Your Show of Shows" and then as on site producer-director for remote coverage of global events such as Ruby's shooting of Lee Harvey Oswald and remotes of political Conventions 1956 1972. In 1974, he founded The Post Group, a leading edge Post Production facility in Hollywood, co-founded Motorweek productions/World Sports Enterprises, and garnered a myriad of producing, directing and entrepreneurial credits. He is survived by his wife Suzanne, daughter Linda C. Rheinstein, son David A. Rheinstein, daughter, Katherine R Brodsky, son-in-law Alexander Brodsky, granddaughters Beatriz and Frederica Brodsky, brother Robert Rheinstein and seven nieces and nephews. He was predeceased by his sister Katherine R. Warren. His marriage to Patricia Horn ended in divorce. A memorial service will held at All Saints Episcopal Church, Beverly Hills, CA on January 25th.

REUTER--Peter J.,Roslyn NY, 86, engineer and entrepreneur died peacefully at home, December 26. Born in Germany, Peter emigrated to the United States in 1940. He earned an engineering degree from Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute and an MBA from New York University. He co-founded Trygon Electronics, Inc. He is survived by his wife, Edith (nee Dolinko), his daughter, Susan Reuter and her husband, Roger Spingarn, two granddaughters, Abi and Leah, stepsons, Steven and Neal Shupak, sister, Ann (Helft) and her sons, John and Ralph and their families. A private burial will be held in Bennington, Vermont. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his memory to NYU at giving.poly.edu.

POOR--J. Sheppard, Died December 15. A life-long resident of Locust who, after attending Williams, graduated from Harvard Business School. He was a WWII Navy pilot; a banker in New York, Paris and London, and always an avid sailor. He was the beloved husband of the late Lee and father of Avery, Penelope and Deborah. A service will be held in the spring.

PHELPS--Stowe C. Third Street Music School Settlement mourns the death of its esteemed Chairman Emeritus, Stowe Phelps, who joined the Board of Directors in 1968. For more than 45 years, he offered his wise counsel, served as the School's historian and shared a love of music that inspired thousands of students. Everyone at Third Street extends heartfelt condolences to Charlton, his daughters and the entire family. The School's annual concert, named in his honor in 1996, serves as a living legacy that will sing forever in our hearts and minds. Vincent C. Perro, Chairman, and the Board of Directors

PHELPS--Stowe Catlin. Born April 15, 1917, died peacefully at home on December 24th, 2013. He had lived "Many Very Good Years" to quote the title of his memoirs. On June 24, 1944 he married Charlton Yarnall Jacobs of Philadelphia. They had two daughters: Sophia Yarnall Payne of Fort Worth, TX and Meredith Phelps Rugg of New York City. Stowe had a varied, creative career that included acting on Broadway, working at CBS television and writing and producing documentary films. He spent many years on the Board of the Third Street Music School Settlement and was an active member of The Century Association. Music was central to his life and he was the oldest living Whiffenpoof. He loved golf and enjoyed his many years as a U.S. Senior. His family was all important to him and in addition to his wife and two daughters he is survived by his son-in-law Peter Rugg, five grandchildren and seven great-grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to: The Third Street Music School Settlement, 235 E. 11th St, New York, NY 10003 or The Fishers Island Sea Stretcher, c/o FIFD Box 222, Fishers Island, NY 06390 or The Century Association Foundation, 7 West 43rd St, New York, NY 10036. There will be a memorial service soon in 2014.
MILLER--Sara (Sukie) Unobskey. Dear classmate. Witty, wise, wonderful and forever in our hearts. Fieldston Friends

LOONIE--Justin T.,36, longtime resident of Longmeadow, MA, passed away suddenly on Tuesday, December 24, 2013 at Baystate Medical Center. Born in Norwood, MA on July 26, 1977, he was the beloved husband of Ashley Ginsburg of New York City and son of Michael and Joanne (Downey) Loonie of Longmeadow. Justin was a 1996 graduate of Longmeadow High School and a 2000 graduate of Villanova University. Justin was a passionate lacrosse player and excelled at this sport at both Longmeadow High School and Villanova. Upon graduation, Justin began his career as a Retirement Advisor with Lord Abbett in New Jersey and then on to Lenox Advisors (Mass Mutual) in New York City where he was Vice President of Sales. Most recently, he was the Senior Plan Consultant at Alliant Retirement Services Group in New York City. In 2003, Justin earned Mass Mutual's "Freshman Five" award for having the highest sales production of all first year agents in the country, and currently, he was in the top 300 most influential retirement advisors in the country. Over the years, Justin became a true New Yorker. He enjoyed relaxing in Madison Square Park with his wife Ashley, visiting Brooklyn to spend weekends with his niece Izzy, who always knew Justin would bring her a lollipop. His kindness to his nephews is remembered by his sister-in-law Stephanie Zucker who praises his guidance to her sons Eric and Ryan Zucker. Justin was surrounded by family and beloved by his in-laws, Allan Ginsburg and Carolyn, who shares their thoughts on this tragic loss, "Justin Loonie was the most wonderful, considerate, sincere person we have ever met and he was married to our daughter Katherine Ashley Ginsburg, who also posses those same core values. They were only married a short time when he was taken from us. He will be remembered forever and missed forever. He was one of a kind." As a lover of the outdoors he looked forward to trips to Maui and fishing in Quincy and South Carolina. Justin was kind, hardworking and devoted to helping people in any way that he could. As an organ donor, Justin's legacy and gift of life will continue to live on in others. He may have been a quiet person, but he was well known and liked by all and had a huge heart. He will be dearly missed by his loving wife, Ashley Ginsburg of New York, NY; parents, Michael and Joanne Loonie of Longmeadow; his two brothers and best friends, Christopher Loonie of Windsor Locks, CT and David Loonie, Brandy and Gabrielle of Longmeadow; his aunts and uncles, Karen Ross and her husband Robb of Quincy, MA, Kenneth Downey and his wife Mary of West Roxbury, MA, Stephen Downey and his wife Jane of Dedham, MA and Ciaran Dalton and his wife Mary of Stoneham, MA; cousins, Karen, Brian, Michael, Andrew, Emily, Julie, Thomas, Steven and Kevin; his father-in-law and mother-in-law, Allan and Carolyn Ginsburg of New Jersey; brothers and sisters-in-law, Jeff Ginsburg and his wife Melissa of Kinnelon, NJ, Kenny Ginsburg and his wife Gail of Closter, NJ, Stephanie Ellis of Mamaroneck, NJ and Greg Ginsburg and his wife Zora of Brooklyn, NY and by many nieces and nephews and dear friends and co-workers. Family and friends are invited to meet for calling hours on Sunday, December 29th from 3pm to 7pm at the Forastiere Smith Funeral Home, 220 North Main St., East Longmeadow, MA. Justin's funeral ceremony will be held on Monday, December 30th starting at 9:30am at the funeral home, followed by a Liturgy of Christian Burial at 10:30am at St. Michael's Church, 128 Maple St., East Longmeadow, MA. Burial will be in Longmeadow Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Justin's memory to the Wounded Warrior Project, P.O. Box 758517, Topeka, Kansas 66675 or to the Alzheimer's Association, 263 Cottage St., Springfield, MA 01104.

HUNTER--Betty Ann, (Ann Gertrude Zemon) passed away December 22 with her daughters Hilary Hunter and Nancy Marino and son-in-law Paul Marino by her side. Betty Ann was born August 4, 1925 in San Francisco, CA, the only child born to the union of Celia (Rabinowitz) Zemon and Harry Zemon. Betty attended Castilleja Boarding School and graduated from Berkeley High School. She attended the University of Oregon for one year and had fond memories of that time. Upon her marriage, Betty relocated to the New York area and was a homemaker, raising her family on Long Island. Betty Ann leaves grand-daughters Rachel Marino Rainey (Ian) and Arielle Herrera Hunter, her cousin Harvey Kameny (Marty), along with a number of close friends who became her second family. Not a particularly religious person, Betty was very proud of her Jewish heritage and at the age of 80 she became a Bat Mitvah at Temple Sharray Tefila in Bedford Corners, NY. Betty Ann volunteered at Temple Tefilah's nursery school and at Northern Westchester Hospital, where her friendly and generous personality were much appreciated. Donations being accepted by Temple Sharray Tefila.

HAUER--Andreas, 67, died suddenly on December 24, 2013 at his home in New York City. Born in Norway, "Andy" was the son of Karl and Ellen Hauer and grew up in the San Francisco Bay area. He served in the Navy during the Vietnam War on the hospital ship USS Repose. Andy was well known for his expertise in the compensation and benefits field. HAMILTON--Robert Alexander, Jr. died peacefully at his home surrounded by his wife and family in Surfside, Florida on December 19th. Bob was born to the late Pauline and Robert Hamilton, Sr. at home in Ridgefield Park, New Jersey on January 24, 1917. He was predeceased by his wives, Polly Thacher Hamilton and Geraldine McKinney Hamilton and his stepson John McKinney. Bob is survived by his wife, Frederica Tubb Hamilton, his daughters Gale Hamilton and Toni Doggett, his stepchildren, Patricia Driscoll, Thomas McKinney, Sharon Beyers, Kevin McKinney, and Michael McKinney as well as nine grandchildren, nine great-grandchildren and by his long time loyal friend and family manager, Joseph Galluccio. He graduated from Duke University in 1938 before going on to own and manage a successful construction Company, R.A. Hamilton Corporation in Hackensack, New Jersey. Bob was a member of The Reading Room, The Rover Boys, DOCA, and Skeeters. For twenty-five years he served on the Board of Directors of Hackensack Hospital. He was a member of the Surf Club and Indian Creek Country Club of Miami Beach Florida for the last 50 years. He will be remembered for his love of travel, an excellent round of golf and a successful day at the race track. There will be a memorial service at a later date. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Hackensack Hospital in Hackensack, New Jersey.

BRONFMAN--Edgar M. The students, staff and Advisory Board members of the Bronfman Center for Jewish Student Life at New York University mourn with great sadness the passing of our founder, mentor and guide, Edgar M. Bronfman Sr. A great man with deep concern for the Jewish People and its global welfare, Mr. Edgar Bronfman's passion for pluralism, inclusiveness, and Torah study inspired thousands of Jewish youth, catalyzing a generational renaissance. Mr. Bronfman's bold and generous ambitions for the future of the Jewish community will continue to be fulfilled, though we will miss his presence. We remain eternally grateful. Steven M. Cohen, Dorothy Tananbaum, Rabbi Yehuda Sarna

BRONFMAN--Edgar M. New York University mourns the passing of Edgar M. Bronfman Sr., founder of the Bronfman Center for Jewish Student Life at New York University. A visionary leader, businessman and philanthropist, Mr. Bronfman's generosity provides an enduring gift to the thousands of students, parents and alumni inspired by the Center bearing his name. We extend our deepest condolences to the entire Bronfman family and pledge to uphold his legacy. Martin Lipton, John Sexton
BRONFMAN--Edgar. WIZO mourns the loss of courageous leader and tireless advocate for Jewish and women's rights. Evelyn Sommer, Founding President Gail Perl, Co-President

BRONFMAN--Edgar. The Jewish Museum mourns the loss of Edgar Bronfman, a true leader and philanthropist. His memory and impact continue to live on at the Museum through the Edgar M. Bronfman Education Center. Established on the occasion of Edgar's 60th birthday, the Center provides a range of programs for children, families and school groups. We extend our condolences to his wife Jan, children Adam, Clare, Edgar Jr., Holly, Matthew, Samuel, and Sara, to his brother Charles, sister Phyllis and to the entire family. BLUM--Martin H. M.D.,an extraordinary and dedicated teacher who influenced the lives and careers of hundreds of psychiatric residents during his long career at The Zucker Hillside Hospital died on December 4th. Teaching the art and science of psychotherapy is a daunting task. To do so with extraordinary patience and erudition, while pushing the trainee to recognize the complex interplay of the numerous factors that influence our perceptions, beliefs and behavior was as characteristic of Marty as the uniquely intoned 'hmm' which followed his comments. His ability to link diverse areas and aspects of history, the arts and human experience in the context of his teaching and supervision was a characteristic which made him one of the most consistently sought after and admired teachers, year after year. Even when an idea or interpretation was proven to be off the mark, it was provocative and useful as a stimulus to critical thinking. He taught us how to think and reflect, not only about our patients, but ourselves as well. What greater gift. Dr. Blum was on the staff at The Zucker Hillside Hospital for forty six years. He was always willing to help meet any clinical and teaching need that arose. He embraced new technology with greater ease than many of his younger colleagues, and was open to new systems, if they made sense, even into his 80's. He was voted teacher of the year on multiple occasions. His patients were enormously grateful to him for his ability to hone in on their particular problems, to make them feel special and understood, no matter what their condition. His intellectual curiosity led him to know an enormous amount about very diverse topics. He was a true gentleman. Martin Blum was born on October 20, 1932. He received his BA from Columbia University and his MD from The State University of New York College of Medicine in Brooklyn. He completed both a psychiatric residency and psychoanalytic training at SUNY Downstate Medical Center. He is survived by a son Asher, a daughter Agnes and two grandchildren. He will be sorely missed.

BRONFMAN--Edgar M.,Sr. The leadership and staff of the USC Shoah Foundation mourn the passing of our longtime friend and colleague, Edgar Bronfman, Sr. As a world leader, philanthropist, humanitarian, and staunch advocate for the Jewish people, and as the USC Shoah Foundation's Honorary Board Co-Chair for nearly two decades, Edgar was an inspiration and mentor to all of us helping to give voice to more than 50,000 survivors and witnesses of the Holocaust. His legacy of service and the impact of his efforts to stand against hatred and injustice and to expose evil around the world will be felt for generations to come. We extend our deepest sympathies to the entire Bronfman family. C. L. Max Nikias, President, University of Southern California; Steven Spielberg, Founder, USC Shoah Foundation; Robert J. Katz, Chair, Board of Councilors, USC Shoah Foundation; Stephen Smith, Executive Director, USC Shoah Foundation

BEREDAY--Dr. Mary H. (Gillam) of North Hill, Needham formerly of New York City, December 25, 2013. Beloved wife of the late Dr. George Z. F. Bereday. Loving mother of Cornelia Krystyna Burnham and her husband Stephen of Newton and Thaddeus Bereday and his wife Margaret Russell of Tampa, FL. Grandmother of John, Margaux, and Samuel Burnham, and Jarvis, Halina, Wright, and Zigmund Bereday. Sister of Gretchen Connolly and her husband John of Springfield, VA and the late Cornelius Gillam. Also survived by many nieces and nephews. Mary was a graduate of Skidmore College, 1952 and received her Doctorate at Columbia University Teachers College. She directed the Art Studio at the Weekday School at Riverside Church in New York and was a member of the West End Collegiate Church where she was a certified Stephen Minister. Memorial Service in the First Church Cambridge Congregational, 11 Garden St., Cambridge, Saturday, January 4 at 3pm. Relatives and friends kindly invited. Expressions of sympathy may be made in Mary's memory to either the Employee Assistance Fund c/o Finance Department at North Hill, 865 Central Avenue, Needham, MA 02492 or to The West End Collegiate Church, c/o Parish Administrator, 245 West 77th Street, NY, NY 10024. Online guestbook at www.gfdoherty.com.

BELLSEY--Edwin M. June 8, 1919-December 24, 2013. Devoted husband to Ruthellen ("Rusty"); loving father to Bill, Debi, Janet and Jim, and grandfather to Elizabeth, Jay and Drew; father-in-law to Amy, Linda, and Barry; and beloved brother, uncle and brother-in-law. Predeceased by his first wife, Barbara, in 1972. Proud WWII veteran who served in the 8th Army Air Corps. Returned from the War to join the family business (Dave Bellsey Co., Inc.) and later became a financial advisor. Passionate artist, calligrapher, poet, tennis and bridge player. Competitive swimmer in his youth. Cherished friend. Remembered for his warmth, kindness and humor. Last man standing. Forever in our hearts.

BARR--Lenore. December 26, 2013. Widow of Irving Barr. Beloved sister of Faith Wolitzer. Loving mother of Kathie and Arnold Kaplan, Jackie and Eliot Morrison, Susan and David Currier, Alan and Burta Barr. Cherished grandmother and great-grandmother. Services Sunday 12:30pm, Riverside Cha-pels, Great Neck, NY.

BARRETT--Dolores J. Dolores died peacefully in her sleep on December 24, 2013, after a series of long and debilitating illnesses, which she suffered with her characteristic restraint, dignity, and indomitable spirit. Her many friends in the fields of fashion, design, medicine, and media admired her as an elegant woman of impeccable taste, rock-steady values, and an empathetic nature that allowed her to understand and share the feelings of others. She was the middle child of Mildred and Dwight Cupp, both of whom were well-known residents of Johnstown, Pennsylvania. Her father died when she was two years old, and she eventually adopted the surname of her stepfather, Robert Jones. She was a graduate of Penn State, where she was invited to join Mortar Board, the premier national honor society recognizing college seniors. After receiving her master's degree from the University of Pennsylvania's Annenberg School for Communication, she embarked on a distinguished career as a public relations executive at The New York Hospital, CBS, and Polo Ralph Lauren. During the eight years in which she served as the Senior Vice President for Worldwide Public Relations at Polo, Dolores worked closely with the designer Ralph Lauren, and is widely credited with helping him build his global brand and making Ralph Lauren a household name beyond the fashion industry. She was married for 26 years to Edward Klein, the former editor in chief of The New York Times Magazine and the author of numerous nonfiction bestsellers. Her son, Robertson Barrett, is Vice President of Yahoo News and Finance. Her daughter, Melissa Barrett Rhodes, is Vice President of Brand Development for Clarins. Her stepdaughter, Karen Hirsch, is the former co-manager of the Four Seasons Restaurant. Dolores was a loving and deeply involved grandmother to John and Annalise Rhodes, Nathaniel and Cora Barrett, and Jesse Hirsch. She is also survived by her sister, Natalie Kearns, and her brother, John Jones. She leaves a void in the hearts of her family and friends that can only be filled by the memories of love, warmth and happiness that she left behind.

BALDWIN--David S.,M.D. The distinguished physician and scholar died at the age of 92 in his sleep on December 23 at his home in New York City. Dr. Baldwin was born in Rochester, New York, where he trained at the University of Rochester School of Medicine. For half a century, this tireless pioneer in the origins of hypertension and nephritis practiced internal medicine at his office in Manhattan while teaching generations of aspiring doctors at Bellevue Hospital and New York University Tisch/Langone Medical Center as a Professor of Medicine. Dr. Baldwin was married for 68 years to Halee Jean (Morris) Baldwin, who survives him. He also leaves four loving sons and three daughters-in-law, Neil (Roberta), Andrew (Susan), Daniel (Nancy) and James; seven grandchildren, Nicholas, Allegra, Seth, Laura, Matthew, Joshua, and Julia; two great-grandchildren, Levi and Emily; as well as countless grateful patients and their families. Funeral services will be private.

AUFDERHEIDE--John, 73, of Savannah, GA died suddenly on Sunday, December 22, 2013. John was born in Pittsburgh, PA. John served in the U.S. Army with a tour of duty in Vietnam. He started his professional life in the field of public accounting then joined ITT Corporation. He rose quickly through the ranks, becoming an important member of ITT's senior management team. In 1986, he left ITT to join business software company Shaw Data Services Inc. as CFO. After its acquisition by Sunguard, in 1992 until 1996 John served as President. John then engaged in pro bono work, for a troubled non-profit medical research institute, restoring it to financial health. For the last decade, after retiring to Savannah, John worked as a consultant with U.S. Summit Company, headquartered in NY with operations throughout China and the Far East. His contributions to the company were extraordinary, his colleagues will miss his exceedingly rare combination of technical expertise, common sense wisdom and calm under pressure, all delivered with a twinkle in his eye. John shared his joy of travel with his family. He was an avid golfer and loved sports, traveling to many baseball parks and following the Pittsburgh Steelers. His love of history fueled his extensive travel around the world. He appreciated and generously supported The Arts, both locally and abroad. Many know John as a talented conversationalist with a compelling and playful sense of humor. John received degrees from Robert Morris College and the University of Hartford. He became a Certified Public Accountant in 1966. John Aufderheide is survived by his wife, Elizabeth; three sons, Brian, John, and Brad; five grandchildren, Jacqueline, Chela, Sean, Ruby and Olivia; and his sister, Mary Ann Guetthoff. Donations can be made to the American Heart Association.

ALLING--Charles Booth Jr.,92, of Exeter, New Hampshire, and Kennebunk, Maine, died peacefully at home on December 19 after a long illness. Before he graduated from Yale University (1947), he flew 27 combat missions, 19 as a lead pilot, and two mercy missions with the Eighth Air Force over Europe earning the Distinguished Flying Cross and the Air Medal with four Oak Leaf Clusters. In New York City, he became a management consultant and later a Partner and Senior Director of SpencerStuart, an executive search firm. He is survived by his wife Gail McMaster Alling; three daughters Charlotte Alling, Elizabeth Alling Hildt, and Abigail Alling; three grandchildren Christopher Cooke, Abigail Alling, and Charles Hildt; and sister, Elizabeth Atwood. A Celebration of his Life will be held at St. Ann's Episcopal Church in Kennebunk, Maine (summer 2014). In lieu of flowers, a contribution in his memory may be made to St. Ann's Episcopal Church, Box 44, Kennebunkport, Maine 04046 or Yale University, Office of Development, 157 Church Street, New Haven, Connecticut 06510-2100.

WILSON--Robert W.,The National Audubon Society staff and board regret the passing of Robert W. Wilson, a conservation hero and model of philanthropy. We extend our condolences to his friends and celebrate his generosity. David Yarnold, President & CEO; B. Holt Thrasher, Chairman

WELLS--Wayne, 89, of North Palm Beach and St. Louis, died peacefully in North Palm Beach after a long illness on December 23. An avid Cardinals fan, he attended spring training, keeping stats on his beloved team. He also loved Iowa, good restaurants, the arts, travel, his friends and family. Mr. Wells was born on a farm in Cantril, Iowa, and served in the Navy. He graduated from the University of Iowa and quickly became a partner at Arthur Andersen & Co in New York City. He also worked at Deering Milliken, Mohawk Data Sciences, General Dynamics, and Alltype Fire Protection. He served on the Vestry of The Church of St. Michael & St. George. He is survived by his wife of 58 years, Jean Burchell Wells; his brothers Van and Dwight; his children Jeffrey (Serena) of New Canaan, Linda of Manhattan, Jennifer of Novato, and David (Anne) of Darien, along with eight grandchildren and countless friends. He was predeceased by his brother Donald. Hismemorial service is on January 11th at the Lost Tree Chapel.
WILSON--Robert W. BAM mourns generous donor, unique individual, and BAM supporter for 30 years. Karen Hopkins, President

SACKS--Bernice, died December 26, Manhattan, age 89. Beloved daughter of Samuel and Fanny Zwick and widow of Raymond Sacks, survived by her loving children Raina Sacks Blankenhorn and Ivan Sacks, son-in-law David Blankenhorn, and grandchildren, Raymond, Alexandra, Sophia and Madeline. Cherished by so many extended family and friends. Singer, dancer, patroness of the arts, humanist, political mind, the empress of West 70th Street. She was and remains the spiritual mother to a broad flock and the center of our compass. A memorial service will be held at a later date to be announced. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made in her name to WBGO Jazz Radio.
ROTHSTEIN--Gordon J.,Of New City, NY. On December 24th at age 94. He will be remembered by three generations.

RICE--Laurence J.,of Garden City on December 27th, 2013. Beloved husband of the late Christine C.; devoted brother of Maura K. Murphy, Charles E. and the late James B.; loving father of Louis (Jana), Timothy (Sheila), Paul (Ward), Mary Ann (Owen) Blicksilver, Ellen, Kathleen, Christine, Elizabeth (Michael) Connors, Sheila and the late Laurence J. (Cheryl). Adored grandfather of eleven. Viewing at Fairchild Sons Funeral Home 1201 Franklin Ave, Garden City December 29th, 2013, 7pm-9pm, and Monday, December 30th, 2013 2pm-4pm and 7pm-9pm. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday, December 31st, 2013 at St. Joseph's Church, Garden City at 10am. Interment to follow at Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Hospice Care Network, 99 Sunnyside Blvd. Woodbury, NY 11797.

RHEINSTEIN--Frederic, age 86, died on December 22, 2013 in Los Angeles, CA. Born in New York City on November 5, 1927, he attended Exeter and Princeton University Class of 1949. He worked for NBC-TV as a stage manager for "Your Show of Shows" and then as on site producer-director for remote coverage of global events such as Ruby's shooting of Lee Harvey Oswald and remotes of political Conventions 1956 1972. In 1974, he founded The Post Group, a leading edge Post Production facility in Hollywood, co-founded Motorweek productions/World Sports Enterprises, and garnered a myriad of producing, directing and entrepreneurial credits. He is survived by his wife Suzanne, daughter Linda C. Rheinstein, son David A. Rheinstein, daughter, Katherine R Brodsky, son-in-law Alexander Brodsky, granddaughters Beatriz and Frederica Brodsky, brother Robert Rheinstein and seven nieces and nephews. He was predeceased by his sister Katherine R. Warren. His marriage to Patricia Horn ended in divorce. A memorial service will be held at All Saints Episcopal Church, Beverly Hills, CA on January 25th.

REUTER--Peter J.,Roslyn NY, 86, engineer and entrepreneur died peacefully at home, December 26. Born in Germany, Peter emigrated to the United States in 1940. He earned an engineering degree from Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute and an MBA from New York University. He co-founded Trygon Electronics, Inc. He is survived by his wife, Edith (nee Dolinko), his daughter, Susan Reuter and her husband, Roger Spingarn, two granddaughters, Abi and Leah, stepsons, Steven and Neal Shupak, sister, Ann (Helft) and her sons, John and Ralph and their families. A private burial will be held in Bennington, Vermont. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his memory to NYU at giving.poly.edu.

KURLAND--Bruce. American still-life painter Bruce Kurland died on December 11, 2013 after a long illness. Born on May 16, 1938 in the Bronx, Kurland studied at the Art Students League of New York and at the National Academy School of Fine Arts. He was represented by the Joan Washburn, Claude Bernard, and Victoria Munroe galleries and his work is housed in public collections including the Smithsonian Institute's National Museum of American Art and the Burchfield Penney Art Center. Kurland is survived by three daughters, Hannah Kurland, Yetta Kurland, and Justine Kurland; two grandchildren, Vita Kurland and Casper McCorkle; and his former wife Toni Lamberti. A memorial service is planned for February. Scholarship donations may be sent in Kurland's name to the Art Students League of New York.

JOHNSON--Kenneth J.,beloved husband, father and grandfather, passed away on December 24, 2013 in Medford, NY. He was born in Greenwich Village on January 9, 1925. Ken was married to Mary Ganley Johnson and is survived by his wife and three sons: Daniel, Evan and Jason and his sister Carol Johnson Shedd. Ken worked as a photojournalist for most of his career, inspiring other photographers through his teaching. Ken was a veteran of WWII, serving in the Pacific. For information on memorial services please email: wenev@optonline.net.

JESSELSON--Ilse Merzbach, died on December 29, 2013. She was born on February 25, 1921 in Frankfurt, Germany. Her parents were the late Paula and Rudolf Merzbach, whose family traces back to the Frankfurt ghetto in the 16th century. She was predeceased by her husband Kurt Jesselson. She is survived by her son Robert and wife Sara in Columbia, SC and brother Bill Merzbach in LA. Funeral service and burial will be held on Tuesday, December 31 at 2pm in Cedar Park Cemetery, Westwood, NJ. www.dunbarfunerals.com.

GILBERT--Richard L.,Beloved husband to Marjorie for 62 incredible years, devoted father of Adam (and Emily), loving brother of Sheldon, and cherished grandfather of Lily and Charlotte. Richard was unstoppable, living his life to the fullest during each one of his 92 years. Services 11am Tuesday, December 31, 2013 at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 91st and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions in his memory may be made to the New-York Historical Society.

GETRAJDMAN--Nat, passed peacefully on December 27 at home. Beloved husband of Celina. Father of Sergio, George and Alex. Loving grandfather of seven and faithful friend to many. He will live on in our thoughts.

FEINSTEIN--Phyllis Helene, (nee Cohen), 83, passed away peacefully on December 28, 2013. She was predeceased by her parents Sarah and Sol Cohen. Phyllis was a loving mother to Stuart (Margaret) and Steven (Yvonne), devoted grandmother of Mary, David, Andrew and Matthew, and caring sister of Francine Hornstein (predeceased by brother-in-law, S. Lawrence). Phyllis was born in Brooklyn, graduated from Tilden High School and New York University, and raised her family in Roslyn, NY. Phyllis enjoyed travel, theater, and time with lifelong friends. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Ronald McDonald House of New Haven, CT or St. Jude Children's Research Hospital. Services will be held on Monday, December 30, 2013, 11am, at Gutterman's Funeral Home, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, NY followed by Shiva at the home of Steven and Yvonne Feinstein, Old Brookville, NY.

ELLER--Anita Rosenhan, on Tuesday, December 17th in Jerusalem. Daughter of the late Irving and Rose Rosenhan, she was the beloved wife of Albert who predeceased her in 2004. She is survived by her devoted daughter, Yael (Ben) Berlinger and four loving grandchildren; Levannah, Ze'ev, Assaf and Avraham. Her sisters Ruby (Sidney) Glassel and Goldie (Donald) Morchower also survive her, as do a niece and nephews Felice (Glenn) Zalk, Jeff Glassel and Matt Morchower, and great-nieces and nephew Jennifer Zalk and Andrew (Allison) Zalk. Burial took place in Jerusalem. May her memory be for a blessing.

BRODY--Evelyn, on December 28, 2013. Beloved wife of the late Leo, devoted mother Lorna, Richard and Robert. Doting grandmother, aunt and great-aunt. Co-founder with her husband Leo of UFO Contemporary, Inc., a global jeans company. Services Monday 11:30am at "The Riverside", 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to DOROT at www.dorotusa.org or a charity of choice.

WILSON--Robert W. The Nature Conservancy offers its heartfelt remembrance of the life and spirit of Robert W. Wilson. Bob was a member of The Nature Conservancy for more than 50 years and helped establish and lead some of our first programs in New York. He was a man of extraordinary vision and ardor. His passion for conservation and indomitable spirit live on through the people and places that today thrive as a result of his generosity. Bob challenged us through his ideas, counsel and generosity to rethink the boundaries of what is possible. He pushed us to be better, to think bigger and to experiment. He has had a profound impact on the conservation movement, and his impact can be seen and felt through the organizations, like ours, that are stronger and more capable as a result of Bob's involvement. The Nature Conservancy sends our sincere condolences to Bob's family and friends. And, we share our gratitude for all that Bob has done to make this world a better place.

WILSON--Robert W. The Board and staff of Environmental Defense Fund mourn the passing of their dear friend, Robert W. Wilson. We will be forever grateful to Bob for his leadership and support, and offer our deepest condolences to his friends and colleagues. Carl Ferenbach, Chairman Fred Krupp, President

WEEN--Jeffrey (Jacob). Born in New York City on May 29, 1946, died December 28, 2013. We are heartbroken at the loss of our beloved Jacob. An extraordinary husband, stepfather, father-in-law, grandfather, family man and friend. Graduate of NYU Law and Oxford University, he had an untold impact, tirelessly fighting for tenants' and artists' rights throughout New York City for 35 years. He has taught us many lessons, including the imperative of performing daily acts of generosity and loving kindness. In lieu of flowers, donations should be made to IYYUN or The Mussar Institute.

TANNHAUSER--Jutta, on December 29, 2013. Beloved wife of the late Erwin. Beneficiary of Kindertransport, a not-for-profit organization of child holocaust survivors who were sent without their parents out of Germany, Austria and Poland. Services Tuesday 11am at "The Riverside" 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave.

STUART--Jeannette Wigton, 97, of Lake Wales, FL passed away Saturday, December 21, 2013 at her residence. She was born December 11, 1916 in Plainfield, NJ to the late Charles Benson and Anna Maxwell Wigton; and she came here from Oldwick, NJ in 1994. She attended Hartridge School in Plainfield, NJ, Dana Hall School in Wellesley, MA and the Fashion Institute of Technology in Manhattan. Jeannette was preceded in death by her husband, Linden Stuart, Jr. Survivors include her daughters, Carol Stuart Henry of Pottersville, NJ and Beverly Stuart Melius of St. John, Virgin Islands; sons, Terry Stuart of Boulder, CO and Gordon Stuart of Bernardsville, NJ; sisters, Betty Bours of Wilmington, DE and Ann Hall of Essex, CT; five grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. Interment services will be held at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Gladstone, New Jersey in the Spring. Services by Marion Nelson Funeral Home in Lake Wales, FL.

SEIDMAN--Anne Sherman, of Manhattan, also known as Jan, died Sunday, December 22, 2013 at 1pm. Jan was widowed from accountant Jacob Seidman. She is survived by nephews Rob and Charles Sherman of New Jersey. Services are private.

PREZIOTTI--Nicholas R.,77, died peacefully at his Middletown, NJ home in December from liver cancer. Nick is survived by his wife of 22 years, Patricia Anne (Conahan) Preziotti; his four children, Sue Preziotti of NYC; Christine Troost & husband Ed of McKinney, TX; Rich Preziotti, wife Elaine & daughter Gia of West Caldwell, NJ; Donna Preziotti & daughter Sasha of Milan, MI; and his siblings, Joe Preziotti and Janet DiCosta of Staten Island. Nick worked at The New York Times for 45 years in advertising sales and created the paper's highly successful nationwide Job Fairs. He retired in 1999 and is remembered as a knowledgeable, helpful manager with a quick wit, and a proud father who liked to talk about his children and tell funny stories. Donations may be made in Nick's memory to American Liver Foundation or American Cancer Society.

MARSHALL--Alfred, of Boca Raton FL, formerly of Beverly, MA and St. Maarten, beloved husband of Estelle (Newburg) Marshall and the late Marirose (Pelletier) Marshall, passed away in Boca Raton December 28, 2013 following a short illness. He was 94. Born February 28, 1919 in Lawrence, MA he was the son of the late Louis and Annie (Spector) Marshall. Alfred grew up in Beverly and graduated from Beverly High School. After graduation, he enlisted in the Navy and was enroute to Pearl Harbor in Hawaii on December 7th, 1941. On arrival he volunteered to be an underwater diver, repairing the ships that were destroyed in the attack. Following the war, he returned to live in Beverly. His many jobs included building homes and general contracting as well as welding, which he had learned in the Navy. On Enon Street in North Beverly, he started many businesses including a fruit stand, grocery store and an ice cream stand where he sold banana splits on Sundays for 29 cents to use the ripe bananas. He also ran an auction in the basement. In 1956, Marshall conceived the idea of a self-service department store offering brand names for less. It was on that spot that he opened the original Marshall's Department Store, which he helped build. Years later, after selling Marshall's in the US, he moved to the Caribbean where he opened Marshall's in St. Thomas, St. Croix and St. Maarten. American tourists leaving their cruise ships in St. Thomas were always pleasantly surprised to be greeted by the familiar Marshall's sign. Alfred loved to sail and to travel. He set up buying offices in South Korea and Hong Kong, importing all manner of merchandise to sell and distribute throughout the Caribbean. In St. Maarten, he started Marshall Motors and his grandson Aaron is still affiliated with the company. In addition to his wife, Marshall is survived by his children; Ronald and his wife Carolann of Hampton, NH, Jan and his wife Patricia of St. Maarten and Deborah Miller and her husband Dudley of Ipswich and Naples, FL.; his grandchildren Aaron of St. Maarten, Nicole (Marshall) Gouin and her husband Christopher of Exeter, NH, Zachary Miller of Ipswich, Courtney (Miller) Calvert and her husband of California, Dana (Marshall) Fisher and her husband, and two great-grandchildren. He was also predeceased by a sister, "Buddy" Kaplan. Services will be at Temple B'nai Abraham, 200 East Lothrop St, Beverly, MA on Thursday, January 2nd at 10am followed by interment at the Sons of Abraham cemetery in Beverly, MA.
LEVITT--Myra. You were a sister to Edna; an aunt to us. A lifetime of kindness, laughs and love will truly be missed. Edna, Jay, Karen, Brett, Jared and Ali Kasner

LEVITT--Myra Knapp, We had the best times, Queen Mary, Queen Elizabeth, Paris, Europe. We were only 16. Our weekly lunches ever since. You are my best friend. I love you and miss you forever. Rhona and Floyd

LERIGO--Geoffrey. Prominent International Hotelier extraordinaire and a sartorial gentleman of uncommon dignity, loved and respected by all who knew him, including a host of hotel workers, passed away at Holy Cross Hospital, Ft. Lauderdale, FL, December 26, 2013. Born in Farnham, Surrey, UK, to Frederick Bowen and Joanna Jane Lerigo on June 2, 1933. Predeceased by his parents and younger brother Robert Bryan Lerigo (2009). Geoffrey is survived by his devoted life partner of 27 years, Richard Dietz, Fort Lauderdale, FL; his loving sister Anne Jeffrey (David), Gibsons, BC, Canada; brother Vyvian (Mary) Lerigo, Whitstable, Kent, UK; nieces Marion Stewart and Hazel Lerigo, UK; nephew Martin (Rachel) Lerigo, Hong Kong, to great- nephews, Michael and Anthony; and Lerigo and Baugh cousins in Hereford, UK. Geoffrey's laugh, effervescent personality and love of life will be missed by his numerous friends and family world wide. He touched the hearts of many and enriched the lives of most. He will be missed dearly. No service by request.

LAZAROF--Henri. Prolific composer and educator, Henri Lazarof, passed away from Alzheimer's disease at his home in Los Angeles, California. Mr. Lazarof was born in Sofia, Bulgaria on April 12, 1943, where he spent his youth studying at the Jesuit Lycee Francais. As a student, he showed an early talent in music, and became a concert pianist before his teenage years. In his early teens, he turned to music composition. His family immigrated to Tel Aviv, Israel where he studied with Paul Ben-Haim, a prominent Israeli composer. During Mr. Lazarof's army service, he organized concerts throughout Israel for the Israeli troops. He won the first musical scholarship awarded in Israel to attend the prestigious Saint Cecilia Academy in Rome, where he studied with the renowned composer Goffredo Petrassi. Mr. Lazarof arrived in Rome speaking four languages fluently but not one word of Italian. In three months, he mastered the Italian language and became a tour guide. He finished his four-year courses in three years, and won another scholarship to Brandeis University in Massachusetts. There he studied under the guidance of American composers Arthur Berger and Harold Shapero, and became fluent in English, his eighth language. In 1966, Mr. Lazarof moved to California and became a Professor Emeritus at the University of California, Los Angeles, teaching music composition and organizing contemporary music festivals. From 1970 to 1971, he served as composer-in-residence in Berlin; in 1979 he held the same position at the highly acclaimed Tanglewood Music Center in Boston, Massachusetts. In 1982 Mr. Lazarof decided to solely focus his attention on musical composition. Throughout the course of his career, Mr. Lazarof had 126 works published with the Associated Music Publishers, Theodore Presser, Bot and Bock, and others. These works include seven symphonies, three concertos for orchestra, three violin concertos, three cello concertos, two flute concertos, a viola concerto, a piano concerto, 11 string quartets, and innumerable pieces for orchestra, chamber orchestra, small ensembles, solo instruments, and mixed chorus. Numerous works were commissioned and recorded, and premiered by various orchestras throughout Europe, Asia, and the United States, including Carnegie Hall in New York; "First Symphony" with the Utah Symphony Orchestra; "Concerto No. 2 Icarus" with the Houston Symphony Orchestra; "Concerto for Oboe and Chamber Orchestra" with the New York Chamber Symphony; "Symphony No. 5 for Solo Baritone, Mixed Chorus and Orchestra" with the Seattle Symphony Orchestra. Mr. Lazarof's passion for art was reflected in his music, such as the "String Quartet No. 8," homage to Paul Klee, and "Tableaux (after Kandinsky)" premiered by Garrick Ohlson and the Seattle Symphony Orchestra. His prizes included first place in the International Tchaikovsky Competition; First International Competition from Monaco for Concerto for Viola and Orchestra; and First International Prize City of Milan La Scala Award for his musical composition, "Structures Sonores." He also received grants from the Ford Foundation and the National Endowment for the Arts, as well as two Grammy nominations in 1991 for Best Contemporary Composition and Best Classical Performance Instrumental Soloist(s) with Orchestra. Mr. Lazarof's compositions were known for their broad range of textures, dynamics, and diversity of rhythms. Many of his works used unusual, seldom written combinations of instruments. By refusing to settle within any one ideology or style even those of his own previous works Mr. Lazarof remained faithful to his principal of growth and exploration, producing a body of work that will endure. Survivors include his wife, sister, son, daughter-in-law, four stepdaughters and their spouses, and nine grandchildren. Services will be on Friday, January 3, 2014, at Hillside Mortuary in Los Angeles, California, at 2:00pm. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate contributions to the Henri Lazarof Memorial Fund, c/o American Youth Symphony, 3424 Wilshire Boulevard, Suite 830, Los Angeles, California 90010, (310) 470-2332.

GILBERT--Richard L.,Beloved husband to Marjorie for 62 incredible years, devoted father of Adam (and Emily), loving brother of Sheldon, and cherished grandfather of Lily and Charlotte. Richard was unstoppable, living his life to the fullest during each one of his 92 years. Services 11am Tuesday, December 31, 2013 at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 91st and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions in his memory may be made to the New-York Historical Society.

GETRAJDMAN--Nat, passed peacefully on December 27 at home. Beloved husband of Celina. Father of Sergio, George and Alex. Loving grandfather of seven and faithful friend to many. He will live on in our thoughts.

GANSBERG--Seymour, died on December 26 in Palm Springs. He was 94. He grew up in the Bronx, New York, graduated from New York University School of Commerce in 1940 and proudly served in combat in the Aleutian Islands as a Captain in the US Air Force during World War II. He is survived by his loving wife of 69 years, Selma; his sister, Arlene; two sons, Jeffrey and Andrew; four grandchildren, Brad, Tara, Amy and Michael; and three great-grandchildren, Jessie, Riley and Sydney.

EGGERTH--Marta. We mourn the death of our dear friend Marta and will never forget her magnificent voice and the joy she brought to us and her multitude of fans. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Marjan Kiepura and his wife Jane. Robert J Campbell, M.D., Cesare L Santeramo

EGGERTH--Marta, legend of stage and screen, died peacefully at her Westchester home on December 26th at age 101. Funeral services take place on Thursday, January 2nd at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, New York City. Visitation is from 2 to 5pm and 7 to 9pm with a short prayer service. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation in Marta's name to a musical charity of your choice. Survivors include son John Thade, and son and daughter-in-law Marjan and Jane Knox-Kiepura. Marta Eggerth, wife of Polish Tenor Jan Kiepura, was born on April 17, 1912 in Budapest, Hungary.

DRENTTEL--William. The Smithsonian's Cooper-Hewitt, National Design Museum mourns the loss of Bill Drenttel. A trustee from 1998-2009, Bill was an extraordinary design mind and an enthusiastic advocate for the museum. We extend our deepest sympathies to Jessica and the family. Cooper-Hewitt Board of Trustees and Staff

DOUGHERTY--Jaye. On behalf of the entire Juilliard School community, and its Drama Division, we mourn the loss of our dear colleague and friend. Jaye was an inspiration and passionate teacher to the many students whose lives she touched for over twenty one years. She will be remembered and celebrated for her unflinching dedication and compassion. Our prayers and condolences go out to her beloved husband, Steve, and her entire family. Jaye will be missed dearly. Joseph W. Polisi, Juilliard President Ara Guzelimian, Provost and Dean James Houghton, Richard Rodgers Director of the Drama Division Katherine Hood, Administrative Director

CROUSE--Anna. The Board and Staff of Lincoln Center Theater are deeply saddened by the death of our beloved Anna Crouse. A longtime Director and an Honorary Trustee for many years, Anna was passionate about the Theater, particularly our theater. She was feisty, informed, enthusiastic, intelligent, opinionated, generous and always loving, always caring. Indeed, Lincoln Center Theater probably would not exist today without Anna's early advocacy and devotion. We extend our sympathy and love to Tim and Lindsay who took such magnificent care of their mother in recent years. Anna was a formidable figure, and we will miss her every single day. J. Tomilson Hill Chairman, Board of Directors Andre Bishop, Producing Artistic Director

CROUSE--Anna. We at Rodgers & Hammerstein mourn the death of Anna Crouse. She was smart and she was passionate - and was always appreciative of the work we do to keep the "The Sound of Music" performed the world over. Above all, she was an advocate for good theater everywhere. There will not be another one like her. We send our condolences to Tim and Lindsay. Ted Chapin Rodgers & Hammerstein

BIJUR--Hilda Reis. Hilda Reis Bijur died peacefully December 26, surrounded by adoring family. She was born in Greenwich, CT, in 1918 and grew up in New York City, where she was valedictorian of her class at the Lincoln School. Hilda graduated from Vassar College in 1940. After working for Theatre Arts Magazine she went to Washington, D.C., to work at the Red Cross during WWII, writing for its publication. She came back to New York after the war and studied photography with Josef Breitenbach. In 1952 she married the love of her life, Bill Bijur, and within two years they were the doting parents of Arthur and Victoria. Bill's life was cut devastatingly short in 1960 after a long illness, and Hilda carried on with the utmost grace, strength, dignity, and quiet joy. Within a week of Bill's death, she was photographing at Union Theological Seminary. In 1965 she started photographing for the World Bank. Over the next ten years she was sent to the Ivory Coast, Senegal, Spain, Portugal, Turkey, Malta, Jamaica, Mexico, Trinidad, Morocco, and Israel to photograph World Bank projects. She also served proudly as president of the Cosmopolitan Club. She was the most devoted, supportive, and loving mother, a rock of Gibralter not just to her children but also to her extended family and her friends. Since 1973 she had spent summers at a beloved house on Martha's Vineyard, where she celebrated her 95th birthday in August. She is survived by her children, Arthur and Victoria, her son-in-law, Ed Levine, and two magnificent grandsons, William Levine and Benjamin Bijur.

BACCUS--Barbara "Brett", died peacefully on December 29, 2013 in New York City, at age 79 after a brief illness. She is survived by her partner Diane Friedman, her sister Marcia Johnson, her brother-in-law Jay Johnson, her nephew Bret Johnson, and her brother Barry Baccus. Brett's interests and successes were many and varied. An entrepreneur and connoisseur, she was also passionate about animals, always advocating on their behalf. She was a lover of the arts, mentoring young artists. She enjoyed a good martini followed by fine food and wine. She appreciated the finer things in life, while always showing empathy for others. Brett enjoyed and shared the good life with her beloved partner of 34 years, Diane. Brett and Diane were married on December 23, 2013. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Fire Island Pines Care Center, PO Box 5333, Sayville, NY 11782. A life celebration will be held on January 2, 2014 at 6:30pm at their NYC home.
