EISEN--Miriam R.,on December 31, age 94, died peacefully at home. Survived by three children, four grandchildren and one great-grandchild.

GROSS--Dolores Veronica Farrell (Aunt Honey), age 83, a long-time resident of Rockville Centre, Long Island, died on Tuesday, December 31, 2013 in her home after a brief illness with metastatic lung cancer. Born on December 22, 1930 she is predeceased by her parents, Joseph and Pauline Farrell, her sister Rose Tator and her brother, George Farrell. She was the loving wife of William Gross, mother of Kevin and Keith Gross, grandmother of Olivia and Hunter Gross and beloved sister of Margaret Keefe and Dr. Patricia Farrell, mother-in-law of Maria Gross and Donna Gross and sister-in-law of Dr. Rita D. Posner. In addition, she is mourned by her 10 nieces and nephews and 10 great-nieces and great-nephews. During her lifetime, Aunt Honey was the central figure in her extended family while maintaining herself in computer services and has a lifetime of achievement of helping others to achieve their goals in life. Words fail to express her contributions to others. No funeral services will be held. Her remains will be cremated as was her wish In lieu of flowers, please make contributions to the cancer fund of your choice.

GRIFFITHS--Jeanne McAlister, beloved daughter, caring sibling, adoring mother, and soul mate of her spouse, died on December 30th in Hudson, NY. She was 56 years young. Jeanne attended Friends Seminary in New York City, graduated from the University of Rochester and attended the Cornell School of Hotel Management in Paris and Ithaca. Upon graduating, Jeanne entered the world of hospitality, where she held major roles in the banquet departments for some of the finest hotels in New York, including Hotel Macklowe, the Stanhope and the Waldorf Astoria. Jeanne and her husband, Chip, left the hotel world to start their catering company, Tastefully Done, which they operated in the NYC area for nearly 20 years. As her own boss, Jeanne, with her partner, Chip, took as much pride in the freedom to attend every one of their children's sports games as she did in the wonderful events they hosted for their clients. In 2010, Jeanne and Chip left the greater New York City area and relocated upstate to Hudson, NY. Jeanne is survived by her parents, Irma and Andrew Hilton, her two younger sisters, Debbie McAlister Jones and Liz Hilton Segel, her brothers-in-law, Christopher Jones and Seth Segel, her nephews and niece Kyle, Cary, Conor, Daniel and Kate. She will be deeply missed by them and her two sons, Brad and James, her husband and best friend, Chip, and her 11 month-old German Shepherd puppy, Dutch. A memorial service will be held at the Friends Seminary Meeting House in New York (corner of East 15th Street and Rutherford Place) on Friday, January 10th at 6pm.

FRIEDMAN--Jeffrey Arnold, died on December 30th after losing his battle with brain cancer, a battle he fought with admirable courage and strength. He was a true warrior. He was only 51 but lived a full life by giving unconditional support and love to his family and friends. His love for his family was all encompassing, always protecting and providing. Passionate in all aspects of his life, he was a true and loyal friend. His commitment to his work was unshakeable to a fault until the end. Possessing deep convictions, he was steadfast when following his spiritual journey. He was a man of few words, but when said, they were pointed, real and true. He is survived by his wife, Adriana Friedman; daughter, Arielle Julia Friedman; sister, Jennifer Braunstein; brother-in-law, Rich Braunstein; neice, Jessica; nephew, Max; father, Arnold Friedman; and mother, Roz Guerriero. His memorial service will be held at Frank E. Campbell on Tuesday, January 7th, 2014 at 6:00pm. In lieu of flowers, donations should be made to Voices Against Brain Cancer to "Team Jeffrey." For those of us who had the honor and privilege of knowing him, his love will continue to live with us each and every day.

JEE--Stephen, 89 of Riverdale, NY died December 24, 2013. He is survived by his wife Dorothy, children: Victor, Lester and Kathy, and granddaughter: Dyrdra. He was loved by friends and family and will be greatly missed by all.

HERRMANN--Ruth, May 11, 1913-January 3, 2014. Loving and beloved wife of Louis, who predeceased her. Adored mother of Frederica and Marvin Amstey, Patricia and Stephen Brecher. Devoted grandmother of Ross Amstey and Trish Annese, Karen and Cyril Lemaire, Ethan Brecher, Jennifer and Kenneth Burstiner. BLOOM--Christina Marie (nee Maneri), died peacefully in her sleep on December 26 in her Manhattan home after a long battle with breast cancer, surrounded by her two children. Born December 25, 1958, she grew up in Holmdel, NJ. In 1976, she graduated from Holmdel High as class president. She earned her BA from Providence College in 1980. Christina's life passion was to understand how and why people fall in love. Serving as CEO until her passing, she founded the innovative dating website FindYourFaceMate, based on the research that facial similarities spark greater chemistry, necessary for lasting love. Her pioneering efforts resulted in a unique algorithm in photo-analysis. Active in philanthropy and the arts, Christina helped underwrite theatrical and film productions, served as a board member for the Joe Torre Safe at Home Foundation, and gave generously to cancer research, Operation Smile, and other causes. In this spirit of giving, she has donated her body to cancer research. She is survived by her two children; as well as her father, Vincent Maneri; eight siblings, 21 nieces and nephews, and her beloved dog. A caring mother, cool aunt, loyal sister and friend, and adoring daughter to her father and late mother, Marie, whom she missed profoundly. She joins her peacefully. Rest in Peace, Mommykins.

BRANDT--Helene. Artist and Teacher. Born in Philadelphia on September 17, 1936, died on August 27, 2013 of sudden cardiac arrest. 1970 B.A. City College, Phi Beta Kappa. 1976 Certificate of Advanced Studies, St. Martin's School of Art, London. 1975 MFA Columbia University. 1985 Guggenheim Fellow. Review NY Times May 12, l989 "Helene Brandt" by Michael Brenson. Many solo and group shows - for CV see helenebrandt.com. I was blessed to be Helene's husband. We were married when she was just 18. We grew up, raised a family, and grew old together. We shared a love of classical music, hiking, camping, travel and living abroad. Helene loved languages and became fluent in French, Danish, and Italian. Most of all Helene loved making art in her studio at 43 Great Jones Street, NoHo. Many writers have created fantasy worlds, populated with unusual forms of life and explored by heroic mortals. Helene sculpted a welded steel collection of imaginary forms of life as well as her signature cages. It was her fantasy world and she was its hero. Her later work combined steel with other more organic materials like vegetables and roots in wall pieces that expanded her magic world. She has left us all grieving: her husband, Philip; two sons, David and Daniel; a daughter-in-law, Kristin; two grandchildren, Alexander and Christopher; and many friends and students. It must be so.

BLANK--Karen J.,of Manhattan, NY, passed away from complications related to cancer on December 31, 2013. Loving wife of Jim Milligan (deceased, January 2005), devoted mother of Ned Milligan, and treasured colleague, mentor, and friend to many. Karen served as Dean of Studies at Barnard College from 1993 through 2012, spending the previous decade as Associate Dean for Student Affairs at Columbia College. After graduating from the University of California-Berkeley, Karen left Albany, CA, where she was raised, to search out work in the field of higher education. This pursuit allowed her to experience and enhance student life at several colleges, ultimately bringing her to the Columbia University community of which she was proud to be a member for thirty years. In illness, Karen was cared for by her dedicated team of nurses, together with loyal friends and family. She drew love, strength and support from Ned, his wife Jamie, and the Cahill family (Barbara, Barry, Kristen, and Greg)-- relatives of Jim's who cared for Karen as one of their own. She is survived by them all, as well as her brother, Bob. Karen was always grateful for her life and to those who made it better. She will be celebrated in memoriam with a service on Thursday, January 9, 11am at West End Collegiate Church, 245 West 77th Street, New York.

BASS--Susan, on December 29, 2013. 75 years old. Daughter of the late Harry and Yetta Wagonfeld. She was the beloved wife of Walter, who predeceased her in 2007. She is survived by her loving children Betty Dwoskin Sternlicht, Marjorie Knechtel and Peter Dwoskin, sons-in-law Elliot Sternlicht and Peter Knechtel, daughter-in-law Sara Corello and brother Samuel Wagonfeld. Adoring grandmother of Harry and Asher Dwoskin and James Sternlicht. May her memory be a blessing.

BRAUER--Arnold Lee, age 84, died on December 29, 2013 at home in Morristown, New Jersey. Beloved husband of the late Bernice; devoted sister of the late Jacqueline Kruger; loving father of Jonathan Brauer (Elizabeth), Susan Brauer and Cynthia Brauer (Stacy Dick); adoring grandfather of Ben Mackoff, Sam Mackoff, Jake Mackoff, William Brauer, Robert Brauer, Alexandra Brauer and Lillian Dick. Born in Jersey City, New Jersey, to Ben and Sylvia (Libman) Brauer, he was raised in South Orange, New Jersey. Arnold attended Cornell University and Columbia University, graduating in 1952. He then served in the US Air Force in Wyoming and France, a high point of his life. Arnold had a 50 year career as an automobile dealer in New Jersey and New York. His passions were his family, travel, and skiing. His last years were blessed by his devoted caregivers David Tskalobadze, Levani Kezevadze, and Katevan Harding. Private burial occurred on December 31, 2013. A memorial service will be held at 11am on January 8 at Temple B'nai Or, Overlook Road, Morristown, NJ. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Foundation for Morristown Medical Center or The Alzheimer's Association.

ALPERT--Dr. Joel J.,The Board of Directors of American Friends of Shalva mourn the passing of Dr. Joel J. Alpert, beloved father of Shalva Co-President Norman Alpert. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife Barbara and the entire family. May they be consoled among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Carol Levin, Co-President, Kalman Samuels, Shalva Founder & Director Leo Klein, Executive Director.

BURGER--Elisabeth Owen, Died peacefully at home on December 22nd, 2013. She will always be remembered as a loving mother, grandmother and great-grandmother. She could always be counted on for wise counsel, emotional support, wonderful meals and a place to stay in New York. She was joined in these activities by her second husband, Chester Burger, who passed away in March, 2011. Elisabeth was an avid reader and traveler, having been to every continent. She was an elegant woman with a great sense of humor, and especially good at making puns! She was a wonderful hostess, and was gracious to all around her to the day she died. She graduated from Vassar, and trained as an economist early in her professional career. After World War II she joined the staff of the International Labor Organization in Geneva, Switzerland where she met and later married Arthur David Kemp Owen, with whom she had two sons, Michael and Hugh. He was Assistant-Secretary General for Economic Affairs at the United Nations, and later co-founded the United Nations Development Program. After retiring from the UN in 1969, Owen was knighted by Queen Elisabeth II and she became Lady Owen. After Sir David's death in 1970, she later married Chester Burger, a New York management consultant. Mrs. Burger continued to work as a consultant to state, national and international organizations and served in the United Nations Secretariat for International Women's Year in 1975. She was a member of the board of Directors of Planned Parenthood in New York, and a long time member of the Cosmopolitan Club. She is survived by her two sons, Michael David Owen of New York City, and Hugh Miller Owen of Mt. Jackson, VA, ten grandchildren and eleven great-grandchildren, as well as five step-children, nine step-grandchildren, eight step-great-grandchildren and three grand-nieces.

ALPERT--Joel J.,MD, of Palm Beach Gardens, FL, Wayland, MA and East Parsonsfield, ME. Professor and chair Emeritus of the Boston University School of Medicine (BUSM) Department of Pediatrics, assistant dean for student affairs, member of the BUSM Dean's Advisory Board (DAB), and chief of Pediatrics at Boston Medical Center (BMC) died Tuesday, December 31, 2013 of leukemia at the age of 83, born on May 9, 1930. Loving son of the late Herman and Alice (Jacobs) Alpert. Beloved husband of Barbara (Wasserstrom) Alpert. Devoted father of Norman Alpert and his wife Jane of Purchase, NY, Mark Alpert and his wife Michelle of Canton, Deborah Levin and her husband Steven of Wellesley. Adored grandfather of Caroline, Erin, Heidi, Adam and Natalie Alpert, Joshua and Zachary Levin and Samantha Alpert. Dear brother of Edith Slossberg and her husband Burton of Hamden, CT. Also survived by many nieces and nephews. Dr. Alpert was a recognized leader in pediatrics. During his 42 years at BUSM and BMC (and its precursor Boston City Hospital) he pioneered pediatric primary care training, including continuity clinic sites at community health centers and the development of a curriculum that emphasized child development, advocacy and community care. BUMC's pediatric resident training in primary care in health centers was among the first in the United States. A graduate of Hillhouse High School, New Haven, CT Class of 1948, Yale College Class of 1952 and Harvard Medical School Class of 1956. Dr. Alpert completed his residency at Boston Children's Hospital and also trained as an Exchange Registrar at St. Mary's Hospital in London, UK from 1958 until 1959, he then served as Captain in the US Army at Ft. Leavenworth, KS from 1959 to 1961 and joined the Harvard faculty in 1961. He became professor and chair of the Department of Pediatrics at BUSM and Boston City Hospital in 1972. Dr. Alpert served as president of the American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP), where he received the AAP Job Lewis Smith Award in Community Pediatrics in 1994. He also served as president of the Ambulatory Pediatric Association (APA) and received the APA George Armstrong Award in 1992, the APA Lifetime Career Achievement Award in 2000, and the APA Public Policy and Advocacy Award in 2002. In 1992, the Massachusetts Poison Control System presented Dr. Alpert with a Lifetime Achievement Award and in 1998, he received the prestigious Pew Foundation Award for Achievement in Primary Care-Education. A member of the Institute of Medicine of the National Academy of Sciences (IOM), Dr. Alpert served on the IOM Governing Council and was the pediatric clinician on the IOM Task Force on the Future of Primary Care. He was a member of the Society for Pediatric Research, Alpha Omega Alpha (Boston University) and the American Pediatric Society, and an Honorary Fellow of the Royal College of Pediatrics and Child Health (London). He authored numerous publications, including The Education of Physicians for Primary Care (1974), which included the definition of primary care adopted by the Bureau of Health Professions for Title VII training in general medicine, family medicine and pediatrics. In 2000, Dr. Alpert and his wife Barbara established the Joel and Barbara Alpert Professorship in Pediatrics at BUSM with the support of the Alpert family, the Department of Pediatrics, and their colleagues and friends. The professorship is held by the chair of the Department of Pediatrics. The first incumbent was Barry Zuckerman, MD, from 2000 to 2013. Robert Vinci, MD, was installed as the second Alpert Professor in June 2013. The Alperts also established the Children of the City Fund at BMC in 2000 to support early career pediatric researchers who study issues of importance to inner-city children served by the hospital. Services at Temple Isaiah, 55 Lincoln St., Lexington on Monday, January 6 at 10am. Burial will follow at Westview Cemetery, 520 Bedford St., Lexington. Memorial observance will be at the home of Deborah and Steven Levin following burial until 4pm, continuing on Monday evening from 7-9pm, then on Tuesday and Wednesday from 1:30-4pm and 7-9pm with services at 7:30pm. Memorial observance will also be at the home of Norman and Jane Alpert in Purchase, NY on Wednesday, January 8 and Thursday, January 9 from 5:30-9pm with services at 7pm. Minyan Services will take place at the home of Norman Alpert on Thursday morning, January 9 at 7am and Friday morning, January 10th at 7am. In lieu of flowers, remembrances may be made to the Joel and Barbara Alpert Children of the City Fund at Boston University School of Medicine, 850 Harrison Ave., 5th Floor, Boston, MA 02118 or to a charity of one's choice.

BENENSON--Jane Stein (nee Garcy), widow of Charles B. Benenson, mother of Cathy Ives, grandmother of Galen McCown and Sion McCormick, stepmother of Lawrence, Billy and Freddy, aunt of Maggie Bruck and Nancy Bruck. Died peacefully in her North Hills, Long Island home on December 30, aged 94. Jane was a vibrant, engaging, strong willed and admirably opinionated woman. A great golfer, she was club champion at numerous golf clubs especially Sands Point Golf Club, her home course, where she won many times. Jane was very involved in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association and cherished the camaraderie of her team matches. A private graveside service and a memorial will be held in the spring. In lieu of flowers, please send donations in her memory to her beloved Metropolitan Opera at Support The Met Broadcasts, Lincoln Center, New York, NY 10023 or to the Caddie Scholarship Fund Sand Point Golf Club, 130 Middleneck Rd Sands Point, NY 11050.

COHEN--Richard Norman, son of Janet Goldsmith and Norman M. Cohen, passed away January 2 in Stamford Hospital at the age of 90. Born in New York City, he was a graduate of Phillips Exeter Academy and Yale University. His college years were interrupted by his service during World War II from 1942 to 1945. He served as a 2nd Lieutenant in the United States Air Force and was stationed in Morocco, Italy and France. Returning to the US, Cohen graduated from Yale University as a member of the Class of 1945. Cohen began a 49-year career in the insurance industry in 1951 with Mass Mutual, ending his career in 2000 as a senior executive for Leonard Newman Agency and Arthur Gallagher & Co. He served on the Board of the New York Times for 12 years from 1960-1972. He also served on the boards of The New Canaan Country School and Silver Hill Hospital. He leaves behind his devoted wife of 39 years, Ann Robertson Cohen, two sons: Daniel Hays (Leah Keith), James Matthew (Barbara Carey), stepson Mark Maxwell Thompson (Marcia Buckley) and seven grandchildren. Memorial donations may be made to Horizons Student Enrichment Program, P.O. Box 992, New Canaan, CT 06840 or Norwalk Community College Foundation, 188 Richards Ave., Norwalk, CT 06854.

COURTMAN--David, 91, died December 19, 2013 under the kind care of Casa de la Luz Hospice. He served in the Navy during WWII. David is survived by his wife Roberta; sons: William (Miranda) and Donald (Christine); grandsons: Gregory, Alex, Jesse and Jake. Spare with the spoken word- gifted with the written word-obsessed with the game of golf, David's long life held much joy and love. Services under the care of Vistoso Funeral Home.

BENENSON--Jane Stein. We mourn the loss of our father Charlie's widow, Jane. She passed away at the age of 94 on Monday, December 30. Jane and Charlie were together over 24 years until his passing in 2004. Charlie met Jane in 1948 and was overjoyed to encounter her again in 1980. The two of them enjoyed a loving relationship that revolved around museumgoing, tennis, their partnerships at bridge, travel, crossword puzzles, politics and most of all, golf. We express our deepest condolences to her daughter Cathy and her grandchildren Galen and Sion. We express our gratitude for the care and love Victoria Sotelo gave Jane during the last four years. Bill Benenson, Fred Benenson and Lawrence Benenson

BIJUR--Hilda Reis. Hilda Reis Bijur died peacefully December 26, surrounded by adoring family. She was born in Greenwich, CT, in 1918 and grew up in New York City, where she was valedictorian of her class at the Lincoln School. Hilda graduated from Vassar College in 1940. After working for Theatre Arts Magazine she went to Washington, D.C., to work at the Red Cross during WWII, writing for its publication. She came back to New York after the war and studied photography with Josef Breitenbach. In 1952 she married the love of her life, Bill Bijur, and within two years they were the doting parents of Arthur and Victoria. Bill's life was cut devastatingly short in 1960 after a long illness, and Hilda carried on with the utmost grace, strength, dignity, and quiet joy. Within a week of Bill's death, she was photographing at Union Theological Seminary. In 1965 she started photographing for the World Bank. Over the next ten years she was sent to the Ivory Coast, Senegal, Spain, Portugal, Turkey, Malta, Jamaica, Mexico, Trinidad, Morocco, and Israel to photograph World Bank projects. She also served proudly as president of the Cosmopolitan Club. She was the most devoted, supportive, and loving mother, a rock of Gibralter not just to her children but also to her extended family and her friends. Since 1973 she had spent summers at a beloved house on Martha's Vineyard, where she celebrated her 95th birthday in August. She is survived by her children, Arthur and Victoria, her son-in-law, Ed Levine, and two magnificent grandsons, William Levine and Benjamin Bijur.

DALTON--Dorothy, 76, of Riverdale, NY passed away peacefully on January 1 at the Hebrew Home at Riverdale following a long illness. Beloved wife of Alfred, and devoted mother to Mark and Rachel Dalton and Laura and Steven Burman. Loving grandmother of Lloyd, Ross, Faith, Marlowe, Wesley and Harry. Donations may be made to the Hebrew Home: development@hebrew home.org.

BINGER--Bronson, 1930-2013. Bronson Binger, a fifth-generation New Yorker and preservation architect, whose lifetime of work significantly improved the architectural integrity and beauty of the city, died from complications of kidney failure on December 23rd, 2013, at his daughter's home in Housatonic, MA. He was 83 and had been ill for several months. Mr. Binger, who grew up on East 75th Street, attended the Buckley School, Phillips Exeter Academy, Harvard College and Carnegie Mellon. He was perhaps best known for the restoration of Union Square during the first Koch administration, while working as Director of Capital Projects for the city's Parks Department. He also headed up the design teams and architectural consultants who restored Central Park from 1978 until he resigned in 1985. Working with Elizabeth Barlow Rogers, the first Central Park Administrator, his team completely restored Bethesda Terrace, Sheep's Meadow, the Dairy and many other major structures of the Park. He is survived by his sister, Frances Mitchell, his companion, Ann Gaffney, his first wife, Susan Binger, his second wife, Julie Wang, his three children, Lucie Spieler, Sarah B. James and Walter D. Binger, two stepchildren, Timothy Wang and Katharine Wang, five grandchildren and one great-grandchild. A memorial service will be held at Grace Church, Brooklyn Heights, at 11am on January 11, 2014. In lieu of flowers, his family requests donations in his memory to one of the organizations he supported-- Forestdale (www.forestdaleinc.org), the Phillips Exeter Academy (www.exeter.edu), Grace Church (www.gracebrooklyn.org)--or a charity of your choice.

CHRYSTIE--Thomas Ludlow, Thomas Ludlow Chrystie II, 80, died on December 24, 2013 in Charleston, South Carolina. Born in New York City, he was the son of Thomas Witter Chrystie and Helen Duell Chrystie. He graduated from the Taft School in 1951 and Columbia University, Phi Beta Kappa, in 1955. He served in the US Air Force from 1956 to 1958 as a management analysis officer. In 1960, he received an MBA, Beta Gamma Sigma, from New York University. Tom had a distinguished 33-year career with Merrill Lynch & Co. He served in various investment banking and management capacities from 1955 to 1988, when he retired to live in Jackson Hole, Wyoming. At Merrill Lynch, he headed the investment banking division, real estate, capital markets and merchant banking activities, each of which he helped build. Under Tom Chrystie's leadership, Merrill Lynch for the first time achieved the number one ranking as a manager of corporate financings and municipal financings and became a major factor in merger and acquisition services. After Merrill Lynch went public, Tom served as its first Chief Financial Officer with additional responsibility for planning and development. In that capacity, he conceived and directed the development of Merrill Lynch's Cash Management Account. In addition to serving on many corporate boards, Mr. Chrystie was a Trustee and Trustee Emeritus of Columbia University and Columbia Presbyterian Hospital. He served on the boards of the Taft School, The American Health Foundation and The Middleton Place Foundation. In Jackson Hole, he was a founding Trustee of the National Museum of Wildlife Art. As principal owner of Spring Creek Ranch, he was instrumental in attracting the first Aman Resort to North America. Tom Chrystie is survived by his wife Eliza and children: Alice C. Wyman (Peter), Helen C. Hipp (Walter), Adden Balis Chrystie and James MacDougal Chrystie. He was preceded in death by his son Thomas Witter Chrystie and his sister Mabel Dennison. He is survived by five grandchildren: Eliza K. Chadwick, Raymond G. Chadwick, Peter Hunt Wyman Jr., Henry Trumbull Wyman and John Ludlow Wyman. Memorial services will be private. Memorial gifts in Tom's honor may be given to Columbia University's Frontier Fund.

DWORKIN--Ruth G.,age 89, born in Brooklyn, NY, died on Friday, January 3, 2014, after bravely fighting cancer for five years. Ruth was predeceased by her husband, Lawrence, and their daughter Susan Levering. She is survived by her daughter Nancy D. Miller (Jerry Miller), son Greg (Denise Kaiser), son-in-law Les Baltimore, and grandchildren Lisa and Geordana Weber, Beth and Sam Baltimore, and Larry and Stephen Dworkin. Ruth's contributions and awards for her work in the labor movement spanned over five decades, as a Yonkers teacher in PS 32, Yonkers Federation of Teachers Building Rep, Elementary Vice President, the first YFT Staff Director, Grievance Co-Chair, President of Retiree Council 15-16, NYSUT Board Member and the YFT and the Westchester/Putnam Retirees newsletter editor. Ruth is remembered for fierce contract negotiating and for cultivating union leaders through her mentorship. Ruth adored travel, Broadway theater, the ballet, her family and union friends. Our hearts swell with grief, pride and love for our beautiful matriarch. Services will be held at 12:30pm on Sunday, January 5, 2014 at Zion Memorial Chapel, 785 E. Boston Post Road, Mamaroneck, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to: VISIONS/Services for the Blind and Visually Impaired, the Susan Levering Social Justice Endowment at Adelphi University, or the American Lung Association.

ALLEN--Silvia G.,died peacefully on December 31. Loving wife of the late Alton K. Allen (founder of A.K. Allen Corp. and Allenair Products). Devoted mother of Harvey and Lois. Dear mother-in-law of Donna. Dear sister-in-law of Rosalind Perlman. Beloved aunt of many nieces and nephews. Friend and mentor to many of all generations. Services at "Riverside-Nassau North Chapels," 55 North Station Plaza (opposite the LIRR), Great Neck, NY. Call for information regarding services, 516-487-9600.

NORTON--Robert William, 61, from Delray Beach, Florida and Beach Haven, New Jersey died tragically on December 31, 2013 in Delray Beach in a motorcycle accident. Bob was born on August 20, 1952 in Hackensack, New Jersey. He spent his childhood in Bogota, NJ. He lived in Summit, Basking Ridge and New Providence, New Jersey before settling in Delray Beach, Florida and Beach Haven, New Jersey. In all walks of life, Bob was a deeply humble and caring man. His genuine compassion towards others, overflowing generosity, and unequivocal love for life were the hallmarks of his interactions with the family, friends, colleagues, and community that he cherished. He was a gifted leader due to his integrity and honesty. He was a devoted and honest husband and friend. Most important to Bob were his wife and their many dear friends and family. He had a passion for Harley Davidsons and old American cars which was evident through their meticulous care. Bob loved boating and fishing, golf, and traveling for pleasure. He had a strong interest in politics. Bob was a graduate from Montclair State University and received his MBA from Seton Hall University. Most recently Bob was Executive Vice President of Smith Graham since March, 2009. He was managing director, head of marketing at Ark Asset Management from 1984-2009. He was at Lehman Bros. Management from 1984-1989. Bob will be missed by his wife Karen Norton, formerly Karen Pontier Gray. He also leaves behind a sister and brother-in-law, Janice and David Lefebvre of W. Milford, New Jersey, a niece and nephew, Julie Tomarro and her son Joey Tomarro of Greenwood Lake, NY and Mike Lefebvre and his wife Cindy of Yonkers, NY. A step-daughter, Lauren Gray from Jersey City, NJ. He also leaves behind his mother-in-law, Ruth Pontier, Manchester, NJ, brother and sister-in-law, Scott and Meral Pontier from Branchburg, NJ and sister and brother-in-law, Donna and Jim Kymer from Bedminster, NJ along with many nieces and nephews who include Ryan, Tyler, Luke, Justin, Katie, Emily, Jake and Aubree. A service will be held on Saturday, January 11, 2014 at the Hilton in Short Hills, NJ at 1pm. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Leukemia and Lymphoma Society, Donor Services, PO Box 4072 Pittsfield, MA 01202 or The Mikva Challenge Foundation, 332 S. Michigan Avenue, Ste 400, Chicago, Illinois 60604.

SNIDER--Arnold, We are devastated at the untimely loss of a visionary philanthropist who forever changed our institution, our lives and the lives of lupus patients. Together with his wife Katherine, and in honor of her mother, Arnie created and supported the Mary Kirkland Center for Lupus Research at Hospital for Special Surgery to expand the understanding of lupus, develop new treatments and improve the lives of patients with lupus. They also established the Kirkland Scholar Program, to advance innovative and collaborative lupus research throughout the country. The impact of Arnie's brilliance, wisdom and generosity will endure through the advances in the care of lupus patients that he made possible. Most of all, we will miss his friendship and mentorship. Our sincere condolences go to Kit, Sarah, Ned and the extended Snider family. Peggy Crow, MD Physician-in-Chief; Co-Director, Mary Kirkland Center for Lupus Research Michael D. Lockshin, MD Stephen A. Paget, MD Jane E. Salmon, MD Co-Directors, Mary Kirkland Center for Lupus Research Steven R. Goldring, MD Chief Scientific Officer Thomas P. Sculco, MD Surgeon-in-Chief Louis A. Shapiro, President and CEO Hospital for Special Surgery

SALTZMAN--Arnold A.,Businessman, art collector, diplomat and beloved husband, father, grandfather, and great-grandfather. Died peacefully at home with his family in Sands Point, NY, January 2, 2014. To no one's surprise, he was at work in his Manhattan office until a few weeks ago. Born October 1, 1916, in New York City of immigrant parents, Isidore and Dora. Brother of Muriel and Ruth. Runner-up in a citywide grade school oratory contest, and upward from there. His principal at Brooklyn's Samuel J. Tilden High School recommended him to Columbia College, certain he "would be a credit to his race." Columbia opened the world to 16-year-old Arnold. President of his fraternity, tennis team member, a debater, economics and government major, with a single class in art history these formed four great passions of Arnold's life: business, government service, arguing, and collecting art. The fifth was family, starting with a sales call for his family's sweater company (Premier Knitting) to Abraham & Straus, where a beautiful young woman, Joan Roth, caught his eye and accepted his invitation for lunch (although she'd just eaten). Joan's mother learned that evening "I just met the man I'm going to marry." Married November 21, 1942, in a rabbi's study on West 88th Street, then off to a three-hour honeymoon on the train to Washington, DC, where Arnold worked on military procurement. During the war, Arnold served as Lieutenant J.G. in the US Coast Guard. Sons Robert and Eric were born in 1945 and 1947 and daughter Marian (Mimi) in 1951. Arnold merged Premier Knitting with Botany Industries, then became CEO of Seagrave Corp. (a NYSE company, later Vista Resources), which made Seagrave fire engines, paint, leather, glass and architectural window walls. He maintained a devotion to public service, during the Korean War, working for the Office of Price Administration, and later with USAID and advising the Office of Economic Opportunity, and Sargent Shriver's new Peace Corps (and giving a Seagrave fire engine to Adis Ababa). Arnold undertook diplomatic assignments for Presidents Kennedy and Johnson. In 1967, he marched in a Washington, DC demonstration holding his hand-made sign, "Businessmen Against the Vietnam War". In 1968, he received a Presidential Commendation for his work on the Atomic Weapons Non-proliferation Treaty. He was a close friend and senior adviser to Senator Hubert Humphrey during his run for President, and was chairman of the National Committee on American Foreign Policy and worked on US relations with the USSR, and later with the new republics after it broke up. Reciprocating at Columbia College, Arnold served as chairman of the Board of Trustees. He established the much-admired Double Discovery program, pairing college and Harlem students. He received the Columbia University Medal, and the Institute for War and Peace Studies, founded by President Eisenhower, was later named for Arnold. Grateful for his own opportunity, Arnold has given scores of scholarships both through university programs, and directly to young people eager to learn and in need of a financial leg up. At the 2012 Columbia College commencement, he walked behind the Class of 1936 banner, its sole representative, to the cheers of the new graduates. That art history class kindled a lifelong love of art. Arnold collected throughout his life, astutely studying and chasing paintings and sculpture -- in New York and Europe, at artists' studios, auction houses and art dealers buying, trading, and selling. He made a major gift, of his German Expressionist paintings, to the National Gallery of Art in Washington. He assumed direction and revitalized the Nassau County Museum of Fine Arts. He was a Trustee of the Baltimore Museum of Art. He and Joan established the Joan and Arnold Saltzman Center for Community Services at Hofstra University, and a group home in Glen Cove, NY, with the YAI Network. Arnold was a Trustee of North Shore University Hospital and Maimonides Hospital and a major donor to the New York Public Library. He was awarded honorary doctorates from Hofstra and Adelphi Universities. He adored his five grandchildren -- Xylon Saltzman; Chloe Saltzman, Gabriel Saltzman; Ian Gottschalk; Michael Saltzman; and two great-grandchildren, Theo and Saskia Saltzman and they loved and admired him often expressed with anecdotes and insightful "Pop" imitations. He was devoted to his granddaughter, Chloe, who was born with disabilities. Arnold was like a father to his nephew and nieces, Rick Salwen, Laura Salwen, Barbara Dash and Muriel Wolf. The love of Arnold's life was, and remained to his last day, his remarkable wife, Joan, who survives him. Everyone recognized this, as in this toast at his 80th birthday, "To the best thing about Arnold -- Joan." To which Arnold promptly assented. Services will be at Temple Beth-El, 5 Old Mill Road, Great Neck, New York, 11:30am Monday, January 6. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Joan and Arnold Saltzman Center for Community Services at Hofstra University.

SINGER--Howard A.,died peacefully at home in Rye, NY, December 22. An attorney who specialized in entertainment, arts and corporate law, he pursued many creative personal and professional interests throughout his life. Born January 15, 1929, he grew up in Brooklyn, graduated from City College of New York and Brooklyn Law School (LLB, JD). He became a recognized authority on motion picture and theatrical law and artistic joint ventures in Eastern Europe. After military service in Army counterintelligence in the 1950s, he remained committed to military volunteer service as a member of the Veteran Corps of Artillery of New York and the New York State Guard. He is survived by his wife of 33 years, Marilyn Castaldi; brother Daniel; children Barbara and Alan; grandchildren Evan and Eleanor Peters and Kelly and Ian Singer. A memorial service will be held at 3:30pm, Wednesday, January 15, 2014 at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave. (81st St.). Contributions in his memory may be made to the Cancer Support Team, Purchase, NY 10577 or Rye Free Reading Room, Rye, NY 10580.

BLANK--Karen J.,of Manhattan, NY, passed away from complications related to cancer on December 31, 2013. Loving wife of Jim Milligan (deceased, January 2005), devoted mother of Ned Milligan, and treasured colleague, mentor, and friend to many. Karen served as Dean of Studies at Barnard College from 1993 through 2012, spending the previous decade as Associate Dean for Student Affairs at Columbia College. After graduating from the University of California-Berkeley, Karen left Albany, CA, where she was raised, to search out work in the field of higher education. This pursuit allowed her to experience and enhance student life at several colleges, ultimately bringing her to the Columbia University community of which she was proud to be a member for thirty years. In illness, Karen was cared for by her dedicated team of nurses, together with loyal friends and family. She drew love, strength and support from Ned, his wife Jamie, and the Cahill family (Barbara, Barry, Kristen, and Greg)-- relatives of Jim's who cared for Karen as one of their own. She is survived by them all, as well as her brother, Bob. Karen was always grateful for her life and to those who made it better. She will be celebrated in memoriam with a service on Thursday, January 9, 11am at West End Collegiate Church, 245 West 77th Street, New York.

vAN BEUREN--John Archbold Died on Monday, the 23rd of December in Middletown, RI. Born in New York City, in 1932, to Archbold van Beuren and Margaret Plumer Zeigler. He attended Yale University, graduating in 1954, and subsequently served in the United States Army Counter Intelligence Corp. Following his military service, he earned an MBA from Columbia University, and pursued a successful career in private equity and investment management. In 1972, inspired by a lifelong passion for architecture, he enrolled in the University of Pennsylvania and received his Masters in Architecture. He will be remembered most notably for his extraordinary philanthropic vision, humble spirit, and charitable gestures for which he sought no accolades. His enduring contributions and community leadership are best described by his dedication to the public and private institutions of Rhode Island. He served on the Board of Directors of Fleet Bank, the Naval War College Foundation, St. George's School, was a Governor, Trustee and Chair of the Investments Committee for Newport Hospital, and a Governor of Lifespan. In 1986, with his wife Happy, he established the van Beuren Charitable Foundation. Through the Foundation he put forward his vision of public service. The Foundation became the largest contributor to the Newport Hospital Foundation; the driving force behind the creation of the Trinity Landmark Preservation Fund; an initial investor in the Aquidneck Land Trust; and funder of the Chair of Asia-Pacific Studies at the Naval War College. His lifelong love for architecture was demonstrated by his support of all Newport's historic buildings and sites. In 2013, in recognition of his untiring dedication to serving his community and his country, he was presented with the Navy Meritorious Public Service Award by Admiral Jonathan Greenert, United States Chief of Naval Operations. Beyond his civic commitments, his leisure activities were informed by his love of the outdoors, and his intellectual curiosity. He was an avid sportsman, particularly in fly-fishing, field shooting, and golf; an ardent consumer of history and current events; and a lover of dogs. Most recently, he chose to spend time in Boca Grande, FL. Beloved husband, brother, father, grandfather, Archie van Beuren is survived by his wife Happy; his sister, Marilla van Beuren; his three children, Barbara van Beuren, Archbold Dorrance van Beuren, and Andrea van Beuren; his grandchildren, Alexander Hill Glascock, Adrianne Glascock, Archbold Victor van Beuren, Andrew Hill van Beuren, Ainsley Dorrance Kass, Fiona Sarah Kass, and Lucian Evan Kass. A memorial service will be held on Friday, January 10 at 11am, St. George's School Chapel, Middletown, RI. Donations in his memory may be made to the Naval War College Foundation; 686 Cushing Road, Newport, RI, 02840, attn: John Odegaard and the Newport Hospital Foundation, 11 Friendship Street, Newport, RI, 02840, attn: Lianne Pinheiro.
PETSCHEK--Charles I. One year without you but always remembered and always loved. You were a special husband, father, grandfather and friend . Forever in our hearts. Elaine and your whole family

WEYERHAEUSER--Elizabeth "Betsy" Fairman 52, of Wayzata, Minnesota passed away on December 31, 2013 with loving members of her family gathered around her after a courageous battle with cancer. Born Elizabeth Jane Fairman in New York City, Betsy attended the Spence School before moving with her family to Locust Valley, Long Island. She graduated from the Green Vale School; cum laude from St. Paul's School and magna cum laude from Harvard. Thereafter she received an MBA from the Harvard Business School. While subsequently working as a partner at McKinsey & Company, she was introduced to David Weyerhaeuser by a cousin of David's. They were married in 1999. Prior to her 13 years at McKinsey, Betsy's career included two years as a buyer with Bloomingdale's and five years with Procter & Gamble as a Brand Manager. She served on the boards of the Minneapolis Institute of Arts, the Minnesota Zoo Foundation, and Rock Island Company. She was an avid tennis player, golfer, reader, chef and traveler but her greatest creativity and commitment were devoted to raising her three children, for whom she retired from her business career. Betsy is survived by her husband, David; her children, Blake, Jackie, and Charlie; her father, Joel Fairman; her brother, David Fairman (Juliette Zener); and her sister, Helen Fairman. She is preceded in passing by her mother, Claire Martin Fairman. Betsy's strength, determination, quick wit, positive spirit, and commitment to family made a lasting impact on the many people she touched throughout her life. A memorial service to celebrate her life will be held on Thursday, January 16, at 4:00pm at Wayzata Community Church, 125 Wayzata Blvd. East, Wayzata, Minnesota. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to the Minneapolis Institute of Arts, 2400 3rd Avenue South, Minneapolis, MN 55404 or Learning Works at Blake, The Blake School, 110 Blake Road South, Hopkins, MN 55343.

ULRICH--Ernest, died November 26, 2013. Born a Jew in Nazi Germany, Ernest immigrated to the United States at age 12, and graduated from NYU. He ran an international export company and upon retirement found his other true calling volunteering for Human Rights Watch and Big Apple Greeters. Ernest helped conceive and launch HRW Berlin and in 2005 was awarded the Theodor Heuss Prize for civil courage and initiative on behalf of HRW by the President of Germany. Ernest was a quiet hero. He saw people as human beings first, crossing ethnic, religious, racial and economic boundaries in the name of friendship. A devoted family man, Ernest is survived by his wife of 53 years, Margit, his daughters Lisa and Nancy, his son-in-laws Seth and Micheal, his grandsons Adin and Lucas, his brother and sister-in-law Werner and Ursula, and countless relatives, friends and co-workers. Donations can be made in his name to the Global Internship Program at Human Rights Watch, 350 Fifth Avenue, New York, NY 10118 or to City Year; attn. Jeremy Cramer, City Year HQ, 287 Columbus Avenue Boston, MA 02116.

SHAPIRO--Joseph G. The Hofstra community is deeply saddened by the passing of Joseph G. Shapiro, Class of 1954, a devoted friend and benefactor who was awarded the University's Alumnus of the Year Award in September 2013. Mr. Shapiro and his wife, Libby (also Class of 1954), established the Libby and Joseph Shapiro Endowed Distinguished Academic Scholarship and the Eva and Benjamin Shapiro Memorial Scholarship at Hofstra University. They also created the Joseph and Libby Shapiro Family Foundation, which generously donates to educational, religious, health, and civic institutions and organizations. Mr. Shapiro served as co-chair of Hofstra's 2004 Gala Ball honoring Monsignor Thomas Hartman, which was successful in funding an academic chair in Catholic studies at Hofstra. Also in 2004 Hofstra dedicated the Libby and Joseph G. Shapiro Alumni House in honor of the Shapiros' loyalty and generosity to Hofstra. In 2010 Mr. Shapiro was honored at the University's 14th Annual Gala and was presented with the Hofstra University Presidential Medal of Honor. He received Hofstra's Alumni Lifetime Achievement Award and its George M. Estabrook Distinguished Service Award. Mr. Shapiro served as chairman and CEO of Commander Enterprises, a family-owned real estate investment company. He earned a BBA from Hofstra University where he was also a member of Epsilon Sigma fraternity. He served in the United States Army and saw active duty in Korea, and he held numerous business and professional affiliations during his career. These included director of Fleet Bank, Long Island Association, and Oil Heat Institute of Long Island; chairman of the Long Island Heart Council, American Heart Association, Glen Cove Zoning Board of Appeals, and New York State Joint Legislative Committee of Environmental Management of Natural Resources; board member of the Broward Sheriff's Advisory Council; and member of the Royal Knights of Chivalry for Cancer Research. To honor the memory of Mr. Shapiro, all Hofstra University flags were lowered to half-staff. Janis M. Meyer Chair, Hofstra University Board of Trustees; Stuart Rabinowitz President, Hofstra University

NORTON--Robert William, 61, from Delray Beach, Florida and Beach Haven, New Jersey died tragically on December 31, 2013 in Delray Beach in a motorcycle accident. Bob was born on August 20, 1952 in Hackensack, New Jersey. He spent his childhood in Bogota, NJ. He lived in Summit, Basking Ridge and New Providence, New Jersey before settling in Delray Beach, Florida and Beach Haven, New Jersey. In all walks of life, Bob was a deeply humble and caring man. His genuine compassion towards others, overflowing generosity, and unequivocal love for life were the hallmarks of his interactions with the family, friends, colleagues, and community that he cherished. He was a gifted leader due to his integrity and honesty. He was a devoted and honest husband and friend. Most important to Bob were his wife and their many dear friends and family. He had a passion for Harley Davidsons and old American cars which was evident through their meticulous care. Bob loved boating and fishing, golf, and traveling for pleasure. He had a strong interest in politics. Bob was a graduate from Montclair State University and received his MBA from Seton Hall University. Most recently Bob was Executive Vice President of Smith Graham since March, 2009. He was managing director, head of marketing at Ark Asset Management from 1984-2009. He was at Lehman Bros. Management from 1984-1989. Bob will be missed by his wife Karen Norton, formerly Karen Pontier Gray. He also leaves behind a sister and brother-in-law, Janice and David Lefebvre of W. Milford, New Jersey, a niece and nephew, Julie Tomarro and her son Joey Tomarro of Greenwood Lake, NY and Mike Lefebvre and his wife Cindy of Yonkers, NY. A step-daughter, Lauren Gray from Jersey City, NJ. He also leaves behind his mother-in-law, Ruth Pontier, Manchester, NJ, brother and sister-in-law, Scott and Meral Pontier from Branchburg, NJ and sister and brother-in-law, Donna and Jim Kymer from Bedminster, NJ along with many nieces and nephews who include Ryan, Tyler, Luke, Justin, Katie, Emily, Jake and Aubree. A service will be held on Saturday, January 11, 2014 at the Hilton in Short Hills, NJ at 1pm. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Leukemia and Lymphoma Society, Donor Services, PO Box 4072 Pittsfield, MA 01202 or The Mikva Challenge Foundation, 332 S. Michigan Avenue, Ste 400, Chicago, Illinois 60604.

TEPPER--Norman, on January 5, 2014. Beloved husband of the late Barbara. Loving father of Larry, and Harold and Nancy. Cherished grandfather of Adam, Haley, David and Stephanie, Brian and Elana, and Robby. Services were held.

MATTSON--Robert N.,76, of Manhattan and Chappaqua, NY, died on January 5, 2014, surrounded by his family. Bob Mattson was a sweet and loving man who knew the value of a well-timed tease or joke. He was born in 1937 in New Albany, Indiana, to Ruth and Herbert Mattson, and grew up in Louisville, Kentucky. He received a BS in Economics from the University of Pennsylvania Wharton School in 1958. He later earned a JD from Fordham University and an LLM from New York University Law School. He married his wife Diana in Manhattan in 1964. Bob was employed at IBM for more than 30 years and retired as an assistant treasurer and the Chief Tax Officer in 1998. Following that, he joined Deloitte & Touche, specializing in international tax transactions for corporate clients, before retiring again in June 2002. When his children were young, Bob served on the Chappaqua School Board. Later he volunteered for several non-profit organizations that work with families and children involved in the criminal justice system. Since 2005 he served as Financial Advisor for Hour Children, a non-profit that provides a wide range of services to formerly incarcerated women and their children. He also served on the Board of Trustees for Greenburgh Eleven Union Free School District, which provides education for children residing on Children's Village Dobbs Ferry campus. His favorite activities were reading, gardening, and playing golf and bridge. He is remembered with love by a large circle of family and dear friends, including members of his beloved chavurah, his college fraternity, and his golf buddies. He is survived by his wife, Diana, of Manhattan; their son, Geoffrey, of Manhattan; and their daughter, Rachel, of Brooklyn, as well as by his daughter Kathy Zoeller and his siblings, Gloria Reese, Patricia Beiler, and David Mattson. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to his favorite charities, Hour Children's Hour Working Women Program (36-11 12th Street, Long Island City, NY 11106) and the Central Park Conservancy (14 E. 60th St, New York, NY, 10022).

SALTZMAN--Amb. Arnold A. The Hofstra community is deeply saddened by the passing of Trustee Emeritus Arnold A. Saltzman on January 2, 2014. A noted businessman and diplomat, Ambassador Saltzman served five American presidents in a wide range of policy-level diplomatic and economic assignments; he received a Presidential Commendation for his efforts on the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty. Ambassador Saltzman carried out diplomatic assignments in the former Czechoslovakia, the former Soviet Union, South America, Central America, and Austria. He and his wife, Joan, have a long history with Hofstra University, as benefactors and trusted advisors. Ambassador Saltzman served on Hofstra's Board of Trustees from April 1987 until October 1994, and he was elected Trustee Emeritus in October 1994. He was awarded an honorary doctorate from Hofstra in 1986. In 1991 Ambassador and Mrs. Saltzman founded the Joan and Arnold Saltzman Community Services Center, a multidisciplinary clinical service center that provides low-cost, cutting-edge therapies to the public and unique research and training opportunities to students. The Saltzman Center unites the talents and capabilities of separate organizations at the University the Diane Lindner-Goldberg Child Care Institute; Marriage and Family Therapy Clinic; Psychological Evaluation, Research and Counseling Clinic; Reading/Writing Learning Clinic; and Speech-Language-Hearing Clinic. The Saltzman Center was one of the first facilities of its kind and stands as a tribute to the Saltzmans' commitment to public service and the advancement of higher education. Ambassador Saltzman also conceived of and funded Hofstra's State of the Union Lecture, which has presented distinguished speakers, such as Donna Brazile, Howard Dean, David Gergen and George Mitchell, to discuss America's political landscape. To honor the memory of Ambassador Saltzman, all Hofstra University flags were lowered to half-staff. Janis M. Meyer Chair, Hofstra University Board of Trustees; Stuart Rabinowitz President, Hofstra University

SEMEL--Vera, 88, passed away on January 5th. Beloved wife of Abraham for 64 years, loving mother to Susan Burris (David), adoring grandmother to Rachel and Sarah. We will always love her, and miss her kindness, generosity and wisdom. She will be sorely missed by all whose lives she touched. Services Wednesday, January 8th at 12:45 at "The Riverside" 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

SHAPIRO--Joseph G.,81, Ft. Lauderdale, FL and Oyster Bay Cove, NY passed away on January 4th 2014, at The University of Miami Hospital. Mr. Shapiro was born on December 3, 1932 in Glen Cove, NY to Benjamin and Eva (Shorenstein) Shapiro. Joseph grew up in Glen Cove, attended Bordentown Military Institute, and graduated from Eastern Military Academy. He attended Hofstra University and served in the United States Army, where he saw active duty in Korea. Following his service, he returned to Hofstra, pledged Epsilon Sigma, and received a degree in business. Joseph met Libby Posner when they were ten and her family moved to his street in Glen Cove. They were married in 1952 and have spent over 61 years together. They were members of Congregation Tifereth Israel in Glen Cove and both Mr. Shapiro and his father were President and generous supporters of the oldest Synagogue on Long Island. Mr. Shapiro began work at age 12 for Commander Oil Corp, the company his father, Benjamin, founded in 1929. He never retired from business and, at the time of his death, was the Chairman and CEO of Commander Enterprises, President and CEO of Commander Oil Corp., Co-Chairman of TXX Services, and a Partner in Kennesaw Fruit & Juice Company. Mr. Shapiro held numerous Board and professional affiliations amongst which were Fleet Bank, Oil Heat Institute of Long Island, LIA, Glen Cove Zoning Board of Appeals, New York State Joint Legislative Committee of Environmental Management of Natural Resources, New York State Boating Council, North Shore University Hospital, Congregation Tifereth Israel of Glen Cove, and the Broward Sheriffs Advisory Council. Mr. and Mrs. Shapiro devoted the majority of their philanthropic efforts to benefit their Alma Mater, Hofstra University. Mr Shapiro was honored numerous times by Hofstra University with their Alumni Lifetime Achievement Award, Estabrook Award, and Presidential Medal of Honor. The Libby and Joseph G. Shapiro Alumni House at Hofstra was dedicated in 2004, and also the Libby and Joseph Shapiro Endowed Distinguished Academic Scholarship, Libby and Joseph Shapiro Endowed Scholarship at The School of Medicine and the Eva and Benjamin Shapiro Memorial Scholarship were established at the University. In addition, the Joseph and Libby Shapiro Family Foundation generously donates to educational, religious, health and civic institutions and organizations. Over his lifetime, Mr. Shapiro enjoyed golf, cars, sports, traveling and all types of boating. He loved to be at sea and spent considerable time yachting from Maine to the Bahamas. He was a member of the 32 degree Masons, Shriners International, Huntington Yacht Club, Coral Ridge Yacht Club, Coral Ridge Country Club, Cold Spring Country Club and the Ocean Reef Club. He loved his Country and wore an American Flag on his lapel every day. Joseph is survived by his beloved wife, Libby and their four children and their spouses: Leonard (Caryl) Shapiro, Carol (Jeffrey) Engel, Beth (Warren) Bromberg, and Susan Volk. He was known as Papa Joe or Pop-Pop, loved his grandchildren: Benjamin and Eve Shapiro, Blake and Grant Engel, Erica and Melissa Bromberg, and Jennifer Volk. A memorial service will be held at Congregation Tifereth Israel, 40 Hill Street Glen Cove, New York at 1pm on January 8th, burial will follow. In lieu of flowers, the family requests memorial donations be made to Hofstra University School of Medicine.

SALTZMAN--Arnold A. '36CC. Columbia College and Columbia School of International and Public Affairs mourn the passing of Ambassador Arnold A. Saltzman '36CC, whose vision and philanthropy will continue to have a lasting impact on our lives and so many others. As a Columbia alumnus, Ambassador Saltzman was awarded the University Medal and chaired the Columbia College Board of Overseers, the Columbia College Fund, and the John Jay Associates, among other roles. He helped to establish the first Dean's advisory board for the School of International and Public Affairs. He also co-founded the Double Discovery program, which partners Columbia undergraduates with low-income Manhattan-area youth to ensure high school graduation, college enrollment, and completion. While President of Columbia University, Dwight D. Eisenhower created The Institute of War and Peace Studies in 1951. To honor Ambassador Saltzman's vast contributions to the University, and in recognition of his longstanding career in American foreign policy, the Institute was re-named The Arnold A. Saltzman Institute of War and Peace Studies in 2003, and is devoted to the study of the causes, conduct, and consequences of war and peaceful alternatives to the use of force in international politics. It is housed in Columbia's School of International and Public Affairs. Ambassador Saltzman's deep commitment to Columbia University will continue in perpetuity through the Saltzman Institute, through scores of scholarships to deserving students, and through the two professorships endowed in his name at the School of International and Public Affairs: the Arnold A. Saltzman Professor of War and Peace Studies and the Professor of Professional Practice in International and Public Affairs. We extend our deepest sympathy to the entire Saltzman family, especially his wife, Joan; and their three children, Robert '67CC, Eric '69CC, and Mimi. James J. Valentini Dean of Columbia College and Vice President for Undergraduate Education; Merit E. Janow Dean of Columbia School of International and Public Affairs

LESE--John Henry, January 5, 2014 at 85. Loving husband of Linda (Shain) for 56 years; proud father of Jon, Andrew, and Carolyn (Goldberg); father-in-law to Debbie, Susan and Steven; and grandfather to Michael, Katie, Rachel, Jordan and Jack. Predeceased by his brother William. Graduate of Loomis Chaffee and New York University. A General's aide in the National Guard. A real estate developer of quality homes and apartments. His joy was spending time with family and friends and his zest for life showed through a wonderful sense of humor and optimistic outlook. Services at 1pm, Wednesday, January 8, Congregation Emanuel, 2125 Westchester Ave, Rye, NY. Memorial donations may be made to the "In Praise of Merit Scholarship Fund" at SUNY Purchase.

GLADSTONE--Morton, Died on January 3rd at age 91 after leading a rich and full life. He leaves his cherished wife, Gertrude Karp Gladstone. He was the loving father of Daniel, Brett, Russell and Nina Gladstone, and adored grandfather of Matthew and Sara Gladstone, and Salomon and Jessica Burstein, and beloved brother to Julian Gladstone. Formerly married to the late Phyllis Gladstone of Bay Harbor, Florida. Morton was the son of Rhoda Gladstone, a prominent dressmaker and Milton Gladstone, a New York lawyer. Born in New York, Morton was a graduate of the University of Pennsylvania, an Air Force captain in World War II, President of Sales Direction, and a leading activist for the World Federalists. Funeral will be held Wednesday, January 8th at 1:45pm at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel at 1076 Madison Avenue, NY, and burial at Mount Hebron Cemetery in Flushing, NY. EISNER--Nathaniel, 93, passed peacefully on January 5. Beloved husband of Frances; father of Susan, Wendy, and Mark; father-in-law of Tricia; grandfather of four. Gifted mathematician, brilliant mind, and aficionado of life's many dimensions from sports to politics. His joie de vivre, courage, optimism, smile, and dedication to family remain inspirational. He defied the odds through sheer determination to live life to its fullest and best. He epitomized "The Impossible Dream," and shall be deeply missed. Graveside services January 9 at Sharon Gardens. Contributions in his memory may be made to www.childrenshealthfund.org.

GLADSTONE--Morton. We note with sorrow the passing of our member Morton Gladstone and extend sincerest condolences to his bereaved family. Rabbi Peter J. Rubinstein President, David B. Edelson Central Synagogue of New York City

GLANZ--Marcy. Marcy's book-loving, bridge-playing friends mourn her loss and express their deepest sympathy to Marion and family. Her TBC sisters will miss her kindness, creativity, intellect, good humor and all-embracing love.

COHEN--Herbert I.,M.D., on January 6, 2014. WWII and Korean War veteran. Pediatrician in Rochester, NY for five years then in NYC as an allergist for 41 years. A gay activist in NYC and the Hamptons where he co-chaired East End Gay Organization for three years, executive board member of SAGE. Survived by Daniel C. Cook, beloved partner for 52 years and spouse for four years. Also survived by his sister-in-law Amy Scheuer Cohen, eight nieces and nephews, and 18 greatnieces and greatnephews. COWLAN--Richard, 78, passed away at his home in Fort Lee, NJ on January 3rd. Richard was born in New York City on March 16, 1935 to Louis and Sylvia (Virshup) Cohen and raised in the Bronx. He graduated from CCUNY and Bernard Baruch College, majoring in accounting as a prelude to his lifelong passion for numbers. He was a veteran of the U.S. Army. He achieved his greatest success in the travel industry, serving as CFO of Liberty Travel while contributing innovative programs and ideas that fueled its explosive growth from 1974 through his retirement in 2001. Richard is survived by his devoted wife Joan, his son Lawrence, his daughter Sara and son-in-law Scott, and his grandchildren Gabriella, Lewis and Tess. Donations in Richard's memory can be made to The COPD Foundation, c/o Dr. Byron Thomashow, Columbia University, 161 Ft. Washington Ave., New York, NY 10032.

BARTRAM--J. Burr, Jr.,died peacefully on December 24, 2013 at the age of 79. Survived by wife Barbara Hart Bartram, and sister Nina Bartram Griswold. Son of J. Burr Bartram and Mary (Sheppard) Bartram (Deceased). Born in NYC July 12, 1934. He attended Choate School in Wallingford, CT. He served in the US Navy from 19531955. An active member and Trustee of Indian Harbor Yacht Club, while residing in Greenwich, CT until 1976. Joe resided in Marion, MA. From 1976-1996. He was a resident of Middletown, RI from 19962001. In 2001, he relocated to Fort Lauderdale, FL. Member of the New York Yacht Club since 1955, where he served on the Race, House and Membership committees. Co-manager of the 1974 COURAGEOUS Syndicate, which successfully defended the America's Cup. He was a NYYC Trustee from 1994-1997. Joe started his yacht brokerage career with Northrop and Johnson, where he attained the position of Vice President and General Manager of the Stamford, CT office. In 1997, with his late partner Bruce R. Brakenhoff, the yacht brokerage firm of Bartram & Brakenhoff was formed, in Greenwich, CT. Between 1980 and 1985 a second office opened in Newport, Rhode Island. This location became the principal office, and the Connecticut office was closed. Bartram & Brakenhoff was sold in 1998, and Joe continued to work with his clients and the company until shortly before his death. In lieu of flowers, cash contributions are encouraged to the Carpenters Boat Shop, 440 Old County Road, Pemaquid, ME 04558. Attn: Robert Ives or Lahey Clinic, 41 Mall Road, Burlington, MA 01805. A Memorial Service will be held in Ft. Lauderdale, Florida, and an additional Service in Greenwich, CT. Dates to be announced later.

DALTON--Dorothy, 76, of Riverdale, NY passed away peacefully on January 1 at the Hebrew Home at Riverdale following a long illness. BECKENSTEIN--Brenda M.,of Jupiter, FL and Woodcliff Lake, NJ on January 5th, 2014. Beloved wife of Martin. Devoted mother of Jill Lerner (Gary) and Kim Fiedler (Bryan). Dear sister of Charles Debrover (Patricia). Cherished grandmother of Amanda and Corey Lerner, Dylan and Halle Fiedler. Funeral service will be 1:15pm today at the Sanctuary of Abraham and Sarah, Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ. www.guttermanandmusicant. com. She will be loved and missed.

BARD--Henry H.,MD, died suddenly on January 3rd at the age of 91. He is survived by his widow, Lucie Taft Bard, of Locust Valley and his daughter, Holly Bard of Camas, WA. He is predeceased by his sons Bruce and Douglas Bard. He was the son of Alberta Loppacker Bard and Dr. Henry Bard of Pittsfield, MA. Dr. Bard graduated from Berkshire Academy, Princeton University and Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons. He served in the Army briefly during World War II and later as a Navy Medical Officer during the Korean War. After training in New York, he spent his career as a General Surgeon at the Glen Cove Hospital. Upon retirement he found pleasure in gardening, reading, croquet, bridge, walking his dog Rufus and many cruises to far-away places. He was a kind, generous man with a good sense of humor who will be sorely missed by all who knew him. Funeral services will be held at St. John's Church, Cold Spring Harbor on Friday, January 10th at 11am. In lieu of flowers, a donation may be made to Berkshire School, 245 Undermountian Road, Sheffield, MA 01257.

SILLECK--Katherine Wallace. Kathy passed away peacefully at her long-time home on the Upper East Side of Manhattan on January 5, 2014 after a courageous battle with pancreatic cancer. She was 72. Kathy was born in White Plains, NY, and grew up in Hartsdale, Bronxville, and Scarsdale, attending local public schools. She enjoyed spending her summers at the family beach house on Peconic Bay at Kimogenor Point, New Suffolk, L.I. Kathy graduated from St. Mary's School in Garden City, L.I., attended Centenary College for two years, and graduated from Cedar Crest College in 1964. After brief employment with First National City Bank and Chemical Bank, Kathy turned to her true calling the teaching of young children. She began her career at All Souls Day School and then accepted a position on the faculty of the Heavenly Rest Day School, later known as the Trevor Day School, from which she retired after a career of over 30 years. Kathy taught hundreds of kindergarten and pre-K children, many of whom came back as adults to see their beloved "Miss Silleck." Kathy was greatly admired by the parents of her students, who appreciated her unfailing dedication, patience, kindness, and good humor. In retirement, Kathy demonstrated an entrepreneurial flair, matching her many friends with the right clothing and accessories. She is survived by her loving brothers Bayley, Gordon, and Tom. Kathy will be greatly missed by all her family and friends. A memorial service, interment, and reception will be held at the Episcopal Church of St. James the Less, Scarsdale, NY, at 11am on January 18, 2014. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests donations to The Lustgarten Foundation for pancreatic cancer research: www.lustgarten.org

SHAW--Gloria Mauriell, 89, died peacefully at home in Rye, NY on January 4, 2014. Widow of Russell C. Shaw. Survived by loving daughters Nancy Dempsey (Guy) and Karen Stubbs (Monte) and beloved grandchildren Katie, Elizabeth and Laura Dempsey and Emily, Sarah and Teddy Stubbs. Funeral at Christ's Church, Rye on Friday, January 10, 2pm. Memorial contributions to Yale University.

STRONG--George Hotham, of Locust, NJ died Sunday, January 5, as a result of cardiac arrest at the age of 87. Born in 1926, he was the son of George Hite Strong and Mary Elizabeth Hotham Strong. George served in the United States Army in Italy during WWII. He graduated from Allegheny College in 1949 Magna cum Laude, Salutatorian, and Phi Beta Kappa. He earned his MBA in Finance from Harvard Business School in 1951. His career as a financial and health care executive included Vice President at Smith, Barney & Co. and Vice President & Chief Financial Officer with The Norlin Corporation, American Medicorp and Universal Health Services. This was followed by twenty years as a venture capital investor. He served on the boards of over a dozen companies, primarily in the health care industry. He is known as one of the health care industry's leading specialists in the area of finance. He has been instrumental in building a number of major healthcare service businesses, including hospital chains. He was active in Harvard Business School alumnae affairs for over fifty years, including serving as Chairman of the Special Gifts Committee. He was an avid reader with many intellectual interests, and had a gift for occasional poetry. George is survived by his wife of sixty years, Mary Lou Lyon Strong; three children: Cynthia Strong Hibbard of Cambridge, MA, Dexter Strong of Providence, RI, and Sarah Strong Bornstein of Danvers, MA; and six grandchildren. Two sisters, Marjorie Schaeffer and Rebecca Auman, both of Pittsburgh, survive. A funeral service will be held at All Saints Memorial Church in Navesink, NJ at 10am on Friday, January 10th. Thompson Memorial Home in Red Bank, NJ is in charge of services. Donations, in lieu of flowers, should be sent to the American Heart Association.
GOLD--Beatrice. Jan 8, 1994 Memories of you Mother are always in our hearts. Your loving Daughter and family.

SHAPIRO--Joseph G.,81, Ft. Lauderdale, FL and Oyster Bay Cove, NY passed away on January 4th 2014, at The University of Miami Hospital. Mr. Shapiro was born on December 3, 1932 in Glen Cove, NY to Benjamin and Eva (Shorenstein) Shapiro. Joseph grew up in Glen Cove, attended Bordentown Military Institute, and graduated from Eastern Military Academy. He attended Hofstra University and served in the United States Army, where he saw active duty in Korea. Following his service, he returned to Hofstra, pledged Epsilon Sigma, and received a degree in business. Joseph met Libby Posner when they were ten and her family moved to his street in Glen Cove. They were married in 1952 and have spent over 61 years together. They were members of Congregation Tifereth Israel in Glen Cove and both Mr. Shapiro and his father were President and generous supporters of the oldest Synagogue on Long Island. Mr. Shapiro began work at age 12 for Commander Oil Corp, the company his father, Benjamin, founded in 1929. He never retired from business and, at the time of his death, was the Chairman and CEO of Commander Enterprises, President and CEO of Commander Oil Corp., Co-Chairman of TXX Services, and a Partner in Kennesaw Fruit & Juice Company. Mr. Shapiro held numerous Board and professional affiliations amongst which were Fleet Bank, Oil Heat Institute of Long Island, LIA, Glen Cove Zoning Board of Appeals, New York State Joint Legislative Committee of Environmental Management of Natural Resources, New York State Boating Council, North Shore University Hospital, Congregation Tifereth Israel of Glen Cove, and the Broward Sheriffs Advisory Council. Mr. and Mrs. Shapiro devoted the majority of their philanthropic efforts to benefit their Alma Mater, Hofstra University. Mr Shapiro was honored numerous times by Hofstra University with their Alumni Lifetime Achievement Award, Estabrook Award, and Presidential Medal of Honor. The Libby and Joseph G. Shapiro Alumni House at Hofstra was dedicated in 2004, and also the Libby and Joseph Shapiro Endowed Distinguished Academic Scholarship, Libby and Joseph Shapiro Endowed Scholarship at The School of Medicine and the Eva and Benjamin Shapiro Memorial Scholarship were established at the University. In addition, the Joseph and Libby Shapiro Family Foundation generously donates to educational, religious, health and civic institutions and organizations. Over his lifetime, Mr. Shapiro enjoyed golf, cars, sports, traveling and all types of boating. He loved to be at sea and spent considerable time yachting from Maine to the Bahamas. He was a member of the 32 degree Masons, Shriners International, Huntington Yacht Club, Coral Ridge Yacht Club, Coral Ridge Country Club, Cold Spring Country Club and the Ocean Reef Club. He loved his Country and wore an American Flag on his lapel every day. Joseph is survived by his beloved wife, Libby and their four children and their spouses: Leonard (Caryl) Shapiro, Carol (Jeffrey) Engel, Beth (Warren) Bromberg, and Susan Volk. He was known as Papa Joe or Pop-Pop, loved his grandchildren: Benjamin and Eve Shapiro, Blake and Grant Engel, Erica and Melissa Bromberg, and Jennifer Volk. A memorial service will be held at Congregation Tifereth Israel, 40 Hill Street Glen Cove, New York at 1pm on January 8th, burial will follow. In lieu of flowers, the family requests memorial donations be made to Hofstra University School of Medicine.

WASSERMAN--Burton D.,81, of New Rochelle, NY died peacefully on January 7, 2014. Burt was a wonderful, kind man, who valued family and friends above all else. He was a man of intellect and empathy, a gifted poet, and a beloved joke teller. He leaves his cherished wife of 48 years, Norma. He was the loving father of Melinda (David) and Michael (Gayle), and the adored grandfather of Matty, Emma, Zoe and Phoebe. He was the devoted brother of Stanley, and his late sister Leatrice. The funeral will be held on Thursday, January 9, 2014 at 10:00am at Beth El Synagogue, 1324 North Avenue, New Rochelle, to be followed by burial at Mt. Eden Cemetery in Valhalla. Memorial contributions, if desired, to the National Stroke Association (www.stroke.org) or Hadassah (www.hadassah.org).

SNIDER--Arnold (Arnie). The Board of Directors and staff of the Christopher & Dana Reeve Foundation express great sadness at the loss of our Vice Chairman, Arnie Snider; he was an influential leader and visionary for the Reeve Foundation, sharing his stellar intellect and big heart for humanitarian efforts. What was truly unique about Arnie's arrival as a board member in 2005 was he had no personal connection to spinal cord injuries. His reasons for locking arms with the Reeve Foundation was fueled by a moral imperative to change the world and transform the quality of life for millions living with paralysis. He was instrumental in the wake of Christopher and Dana Reeve's untimely passing, pioneering new initiatives such as epidural stimulation and rallying for advanced rehabilitative methods through the NeuroRecovery Network. It is due to Arnie's unwavering commitment that the organization is on the precipice of discovering cures for paralysis. We will remember Arnie's wisdom and spirit, but most of all, his determination to achieve the "impossible dream" of redefining the reality for those with spinal cord injuries. In Arnie's honor, the Reeve Foundation will harness his legacy to move its mission forward with his vision shaping the future of the organization. Our thoughts are with Arnie's wife, Katherine, and the entire Snider family.

JACOBS--Dorothy, 93, died peacefully at her home January 7, 2014 surrounded by her daughters. Beloved wife of the late Arthur Jacobs. MONTES--Oscar G.,on January 7, 2014. Beloved husband of Martha (nee Puente). Devoted father of Martha (Michael) DiVittorio. Proud grandfather of Benjamin and Andrew DiVittorio.
