KANTER--Kit B.,Wife of motion picture producer, agent, and studio executive Jay Kanter, died peacefully at her home on January 4, 2014. She was 80 years old. Kit was born in New York to parents Celia and Sidney Bennett. In the early 1960's Kit was a fashion model for petite sizes and went on to design and manufacture her own line of reversible shift dresses, called "Flips." She was a resident of Los Angeles before moving to London with her husband and family in 1965. From there she travelled the world, always with her husband and large brood in tow. Upon returning to Los Angeles in the early 1970's, Kit began a new career in home remodeling and interior design that stemmed from her love of antique furniture and objets d'art. Throughout her life, she had a passion for creating handcrafted projects and loved teaching her children the art of needlepoint, quilting, and botanical painting. In later years Kit turned her attention to philanthropy, supporting organizations such as the Motion Picture & Television Fund and numerous causes dedicated to animal rights, local politics and the environment. She is survived by her loving husband, Jay; her children Dustin Bernard, Cydney Bernard, Tom Bernard, Amy Kanter Thiele, Victoria Kanter Colombetti, Adam Kanter, Michael Kanter; daughters-in-law Debra Bernard, Jodie Foster, Brooke Kanter, Erica Kanter; son-in-law Bob Thiele, Jr.; her grandchildren Jason Colombetti, Matthew Colombetti, Owen Thiele, Sophie Bernard, Charlie B. Foster, Hannah Kanter, Kit B. Foster, Cleo Kanter, Grayson Kanter, and Ryan Kanter. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Kit's memory to the Motion Picture & Television Fund (MPTF) online at: www.mptf.com, or by mail at: P.O. Box 51150, Los Angeles, CA 90051-9706. Additionally, donations may be made to the World Wildlife Fund (WWF) online at: www.worldwildlife.org or call 800-225-5993. Service and interment took place Tuesday, January 7, 2014 at Hillside Memorial Park and Mortuary in Los Angeles, CA.

KIRSCHNER--Paul A.,MD. We at the Mount Sinai Health System are deeply saddened by the passing of our friend, mentor, and longtime colleague, Paul A. Kirschner, MD. A pillar of the Mount Sinai community, Dr. Kirschner was an internationally acclaimed thoracic surgeon, investigator, and educator during a distinguished career at Mount Sinai that spanned more than 50 years and included a long tenure as the Chief of Thoracic Surgery at The Mount Sinai Hospital. Dr. Kirschner has a legacy of achievements. His seminal contributions in the management of lung cancer, myasthenia gravis, and the use of mediastinoscopy provided a foundation for the treatment of thoracic diseases that remain relevant today. Recognized for his keen intellect and extraordinary teaching skills, he was a favorite of students and faculty at the Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai, where he remained as Professor Emeritus. Known as a "doctor's doctor," his Mount Sinai peers awarded him the Jacobi Medallion and the Alexander Richman Award for Humanism. We extend our condolences to his family, friends, and colleagues. Peter W. May, Chairman, Boards of Trustees, Mount Sinai Health System Kenneth L. Davis, MD, Chief Executive Officer and President, Mount Sinai Health System Dennis S. Charney, MD Anne and Joel Ehrenkranz Dean, Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai, President for Academic Affairs, Mount Sinai Health System

JACKSON--Robert M. Sr.,92, and WWII Navy Veteran, is survived by his wife Ethel, 87; three children, two sisters; two brothers; many grand and great-grandchildren and a host of other relatives and friends.

SALTZMAN--Arnold. The family of the late Irwin and Sylvia Grossman mourns the passing of Arnold Saltzman, a fellow Columbian, a great American, and a lifelong friend. We extend our deepest sympathy to Joan and the entire Saltzman family.

KLIMLEY--Zoe Brooks. Died unexpectedly in the company of her family on January 2. Zoe spent her early childhood in Bronxville, NY where she grew up with her triplet brothers Graham and Preston. From an early age Zoe was blessed with an indefatigable spirit and joy for life. She was an excellent student and an accomplished athlete. Zoe matriculated to The Taft School in 2011. While at Taft, Zoe was an Honor Roll student, acted as a Class Monitor for her dorm and was elected Co-President of her Class Committee in each eligible term. At the conclusion of her sophomore year, Zoe was elected by her peers to captain the Taft women's crew team and, following the school year, she competed for the Pelham Community Rowing Association. Zoe was radiant every day and in everything she did. Her enthusiasm was infectious and her smile dazzling. In addition to her brothers, Zoe will be deeply missed by her parents, Laura and Brooks, surviving family members and all who knew her. A candlelight vigil in honor of Zoe was held on January 5 in Bronxville, NY where 500 of her friends gathered to reflect on her life. A service of remembrance and celebration of Zoe's life will be held on Friday, January 10th at 11am at the Reformed Church of Bronxville. In lieu of flowers, donations should be made to the "Zoe B. Klimley Scholarship Fund," which has been established at the Taft School.

SCHAECHTER--Charne (Charlotte). The Sholem Aleichem Cultural Center, Bronx, mourns the passing of long-time board member on January 3 at 86. Widow of Mordkhe, mother of Rukhl, Gitl, Eydl, Binyumen; grandmother and great-grandmother of 16. Devoted her life to Yiddish, music and literature. Zol zi hobn a likhtikn gan-eydn.
SHAPIRO--Joseph. Papa Joe, We will cherish all of the times we spent together and will miss you terribly. All our love, Carol, Jeff, Blake, and Grant Engel.

SCHOER--Beatrice. NOWINSKI--Judith, Ph.D.,on January 7, 2014. CUNY Professor Emerita. Dearly beloved aunt. Services: Friday, January 10, 2014, 11:30am at "The Riverside," 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

MORRISON--Nicholas Randolph "Randy," passed away December 29, 2013 after a short illness. Randy was the son of Elizabeth (Betty) Smith and Hobe Morrison, the renowned theatre critic for Variety Magazine. He attended Friends Seminary School in New York City. Sharing his father's love of theatre, he gave up playing drums in a rock band to become a stagehand and in 1974 proudly joined IATSE Local One. He eventually moved into sound production and has worked at the Shubert Theatre for over 23 years. Randy was known throughout the Broadway community for his generosity and kind spirit and was always eager to lend a hand to anyone who needed it. He had a love of photography, technology, music and always enjoyed sharing his passions and talents with friends and co-workers. His colorful Hawaiian shirts were his trademark. Randy was so loved and will be greatly missed by all who knew him. Survivors include his brothers Christopher and Douglas and his beloved cats, Midas and Pandora. A celebration of Randy's life will be held at 8pm at the Glass House Tavern, 252 West 47th St. on Monday, January 13th, 2014. In lieu of flowers, donations in the name of Nicholas R. Morrison may be made to The Actors Fund at www.actorsfund.org

GLANZ--Marcy. Marcy's book-loving, bridge-playing friends mourn her loss and express their deepest sympathy to Marion and family. Her TBC sisters will miss her kindness, creativity, intellect, good humor and all-embracing love.

BARAL--Annabelle, 94, passed away peacefully on January 7, 2014. Beloved wife of the late Joseph. Loving mother of Stephen and Lillian, Jerry and Chris and Eileen and Richard. Special grandma to Gina, Adam, Sara, Emily, Jake and Glenn. Adoring great-grandma of Naomi. Caring aunt to her nieces and nephews. Her warmth, spirit and sense of humor touched so many. Service 10am Thursday at Riverside Nassau-North Chapels 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, New York.

BARD--Henry H.,MD, died suddenly on January 3rd at the age of 91. He is survived by his widow, Lucie Taft Bard, of Locust Valley and his daughter, Holly Bard of Camas, WA. He is predeceased by his sons Bruce and Douglas Bard. He was the son of Alberta Loppacker Bard and Dr. Henry Bard of Pittsfield, MA. Dr. Bard graduated from Berkshire Academy, Princeton University and Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons. He served in the Army briefly during World War II and later as a Navy Medical Officer during the Korean War. After training in New York, he spent his career as a General Surgeon at the Glen Cove Hospital. Upon retirement he found pleasure in gardening, reading, croquet, bridge, walking his dog Rufus and many cruises to far-away places. He was a kind, generous man with a good sense of humor who will be sorely missed by all who knew him. Funeral services will be held at St. John's Church, Cold Spring Harbor on Friday, January 10th at 11am. In lieu of flowers, a donation may be made to Berkshire School, 245 Undermountian Road, Sheffield, MA 01257.

SCHIFFMAN--Gerald, PhD, SUNY Downstate Medical Center mourns the passing of Gerald Schiffman, PhD, distinguished service professor emeritus of microbiology and immunology. Along with the late Robert Austrian, MD, Dr. Schiffman developed and introduced the first effective, widely used vaccine to prevent a potentially lethal variety of bacterial pneumonia caused by Pneumococcus. His pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine (PPSV23) stimulated global interest in efforts to block bacterial pneumonia by prior immunization. Dr. Schiffman's work established SUNY Downstate as a national resource for pneumococcal typing. He also developed a unique assay to test immune function. Although two vaccines against bacterial pneumonia were available in the 1940s, they were withdrawn from the market because most physicians preferred treating the disease with antibiotics rather than submitting the adult population to extensive injections with multiple vaccines, as a wide range of bacteria is known to induce life threatening lung infections. Dr. Schiffman demonstrated severe limitations in treating pneumococcal infections with antibiotic therapy, and, with Dr. Austrian, introduced a new vaccine in 1978. However, it was not until the 1990s, with the increasing pneumococcal resistance to multiple antibiotics, that the world of medicine fully accepted their wisdom. Pneumococcal vaccination has since become the established standard of care for high-risk patients. Dr. Schiffman was also known for developing a test to measure a wide range of immune system functions and disorders. His was the only laboratory to use this assay, and each year, about 100,000 samples from around the world were sent to him for analysis. In 2010, the State University of New York awarded Dr. Schiffman an honorary Doctor of Science degree. John F. Williams, MD, EdD, MPH, President Ian L. Taylor, MD, PhD, Dean, College of Medicine

LOWENFELD--Leroy S. (Buddy), passed away peacefully in Boca Raton, FL on January 7, 2014 at the age of 90. He is survived by his loving family: beloved wife Helene, devoted children David and Sally and Ivey, loving grandchildren Jonah and Rebekah, Lea, Allison, Elie and Melanie, and adored great-grandchildren Zeke and Zooey. Born in Brooklyn, he served in the Army Air Forces in WWII and graduated from NYU as a member of Beta Gamma Sigma. Founder and President of Wicke and Lowenfeld, Insurance Agency and past President of Temple Hillel, North Woodmere. His generosity extended to numerous Jewish philanthropies. His kindness, optimism and good humor will be missed by friends and family.

PALENBERG--John C.,Passed away peacefully on January 6th. Born September 13th, 1956 in Richardton, ND, he graduated from the University of North Dakota and from Harvard Law and the Fletcher Schools with joint degrees in law and diplomacy and was a Fulbright Scholar. He joined the law firm of Cleary Gottlieb Steen & Hamilton, LLP in 1983 and had an illustrious career in six of the firm's offices around the world until his untimely passing. He is survived by the love of his life, his wife Chieko, his beloved children, Henry and Sophia, his dear mother, Theresa, his adoring sisters, Fay and Jan, and by a myriad of faithful friends. A wake will be held at Vanella's Funeral Chapel, 29 Madison St., NYC on January 13 at 3-5pm and 7-9 pm. A funeral mass will be celebrated at St. Peter's R.C. Church, 22 Barclay St., NYC at 10am on January 14. Contributions may be made to AutismSpeaks.org.

SANDHU--Kuldip K.,surrounded by her family, died at her home in Fayetteville, NY on January 4, 2014. She was 84. Born in Amritsar, India, she came to the United States in 1958. Her passion for learning earned her eight degrees ranging from economics to biology. It culminated in a PhD in Microbiology from St. John's University, NYC. She served as adjunct assistant professor at NYU and Chief of Microbiology at the VA New York Harbor Healthcare System from which she retired at age 82. Her work at the VA made her proud. Those she worked with gave her joy. Pre-deceased by her son Robert Sandhu she is survived by her husband of 55 years, Randhir S. Sandhu; her daughter, Satinderpal Sandhu; her daughter, Sameena Sandhu-Pollock, her son-in-law, Sherwin Pollock and her three granddaughters, Kyrin, Maya and Tara. Always to be loved, never to be forgotten. Services: Saturday, January 11 at 12noon, Fiore Funeral Home, 236 Monmouth Rd, Oakhurst, NJ.

SWORDS--Cherry Shaw, 96, died peacefully at hospice in Branford, CT, on January 7, 2014. Born in Rye, NY, on July 15, 1917, to Guthrie and Virginia Thorne Shaw, she graduated from the Ethel Walker School and Sarah Lawrence College. During World War II, she was a driver for the Red Cross Motor Corps. She married Gerard S. Swords of New York City in 1943. They shared 38 years in New Haven, CT, as part of the Yale community, until his death in 1981. She was a member of The Cosmopolitan Club, and The Garden Club of New Haven, where she was an active member since 1951. She is remembered for her friendship, and for her love and devotion to her family. She is survived by her daughter, Susan Swords Stevens of Hamden, CT, her granddaughter, Virginia Stevens, and her grandson, Peter Swords Stevens. In lieu of flowers, donations in her memory can be made to The Garden Club of New Haven at P.O. Box 6197, Hamden, CT 06517.

WHITE--Edgar P.E.,died peacefully on January 7 surrounded by his family. A life-long resident of Manhattan and Mantoloking, NJ he graduated from Allen Stevenson, Groton and Harvard. Down, down, down into the darkness of the grave Gently they go, the beautiful, the tender, the kind; Quietly they go, the intelligent, the witty, the brave. I know. But I do not approve. NEY--Edward N. Y&R mourns the loss of Edward N. Ney, our beloved Chairman Emeritus. Ed led Young & Rubicam as CEO and Chairman from 1970 through 1986. He transformed Y&R and our industry, with his visionary idea of integrated communications. Under his leadership, he acquired companies that included Burson-Marsteller, Wunderman, Sudler & Hennessy and Landor. Ed later served as U.S. Ambassador to Canada, then chair of Burson-Marsteller's worldwide Board of Advisors, before coming back home to Y&R in 1999. We offer our deepest condolences to his widow, Patricia Murray Wood; his son, Nicholas; daughters, Hilary and Michelle, as well as to his five grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. He was loved and will be greatly missed by so many people whose lives he touched. The wake will be held on Friday, January 10th 2-5pm/7-9pm at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave (at 81st St.) Funeral services will be held on Saturday, January 11th at 1:30pm at St. Vincent Ferrer Roman Catholic Parish, 869 Lexington Ave (at 66th St.) In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Alzheimer's Association, NYC Chapter's Education and Training Program. www.alznyc.org/donate

SNIDER--Arnold H. III, passed away Friday, January 3rd after a short but courageous battle with cancer. Arnie was 68 years old. Arnie was a loving husband, father and grandfather who not only achieved great success in his career on Wall Street, but was also a dedicated and tireless philanthropist. Arnie began his career as a financial analyst specializing in pharmaceuticals at Kidder Peabody. During his seventeen years at Kidder, he established and led a recognized team of health care analysts, served as Head of the Healthcare Research Group as Managing Director, and as Chairman of the Stock Selection Committee. He was considered a highly successful analyst and "stock picker", who was selected to the Institutional Investor All-America Research Team in 1986 and 1987. He was also ranked as the leading pharmaceutical industry analyst by the Greenwich Research Poll. Arnie moved to the field of asset management in 1988 when he joined Tiger Management, bringing his business acumen and deep knowledge of the pharmaceutical industry to his oversight of the firm's global healthcare investments. In 1993, he founded Deerfield Management Company, which specialized in healthcare equities, and served as Deerfield's Managing Partner until he formally retired in 2005. During retirement, he utilized his business and financial skills to successfully advise on a number of important business and charitable projects. He served as a Chairman of the Board of N30, a small, privately owned pharmaceutical company engaged in the development of novel drugs in diseases which currently have no cure. He also served as a trustee and as the Chairman of the Investment Committee for the Davidson College endowment, his alma mater where he was a champion of The Davidson Trust, committed to making Davidson accessible to all talented students regardless of their financial circumstances. While a Trustee, he created the Arnold H. Snider Scholarship, which provides full scholarships for two students in each class. As important as Arnie's professional accomplishments were, he was equally committed to a number of philanthropic endeavors. Arnie's expansive knowledge of the healthcare industry and drug development provided a foundation for his philanthropic efforts in a number of areas of medical and scientific research, including geriatric medicine, spinal cord injuries, and lupus. Along with his wife, Katherine, he endowed the Kate Mills Snider Geropsychiatry Outreach Program and Professorship Fund within the Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Medicine at Wake Forest Baptist Medical Center. They also established the Arnold and Katherine Snider Geriatric Fund at Princeton Hospital. Arnie also served as the Vice Chairman, Board of Directors, for the Christopher & Dana Reeve Foundation and as Chairman of the Foundation's Research Planning Committee. In 2000, Arnie and his wife established Rheuminations, Inc. a foundation to support lupus research and develop educational programs for patients with lupus, through which they created The Mary Kirkland Center for Lupus Research at the Hospital for Special Surgery, a related Kirkland Scholar Program that has provided research grants to individual lupus investigators at academic institutions in the US and Canada, and an educational website for lupus patients. In 2003, they founded the Lupus Clinical Trials Consortium, Inc. to support the development of new therapies for lupus, which evolved into a multi-center lupus patient data base registry intended to support lupus research and related publications. Arnie received his BA from Davidson College and an MBA from the University of Virginia School of Business. Arnie was an avid reader of politics and history, and was devoted to classical music and to golf. He was a gentle, kind and generous person whose friendships were defined by warmth and loyalty. Arnie deeply loved and took immense pride in his family. He is survived by his wife, Katherine, daughter, Sarah Kirkland Snider Mackey, son, Ned Snider, son-in-law, Steven Mackey, daughter-in-law Marina Greenstein Snider, three grandchildren, Jasper and Dylan Mackey and Simone Snider; his brother, Lewis Brittle Snider of McLean Virginia, and a nephew, Britt Arnold Snider of Chevy Chase, VA. In lieu of flowers, contributions in Arnie's memory may be made to any of the following charities: Arnold H. Snider Scholarship at Davidson College; the Kate Mills Snider Geropsychiatry Outreach Program (GO) at Wake Forest Baptist Health, or the Christopher and Dana Reeve Foundation.

CAREY--John (Jack) Leonard, of Manhattan died peacefully on January 7, 2014 at the age of 83, with his wife at his side. John was born in Millville, Massachusetts in 1930 to Leonard and Molly. In 1947, as the first person in his family to finish high school, he graduated as valedictorian from St Mary's of Milford, and received a full scholarship to attend the College of the Holy Cross in Worcester, MA. During this time he developed his lifelong passion for literature, and received a Master's in English from Boston College in 1952. John then enrolled in a Ph.D program in English at the University of Wisconsin, but left in 1953 to enter the Catholic priesthood. He was ordained as a Franciscan friar after six years, and as Father Alfred Augustus, served in the priesthood for ten years. He returned to Wisconsin and completed his Ph.D in 1965, then worked as a friar and professor at St. Bonaventure University and Brandeis University until 1969. He left the priesthood that year, and in 1970 married his beloved wife Dorothy. John spent the final 33 years of his career at Bloomfield College in Bloomfield, New Jersey, a school whose students, faculty and staff he loved. He was well known for his dynamic lectures, particularly on Shakespeare and Chaucer. John lived in Manhattan from 1970 until his death, and he and Dorothy raised their two daughters in the West Village. John's greatest passions were his family, Bloomfield, his books, and the Boston Red Sox. He will be missed for his wit, intelligence, and, most of all, his devotion to those he loved. He is survived by his wife Dorothy; daughter Michelle Carey and son-in-law Navin Pant of New York; and daughter Megan Carey of New York. Funeral services will be held at St. Luke's in the Field (487 Hudson Street) on Saturday, January 18th at 2pm; all are welcome. Donations in his memory can be made to the John L. Carey Scholarship Fund at Bloomfield College.

SPENCER--Melvin, 89 of Palm Beach Gardens, FL and originally of Cleveland, OH passed away January 6, 2014. Melvin is survived by his three sons, six grandchildren and brother, Julius Spencer.

LICHT--Paul. May 5, 1920 - January 8, 2014. Beloved husband to Vera and then after her passing, to the late Blossom, adored father to Beth, David, Larry and Judy, loving stepfather to Jane Melnick, David Melnick and Ed Melnick, loving grandfather to 19, and delighted great-grandfather to six. He was a man who loved to be busy, fixing things, making things. He loved travel, and the outdoors especially in Lee, Massachusetts where he was usually sailing, canoeing, chopping wood or fixing what ever was broken in the house. Poppi, as he was known to his children and grandchildren lived his life doing what had to be done for his family. When he left college to support his young family, he gave up his dream of becoming a chemist, and began working in a store, a store he wound up owning and running for the next 56 years, retiring at the youthful age of 81. His store, Canal Self Service was an "everything store" that took customers back to an era where they could, as the slogan said, "Serve yourself and save" in the days when lower Manhattan was home to industry. Paul found time to have fun. One summer while out on party boat to fish for bluefish, Poppi got seasick. But while suffering, he still had a positive attitude and Poppi said with a smile: "Well, now you've got Hot Chum. Catch some fish!" It seemed he could fix most anything including replacing all the copper pipes in his house in Valley Stream, LI and fixing the roof of the house in Lee, MA. As Poppi got older his determination and strength seemingly knew no bounds. In his late 80's he still went to the gym regularly. His strength was a marvel; he was respected by all of the weightlifters, all while wearing his blue jeans, flannel shirts and Leatherman. Poppi had a way of talking with people that garnered him many acquaintances throughout the Chinatown and Tribeca neighborhoods that he spent the past 30+ years in. All who knew him were touched by his generosity, his willingness to lend a helping hand and most importantly his love for family and friends.

McGAR--Thad Martin, died peacefully at home on December 30, 2013 at the age of 86. Coming to New York from his native Texas in 1952, he trained in the then new technique of color transparency retouching and became one of New York City's top retouchers. In the 1960's, he set up Creative Colour companies in London and Hamburg, Germany introducing transparency-retouching technology to Europe. In the early 1970's, he opened Welbeck Studio in New York. He retired in 1989. He is survived by his husband, Paul Bodden. He touched many people with his light.
LEWIS--Richard, Two years gone, loving you and missing you every minute of every day. Harriet

UCHIDA--Izumi, died January 6, 2014 in Manhattan. Beloved wife of John Guillemin, daughter of Hamako Uchida and the late Nobuki Uchida, sister of Dr.Takayuki and Iseko Uchida, aunt to Kotaro, Ryuchan, Nanachan, Claire and Julia, and godmother of Mira. Cherished by her extended family and friends. Joyously dedicated to jazz music. Service at noon Saturday January 11 John Krtil Funeral Home. Donations School for Improvisational Music (www.schoolforimprov.org).

WEIMAN--Clinton G.,MD. After a long illness, Clinton Weiman, 88, died peacefully at his home in Greenwich, CT on January 7, 2014. Son of Lewis and Angela George Weiman, he graduated from Princeton University and Cornell Medical School. Initially Dr. Weiman practiced medicine in New York City and then became a Senior Vice President for Medical Affairs at CitiBank from which he retired. Citi was one of the first corporations to assign senior rank to a physician. While at Citi, he began an electronic medical record system in 1982 for 14,000 employees enabling him and his staff to give more effective care. He leaves his wife, Susan Schneider Weiman, five children Patrice, Timothy, Peter, Ellen and John, nine grandchildren and one great-grandchild. Friends and family will be received at Gallagher's Funeral Home in Greenwich on Monday, January 13th prior to the Mass at St. Michaels Church, Greenwich. Further information is available at: www.leopgallaghergreenwich. com. In lieu of flowers donations to Princeton University would be appreciated.

RAVITCH--Gloria Moskin, died peacefully in San Francisco after a long illness surrounded by family. Born and educated in New York and at Wellesley, she moved to California in 1960. Gloria shared her passion and expertise for European Decorative Arts as Docent and Assistant Curator at the Fine Arts Museums in San Francisco. She will be missed by many including her children Amy (Friedricks), Jill, John, grandchildren Emily and Henry, and former husband Donald.

WADSWORTH--Deborah. Public policy expert and education advocate Deborah Yohalem Wadsworth died of multiple myeloma on December 24, 2013 just before her 75th birthday. Ms. Wadsworth had a long and distinguished career, dedicated to improving American education and the public's capacity to understand and take action on the great political and social issues of our time. She had a keen understanding of the power and potential of education to transform society. Wadsworth was the Executive Director and then President of Public Agenda Foundation, the nonpartisan education and public policy research organization, between 1986-2004, focusing on how to improve Americans' learning and thinking about issues ranging from abortion and education to crime, national security, health, and welfare. Previously, Wadsworth served as director of the Smart Family Foundation and program officer of the Markle Foundation. Before that, she participated in the planning and development of the new State University of New York at Purchase in the 1960s, and then, as director of admissions in the 1970s, she recruited a nation-wide student body. Since 1998 Wadsworth served on the board of trustees of Bennington College and was board chair from 2000-2011. She was also a member of the boards of Public Agenda, the National Center for Public Policy and Higher Education, the Wenner-Gren Foundation, and the Educational Development Center (for which she was board chair from 2004-2010). She also served as a consultant to many national educational programs. Wadsworth was born and raised in Mount Vernon, New York. She obtained her B.A. from Wellesley College in 1960 with honors and her M.A. from Columbia University in 1965. She was married to Frank Wadsworth, a university literature professor and administrator, who died in 2012. For her, family always came first. She spent as much time as she could with her four grown children, daughter-in-law, son-in-law and five grandchildren, all of whom survive her. She was an avid sailor, loved the cultural world of New York City, and had an infectious can-do approach to life.

PETERSEN--Betsy Stilwell, 84, of Wilmington, DE, formerly of Darien, CT, died peacefully at home on January 7. Born in Indianapolis to Harold and Gay (Hutchings) Taylor, she was later adopted by her mother's second husband Abner Stilwell. She attended the Latin School of Chicago and graduated from Smith College in 1951. She worked as a researcher for Leo Burnett Company, Time and Fortune magazines, and Sylvia Porter; as Editor of the Magazine of Wall Street; and as a freelance writer and editor for an array of periodicals, books, and corporate clients including Xerox Corporation. For 30 years she was Senior Contributing Editor for Boardroom Reports. She was also active as President of the Smith Club of New York, Treasurer of the New York Junior League, and committee member of the Winter Antiques Show, whose catalogue she edited for many years. On the centennial of the Darien Library in 1994, she wrote a book-length history, So Many Friends. Her many longtime friends and loving relatives will miss her generous spirit and lively mind. Married to Bruce R. Petersen (later divorced), she is survived by a son, Stephen (Lauren), of Hockessin, DE, and two grandchildren, Miles and Stella. Her son David predeceased her, as did her sister Sally Anderson. Private burial will be at Putnam Cemetery, Greenwich, CT. A memorial service will be held Saturday, February 1, at 11:00am at the Noroton Presbyterian Church, 2011 Post Rd., Darien, CT. Memorial contributions may be made to Latin School of Chicago or Smith College.
NEY--Edward N.,age 88, your love, grace and kindness will be remembered by the many whose lives were affected by your friendships. Rest in peace. Judy
FERBEL--Philip, June 27, 1922 - January 11, 1994. Loved and remembered everyday.

FINKELSTEIN--Anna. Happy Birthday Dearest Mother. Loved and Remembered Forever and a Day. Cynthia

FAUST--Monroe G.,Died January 9, 2014 age 90. Born in the Bronx to Isidore and Edith. Loving husband for 65 years to Lucie (Haas) Faust. Beloved father of Debbie (David Bacchioni) and Judy (William Hartnett). Adored grandfather of Doug (Krista), Abra, Rebecca Bacchioni and Josie Hartnett. Brother of Leonard. Predeceased by daughter Vicki Faust Dornbusch and sister Florence Weintraub. WWII Army Vet, raised his family in New Rochelle later moved to Bronxville and Lenox. Attended Stuyvesant, NYU, Wharton, Harvard AMP. Longtime executive at William Iselin. He loved the Yankees, the New York Philharmonic, Tanglewood, the Bronx Zoo, Israel, traveling. A kind and wonderful man. Donations to Wildlife Conservation Society or charity of your choice. Borei Pri Hagufen.

BISSO--Anna, 94, wife of the late Sidney Kerner and David Bisso. Beloved mother of Margaret (Donald) and Amy (David). Stepmother of Michael (Margery) and Susan (Stephen). Adored grandmother of Evan (Kaitlin) and Jessica. Anna was an exhibited mixed-media artist and a founding member of Women in the Arts.

HENICK--Murray, 88, passed away peacefully at home in Boca Raton, surrounded by his loved ones on January 9, 2014, from complications of Parkinson's disease. Beloved husband of Rhoda for 63 years; father and father-in-law of Alan (Adrienne), Jeffrey (Olga) and Janet (Eduard); grandfather of Matthew, Zachary, Alixandra, Daniel, Andrew, Amanda, Stefan and April. After serving in the Navy during WWII, Murray graduated from NYU and began his business career. A true entrepreneur, his career successes included Chairman of Western Carpet for many years, importer and parking garage operator. Favorite pastimes included racehorse owner, gin rummy and spending time with his grandchildren. Ambitious, yet humble, he will be forever missed. A private graveside service will be held on January 12. Donations in his memory can be made to: South Palm Beach County Chapter, National Parkinson Foundation, P.O. Box 880145, Boca Raton, FL 33488

LEWIS--Ruth, passed away January 8, 2014. First graduating class Brandeis University. Masters NYU. Loving wife of Neville; mother of Matthew, Andrew and Jonathan; grandmother of Kristin, Kelsey, Dana and Nicholas. A kind and giving person, she will be missed by all that knew her. Ruth brought great happiness and substance to all our lives.

COLLINS--Linda. The Directors, Members, and extended community of Yaddo artists mourn the passing of Linda Collins, a talented writer and a generous and active Board Member of 25 years. Throughout, she demonstrated leadership and support, in particular in securing a home for the Yaddo Archive Collection. We will greatly miss Linda's guiding wisdom, her artistry, humor, and determination, and we extend our condolences to her husband Arthur, sons Rufus and Jacob, and the entire family. The Corporation of Yaddo

GORDON--Rita, 88, died Thursday, January 9, 2014, in a Monroe Township, NJ, nursing facility as a result of head injuries from a fall two years ago. She and her beloved husband, George Gordon, would have celebrated their 66th wedding anniversary this coming February 7. Survivors include her loving children Richard Gordon (and Laurie Moses) and Barbara Ehrenreich (and Yuval Ehrenreich), grandchildren Rachel and David Ehrenreich, and Jessie and Samantha Gordon, as well as her sister Florence Leichter and brother Les Schecter (and Katherine Page-Schecter). She served as Legislative Aide to former New York State Assemblyman and New York Attorney General Oliver Koppell from 1980's 1994. Funeral services are Sunday, January, 12, at 12 noon at Mt. Sinai Memorial Chapel, 454 Cranbury Road, East Brunswick, NJ.

CORBETT--Robert V.,74, NYC attorney, partner of Cardillo & Corbett Law Firm suddenly on January 8th. Beloved husband of Alisa (De Rose), loving father of Nathaniel and Caroline. Funeral, Monday 10am at St. Timothy Lutheran Church, 395 Valley Rd., Wayne, NJ. Visiting Sunday 2-4pm and 7-9pm, Allwood Funeral Home, 660 Allwood Rd., Clifton, NJ 07012. GERSTMANN--Kurt, M.D.,passed away January 9. He is survived by his beloved wife, Sandra Lerner, his children Evan and Laurie Gerstmann, Elan and Carol Gerstmann, his stepchildren Jeff and Debbie Gross, and Cliff Gross, his grandchildren, Issac and Sam, Collette and Lila Gerstmann, David, Alexis, Jordan, Ricki and Scott Gross. GALLAGHER--James. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of James Gallagher, associated with The New York Times from January 15, 1990 until retiring on December 1, 2000.

BERRY--Rynn, Jr.,68, of Brooklyn, New York, writer and authority on vegetarian history, died of complications from cardiac arrest while jogging in Prospect Park on December 29. After undergraduate and graduate studies at the University of Pennsylvania and Columbia, he made his life's work to promote public awareness of vegetarianism and animal rights. His step-mother Nancy W. Berry and half-brothers Charles and Peter Berry join Rynn's co-author and close friend Chris Abreu-Suzuki PhD and the entire vegetarian community in mourning the passing of a brilliant intellect and thoughtful and caring spirit. Donations in Rynn's memory may be made to the Sea Shepherd Conservation Society (www.seashepherd.org), the North American Vegetarian Society (www.navs-online.org) or the Physicians Committee for Responsible Medicine (www.pcrm.org).

HUGHES--Louise M.,passed peacefully, at home in Florida January 10, 2013. A native New Yorker, Louise had a successful career in advertising at The New York Times. An elegant, sophisticated, intelligent, witty woman, who will be missed by her surviving brother, nieces, nephew, stepson, and all the grands. Predeceased by her husband of twenty-nine years, Donald J. Hughes. "Don't be sad because it's over, smile because it happened."

STOCK--Cooper Dean. On January 10, 2014 Cooper Dean Stock, beloved son of Dana Lerner and Dr. Richard Stock, was tragically killed in a vehicular accident near his home on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. He was just nine years old. Cooper was a spirited third grader who attended the Calhoun School. Cooper had a larger than life personality and will be massively missed by everyone who knew him. Cooper loved to play basketball and avidly followed the Knicks. Cooper was a statistic machine when it came to the Knicks. Everyone marveled at what he knew. He was also a fan of the New York Yankees and classic rock 'n' roll. Cooper was the life of the party even when there wasn't a party. He was light, he was reflective, he was beauty in motion, he was charismatic, he has been described as an old soul and wise beyond his years. In addition to his parents he is survived by: sister Gianna, a more loving older sister never existed; grandmother Ronnie Lerner of University Heights, OH; grandmother Nadine Stock of NYC; uncle Barron, aunt Cathy and cousins Ben and Nina Lerner of Hastings-on-Hudson; uncle Matt and aunt Irina and cousins Dennis, Willy and Maxim Stock of NYC; uncle Wayne, aunt Melina and cousin Robert Stock of New Jersey. Cooper was lovingly looked after by Judy Campbell who was like a second mother to him. Cooper was predeceased by both of his grandfathers: Dr. Phillip Lerner and Robert Stock. Cooper will live in our hearts forever. We will never understand why we had to say goodbye so soon. Services will be held on Monday, January 13th at 11:45 at Riverside Memorial Chapel on 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, kindly send donations in Cooper's memory to Temple Beth Shalom, 740 North Broadway, Hastings-on-Hudson, NY 10706. The family will decide which charities to send the donations to at a later date.

WEIMAN--Clinton G.,MD. After a long illness, Clinton Weiman, 88, died peacefully at his home in Greenwich, CT on January 7, 2014. Son of Lewis and Angela George Weiman, he graduated from Princeton University and Cornell Medical School. Initially Dr. Weiman practiced medicine in New York City and then became a Senior Vice President for Medical Affairs at CitiBank from which he retired. Citi was one of the first corporations to assign senior rank to a physician. While at Citi, he began an electronic medical record system in 1982 for 14,000 employees enabling him and his staff to give more effective care. He leaves his wife, Susan Schneider Weiman, five children Patrice, Timothy, Peter, Ellen and John, nine grandchildren and one great-grandchild. Friends and family will be received at Gallagher's Funeral Home in Greenwich on Monday, January 13th prior to the Mass at St. Michaels Church, Greenwich. Further information is available at: www.leopgallaghergreenwich. com. In lieu of flowers donations to Princeton University would be appreciated.

He served in the Korean War, and worked as a stock broker on Wall Street. He was predeceased by his identical twin brother, Sumner W. White, III with whom he won a Gold Medal in Sailing at the 1952 Helsinki Olympics. Edgar was an active member of the Union Club, Mantoloking Yacht Club, and a past Master of the Holland Lodge. He was the beloved husband of D.J., loving father of Cynthia, Daphne, and Virginia, and a devoted grandfather of three grandchildren. Services to be held at the Church of the Epiphany, 1393 York Ave., Thursday, January 30 at 2pm. Memorial donations may be made to Cancer Research at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, PO Box 27106, New York, NY 10087-7106.
LEWIS--Richard, Two years gone, loving you and missing you every minute of every day. Harriet

BABY BEAR Written and illustrated by Kadir Nelson. 40 pp. Balzer & Bray/HarperCollins. $17.99. (Picture book; ages 2 to 6) 
 
Nelson’s illustrations, particularly for books on African-­American themes like “Henry’s Freedom Box” (written by Ellen Levine), have won many awards. Here he tells the story of a little bear who has lost his way. In scenes illuminated by moonlight, Baby Bear encounters a range of wild creatures, from mountain lion to salmon, who offer him wise counsel. In Nelson’s hands, the natural world is enviably ruled by kind intentions and respect.

WELLER-JONES--Wendy, We celebrate the vibrant life of Wendy, an adoring and adored mother, grandmother, wife, friend and proud red-head. A fighter of "isms", Wendy was a Flatbush force to be reckoned with. Her honesty, warmth, good humor and passion touched many and we will miss her dearly.

WEYERHAEUSER--Elizabeth "Betsy" Fairman 52, of Wayzata, Minnesota passed away on December 31, 2013 with loving members of her family gathered around her after a courageous battle with cancer. Born Elizabeth Jane Fairman in New York City, Betsy attended the Spence School before moving with her family to Locust Valley, Long Island. She graduated from the Green Vale School; cum laude from St. Paul's School and magna cum laude from Harvard. Thereafter she received an MBA from the Harvard Business School. While subsequently working as a partner at McKinsey & Company, she was introduced to David Weyerhaeuser by a cousin of David's. They were married in 1999. Prior to her 13 years at McKinsey, Betsy's career included two years as a buyer with Bloomingdale's and five years with Procter & Gamble as a Brand Manager. She served on the boards of the Minneapolis Institute of Arts, the Minnesota Zoo Foundation, and Rock Island Company. She was an avid tennis player, golfer, reader, chef and traveler but her greatest creativity and commitment were devoted to raising her three children, for whom she retired from her business career. Betsy is survived by her husband, David; her children, Blake, Jackie, and Charlie; her father, Joel Fairman; her brother, David Fairman (Juliette Zener); and her sister, Helen Fairman. She is preceded in passing by her mother, Claire Martin Fairman. Betsy's strength, determination, quick wit, positive spirit, and commitment to family made a lasting impact on the many people she touched throughout her life. A memorial service to celebrate her life will be held on Thursday, January 16, at 4:00pm at Wayzata Community Church, 125 Wayzata Blvd. East, Wayzata, Minnesota. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to the Minneapolis Institute of Arts, 2400 3rd Avenue South, Minneapolis, MN 55404 or Learning Works at Blake, The Blake School, 110 Blake Road South, Hopkins, MN 55343.

LOHMAN--Arthur J.,on December 25, 2013. Deeply loved and loving husband of Harriet Walley; devoted father of Peter (Sondra Lomax) and James (Rachel Rogers); adored stepfather of Sarah Kugelman (Daryl Nanes); cherished brother of Laurence; and proud grandfather of Jacob and Alexa. Arthur, raised in Rye and Mt. Vernon, NY, lived most of his adult life in New York City and Southampton. His firm Lohman Organization, a major force in commercial real estate and related fields, was retained by The New York Times as editorial director for its first commercial real estate supplement and advised Fortune Magazine and others on marketing to the industry. He served on the Boards of the NIAE (now Van Alen Institute) and Riverside Symphony where he introduced its Music Memory program to elementary school students. He was a graduate of Harvard College with a degree in physics and a naval radar technician whose tour was marked by a shakedown cruise on the Juneau (CL-119). He was passionate about music from opera to jazz and was an accomplished jazz trumpet player who was a regular at Jazz at Noon. Arthur was defined by his honor, kindness, ethics and sense of humor and touched all who came in contact with him. We will miss him dearly. Donations may be made to the Riverside Symphony. Memorial to be held at the Harvard Club, 27 West 44 St., February 8th at 2pm.

SELCH--Patricia B.,The colleagues and friends of Patricia Selch in the Musical Instruments Department of The Metropolitan Museum of Art send their condolences to her family. Her thoughtful presence will be greatly missed at our Visiting Committee meetings and special events.

LOBKOWICZ--Martin Maximilian George, of Dover, Massachusetts, died January 4, 2014, at the age of eighty-five. Mr. Lobkowicz was born in London, the eldest son of Prince and Princess Maximilian Lobkowicz and raised in Czechoslovakia. At the outbreak of WWII, his family fled to London where his father was Ambassador to the Court of St. James, representing the Czech government in exile. In 1940, Mr. Lobkowicz was sent to the United States under the auspices of Miss Sylvia Warren of Dover, Massachusetts. After graduation from Milton Academy and Harvard College (Class of 1951), he enlisted in the U.S. Army and saw combat in Korea as an infantry officer. Later, he worked as a stockbroker, retiring in 2013. After the Velvet Revolution of 1989, Mr. and Mrs. Lobkowicz and their son William actively participated in a series of restitution laws passed under the inspired leadership of Czech President, Vaclav Havel, to recover the family's castles and art collections stolen by the Nazis and then the Communists. Financed privately and especially through charitable donations, the collections were returned and are being restored. Museums have been opened at Nelahozeves Castle and The Lobkowicz Palace, where scholars and the general public have access to a rich cultural heritage spanning seven centuries. He leaves his wife of 62 years, Margaret Brooks (Juett); a brother Dominik; sons Martin, John, and William; a daughter Margaret; his grandchildren, Elisabeth, Richard, William, Ileana and Sophia Lobkowicz; and granddaughters, Mary and Hope Masri. A memorial service will be held at the Dover Church in Dover, Massachusetts on Sunday, April 13, 2014 at 1pm.

LUSK--George B.,92, of White Plains and Dunewood, Fire Island, passed away peacefully Friday evening surrounded by his loving family.
