LICHT--Paul. May 5, 1920 - January 8, 2014. Beloved husband to Vera and then after her passing, to the late Blossom, adored father to Beth, David, Larry and Judy, loving stepfather to Jane Melnick, David Melnick and Ed Melnick, loving grandfather to 19, and delighted great-grandfather to six. He was a man who loved to be busy, fixing things, making things. He loved travel, and the outdoors especially in Lee, Massachusetts where he was usually sailing, canoeing, chopping wood or fixing what ever was broken in the house. Poppi, as he was known to his children and grandchildren lived his life doing what had to be done for his family. When he left college to support his young family, he gave up his dream of becoming a chemist, and began working in a store, a store he wound up owning and running for the next 56 years, retiring at the youthful age of 81. His store, Canal Self Service was an "everything store" that took customers back to an era where they could, as the slogan said, "Serve yourself and save" in the days when lower Manhattan was home to industry. Paul found time to have fun. One summer while out on party boat to fish for bluefish, Poppi got seasick. But while suffering, he still had a positive attitude and Poppi said with a smile: "Well, now you've got Hot Chum. Catch some fish!" It seemed he could fix most anything including replacing all the copper pipes in his house in Valley Stream, LI and fixing the roof of the house in Lee, MA. As Poppi got older his determination and strength seemingly knew no bounds. In his late 80's he still went to the gym regularly. His strength was a marvel; he was respected by all of the weightlifters, all while wearing his blue jeans, flannel shirts and Leatherman. Poppi had a way of talking with people that garnered him many acquaintances throughout the Chinatown and Tribeca neighborhoods that he spent the past 30+ years in. All who knew him were touched by his generosity, his willingness to lend a helping hand and most importantly his love for family and friends.

LARKIN--Anya. Anya Larkin, internationally recognized designer and founder of Anya Larkin Ltd., passed away on Sunday, December 29th after a courageous struggle with cancer. A rare combination of artist and entrepreneur who single-handedly built a global business, she occupies an important place in the modern design era. Her unique, hand pressed wall coverings, many composed of silver and gold leaf, are housed in the permanent collections of the Louvre's Decorative Arts Museum in Paris and the Victoria and Albert Museum in London, and have been frequently featured in publications and installations worldwide. Born Ann Seymour Larkin, she grew up in Westport, CT, attending the Thomas School (Rowayton, CT), Briarcliff College (Briarcliff Manor, NY) and the Silvermine College of Art (Silvermine, CT) where she received the Dean's Award for the highest academic record in her graduating class. For many years she resided in New York City and Stonington, CT. Anya was a beloved friend, relative and colleague who saw and encouraged the potential in those she loved. Her spirit, courage and lust for life were inspiring; her generosity was boundless. Anya is survived by sister Fay Larkin (Miguel Gomez-Ibanez); brother Richard R. Larkin (Laurie Cameron); nieces Brooke and Julia Chandler, and nephew James Larkin (Allison Hogan). In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Stonington Free Library, 20 High St, Stonington, CT 06378, or the Stonington Village Improvement Association, P.O. Box 18, Stonington, CT 06378.

FREUND--Seelig, MD.,The entire Beth Israel Medical Center community joins with the leadership of its parent company, the Mount Sinai Health System, in acknowledging with sadness the passing of our dear friend and beloved former colleague, Seelig Freund, MD, who served with great distinction on the surgical staff at Beth Israel for many years. He will forever be remembered for his exemplary commitment to patient care and for his dedicated involvement with the hospital's Medical Board and the training of our residents and fellows. To his family, friends and loved ones, we extend heartfelt condolences. Kenneth L. Davis, MD CEO and President Mount Sinai Health System Harris M. Nagler, MD President, Beth Israel Martin S. Karpeh, Jr., MD Chairman, Dept. of Surgery Beth Israel

HENICK--Murray, 88, passed away peacefully at home in Boca Raton, surrounded by his loved ones on January 9, 2014, from complications of Parkinson's disease. Beloved husband of Rhoda for 63 years; father and father-in-law of Alan (Adrienne), Jeffrey (Olga) and Janet (Eduard); grandfather of Matthew, Zachary, Alixandra, Daniel, Andrew, Amanda, Stefan and April. After serving in the Navy during WWII, Murray graduated from NYU and began his business career. A true entrepreneur, his career successes included Chairman of Western Carpet for many years, importer and parking garage operator. Favorite pastimes included racehorse owner, gin rummy and spending time with his grandchildren. Ambitious, yet humble, he will be forever missed. A private graveside service will be held on January 12. Donations in his memory can be made to: South Palm Beach County Chapter, National Parkinson Foundation, P.O. Box 880145, Boca Raton, FL 33488

FREUND--Seelig, longtime resident of Manhattan and surgeon at Beth Israel Hospital in New York, died peacefully of old age on January 8. He was 101 and lived in Palo Alto, CA. Son of immigrant parents from Russia, he graduated from the Heights campus of NYU in 1933 and NYU Medical School in 1937. He served as Chief Medical Officer on the Queen Mary during World War II, which had been converted into a troop transport ship, crossing the Atlantic 44 times and achieving the rank of Lieutenant Colonel. He was in private practice for more than 40 years thereafter at Beth Israel and other hospitals in Manhattan. His beloved wife Charmian died in 2002. He is survived by daughter Deborah Freund of Claremont, CA, her husband Tom Kniesner and grandson William Kniesner; and son John Freund of Atherton, CA, his wife Linda Grais and grandsons Alexander and Nicholas Freund.

GERSTMANN--Kurt, M.D.,passed away January 9. He is survived by his beloved wife, Sandra Lerner, his children Evan and Laurie Gerstmann, Elan and Carol Gerstmann, his stepchildren Jeff and Debbie Gross, and Cliff Gross, his grandchildren, Issac and Sam, Collette and Lila Gerstmann, David, Alexis, Jordan, Ricki and Scott Gross. A memorial service will be held at the Plaza Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, Sunday, January 12, at 1pm.

GOLDENBERG--Arthur, DDS passed away on January 4th at age 83. Born December 14, 1930 in New Rochelle, endodontist in White Plains, 52 years. Served the Army Dental Corps in Japan 1954-56, later with Harvard University, etc., Chairman Emeritus of Sydenham Hospital. Enjoyed photography, had mentors including Ansel Adams. Dental papers were published, juried photographs exhibited, dedicated his life to his family and removing pain from others. Survived by Marc, Karen (Burstin), five grandchildren, one great-grandchild.

HILDES--Libby, beloved wife of Emanuel, mother of Steven and David passed away peacefully on Saturday. She was 89 years old. She was a founding member of The Workmens Circle East Meadow Jewish School and worked all her life for the cause of Jewish education and culture. Funeral services will be held at Gutterman's Funeral Home, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, Long Island (516-921-5757) on Monday, January 13, 4pm. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to the IL Peretz Shule, 575 East Meadow Ave, 11554.

JACKSON--Robert M. Sr.,92, and WWII Navy Veteran, is survived by his wife Ethel, 87; three children, two sisters; two brothers; many grand and great-grandchildren and a host of other relatives and friends.

FAUST--Monroe G.,Died January 9, 2014 age 90. Born in the Bronx to Isidore and Edith. Loving husband for 65 years to Lucie (Haas) Faust. Beloved father of Debbie (David Bacchioni) and Judy (William Hartnett). Adored grandfather of Doug (Krista), Abra, Rebecca Bacchioni and Josie Hartnett. Brother of Leonard. Predeceased by daughter Vicki Faust Dornbusch and sister Florence Weintraub. WWII Army Vet, raised his family in New Rochelle later moved to Bronxville and Lenox. Attended Stuyvesant, NYU, Wharton, Harvard AMP. Longtime executive at William Iselin. He loved the Yankees, the New York Philharmonic, Tanglewood, the Bronx Zoo, Israel, traveling. A kind and wonderful man. Donations to Wildlife Conservation Society or charity of your choice. Borei Pri Hagufen.
KESSLER--Donald P.,age 78, passed on Saturday, December 28, 2013 in Staten Island, NY. Donald is survived by his daughter and granddaughter.

FEINBERG--Arlene. Bone Marrow Registry co-Founder Arlene Feinberg Dies at 81. The Feinberg Family and the Gift of Life Bone Marrow Foundation mourn the loss of the organization's co-founder, Arlene Feinberg. Together with her husband Jack, Arlene was a driving force in the grass roots growth of bone marrow donor registration in the United States and abroad for the benefit of patients suffering from blood cancers. Her pioneering efforts made possible bone marrow transplants for thousands of patients in need. The world is a better place thanks to Arlene Feinberg, a true hero, and her memory will live on through the lives she has saved. Arlene Feinberg is survived by her husband, Jacob, sons Jay, Edward and Steven, daughter-in-law Sheryl, granddaughters Shauna, Michelle and Skylar, and the entire Gift of Life organization she created. She will be missed by her countless friends. Contributions in her memory may be made at www.giftoflife.org.
LIDSKY--Alvin. Beloved husband of Rita. Loving father of Steven (Lisa) and Susan (Scott) Butler. Cherished grandfather of Jake, Owen, Brandon and Ryan.

GRAD--Robert John, 65, of Brewster, NY, died April 17, 2013. He was born January 17, 1948. Bob had many loves: science, music, technology and his friends and family. He was a guitar and auto enthusiast and a huge early fan of the Everly Brothers and Bob Dylan. In his teens, he invented, among other things, an early illuminated Frisbee-type device; designed a primitive lie detector faithfully tested out on a partially willing younger brother, and constructed an elevator device that carried pebbles, hair brushes and turtles outside a seventh floor apartment window facing Arnow Avenue in the Bronx. He went on to create and manage computer systems for IBM and CBS and design software programs, working feverishly for years on a high-speed stock-trade software program before the concept became popular, and came close to putting the final touches on it before the onset of an intestinal disorder that eventually claimed his life. He attended Christopher Columbus High School and the Courant Institute of Mathematical Sciences at NYU. He was predeceased by his father, Zoltan, and is survived by his mother, Fay, of the Bronx; his brother, Peter, of Ridgewood, NJ., cousins, aunts and an extended family of close friends from Kerhonkson to Brewster to Cold Spring, NY.

Freund--Seelig. Very dear valued friend of Doris and mine for over 40 years Like a brother to me throughout our friendship Friend mentor doctor to our entire family. Seelig will be missed deeply by all who knew him and by all his patients whose lives he saved With warmth affection and condolences to his children and grandchildren. Bernard Weiss Wendy Meltzer Cathy Zises Marie Rosen

BINGER--Bronson. The Historic Districts Council mourns the loss of Bronson Binger, our friend, colleague and co-founder. A lively, articulate and extraordinarily capable preservationist; as a neighborhood resident, he helped protect Carnegie Hill; as an activist, he co-founded HDC as a coalition of all of NYC's historic districts; as an architect, he worked to restore beautiful buildings and parks and as a public servant, he saved some of New York's greatest treasures. Our thoughts are with his family and loved ones.

BISSO--Anna, 94, wife of the late Sidney Kerner and David Bisso. Beloved mother of Margaret (Donald) and Amy (David). Stepmother of Michael (Margery) and Susan (Stephen). Adored grandmother of Evan (Kaitlin) and Jessica. Anna was an exhibited mixed-media artist and a founding member of Women in the Arts.

BLAKEMORE--Carolyn. An editor first with J.B. Lippincott and then, until her retirement, with Doubleday, died on December 19 at her home in Manhattan after a long illness. Her age was 81. Carolyn was known for the broad range of her interests, reflected in the writers with whom she worked, such as the prize-winning historian John Toland, the Kennedy-era Washington hostess Susan Mary Alsop and the popular novelist Barbara Taylor Bradford. Carolyn was born on January 15, 1931, in Kennett, Missouri, to Elmo Blakemore, a pharmacist, and Nell Meyers Blakemore, a Latin teacher. She was a graduate of DePauw University, which afforded her a much-treasured experience in her junior year as an exchange student at the University of Stockholm. She is survived by her sister, Barbara Blakemore, of Manhattan.

CRAMER--Adolph B. Jr.,Dolph Cramer of Palm Beach, FL, Southampton, New York and New York City, died peacefully December 19, 2013 from complications of a car accident in October. Born 1927 in New York City to Adolph and Lillian Cramer, Dolph was fourth generation New Yorker whose grandfather was a Tammany Hall politician and developer of parking garages in the 1900s, one of which the family still owns in Manhattan. Dolph attended Hunter Elementary School, Mamaroneck High School and graduated Phi Beta Kappa from Dartmouth College in 1950. Dolph enlisted in the U.S. Navy and served as a radar operator on a destroyer escort during World War II. He worked in the mining business serving as the marketing director for the Bolivian Tin Company, resident in LaPaz Bolivia. On returning to the US he was founding president of Shamrock Metals in New York City, a subsidiary of Transamine S.A., a European metals and trading company, and acted as agent for the Swiss Gold Refinery in Neuchatel, Switzerland. On retiring from the metals business, Dolph joined Gruppo Levey, a boutique investment bank, advising catalog companies. An avid skier, Dolph learned to ski at Dartmouth and was an original stockholder of Sugarbush and of Ski Club 10 in Warren, Vermont. He earned his million foot suit from Canadian Mountain Holidays helicopter skiing in Canada. He was founder of the Green Mountain Tomato War. Dolph had ski houses in Warren, Vermont and Edwards, Colorado. A longtime resident of Southampton, New York, Dolph loved his garden at Post Crossing, croquet and tennis at the Meadow Club of Southampton, where he chaired the Croquet Committee and the annual Meadow Club Croquet Invitational Tournament, sailing his 19 foot Cape Dory Typhoon from the Breakwater Yacht Club in Sag Harbor, the Fourth of July Parades, and lunches on the porch at Shinnecock Hills Golf Club. Most of all, Dolph loved driving his Model T Fords. He bought his first Lizzie in 1947, and in 2009 he drove that Lizzie cross country in the Ocean to Ocean in a Model T, recreating the first cross country race in 1909 won by Henry Ford's Model T. He participated in tours in Vermont, Nantucket, Pennsylvania and was looking forward to a Connecticut tour in 2014. Dolph moved to Palm Beach in 2005, and drove his Model T in the Centennial parade, to the Everglades Club, the Beach Club, the Old Guard Society and the National Croquet Club and was a former director of the Croquet Foundation of America. A poet, Dolph's collected works, "Rhymes", were published in 1996. Dolph is survived by his wife of 30 years, Beatty Page Cramer, his cockapoo, Dixie, his in-laws Ferrell and Chi McClean of Hobe Sound, FL, Vail, Colorado and Locust Valley, NY, and his niece Ferrell Page McClean and nephew William Chichester McClean IV. In lieu of flowers, donations honoring Dolph may be sent to the Foxcroft School, PO Box 5555, 22407 Foxhound Lane, Middleburg, VA 20118. A Memorial Service will be held on Sunday, February 2 at 2:00pm at Holy Trinity Episcopal Church, 211 Trinity Place at Flagler Drive, in West Palm Beach, FL 33401. A service honoring Dolph will be held in Southampton in June. Services by Quattlebaum Funeral Home 561-832-5171.

EISNER--Nathaniel, 93, passed peacefully on January 5. Beloved husband of Frances; father of Susan, Wendy, and Mark; father-in-law of Tricia; grandfather of four. Gifted mathematician, brilliant mind, and aficionado of life's many dimensions from sports to politics. His joie de vivre, courage, optimism, smile, and dedication to family remain inspirational. He defied the odds through sheer determination to live life to its fullest and best. He epitomized "The Impossible Dream," and shall be deeply missed. Graveside services January 9 at Sharon Gardens. Contributions in his memory may be made to www.childrenshealthfund.org.

CORDICE--Dr. John W. V. John W. V. Cordice, Jr.,MD, F.A.C.S, was born on June 16, 1919 in Aurora, North Carolina, to John W. V. Cordice Sr., M.D., and Pearl (Hollingsworth) Cordice. John W. V. Cordice died on December 29, 2013, in Sioux City, IA, surrounded by the loving affection of his family. He is survived by his adoring wife of 65 years Marguerite, his three daughters, Michele (George) Boykin (Sioux City, IA), Jocelyn Basnett (Washington D.C.), Marguerite D. Cordice (Flushing, N.Y.), sister Marion Parham (Norfolk, VA), three grand children, six great-grandchildren and many nieces and nephews. The press has largely reported on his historic role as a surgeon saving MLK's life in 1958. This however was just one day in an extraordinary life journey: Doctor for the Tuskegee Airmen (Captain), he participated in the first open-heart surgery in France, was actively involved with Marguerite in the Civil rights movement, and had an exceptional career as a physician and surgeon. His family remembers him for his life of service to the community, his dedication to his work and patients, and above all for his love for life and family. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to: The United Negro College Fund, Doctors without Borders and National Medical Fellowship.

AUMULLER--Alycia K.,died after a long struggle with cancer on January 6, 2014. She was born on November 13, 1952 to Marie Fernino Aumuller and Charles Aumuller in Brooklyn. She graduated from John Adams High School in Queens and attended Hunter College. She was a talented and tireless casting director for over 30 years and a life long lover of the arts. But most importantly, Alycia's spirit was contagious and she loved life and embraced the people in it. She embodied all those characteristics that made her the best: loyalty, courage, perseverance, generosity and warm-heartedness. Family and friends mourn her loss and extend deepest condolences to Frederick Walcott. Alycia leaves us with many smiles, laughter and fond memories. Services will be held on January 14, 2014 at All Faith Cemetery in Queens at 11am. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Sloan Kettering Cancer Center in her name.

BARAKA--Amiri, The American Academy of Arts and Letters notes with sorrow the death of our distinguished colleague. He was a leader in the Black Arts movement 50 years ago; of his reputation as a controversial voice then, he later described himself as a "revolutionary optimist."

COAR--Richard, Died peacefully at his home in Roanoke, VA, on December 29, 2013. He was 92. During his career, Coar's technical insight and management expertise contributed greatly to advances in aerospace propulsion. Richard John Coar was born in Hanover, NH, on May 2, 1921. He grew up in Hanover and in Kingston, MA, near Boston. As a boy, he worked in the local cranberry bogs, and declared years later that he pursued his engineering studies so vigorously because he never wanted to pick cranberries again. An outstanding student in high school, Coar won a four year scholarship to Tufts University's engineering school. He was awarded his Bachelor's degree in Mechanical Engineering summa cum laude in 1942. He was a member of Tau Beta Pi, the national engineering honor society, equivalent to Phi Beta Kappa for the humanities. Before his final year at Tufts, Coar had been a summer intern in the engineering department at Pratt & Whitney Aircraft, in East Hartford, CT. After he was graduated, he returned as a full-time test engineer, with his initial assignments supporting the company's manufacturing activities for engines powering the majority of the military aircraft flown by the United States in World War II. After the War, Coar began a steady rise in responsibilities with Pratt & Whitney, and later with United Technologies Corporation, P&W's parent company. He was one of the key individuals who led Pratt & Whitney into gas turbine engine design and development, and was involved with every major P&W engine program. In 1956 he became the Chief Engineer at the Florida Research and Development Center in West Palm Beach, FL, which was the company's space and military engine organization. He had technical responsibility for the design and development of advanced propulsion systems, including the J58 Mach 3+ turbojet for the SR-71 "Blackbird" airplane, the pioneering RL-10 hydrogen-fueled rocket engine, high pressure rocket research, and the initial development of the jet engines powering many of the country's frontline military aircraft. In 1971, he was made a vice president and returned to Connecticut. He was responsible for commercial as well as military engine development, and oversaw the introduction of the powerful turbofan engines that made jumbo jets possible and revolutionized commercial air travel. In 1976 he became the executive vice president, and in 1983 he was named president of Pratt & Whitney. In 1984, Coar became the executive vice president of United Technologies. He retired in 1986. Coar had many lifelong interests and avocations, including golf and fine music. His family and colleagues marveled at his collection of orchestral recordings - and the audio equipment he used for listening to it. He became a dedicated sailor, and remarked after his first year with his own sailboat that he'd learned more about subsonic aerodynamics than he had in the previous 30 years. Coar was elected to the National Academy of Engineering, was a member of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers, and a distinguished life member of the American Society for Metals. He served on the National Research Council's Aeronautics and Space Engineering Board. Additional honors include the Society of Automotive Engineers' Franklin W. Kolk Air Transportation Award in 1985 and the American Society of Mechanical Engineers' prestigious George Westinghouse Gold Medal in 1986. He received the Daniel Guggenheim Medal in 1998 for notable achievement in the advancement of aeronautics. He held more than a dozen patents. Coar was predeceased by his wife Cecilie Berle in 1971, and by his wife Lucille Hicks in 2013. He is survived by his son Gregory, of San Diego, CA; his daughter Candace, of Roanoke, VA; his daughter Andrea Tittle, of Pittsburg, CA; his son Kenneth, of Raleigh, NC; and his brother Roger, of Redondo Beach, CA.

CAMPBELL--Esther Francis, Esther Francis Campbell of Southampton, New York, died January 2, 2014. She was born to Dr. Carl Bennison Campbell and Emma Frances Shaffer in Puritan Mines, West Virginia, on February 15, 1924. "Estee", as she preferred to be addressed, was valedictorian of the class of 1940 at Seton Hill Academy in Greensburg, Pennsylvania, graduating at the age of 16. She attended Allegheny College in Meadville, Pennsylvania, for two years before transferring to Penn State University to study journalism. At Penn State Estee met Charles Bishop Scarborough, Jr., of Scranton, Pennsylvania, whom she married in 1943 as he was training to fly B-17 bombers in World War II. They were divorced in 1954. Her second husband was Richard Gilliam Peabody of Kansas City, Missouri. Estee was an accomplished writer and actress, co-founding The Footlight Players in 1950, a theater company in Coshocton, Ohio, where she performed leading roles and wrote the playbills, setting the stage for two significant "firsts" in her professional life. Estee was Kansas City, Missouri's first female weathercaster, broadcasting on KCMO-TV, and was the first female critic for Daily Variety in Los Angeles, working with the redoubtable Army Archerd. She was a publicist for the movie industry until her retirement in 1991. Estee loved words. She was a strict and ruthless grammarian armed with a formidable vocabulary and biting wit. In retirement she began her days by doing the New York Times crossword puzzle in ink in twenty minutes, then venturing out to augment her income playing Bridge. Estee's youngest child, Cynthia Ellen Scarborough, preceded her in death, as did her only sibling, Mary Lois Summer. She is survived by two sons, Charles Bishop Scarborough III and Jeffrey Campbell Scarborough, two daughters-in-law, Ellen Ward Scarborough and Alice Hoppe Scarborough, seven grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. A memorial service will be conducted by Reverend Peter Larsen on January 18, 2014, at two o'clock at St. John's Episcopal Church in Southampton, New York. It is Estee's wish that in lieu of flowers, donations be made to the Animal Rescue Fund of the Hamptons.

DeSILVER--Claire Brandler. Widow of George Burnham DeSilver, died peacefully at home in Northford, CT on December 28, 2013. Born Claire Brandler in New York City in 1925, she spent most of her adult life in Manhattan and Connecticut and many of her later years in Naples, FL. After attending the Universities of Iowa and Wisconsin, Claire's desire for social justice drew her to work as a labor organizer in several cities and as journalist, contributor, and editor for numerous publications. She later had her own design business in Connecticut and New York and was a retired member of American Society of Interior Decorators. In a life rich with service to her community, Claire was notably a former president of the Greenwich Village Homeowners Association, 1966-67, achieving landmark status for three blocks there, and in 1995, founder and past president of the Pelican Bay Mangrove Action Group (Naples, FL). Claire is survived by her daughter, Susan DeSilver, her granddaughter, Margaret DeSilver Bleicher, and three great-grandchildren. She was preceded in death by her beloved son, George Steven DeSilver, Margaret's father. Claire was a passionate supporter of the arts, wildlife and the environment and maintained a lifelong commitment to human and civil rights. She will be remembered for her deep intelligence, generosity, and her ability to organize disparate interests for common good. Memorial contributions may be made to Amnesty International.

ARAKAWA--Madeline Gins, (born 1941), acclaimed American artist-architect, poet and thinker, passed away on January 8, 2014 in New York City. She spent the last five decades with her creative partner and husband, artist-architect Arakawa (1936-2010) constructing literary, artistic and architectural works. They searched for ways to extend the capacities of the body in its architectural surrounds with the aim of prolonging human life. Madeline designed two Reversible Destiny Healing Fun Houses in the three years that followed Arakawa's death in 2010. Together with the team at the Reversible Destiny Foundation she designed and constructed the Biotopological Scale-Juggling Escalator for Rei Kawakubo's Dover Street Market New York. A month ago she completed the book Alive Forever Not If But When that she began with Arakawa. The research and practice of Gins and Arakawa will be carried forward by the Reversible Destiny Foundation in New York and Tokyo.

BARTRAM--J. Burr, Jr.,died peacefully on December 24, 2013 at the age of 79. Survived by wife Barbara Hart Bartram, and sister Nina Bartram Griswold. Son of J. Burr Bartram and Mary (Sheppard) Bartram (Deceased). Born in NYC July 12, 1934. He attended Choate School in Wallingford, CT. He served in the US Navy from 19531955. An active member and Trustee of Indian Harbor Yacht Club, while residing in Greenwich, CT until 1976. Joe resided in Marion, MA. From 1976-1996. He was a resident of Middletown, RI from 19962001. In 2001, he relocated to Fort Lauderdale, FL. Member of the New York Yacht Club since 1955, where he served on the Race, House and Membership committees. Co-manager of the 1974 COURAGEOUS Syndicate, which successfully defended the America's Cup. He was a NYYC Trustee from 1994-1997. Joe started his yacht brokerage career with Northrop and Johnson, where he attained the position of Vice President and General Manager of the Stamford, CT office. In 1997, with his late partner Bruce R. Brakenhoff, the yacht brokerage firm of Bartram & Brakenhoff was formed, in Greenwich, CT. Between 1980 and 1985 a second office opened in Newport, Rhode Island. This location became the principal office, and the Connecticut office was closed. Bartram & Brakenhoff was sold in 1998, and Joe continued to work with his clients and the company until shortly before his death. In lieu of flowers, cash contributions are encouraged to the Carpenters Boat Shop, 440 Old County Road, Pemaquid, ME 04558. Attn: Robert Ives or Lahey Clinic, 41 Mall Road, Burlington, MA 01805. A Memorial Service will be held in Ft. Lauderdale, Florida, and an additional Service in Greenwich, CT. Dates to be announced later.

ARAKAWA--Madeline Gins, died January 8, 2014 as a result of cancer. She was born in New York City in 1941 to her beloved parents Milton and Evelyn Gins. Her husband, partner, and co-muse, the artist-architect Arakawa preceded her in death. She is survived by her brother Stephen Gins and his wife Susan who was like a sister to her. She is held in cherished memory by her cousins, her extended family, by her many friends throughout the world and by her staff and close comrades at the Reversible Destiny Foundation. She graduated from Barnard College where her artistic talents began to bloom. Studying at the Brooklyn Museum College of Art she met and fell in love with Arakawa whose vision of the role of art in the world and of the excitement of creating meshed perfectly with her own. They were like one person and two strong personalities at the same time, sharing ideas, painting, writing and creating unique architectural structures as their work evolved over many years together. The day of her memorial service will be announced in the near future.

BERNER--Joan Caryl Rosenthal, died peacefully at home in Santa Fe, NM, January 9, 2014 at the age of 87. A devoted champion of social justice and human rights, she was the loving heartbeat of our family. Born August 3, 1926 in New York City, she is survived by loving partner Patricia Romer, sons Fred Berner (Liz Manne), Paul Berner (Jackie Frederick-Berner) and Marc Berner, grandsons Michael (Ilana) Sackler-Berner, Benjamin and Theodore Berner, granddaughter Laura (Bill) Tancredi, three great-grandchildren, and brothers-in-law Gene Scott (Jan) Romer and Philip (Kathy) Romer. Pre-deceased by dear friend Lotte Kunstler. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Human Rights Campaign (hrc.org) and Southern Poverty Law Center (splcenter.org).

DOHERTY--Thomas Joseph Doherty, of Hobe Sound, FL, Nahant, MA, and Flathead Lake, MT, January 6, 2014, Thomas Joseph Jr., age 80, retired President and CEO Merrill Lynch Specialists, Inc., husband of 57 years to Carol (Conroy) Doherty, father of William J. Doherty, MD, and his wife Kelly MacCarty Doherty, and their children Matthew C. Doherty and Liam J. Doherty, of Andover; John J. Doherty and his wife Deborah Saba Doherty, of Media, PA, and their children LT Sean Doherty, USN, and his wife Magdelena, of Seabeck, WA, Megan Doherty, of Washington, DC, and Carolyn Doherty, of Durham, NC; the late Robert J. Doherty and his wife Julia Martin Doherty, of Millersville, MD, and their children Conor Doherty and Maeve Doherty; and Susan Gelber and her husband Matthew Gelber and their children Kaitlin and Margaret, of Littleton, CO; brother of Frances Eileen (Doherty) Haskins and her late husband William, of West Palm Beach, FL., uncle of Margaret O'Connell, of Methuen. Funeral was held on Friday January 10, 2014. Services were handled by the Solimine Funeral Home 67 Ocean St. (RTE1A), Lynn. Donations may be made to Massachusetts General Hospital Cancer Center 55 Fruit St. Boston, MA 02114. Directions and guestbook at www.solimine.com.

DOWDLE--William Q.,90, of Sarasota, FL and Oswego, NY. Beloved husband of Betty J. Loving father of William R., Elizabeth Roller and her husband Kenneth, James M. and his wife Katherine. Loving Pop of Brian W., Megan M., DPT, Patrick S. and Caroline L. Dowdle. A loving, kind and gentle soul. He will be greatly missed. Memorials to St. Jude Children's Hospital appreciated.

ANDER--Julian, on January 10, 2014. Loving husband of Sylvia. Donations in Julian's name may be made to Doctor's Without Borders. Funeral Service Monday, 11:15am at "The Riverside," Amsterdam Ave and 76th Street.

Corrections appearing in print on January 12, 2014.
Jahiem Spruill, 17, was charged with murdering Iquan Williams, who was heading home from a birthday party when he was shot in the head.
Florian Homm, a German arrested after five years in hiding, will make a final appeal against extradition to the Italian justice ministry, citing ill health.
Jon Ludwig Hammer and Radoslaw Wojtaszek have sharpened their game after serving as seconds at the World Chess Championship last fall.
France’s highest administrative court upheld a ban on a show by the comedian, Dieudonné M’Bala M’Bala, in Tours, days after it was also banned in Nantes.

RABINOWITZ--Ann Hoch Kubie, 85, died peacefully at home in Greenwich Village in the early evening of January 11, 2014. She was attended throughout her last, brief illness by her loving and grateful children and grandchildren, by her beloved caregiver, Sabrina Vasquez, and by the music of John Dowland, William Byrd, and Orlando Gibbons. She was predeceased by her much-loved husband of nearly fifty years, Bernard Rabinowitz, of Nutley, New Jersey; by her brother Robert Hoch Kubie, and by her step-brother John Jacob Benjamin. Annie was born in London in 1928 while her father, the distinguished neurologist and psychiatrist Lawrence S. Kubie, MD, D.Sc., was conducting research at Guy's Hospital. With her mother, Susan Hoch Kubie, a pioneering gerontologist, lay analyst, photographer and interior designer, she lived in New York, Vienna and Lucerne before returning to the United States in 1936 and resuming residence in New York City with her father and her brother, and, later, with her step-mother Eleanor Gottheil Kubie. Annie was educated at the Horace Mann and Fieldston Schools, and at Radcliffe College and Barnard College (BA 1950). She later pursued graduate studies at New York University, where she took her MA in 1982 and was ABD in Medieval History. Upon her marriage in 1948 to Bernard Rabinowitz she moved for a year to Fair Lawn, New Jersey, and in 1950 to Nutley, where she lived until the death of her husband Bernard in 1996. Through her marriage she became a loving and engaged member of the extensive Rabinowitz-Sonenshein-Blumrosen-Pepkowitz clan of Nutley, Passaic and Clifton, establishing warm and life-long relationships with her extensive network of in-laws, nieces and nephews. She was a published poet, and the author of two novels, Knight on Horseback (Atheneum 1987) and Bethie (Atheneum 1989). Annie was at work on two additional books at the time of her death: a children's book about family life in a family which had lost a child to illness, and an adult novel about a feminist awakening in the New York psychiatric community of the 1940's. Annie was an enthusiastic amateur musician and a lover of early and Baroque music. She was a singer and a lutenist, and one of her greatest pleasures in later years was her lute studies with the well-known teacher and early music specialist Patrick O'Brien. She was a committed member of the St. George's Choral Society, and a cheerfully vociferous advocate within that group for performances of the music of Johann Sebastian Bach. During the nearly fifty years that she lived in Nutley, Annie was a community leader and a committed public servant, serving with distinction on the Boards of the Nutley Family Service Bureau, the Nutley Public Library and Planned Parenthood of New Jersey, and as an elected (and re-elected) member of the Nutley Board of Education. The friendships she made and preserved in her public endeavors were a sustaining element in her life. She was a proud and committed progressive Democrat. She is survived by her children, Daniel Lawrence Rabinowitz and his wife, Ann Freda Thomas (of Greenwich Village); Rebecca Susan Rabinowitz (of Delran, NJ); Sarah Judith Rabinowitz Mognoni and her husband Russell Mognoni (of Labrador Hill Farm, Waterford Works, NJ); and John Benjamin Rabinowitz (of Arlington, MA). She is also survived by much-loved grandchildren: Joshua Nachowitz and his wife Meghan Sheehan (of Brooklyn, NY); Caleb Lawrence Thomas Rabinowitz and his fiancee Lisa Walldez (of Santa Monica, CA); Samuel Dwight Thomas Rabinowitz (of San Francisco, CA); and Elizabeth Mognoni (of Waterford Works, NJ). There will be a Memorial Service for Annie on Tuesday, January 14th, 2014, at 10:45am. The Memorial Service will be held at the Greenwich Village Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker Street (between 6th Avenue and MacDougal Street), New York, New York, 10012. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in Annie's honor to Selfhelp Community Services, Inc., NY, NY; to the St. George's Choral Society, NY, NY; or to the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund, Inc., NY NY.

SHARON--Hon Ariel.The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn with profound sadness the loss of Ariel Sharon, esteemed former prime minister of the State of Israel. Respected and admired for his historic leadership, Ariel Sharon shaped the destiny of the Jewish state over seven decades, serving his country as a bold military and political leader. A lifelong defender of the State of Israel, Sharon forged a vision -- and labored to actualize it -- of a secure Israel at peace with its neighbors. Sharon was also a deeply committed advocate of the Jewish people, mindful of the meaningful bonds between the State of Israel and the Jewish community throughout the world. His efforts to build bridges of mutual understanding and ingather endangered Jews were a testament to his devotion to Klal Yisrael. We extend our deepest sympathies to the Sharon family, to the people of Israel, and to all who mourn this great loss. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; John S. Ruskay, Executive Vice President and CEO

STOCK--Cooper Dean. On January 10, 2014 Cooper Dean Stock, beloved son of Dana Lerner and Dr. Richard Stock, was tragically killed in a vehicular accident near his home on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. He was just nine years old. Cooper was a spirited third grader who attended the Calhoun School. Cooper had a larger than life personality and will be massively missed by everyone who knew him. Cooper loved to play basketball and avidly followed the Knicks. Cooper was a statistic machine when it came to the Knicks. Everyone marveled at what he knew. He was also a fan of the New York Yankees and classic rock 'n' roll. Cooper was the life of the party even when there wasn't a party. He was light, he was reflective, he was beauty in motion, he was charismatic, he has been described as an old soul and wise beyond his years. In addition to his parents he is survived by: sister Gianna, a more loving older sister never existed; grandmother Ronnie Lerner of University Heights, OH; grandmother Nadine Stock of NYC; uncle Barron, aunt Cathy and cousins Ben and Nina Lerner of Hastings-on-Hudson; uncle Matt and aunt Irina and cousins Dennis, Willy and Maxim Stock of NYC; uncle Wayne, aunt Melina and cousin Robert Stock of New Jersey. Cooper was lovingly looked after by Judy Campbell who was like a second mother to him. Cooper was predeceased by both of his grandfathers: Dr. Phillip Lerner and Robert Stock. Cooper will live in our hearts forever. We will never understand why we had to say goodbye so soon. Services will be held on Monday, January 13th at 11:45 at Riverside Memorial Chapel on 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, kindly send donations in Cooper's memory to Temple Beth Shalom, 740 North Broadway, Hastings-on-Hudson, NY 10706. The family will decide which charities to send the donations to at a later date.

MELTZER--Gloria, born January 27, 1932, died on January 2, 2014 in Rockaway Park, New York. She was 81. A former teacher, Gloria Meltzer's parents were Abraham Meltzer and Mary Cohen of New Rochelle, New York. Her three brothers, Harold, James, and Robert Meltzer pre-deceased her. Gloria is survived by her niece Eleanor Meltzer of Austin, TX, and great-niece Jasmine Goodsaid; and by her nephew Abraham Meltzer of Glendale, CA, and great-niece Rose Meltzer and great-nephew Maxwell Meltzer.
STEINER--Robert, I will remember all the good times we had together. My condolences to his family. Jack Stievelman and Doris Taxin
COHEN--Eileen S. Every birthday is special, but today is extra special. Happy birthday with love and admiration.

LUSK--George B.,The Board and staff of Blythedale Children's Hospital mourn the passing of our dear friend George B. Lusk. George was an active member of our Board of Trustees for more than 30 years. He was a former Board Chair, and served on many hospital committees. George was a passionate advocate for helping children with complex medical needs. He was an ardent supporter of Blythedale's mission. George was a kind and wonderful person. We will miss our dear friend greatly. Owen D. Gutfreund Chair, Board of Trustees Larry Levine President & CEO

He was also a brother, a brother-in-law, uncle, nephew and friend to many. Alex was the quintessential New Yorker. With his vast collection of Americana objects, he was a chronicler of the past and a visionary of the future. He will be sorely missed. Rest in peace, Alex. Aunt Pat

DOBBS--Leonard, peacefully at home on January 12, 2014. Beloved father of Loren, Candy and Rochelle, with his former wife Gloria. Dear brother of Fred and the late Irving, devoted uncle, and loving companion of Linda Steinberg. Service Tuesday, January 14, 2014, 12:45 pm at "The Riverside" 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave.

GREEN--Mary Jane (Mimi) Hogan, passed away on January 7, 2014 after suffering a stroke. Mimi was born in 1937 in Chadds Ford, PA and attended Pembroke College in Brown University, graduating in 1959 with a degree in art history. She was a winner of the annual Mademoiselle magazine's Guest Editor Competition in 1958 and was hired to work in sales promotion and was assistant to Leo Lerman at Mademoiselle following college. Mimi moved to Random House in 1965, ultimately being promoted to Managing Director of Trade Sales Promotion. After receiving a diagnosis of multiple sclerosis she retired from Random House in 1991 and divided her time between New York City and Sanibel Island, FL. Mimi was divorced. She will be greatly missed by all who knew her.

FREUND--Seelig, longtime resident of Manhattan and surgeon at Beth Israel Hospital in New York, died peacefully of old age on January 8. He was 101 and lived in Palo Alto, CA. Son of immigrant parents from Russia, he graduated from the Heights campus of NYU in 1933 and NYU Medical School in 1937. He served as Chief Medical Officer on the Queen Mary during World War II, which had been converted into a troop transport ship, crossing the Atlantic 44 times and achieving the rank of Lieutenant Colonel. He was in private practice for more than 40 years thereafter at Beth Israel and other hospitals in Manhattan. His beloved wife Charmian died in 2002. He is survived by daughter Deborah Freund of Claremont, CA, her husband Tom Kniesner and grandson William Kniesner; and son John Freund of Atherton, CA, his wife Linda Grais and grandsons Alexander and Nicholas Freund.
FEINBERG--Frank, Our beloved Uncle Frank will be greatly missed. He was a great man. Tara, Hunter, Holden, Landon, Piper and Walker Lipton.

LUSK--George B.,92, of White Plains and Dunewood, Fire Island, passed away peacefully Friday evening surrounded by his loving family. Born in Brooklyn, New York to Jack and Frances Lusk, he was the beloved husband of the late Ruth R. Lusk, cherished father of Jack (Jane Herzog), Lawrence (Marcia), Bill (Barbara Nusbaum) and Jim (Eileen). Adored grandfather to Becky, Emmy, Zachary, Madeline, Zoe, Isabelle, Darian, Sterling and Peyton. George was the president and owner of Westmail Press, a company he ran for over 50 years. He was a pillar of the Westchester community, serving as President at his beloved Congregation Kol Ami, Blythdale Children's Hospital, The White Plains Board of Education, Southern Westchester BOCES and the Westchester Children's Association. Having attended Bucknell University, George went on to serve in the U.S. Army during World War II. An avid reader, perfect gentleman, a generous and kind man who will be missed by the many friends and family including his large Israeli family who adored him. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to either Congregation Kol Ami or Blythdale Children's Hospital.

KARDON--Dr. Stephen B.,of Scarsdale, NY, on January 12, 2014, at age 70, of cancer. Loving son of Annette Kardon and the late Leonard Kardon. Beloved husband of Ellen (Kaplan) Kardon of Scarsdale, NY and Weston, MA. Devoted father of David (Karen), Brian (Tali), and Aaron (Lisa). Adoring grandfather of Jason, Jeremy, Rivka and Alyssa; Yair, Noah and Alex; Louis, Maya and Shayna. Loving brother of Nancy (Joe) Peters, Peter (Dee Ella), and James (Nancy). Avuncular uncle and step-father. Predeceased by late wife, Dr. Nataline (Berman) Kardon. A graduate of Dartmouth College and Albert Einstein College of Medicine, he was a radiologist at Lincoln Hospital, Bronx, NY, for over 30 years and a long-time member of Young Israel of Scarsdale. He served as a Major in the US Air Force. Member of Willow Ridge Country Club, Harrison, NY, and Belmont Country Club, Belmont, MA. Energetic, witty and warm, he will be deeply missed. In lieu of flowers, give to the fight to promote Paronomasia. Services will be held at 1pm on Monday, January 13, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 W Broad St, Mt Vernon, NY.

BINGER--Bronson. The Historic Districts Council mourns the loss of Bronson Binger, our friend, colleague and co-founder. A lively, articulate and extraordinarily capable preservationist; as a neighborhood resident, he helped protect Carnegie Hill; as an activist, he co-founded HDC as a coalition of all of NYC's historic districts; as an architect, he worked to restore beautiful buildings and parks and as a public servant, he saved some of New York's greatest treasures. Our thoughts are with his family and loved ones.

ANDER--Julian, on January 10, 2014. Loving husband of Sylvia. Donations in Julian's name may be made to Doctor's Without Borders. Funeral Service Monday, 11:15am at "The Riverside," Amsterdam Ave and 76th Street.

ARAKAWA--Madeline Gins, died January 8, 2014 as a result of cancer. She was born in New York City in 1941 to her beloved parents Milton and Evelyn Gins. Her husband, partner, and co-muse, the artist-architect Arakawa preceded her in death. She is survived by her brother Stephen Gins and his wife Susan who was like a sister to her. She is held in cherished memory by her cousins, her extended family, by her many friends throughout the world and by her staff and close comrades at the Reversible Destiny Foundation. She graduated from Barnard College where her artistic talents began to bloom. Studying at the Brooklyn Museum College of Art she met and fell in love with Arakawa whose vision of the role of art in the world and of the excitement of creating meshed perfectly with her own. They were like one person and two strong personalities at the same time, sharing ideas, painting, writing and creating unique architectural structures as their work evolved over many years together. The day of her memorial service will be announced in the near future.

ARAKAWA--Madeline Gins, (born 1941), acclaimed American artist-architect, poet and thinker, passed away on January 8, 2014 in New York City. She spent the last five decades with her creative partner and husband, artist-architect Arakawa (1936-2010) constructing literary, artistic and architectural works. They searched for ways to extend the capacities of the body in its architectural surrounds with the aim of prolonging human life. Madeline designed two Reversible Destiny Healing Fun Houses in the three years that followed Arakawa's death in 2010. Together with the team at the Reversible Destiny Foundation she designed and constructed the Biotopological Scale-Juggling Escalator for Rei Kawakubo's Dover Street Market New York. A month ago she completed the book Alive Forever Not If But When that she began with Arakawa. The research and practice of Gins and Arakawa will be carried forward by the Reversible Destiny Foundation in New York and Tokyo.

TRAUB--Margaret "Peggy." New York, NY, January 13, 2014 Earlier today, the home decor industry lost a great innovator, leader and friend. Adesso mourns the loss of their President and CEO, Peggy Traub, after a long valiant battle with cancer. Peggy started Adesso with business partner, Lee Schaak, in 1994, and built a successful company in lighting and ready-to-assemble furniture. In addition to being a recognized industry leader, Peggy was big believer in the power and benefits of networking. In 1997, she co-founded WithIt, Women in the Home Industries Today, a national trade organization that serves the needs of professional women in the home furnishings industry. She was also a member of the Women Presidents' Organization, the Women's Leadership Board at Harvard's Kennedy School of Government, the Committee of 200 and the advisory board of KIDS (Kids in Distressed Situations). Traub earned a BA from Harvard and resided in Brooklyn Heights with her partner Phyllis Dicker. Together Peggy and Phyllis have sponsored the Traub-Dicker Rainbow Scholarship for several years, which annually awards scholarship funds to worthy college students. Peggy will be greatly missed by the Adesso family. Funeral services will be held tomorrow, January 14, 2014, 2:00pm, Plaza Jewish Memorial Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue at 91st Street, NY, NY 10024, 212-769-4400. Donations may be made in honor of Margaret "Peggy" Traub to: Congregation Beth Simchat Torah or to the LGBT Community Center of New York.
COHEN--Eileen S. Every birthday is special, but today is extra special. Happy birthday with love and admiration.

SHARON--Ariel. The State of Israel and the World Jewish Community have lost a steadfast leader and defender who dedicated his life to ensuring that future generations will not know the suffering, deprivation, and tragedy that was visited upon his brothers and sisters in the past. Likud USA Joel E. Abramson, President Dr. Heskel M. Haddad, Chairman

ROSE--Stephen, on January 12, 2014. Graduate of South Side High School, Rockville Centre, NY, 1958 and Boston University 1962. ROTC, Second Lieutenant. Retired OTC trader for Singer & Mackie for over 30 years. Survived by loved ones, sister, Linda Rose Iennaco, daughters Lisa, Rose-Charlesworth, Laurie Rose-Hershey, son-in-law Stephen Hershey and grandson Harry Charlesworth. Services Wednesday 11:30am at "The Riverside" 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to woundedwarrierproject.org.

SHEAR--Alex, suddenly and tragically left us. He and his insatiable passion for life will be so greatly missed. Survived by sons William and Andrew and brother Ted. In lei of flowers, donations may be made to NAMI.org. Services Tuesday, 2:00pm at "The Riverside," 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

TRAUB--Margaret A. (Peggy), beloved spouse, daughter, sister, aunt, friend and mentor to many, passed away January 13, 2014 peacefully at her home at the age of 55. Peggy is survived by her loving spouse Phyllis Dicker, her mother Lee Traub (Marvin, deceased), her brothers Andrew (Lois) and James (Buffy), her brother-in-law Larry Dicker (Shelly), and her nieces and nephews. Peggy was an industry leader in lighting and home decor as a co-founder and president of Adesso. She was a believer in the powers of networking and mentoring, particularly in support of professional and business women. In 1997 she co-founded Withlt, Women in the Home Industries Today. Peggy was a dedicated member of the Women Presidents' Organization, the Women's Leadership Board at Harvard's Kennedy School of Government, and the Committee of 200. A 1980 graduate and devoted alumna of Harvard College, Peggy and her spouse cosponsored a scholarship for female college students. Peggy was a supporter of GLAAD and passionate about empowering the LGBT community. Peggy was an active member of Congregation Beit Simchat Torah. Peggy was respected, admired and loved by all whose lives were enriched by her presence. Services Tuesday January 14 at 2:00pm, Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, NYC. The family has requested that in lieu of flowers, donations should be made to Congregation Beit Simchat Torah or the LGBT Community Center of New York. May her name be for a blessing.
NADLER--Allen. Loyal Friend, Wise Advisor, a Founding Director of Media Judaica, and respected community leader. Rabbi Jonathan D. Levine
BISHOP--Franklin "Jerry", January 14, 1996 Still sorely missed. -Evelyn

SHARON--Ariel. American Friends of The Hebrew University and The Hebrew University of Jerusalem mourn the passing of former Israeli Prime Minister Ariel "Arik" Sharon, a soldier, statesman, and one of Israel's great leaders. Among the last of Israel's founding fathers, Ariel Sharon was an alumnus of The Hebrew University. Ariel Sharon dedicated his life to Israel and played a central role in the fight for the country's security. We extend our deepest sympathies to Prime Minister Sharon's family, and to the people of Israel. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. American Friends of The Hebrew University Michael S. Kurtz, Chairman Daniel I. Schlessinger, President Peter T. Willner, National Executive Director

PETERSEN--Betsy Stilwell, 84, of Wilmington, DE, formerly of Darien, CT, died peacefully at home on January 7. Born in Indianapolis to Harold and Gay (Hutchings) Taylor, she was later adopted by her mother's second husband Abner Stilwell. She attended the Latin School of Chicago and graduated from Smith College in 1951. She worked as a researcher for Leo Burnett Company, Time and Fortune magazines, and Sylvia Porter; as Editor of the Magazine of Wall Street; and as a freelance writer and editor for an array of periodicals, books, and corporate clients including Xerox Corporation. For 30 years she was Senior Contributing Editor for Boardroom Reports. She was also active as President of the Smith Club of New York, Treasurer of the New York Junior League, and committee member of the Winter Antiques Show, whose catalogue she edited for many years. On the centennial of the Darien Library in 1994, she wrote a book-length history, So Many Friends. Her many longtime friends and loving relatives will miss her generous spirit and lively mind. Married to Bruce R. Petersen (later divorced), she is survived by a son, Stephen (Lauren), of Hockessin, DE, and two grandchildren, Miles and Stella. Her son David predeceased her, as did her sister Sally Anderson. Private burial will be at Putnam Cemetery, Greenwich, CT. A memorial service will be held Saturday, February 1, at 11:00am at the Noroton Presbyterian Church, 2011 Post Rd., Darien, CT. Memorial contributions may be made to Latin School of Chicago or Smith College.

NEWMARK--Harold L.,on January 11, 2014; born July 21, 1918. Advanced developer, Hoffmann- La Roche Inc., later cancer researcher. Beloved husband of Phyllis, father of Jonathan, Robin, Ellen, Dale and Janet. Service at 11:30 Tuesday, January 14, at Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vauxhall Rd., Union, NJ.

WIEDER--Ethel, age 96, died peacefully at home on January 10, 2014. Born February 15, 1917. Longtime resident of 301 E 63rd Street. Retired from Saatchi & Saatchi in 1977 after a long career as an advertising executive at Saatchi, Compton, the Biow Company, and other agencies. Dedicated volunteer for the New York City Ballet. The center of her life was her family, the children and grandchildren of her late brothers Joseph Wieder, Jack Wieder, and Harry Veeder, and of her late sister Victoria Wieder. No detail of their lives could escape her focused attention. She was the last of her kind, and really the only one of her kind. Memorial gathering on Thursday, January 16, at 11:30am at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W 76th Street, New York.

RABINOWITZ--Ann Hoch Kubie, 85, died peacefully at home in Greenwich Village in the early evening of January 11, 2014. She was attended throughout her last, brief illness by her loving and grateful children and grandchildren, by her beloved caregiver, Sabrina Vasquez, and by the music of John Dowland, William Byrd, and Orlando Gibbons. She was predeceased by her much-loved husband of nearly fifty years, Bernard Rabinowitz, of Nutley, New Jersey; by her brother Robert Hoch Kubie, and by her step-brother John Jacob Benjamin. Annie was born in London in 1928 while her father, the distinguished neurologist and psychiatrist Lawrence S. Kubie, MD, D.Sc., was conducting research at Guy's Hospital. With her mother, Susan Hoch Kubie, a pioneering gerontologist, lay analyst, photographer and interior designer, she lived in New York, Vienna and Lucerne before returning to the United States in 1936 and resuming residence in New York City with her father and her brother, and, later, with her step-mother Eleanor Gottheil Kubie. Annie was educated at the Horace Mann and Fieldston Schools, and at Radcliffe College and Barnard College (BA 1950). She later pursued graduate studies at New York University, where she took her MA in 1982 and was ABD in Medieval History. Upon her marriage in 1948 to Bernard Rabinowitz she moved for a year to Fair Lawn, New Jersey, and in 1950 to Nutley, where she lived until the death of her husband Bernard in 1996. Through her marriage she became a loving and engaged member of the extensive Rabinowitz-Sonenshein-Blumrosen-Pepkowitz clan of Nutley, Passaic and Clifton, establishing warm and life-long relationships with her extensive network of in-laws, nieces and nephews. She was a published poet, and the author of two novels, Knight on Horseback (Atheneum 1987) and Bethie (Atheneum 1989). Annie was at work on two additional books at the time of her death: a children's book about family life in a family which had lost a child to illness, and an adult novel about a feminist awakening in the New York psychiatric community of the 1940's. Annie was an enthusiastic amateur musician and a lover of early and Baroque music. She was a singer and a lutenist, and one of her greatest pleasures in later years was her lute studies with the well-known teacher and early music specialist Patrick O'Brien. She was a committed member of the St. George's Choral Society, and a cheerfully vociferous advocate within that group for performances of the music of Johann Sebastian Bach. During the nearly fifty years that she lived in Nutley, Annie was a community leader and a committed public servant, serving with distinction on the Boards of the Nutley Family Service Bureau, the Nutley Public Library and Planned Parenthood of New Jersey, and as an elected (and re-elected) member of the Nutley Board of Education. The friendships she made and preserved in her public endeavors were a sustaining element in her life. She was a proud and committed progressive Democrat. She is survived by her children, Daniel Lawrence Rabinowitz and his wife, Ann Freda Thomas (of Greenwich Village); Rebecca Susan Rabinowitz (of Delran, NJ); Sarah Judith Rabinowitz Mognoni and her husband Russell Mognoni (of Labrador Hill Farm, Waterford Works, NJ); and John Benjamin Rabinowitz (of Arlington, MA). She is also survived by much-loved grandchildren: Joshua Nachowitz and his wife Meghan Sheehan (of Brooklyn, NY); Caleb Lawrence Thomas Rabinowitz and his fiancee Lisa Walldez (of Santa Monica, CA); Samuel Dwight Thomas Rabinowitz (of San Francisco, CA); and Elizabeth Mognoni (of Waterford Works, NJ). There will be a Memorial Service for Annie on Tuesday, January 14th, 2014, at 10:45am. The Memorial Service will be held at the Greenwich Village Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker Street (between 6th Avenue and MacDougal Street), New York, New York, 10012. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in Annie's honor to Selfhelp Community Services, Inc., NY, NY; to the St. George's Choral Society, NY, NY; or to the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund, Inc., NY NY.

RONSON--Gertrude (Trudy), passed away January 11, 2014 peacefully at her home at the age of 87. Beloved wife of the late Morton, the love of her life. Survived by her brother Frank Saul, and sons Chuck, Joseph and David and six grandchildren Hannah, Dillon, Forrest, Peter, Tara and Daniel. She loved to read, bake and spend time with her family. She will be missed by all. Service: Tuesday, January 14 at 11:30am at Riverside Memorial Chapel. Interment at Arlington National Cemetery to be announced.

SCHNABEL--Morris, The members of Department of Surgery mourn the loss of Mr. Morris Schnabel beloved father of Dr. Freya Schnabel and Mrs. Roberta Rappaport. We extend our deepest condolences to Dr. Schnabel, Mrs. Rappaport and their family on their loss. H. Leon Pachter M.D. F.A.C.S The George David Stewart Professor and Chair Department of Surgery NYU School of Medicine

SHERIFF--Nancy, (nee Erlanger) Passed away at age 90 on Friday, January 10, 2014. She was born on May, 21, 1923 in Manhattan and lived her whole life in the city except for five years in Portland, Maine when she was married to the late Saul Sheriff. Nancy will be fondly remembered by all who knew her for her love of family, the stock market, animals, the Knicks and the Yankees and being a New Yorker. Nancy was a hat model in the 1940s and was a beloved 35 year volunteer at Memorial Sloan Kettering Hospital, where she delivered flowers. Nancy is survived by her sons Robert and Alan, her daughters-in-law Karen and Fifi, as well as her grandchildren Stephen, Andrew, Daniel and Laura. She is also survived by a son Joel. As per Nancy's wishes there will not be a funeral service. Donations can be made to the ASPCA, New York.

TOMASHOFF--Helen, on January 13, 2014. Beloved wife of the late David. Devoted mother of Jamie and Glen and mother-in-law of Vicky and Elise. Loving grandmother of Lawrence, Chelsy, Rory, Jonathan, Grant, Kelli and Alex. Graveside service Tuesday, January 14, 2014, 2:00pm at New Montefiore Cemetery.

LAGER--Stanley, on January 10th, 2014. Beloved husband of Elaine. Loving father of Valerie and Michael. Dear brother of Robert. Cherished grandfather of David and Ross. A friend, a mentor, a mensch. During his 56 years at the company he founded, he touched the lives of so many through his advice, his candor, and his friendship. He so enjoyed offering his counsel to those reaching out, and he, a true student of the "Old School," always offered opportunity to those who looked him in the eye and shook his hand.

MARGOLIS--William, on January 13, 2014 of Boca Raton, FL. Master salesman who rose to become president of the BVD Corporation, subsequently founding Main Line Fashions, which he built into a garment industry institution. Beloved husband of the late Ruth (Kurlansky) and the late Harriet (Freeman). Loving father of Carol Lipskar and Eliezer Margolis. Cherished grandfather of Simon, Aaron, Max and Emil. Dear brother of the late Samuel, Frances, Nathan and Edith, and son of the late Lena and Max Margolis. Graveside services at Sharon Memorial Park, 42 Dedham St., Sharon, on Wednesday, January 15 at 12:45pm. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the National Multiple Sclerosis Society.

KINDER--William F.,a former Director at the management consulting firm McKinsey & Co. in a career spanning four decades, died on Wednesday, January 8 in Oakland, California. He was 82. His son Bill confirmed the death, which came suddenly after a five year bout with Alzheimer's disease. Mr. Kinder was born in Providence, Rhode Island on February 19, 1931, the son of Mildred Fearney and Harold Kinder. He grew up in Waynesboro, Virginia and was educated at Northfield Mount Hermon, Brown University (cum laude, Phi Beta Kappa), and Harvard Business School. He enjoyed stints as a radio announcer and Top-Forty disc jockey for stations such as WTON, WEAN, WHIM between 1950-52. Mr. Kinder served as a Lieutenant in the Navy during the Korean conflict, contributing to the deployment of long range missile detection systems on the Distant Early Warning Line near the Arctic Circle. He married Mary Anne Johnson of Waynesboro in 1956. Their daughter Pam was born in 1957 while Mr. Kinder was stationed in San Diego, California. The family moved to Darien, Connecticut, after Mr. Kinder joined McKinsey & Co.'s New York Office in 1958. Son Bill was born in 1963 in Stamford. Mr. Kinder helped build up the consulting firm's practice in Los Angeles after moving there in 1969. He led numerous consulting engagements with eminent corporate clients in a range of industries including media, automotive, and finance. He was instrumental in building the consulting company's widely respected insurance practice. But he is remembered there most for his unflinching integrity, generous mentorship, contagiously positive attitude and mischievous sense of humor. He retired from McKinsey in 1991, and moved with Mary Anne to Savannah, Georgia to enjoy boating, golf, and southern hospitality. Mary Anne passed away in 2002. In addition to Pam and Bill, Mr. Kinder is survived by his sister Carolyn Carr of Washington, D.C. and six thriving grandchildren: Emily, Matthew, and Charlotte Pik of Darien; and Henry, Jackson and Phoebe Kinder of Berkeley, California. In lieu of flowers, the family is requesting that donations be made to the Cure Alzheimer's Fund at www.curealz.

LEIBOWITZ--Sandra (Sperling), passed away on January 13, 2014. She was a life-long resident of New York City. She is survived by her husband of fifty-one years, Harold, her mother, Esther Sperling of Brooklyn, her children, Lisa and Burton Wisotsky, and Jonas and Rebecca Leibowitz, and her sister, Myra Lajoie. She will be missed by her eight grandchildren: Shira, Rachel, Seth, Daniel, and Josh Wisotsky, and Nina, Arthur, and Ryan Leibowitz. Sandra was a teacher for over thirty years, primarily at Public School 247 in Brooklyn, where she "never had a bad day." Private funeral services will be held graveside. Shiva information will be available from Lincoln Square Synagogue at www.lss.org/shiva

LEVINE--Julian, A proud American who loved life, family, friends, acquaintances, he died peacefully at home, age 97. Loving husband of Helen Perelson, his wife of forty-two "wonderful" years. Loving brother of Harold and brother-in-law of Beatrice Levine, both deceased. Cherished brother-in-law of Ruth and Sam Perelson. Beloved uncle of Barbara Levine Rubin and Dr. Jeff Rubin, Lois and Stewart Perelson Gross, Lila and Keith Adwar. Truly "Great" uncle of Hannah, Sarah and Ben Gross, Mikaela and Julia Adwar. Born in Mt. Vernon, NY, he was the son of Frances and "Sam" owners of Pop's Taxi. He lived his 94 years to the fullest until a heart attack felled him in 2011. His joy of exploring new horizons in education and travel was exemplified during his 31 year association with The College at 60 of Fordham University which he joined post retirement from the women's ready-to-wear garment industry. Enlisting in the U.S. Army in 1942, he served with distinction In the SE Asia Command. Promoted to the rank of sergeant, he was cleared by the FBI for courier assignments and code work in China. Outstanding events in his memory were serving with British Commander Lord Louis Mountbatten in the first convoy driving the Burma Road. He was an invitee to Mme Chiang's 100th birthday party at Alice Tully Hall. Selected among the Jewish GIs featured by The Museum of Jewish Heritage program honoring "American Jews in the Second World War," he was the recipient of the following medals: American Campaign, WWII Victory, Asiatic-Pacific Campaign, Good Conduct. A long-time member of Congregation Rodeph Sholam, NYC, he co-starred In many of its theatrical productions. He was a 32nd degree Mason/ Shriner, member of Mt. Masada and Mecca Temples. We will sorely miss his buoyant spirit, love, devotion, and boisterous singing of "Dayenu." Donations in Julian's memory may be made to Congregation Rodeph Sholom, NYC in honor of Gina and Rabbi Robert Levine. Private graveside service with military honors was held.

LEVINE--Julian. Congregation Rodeph Sholom mourns the death of our devoted member, Julian Levine, beloved husband of Helen Levine. The Levine's have been members of our synagogue for close to 40 years and Julian will be sorely missed. Our deepest sympathy is extended to all their dear ones. Robert N. Levine, D.D., Senior Rabbi Karen L. Berman, President

KAPLAN--Linda Z.,57, passed away in Hospice from cancer in Boca Raton, FL. Linda is survived by her son, Nathaniel Jay Kaplan, daughter-in-law Candice Knowles, grandson Noah Israel, her mother Elaine Zelin and her ex-husband Paul.

DOBBS--Leonard, of New York City, died peacefully at home on January 12, 2014. Born in Brooklyn, New York to the late Sophie and Morris Dubrowsky in 1932. Beloved father of Loren, Candice and Rochelle with his former wife Gloria Dobbs. Dear brother of Fred Dubrowsky and the late Irving Dubrowsky, as well as loving uncle to many nieces and nephews. Devoted companion of Linda Steinberg of New York City. Leonard graduated from New York University's School of Commerce, Beta Gamma Sigma, in 1953. He went on to faithfully serve as a lieutenant in the United States Naval Armed Forces during the Korean War. His career started in advertising at the firm Doyle Dane Bernbach where he was a creative director and managed the account for the exclusive Ohrbach's department store. Subsequently, he was hired by the Ohrbach's family, where he was elevated to the position of Executive Vice President responsible for real estate development. His great expertise in real estate and shopping centers led him to the Taubman Realty Group where he joined as a partner in the late 70's. Some of the most notable projects in which he was involved include Queens Center Mall, Stamford Town Center and The Mall at Short Hills. Leonard's love for art led him to travel the world where he sponsored many talented, growing artists, including Dale Chihuly. He became an expert and avid collector of glass art and traveled as a guest of Chihuly to Israel in 2000 for a unique exhibition at the Tower of David Museum in Jerusalem. Leonard was a gifted, creative and courageous soul with a deep passion for life, nature, art, and all things beautiful. He was also a brilliant writer of poems. Below is an excerpt from a favorite poem by the poet William Penn: "They that love beyond the world cannot be separated from it. Death cannot kill what never dies. Nor can spirits ever be divided, that love and live in the same divine principle, the root and record of their friendship. If absence be not death, neither is theirs. Death is but crossing the world, as friends do the seas; they live in one another still". In lieu of flowers, donations can be given to Stand Up To Cancer at www.standup2cancer.org.

FEINBERG--Frank, The Officers, Board of Governors, The Women's Group, Members and Staff of The Muttontown Club mourn the passing of our beloved member, Frank Feinberg, and extend our sincerest condolences to his wife Mildred Feinberg and family. Robert Sherman, President

FISHER--Harvey G.,a retired insurance broker and long-time amateur radio enthusiast, has passed away at the age of 83. Funeral services are to be held at the Riverside Nassau-North Chapel at 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY at 1:30pm on Tuesday, January 14. Harvey is survived by his three children, Allyn, Leslie and Cynthia and five grandchildren. His wife of 60 years, Shirley L. Fisher, passed away last year. Shiva will be observed at Harvey's home at 30 Wheeler Avenue, Albertson, New York.
KARPOFF--Lillian, 93, died peacefully Saturday at home. Beloved wife of Nathan, mother of Sid and Marilyn, grandmother of Marissa and Hilary. She will always be remembered and loved.

DOBBS--Leonard, we are saddened by the loss of our life long friend who enthusiastically shared with us his love of the arts, joy of travel and excitement of Madison Square Garden. He was the consummate New Yorker. Judy Singer, Joanne and Haskell Klaristenfeld and Daniel Nelson

MERK--Theresa Figueira, MD. Born August 16, 1930 died January 9, 2014. Wife of the late Harvey Merk, MD. Visitation Wednesday January 15, 4 to 9pm at Court St. Funeral Home, 230 Court St. Brooklyn. Mass Thursday 10am at St. Charles Borromeo Brooklyn.

FEINBERG--Frank. The staff and trustees of the North Shore-LIJ Health System and Glen Cove Hospital mourn the loss of Frank Feinberg, a long-time benefactor. His dedication and leadership knew no boundaries. Thanks to the generosity of Frank and his wife Mildred, Glen Cove Hospital was able to modernize its facility to provide the highest level of quality care to critically ill patients. In recognition of the Feinbergs' support, the hospital was renamed Glen Cove Hospital, the Mildred and Frank Feinberg campus. Concerned about returning service men and women who served their country in Iraq and Afghanistan, Frank and Mildred generously supported the Unified Behavioral Health Center for Military Veterans and their Families in Bay Shore, NY, operated jointly by the Veterans Administration and Zucker Hillside Hospital. In addition, the Feinbergs' gifts helped fund medical research on Alzheimer's Disease and chronic lymphocytic leukemia. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Mildred, son Benedict and his wife Mary, daughter Janet Sluszka and her husband Michael, brother Herbert, and grandchildren Alexander and Elizabeth. Richard D. Goldstein, Chairman, Board of Trustees Michael J. Dowling, President & CEO North Shore-LIJ Health System

LIEBERMAN--Helen S.,of Port St. Lucie. Beloved mother of Jeffrey, Lawrence and Norma, Abram and Rachel, Shari and Frank Franco. Cherished grandmother of John, Michael, Heather and Lynne. Loving great-grandmother of four. Services: Wednesday 10am at Parkside Chapels, 2576 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, NY.

COSTA--William Albert, Sr.,the former Commissioner of Public Works for New Rochelle, died Saturday at Montefiore Hospital in New York. He was 88. Costa, a civil engineer, was Commissioner of Public Works for New Rochelle from 1971 until his retirement in 1992. Born in the Bronx in 1925, he was a graduate of Dewitt Clinton High School, class of 1943, and Manhattan College, class of 1950. Costa served in the Army Air Force from 1943 to 1946, and was a squadron navigator on a B-29 bomber. He flew 22 missions over Japan, held the rank of First Lieutenant, and was awarded the Distinguished Flying Cross with Oak Leaf Cluster, the Air Medal with two Oak Leaf Clusters, and the Purple Heart. Costa leaves his wife of 63 years, Lida (Draghi), and three children, Barbara and husband Eric Stange, of Arlington, MA; a son, Michael and wife Claudia of Armonk, NY; and William, Jr. of Medford, MA. In addition he leaves four grandchildren, Michael, Cristina, Alexander Stange and Mia Stange. A wake will be held at the George T. Davis Funeral Home, 14 Lecount Place, New Rochelle, on Tuesday, January 14, from 3-7pm. A funeral service will be held on Wednesday, January 15, at 10am, followed by cremation at Ferncliff Cemetery in Hartsdale. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Salvation Army.

CORCORAN--Christopher, 57, of New York City, well-known interior designer, passed away on December 19, 2013 in Cambridge, MA after a valiant battle with glioblastoma. Loving son of the late Thomas J. and Helen (Shedd) Corcoran. Beloved brother of Thomas J. (Beth) Corcoran, Sarah (Kevin) Connolly, Neil (Linda) Corcoran, Nancy (Charles) Ronchetti and Norine (Dustin) Black. Adored uncle and cherished friend. Services were held in Cambridge, MA. Donations may be made in his memory to Elizabeth Evarts deRham Hospice, 65 Chilton St., Cambridge, MA 02138.
CORCORAN--Christopher. We are devastated by the loss of our funny, talented, great-hearted friend. We see you in our home every day. You are in our hearts always. Lesley Dormen and Quentin Spector

BERRY--Rynn, Jr.,68, of Brooklyn, New York, writer and authority on vegetarian history, died of complications from cardiac arrest while jogging in Prospect Park on December 29. After undergraduate and graduate studies at the University of Pennsylvania and Columbia, he made his life's work to promote public awareness of vegetarianism and animal rights. His step-mother Nancy W. Berry and half-brothers Charles and Peter Berry join Rynn's co-author and close friend Chris Abreu-Suzuki PhD and the entire vegetarian community in mourning the passing of a brilliant intellect and thoughtful and caring spirit. Donations in Rynn's memory may be made to the Sea Shepherd Conservation Society (www.seashepherd.org), the North American Vegetarian Society (www.navs-online.org) or the Physicians Committee for Responsible Medicine (www.pcrm.org).

BERGENFIELD--Bert, on January 12, 2014. Beloved husband of Norma for 65 years, devoted father of Caren and Glenn and father-in-law of Steven and Sarah. Adoring grandfather of Emily and David, Alexandra and James, Rachel, Hannah, Harry, Tabitha, Phoebe and Eliot. He was also beloved by other family and friends. Co-trustee of the S.M.L. Simon Charitable Trust. Service Tuesday, January 14, 2014, 12:30pm at Cedar Park Cemetery. Contributions in his memory may be made to the New York Philharmonic.

BRAZILL--William R, passed on January 11th at age 87. Raised in Astoria, NY he served 37 years at the New York Port Authority as Resident Civil Engineer, participating in the growth of JFK and LGA airports. He is survived by his loving wife of 56 years, Marjorie, his seven children and six grandchildren. A devout Catholic, dedicated family man and leader, he left an impression on all. Wake at Donahue Cecere Funeral Home January 15th, 2-4pm/7-9pm, 290 Post Ave. Westbury, NY 11590. Funeral Mass at Saint Bridid's RC Church, January 16th, 11am. Burial to follow at Holy Rood Cemetery (next to Church).
