Television highlights.
An appeals court upheld the conviction and life sentence of a Nigerian man who tried to blow up a Detroit-bound airliner with a bomb in his underwear in 2009.

Gov. Chris Christie’s State of the State address on Tuesday comes days after his last turn at the podium, when he accepted responsibility for his staff’s role in closing traffic lanes on the George Washington Bridge.
Brian VanGorder, the Jets’ linebackers coach, was hired as Notre Dame’s defensive coordinator.
Mr. Pastor, an aide under President Jimmy Carter, shepherded the 1977 Panama Canal treaties and was punished for it years later, when conservatives defeated his nomination to be an ambassador.
Jack Johnson’s power-play goal with 2 minutes 38 seconds left lifted host Columbus past Tampa Bay, 3-2.
Connecticut defeated Baylor, ending the Lady Bears’ national-best, 69-game home winning streak Monday night.

MUSSMAN--Martin, at home on January 13, 2014. Proudly served the Veteran's Administration over 40 years. Beloved husband of Lillian; devoted father of Laurie and John Reische; adored grandfather of Griffin and Danielle. He will be in our hearts forever.

RABINOWITZ--Ann Hoch Kubie, 85, died peacefully at home in Greenwich Village in the early evening of January 11, 2014. She was attended throughout her last, brief illness by her loving and grateful children and grandchildren, by her beloved caregiver, Sabrina Vasquez, and by the music of John Dowland, William Byrd, and Orlando Gibbons. She was predeceased by her much-loved husband of nearly fifty years, Bernard Rabinowitz, of Nutley, New Jersey; by her brother Robert Hoch Kubie, and by her step-brother John Jacob Benjamin. Annie was born in London in 1928 while her father, the distinguished neurologist and psychiatrist Lawrence S. Kubie, MD, D.Sc., was conducting research at Guy's Hospital. With her mother, Susan Hoch Kubie, a pioneering gerontologist, lay analyst, photographer and interior designer, she lived in New York, Vienna and Lucerne before returning to the United States in 1936 and resuming residence in New York City with her father and her brother, and, later, with her step-mother Eleanor Gottheil Kubie. Annie was educated at the Horace Mann and Fieldston Schools, and at Radcliffe College and Barnard College (BA 1950). She later pursued graduate studies at New York University, where she took her MA in 1982 and was ABD in Medieval History. Upon her marriage in 1948 to Bernard Rabinowitz she moved for a year to Fair Lawn, New Jersey, and in 1950 to Nutley, where she lived until the death of her husband Bernard in 1996. Through her marriage she became a loving and engaged member of the extensive Rabinowitz-Sonenshein-Blumrosen-Pepkowitz clan of Nutley, Passaic and Clifton, establishing warm and life-long relationships with her extensive network of in-laws, nieces and nephews. She was a published poet, and the author of two novels, Knight on Horseback (Atheneum 1987) and Bethie (Atheneum 1989). Annie was at work on two additional books at the time of her death: a children's book about family life in a family which had lost a child to illness, and an adult novel about a feminist awakening in the New York psychiatric community of the 1940's. Annie was an enthusiastic amateur musician and a lover of early and Baroque music. She was a singer and a lutenist, and one of her greatest pleasures in later years was her lute studies with the well-known teacher and early music specialist Patrick O'Brien. She was a committed member of the St. George's Choral Society, and a cheerfully vociferous advocate within that group for performances of the music of Johann Sebastian Bach. During the nearly fifty years that she lived in Nutley, Annie was a community leader and a committed public servant, serving with distinction on the Boards of the Nutley Family Service Bureau, the Nutley Public Library and Planned Parenthood of New Jersey, and as an elected (and re-elected) member of the Nutley Board of Education. The friendships she made and preserved in her public endeavors were a sustaining element in her life. She was a proud and committed progressive Democrat. She is survived by her children, Daniel Lawrence Rabinowitz and his wife, Ann Freda Thomas (of Greenwich Village); Rebecca Susan Rabinowitz (of Delran, NJ); Sarah Judith Rabinowitz Mognoni and her husband Russell Mognoni (of Labrador Hill Farm, Waterford Works, NJ); and John Benjamin Rabinowitz (of Arlington, MA). She is also survived by much-loved grandchildren: Joshua Nachowitz and his wife Meghan Sheehan (of Brooklyn, NY); Caleb Lawrence Thomas Rabinowitz and his fiancee Lisa Walldez (of Santa Monica, CA); Samuel Dwight Thomas Rabinowitz (of San Francisco, CA); and Elizabeth Mognoni (of Waterford Works, NJ). There will be a Memorial Service for Annie on Tuesday, January 14th, 2014, at 10:45am. The Memorial Service will be held at the Greenwich Village Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker Street (between 6th Avenue and MacDougal Street), New York, New York, 10012. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in Annie's honor to Selfhelp Community Services, Inc., NY, NY; to the St. George's Choral Society, NY, NY; or to the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund, Inc., NY NY.

TRAUB--Peggy, WPO mourns the loss of founding member and beloved sister, Peggy Traub, whose generosity, compassion and commitment to women in business made her a respected role model. Winner of WPO's 2013 President's Award, Peggy will be deeply missed. Marsha Firestone, President and Founder, Women Presidents' Organization

TRAUB--Peggy. We will always remember and admire the determination, optimism, and extraordinary courage which characterized your entire life. You inherited your finest attributes from your wonderful parents, Lee and Marvin, and they were so proud of you. A true battler who triumphed in business, Adesso; a winner in love, Phyllis; and a noble fighter for so long with your head held high against such great odds for so many years. Our love and sympathy to Lee, Phyllis, Jimmy, and Andy. With respect and admiration--Dalia Larry

WIEDER--Ethel, age 96, died peacefully at home on January 10, 2014. Born February 15, 1917. Longtime resident of 301 E 63rd Street. Retired from Saatchi & Saatchi in 1977 after a long career as an advertising executive at Saatchi, Compton, the Biow Company, and other agencies. Dedicated volunteer for the New York City Ballet. The center of her life was her family, the children and grandchildren of her late brothers Joseph Wieder, Jack Wieder, and Harry Veeder, and of her late sister Victoria Wieder. No detail of their lives could escape her focused attention. She was the last of her kind, and really the only one of her kind. Memorial gathering on Thursday, January 16, at 11:30am at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W 76th Street, New York.
KANE--Ellen T. Jan. 15, 1921 - Nov. 22, 2009 Happy Birthday Darling Sister. Remembering the light of my life - your presence is missed every day. Your loving sister, Pearl T. Maxim

PFEIFFER--Anne Shultz, 61, died in Manhattan on Sunday, January 12. Born in Aurora, Illinois, Anne is survived by her mother, Elizabeth Shultz, husband, Paul, her two children, Christof and Kirsten, and granddaughter, Lily. She was predeceased by her sister Mary and brother Nick. A graduate of Southern Methodist University and a Certified Public Accountant, Anne worked for nearly 35 years as a member of the J.P. Morgan real estate finance team. When she retired in October, 2013, she was a Managing Director, head of J.P. Morgan's U.S. Real Estate Commingled Funds and Senior Portfolio Manager of the JPMorgan Strategic Property Fund, which grew to become the largest core real estate fund in the U.S. under her leadership. Anne enjoyed acting as a mentor to young women in finance and business. As an industry leader, she served on the boards of REIS (Real Estate Investment Standards) and NCREIF (National Council of Real Estate Investment Fiduciaries) and as president of NCREIF for several years. Over the last 20 months, Anne privately fought pancreatic cancer with incredible strength and humility, never allowing the disease to prevent her from living her life. Anne was an accomplished cook and had a passion for travel and art. Her family and friends will remember her for her warmth, generosity, dedication to learning, and whimsical spirit. She was a wonderful mother and an inspiration to those who knew her. Her family is having a small, private funeral ceremony, which will be followed by a celebration of life memorial in New York City at a later date. In lieu of flowers, donations in Anne's memory may be made to the New York Common Pantry, The Susan B. Anthony Project, or Women For Women International.

SHMERLER--Edwin of Scarsdale, NY on January 13, 2014 at age 94. Beloved son of the late Ethel (Wolinsky) and Maxwell. Adored husband of almost 60 years of the late Paula. Cherished father of Andrew (Tina), Bill (Susan) and Cindy (Ford Levy). Loving grandfather of Erica (AJ), Bari, Kristen, Max and Harry. Honored brother of Walter (Hannah) and the late Irving and Natalie. Great-grandfather of Owen and Maggie. Born in Mt. Vernon, NY, Edwin moved to Scarsdale in 1935 and graduated from Scarsdale High School in 1938. He was also a proud alumnus of the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania, Class of 1942, where he was president of the Kappa Nu fraternity and a member of the golf team. A World War II veteran, Edwin served in the Navy in the Solomon Islands. He was a 70-year partner at Maxwell Shmerler & Co., the CPA firm founded by his father, and a past president of Fairview Country Club. Funeral services Friday, January 17 at 11:30am at Congregation B'nai Yisrael in Armonk, NY. The family will receive visitors at Cindy and Ford's home 2-5 Friday, 6-9 pm Saturday and 12-4 on Sunday. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions to Surprise Lake Camp, 307 Seventh Avenue, New York, NY 10001 or to the "Paula Shmerler Endowed Fund for Alzheimer's Research" at the CNDR, University of Pennsylvania, 3535 Market Street, Suite 750, Philadelphia, PA 19104.

BRAZILL--William R, passed on January 11th at age 87. Burial to follow at Holy Rood Cemetery (next to Church).

COLLINS--Linda. The School of American Ballet celebrates the life of Linda Collins, a balletomane and generous friend of SAB for 25 years. Together with her husband Arthur, Linda was a regular visitor and champion of the School, attending classes, choreographic debuts, and student Workshop Performances. Countless dance students have been the recipients of her generous named scholarship, and they have gone on to join professional ballet companies around the world. Linda will be greatly missed and remembered by SAB. We send our gratitude, sympathy and condolences to Arthur and her family. Max R. Shulman, Chairman of the Board Peter Martins, Chairman of Faculty Marjorie Van Dercook, Executive Director

VOLKMAR--Isaac. The Abraham Joshua Heschel School community is deeply saddened by the untimely death of Isaac Volkmar, the beloved son of Eve Goldberg and Natan Volkmar, adored brother of alumna Beatrice Volkmar '11, and precious grandson of William (z"l) and Lili Goldberg. SUSSMAN--Simmy. December 3, 1934 - January 16, 2013. Remembered, cherished, loved everyday and forever. Lovingly, Mitzi

SCHWEITZER--Robert David, D.D.S.,age 83, died suddenly in Ft. Lauderdale, FL on January 14, 2014. He was born on April 1, 1930 in New York City to Jerome and Dorothy Schweitzer. He will always be remembered for his kindness, fairness and generosity to family, friends and those in need. He honorably served his profession with passion and fortitude, providing his patients the greatest of care. He was a man of many avocations and interests; however, his most passionate hobby was gardening. He will be greatly missed by his family and many friends. He is survived by his beloved wife Rosa; his brother Jerry; two sons, Robert Jr. and Kenneth (children of Patricia); four grandchildren, Julia, Alexa, Annaliese and Mariella; four stepchildren, Brad, Lisa, Malory and Rod (children of Rosa); and their children, Noah, Mia, Conner and Ryan. Services will be private.

LIKER--Blanche Marcus, age 80, died peacefully on September 18, 2013. She lived most of her life in the same house in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, NY. A proud graduate of Hunter College with a Bachelor of Arts degree, she earned a Master's degree in Education from Brooklyn College. She is survived by her devoted husband Daniel and her three loving children: Dr. Mark Liker of Los Angeles and his two children Jakob and Libby; Kenneth Liker of Staten Island and Melissa Tavel of Westchester County, NY, her husband Barry and their two children Ethan and Mollie. She survived being afflicted by polio as a young woman and despite requiring treatment in an iron lung with a prognosis that she would never walk again, she rebounded and succeeded in walking and, in fact, returning to full function. Her entire career was dedicated to helping children with speech and developmental delay, as a long-standing speech pathologist for NYC Public Schools and then in private practice nearly up until the time of her first stroke in December 2012. She had been a healthy vibrant woman who attended synagogue every week and enjoyed spending time with friends and family. She will always be in our hearts and thoughts. In lieu of flowers please send donations to the Hadassah Organization. "Strength and honor are her clothing, she smiles at the future; she opens her mouth in wisdom, and the lesson of kindness is on her tongue."

SHMERLER--Edwin. The Board of Governors and members of Fairview Country Club note with profound sorrow the passing of our beloved longtime member and past-President Edwin Shmerler. On behalf of all our members we express our deepest sympathy to his sons Andrew and Bill, daughter Cindy, brother Walter, and the entire family. Fredric C. Apter, President Bryna Sweedler, Secretary

SHMERLER--Edwin of Scarsdale, NY on January 13, 2014 at age 94. Beloved son of the late Ethel (Wolinsky) and Maxwell. Adored husband of almost 60 years of the late Paula. Cherished father of Andrew (Tina), Bill (Susan) and Cindy (Ford Levy). Loving grandfather of Erica (AJ), Bari, Kristen, Max and Harry. Honored brother of Walter (Hannah) and the late Irving and Natalie. Great-grandfather of Owen and Maggie. Born in Mt. Vernon, NY, Edwin moved to Scarsdale in 1935 and graduated from Scarsdale High School in 1938. He was also a proud alumnus of the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania, Class of 1942, where he was president of the Kappa Nu fraternity and a member of the golf team. A World War II veteran, Edwin served in the Navy in the Solomon Islands. He was a 70-year partner at Maxwell Shmerler & Co., the CPA firm founded by his father, and a past president of Fairview Country Club. Funeral services Friday, January 17 at 11:30am at Congregation B'nai Yisrael in Armonk, NY. The family will receive visitors at Cindy and Ford's home 2-5 Friday, 6-9 pm Saturday and 12-4 on Sunday. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions to Surprise Lake Camp, 307 Seventh Avenue, New York, NY 10001 or to the "Paula Shmerler Endowed Fund for Alzheimer's Research" at the CNDR, University of Pennsylvania, 3535 Market Street, Suite 750, Philadelphia, PA 19104.

SPERLING--Peter Ridley, of Wellington, Florida died Sunday, January 5, 2014 at the Hospice of Palm Beach County following complications suffered as the result of a serious accident the previous year. Mr. Sperling was born in 1931 in Madison, Wisconsin, the son of the late Jerome Sperling and the late Gertrude Ridley Sperling. His parents soon moved to New Haven, Connecticut where his father began teaching at Yale University and where he spent his youth, attending Worthington Hooker Grade School together with many other "faculty children." He graduated from Phillips Exeter Academy in 1949, Harvard University in 1953, and Yale Law School in 1956, and was a member of the Massachusetts Bar Association. At Yale he founded and was the first Chairman of the Conservative Society of the Law School. Mr. Sperling worked at New England Merchants Bank (now the Bank of New England) as a Trust Officer for nine years until he joined Citibank, N.A. in 1982. During his career at Citibank, he became a Vice President and was also Senior Marketing Director and Deputy Head of the International Private Banking Division until his retirement in 1995. On retirement, he and a close associate, Robbie Meyjes, founded Meyjes-Sperling Associates, a private banking consultancy firm. While residing in Hong Kong in the early 1970's, and for years thereafter, he wrote a monthly financial column for Insight Magazine and spent many hours training Citibank staff in the field of Private Banking. Mr. Sperling is survived by his wife, Edwina W. Van Winkle Sperling of Bedford, NY; his daughter, Ridley Whitehouse Sperling of Pleasantville, NY; and his brother, David Colton Sperling of Nairobi, Kenya.

MENDELWAGER--Jack, 90, died Tuesday, January 14, husband of Lucille Levine for 54 years, beloved father of Greg Mendelwager, Robin Mendelwager, Yolanda Trujillo, and Terri Ginsberg, survived by second wife Phyllis Epstein. Burial at Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge, NJ, Friday, January 17, 10am.

SIMON--Dorothy. We extend our sincerest condolences to Barbara Strom (Milton and children) and the extended Simon Family. Dorothy was a warm and loving mother, grandmother and great- grandmother who was beloved by all who knew her. Susan, Ben and Family

TRAUB--Peggy. We will always remember and admire the determination, optimism, and extraordinary courage which characterized your entire life. A true battler who triumphed in business, Adesso; a winner in love, Phyllis; and a noble fighter for so long with your head held high against such great odds for so many years. Our love and sympathy to Lee, Phyllis, Jimmy, and Andy. With respect and admiration--Dalia Larry

SIMON--Dorothy, 96, on January 15, 2014. Loving mother of Barbara (Milt) and Jerry (Ruby). Predeceased by beloved husband Harry and sons Larry (Roberta) and Donnie. Adored by eleven grandchildren and twelve great-grandchildren. World traveler, award-winning golfer, avid Giants and Yankees fan, but most of all devoted to her family. A true woman of valor, she was deeply loved by everyone. She will be greatly missed and remain in our hearts forever. Services 10am Friday January 17 at Westchester Jewish Center, 175 Rockland Ave., Mamaroneck.

RABINOWITZ--Ann Hoch Kubie, 85, died peacefully at home in Greenwich Village in the early evening of January 11, 2014. She was attended throughout her last, brief illness by her loving and grateful children and grandchildren, by her beloved caregiver, Sabrina Vasquez, and by the music of John Dowland, William Byrd, and Orlando Gibbons. She was predeceased by her much-loved husband of nearly fifty years, Bernard Rabinowitz, of Nutley, New Jersey; by her brother Robert Hoch Kubie, and by her step-brother John Jacob Benjamin. Annie was born in London in 1928 while her father, the distinguished neurologist and psychiatrist Lawrence S. Kubie, MD, D.Sc., was conducting research at Guy's Hospital. With her mother, Susan Hoch Kubie, a pioneering gerontologist, lay analyst, photographer and interior designer, she lived in New York, Vienna and Lucerne before returning to the United States in 1936 and resuming residence in New York City with her father and her brother, and, later, with her step-mother Eleanor Gottheil Kubie. Annie was educated at the Horace Mann and Fieldston Schools, and at Radcliffe College and Barnard College (BA 1950). She later pursued graduate studies at New York University, where she took her MA in 1982 and was ABD in Medieval History. Upon her marriage in 1948 to Bernard Rabinowitz she moved for a year to Fair Lawn, New Jersey, and in 1950 to Nutley, where she lived until the death of her husband Bernard in 1996. Through her marriage she became a loving and engaged member of the extensive Rabinowitz-Sonenshein-Blumrosen-Pepkowitz clan of Nutley, Passaic and Clifton, establishing warm and life-long relationships with her extensive network of in-laws, nieces and nephews. She was a published poet, and the author of two novels, Knight on Horseback (Atheneum 1987) and Bethie (Atheneum 1989). Annie was at work on two additional books at the time of her death: a children's book about family life in a family which had lost a child to illness, and an adult novel about a feminist awakening in the New York psychiatric community of the 1940's. Annie was an enthusiastic amateur musician and a lover of early and Baroque music. She was a singer and a lutenist, and one of her greatest pleasures in later years was her lute studies with the well-known teacher and early music specialist Patrick O'Brien. She was a committed member of the St. George's Choral Society, and a cheerfully vociferous advocate within that group for performances of the music of Johann Sebastian Bach. During the nearly fifty years that she lived in Nutley, Annie was a community leader and a committed public servant, serving with distinction on the Boards of the Nutley Family Service Bureau, the Nutley Public Library and Planned Parenthood of New Jersey, and as an elected (and re-elected) member of the Nutley Board of Education. The friendships she made and preserved in her public endeavors were a sustaining element in her life. She was a proud and committed progressive Democrat. She is survived by her children, Daniel Lawrence Rabinowitz and his wife, Ann Freda Thomas (of Greenwich Village); Rebecca Susan Rabinowitz (of Delran, NJ); Sarah Judith Rabinowitz Mognoni and her husband Russell Mognoni (of Labrador Hill Farm, Waterford Works, NJ); and John Benjamin Rabinowitz (of Arlington, MA). She is also survived by much-loved grandchildren: Joshua Nachowitz and his wife Meghan Sheehan (of Brooklyn, NY); Caleb Lawrence Thomas Rabinowitz and his fiancee Lisa Walldez (of Santa Monica, CA); Samuel Dwight Thomas Rabinowitz (of San Francisco, CA); and Elizabeth Mognoni (of Waterford Works, NJ). There will be a Memorial Service for Annie on Tuesday, January 14th, 2014, at 10:45am. The Memorial Service will be held at the Greenwich Village Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker Street (between 6th Avenue and MacDougal Street), New York, New York, 10012. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in Annie's honor to Selfhelp Community Services, Inc., NY, NY; to the St. George's Choral Society, NY, NY; or to the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund, Inc., NY NY.

TOBIN--Joseph L.,Jr., of Garden City, NY, formerly of Tequesta, FL, passed away peacefully at the age of 89 on January 13, 2014, surrounded by loved ones. Devoted husband of sixty years of the late Helen (nee McMahon), loving father of Joseph III (Susan), Patricia Adelman (Howard), Janet, Brian, Mary Beth Macaluso (Mark), Daniel and the late Mark L. Tobin. Cherished grandfather of Rebecca, Mara and Michael Adelman and Anne Mari and Tara Lynne Macaluso. Proud World War II Navy Veteran having served in Normandy during the D-Day invasion; graduate of Catholic University School of Law Class of '50; partner in the Mineola law firm of Sprague, Stem, Aspland, Dwyer and Tobin; former President of the Nassau County Bar Association and Acting Village Justice of the Village of Hempstead. A true gentleman, be lived his life committed to family, faith and his profession. Reposing Barnes-Sorrentino Funeral Home, 539 Hempstead Ave., W. Hempstead, NY, Thursday 7-9pm and Friday 9-10:30am. Mass 11am Friday at St. Thomas RCC. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Mark L. Tobin Fellowship at Fordham University, 888 Seventh Avenue, NY, NY 10019.

GELLER--Joshua. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Joshua Geller, beloved father of Sheldon Geller. He leaves behind a legacy of exceptional philanthropy and consistent generosity to UJA-Federation. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Joshua's wife, Linda; his children, Judy Geller-Marlowe (Glenn), Brian (Varda), and Sheldon (Mindy); his grandchildren; and the entire family. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; John S. Ruskay, Executive VP & CEO

CLARK--Ida O'Grady, on January 14, 2014. Predeceased by her husband Duncan Clark and his son, James Fenton. She leaves behind Carol (George) McMullen and Duncan W. (Susan) Clark. Loving grandmother of Meredith McMullen Kelly, George McMullen V, Morgan, Caitlin and Eamon McMullen, Stephanie Salinovich, Sarah and Duncan Clark. Also survived by several great-grandchildren. Ida spent many years as Director of Social Services for Methodist Hospital. She proudly received her Masters from Fordham University. Ida served as Vice Chairman of United Hospital Fund, Director and Past President of the American Lung Association of Brooklyn, Vice President of Visiting Nurse Association of Brooklyn. She also served as President and Director of Park Slope Geriatric Day Center as well as the Director of the Bethany Deaconess Society. Ida's interests included but were not limited to, volunteerism; public health affairs; opera; golf and reading. Visitation Friday 2-5 and 7-9pm at The Joseph G. Duffy Funeral Home, 255 9th Street, Brooklyn. Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated Saturday 9:30am at St. Saviour RC Church. Interment to follow at Calvary Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations, in her memory, would be appreciated to: The Fenton Clark Fund at New York Community Trust, 909 3rd Avenue, 22nd floor, NY, NY 10022.

LIFLAND--Burton R. Otterbourg P.C. mourns the passing of our former colleague, friend and mentor at the age of 84. He celebrated the Firm's 100th Anniversary with us and we remember our shared experiences and good times together. An outstanding jurist, he was the former Chief Bankruptcy Judge of the Southern District of New York and later served on senior status. He presided over landmark cases from Johns Manville, Eastern Airlines, and R.H. Macy's to Blockbuster and Bernard Madoff. His knowledge of international bankruptcy was world renowned. Our deepest condolence to his wife, Elaine, his sons, Howard and Craig, and his family. Otterbourg P.C.

GELLER--Joshua. The Geller family is saddened by the loss of our patriarch, Joshua Geller, adoring father, grandfather, and loving husband. He was the past president of the Bayswater Jewish Center in Far Rockaway and of the congregation Beth Sholom in Lawrence, New York. Joshua was also a major supporter and fundraiser for many Jewish institutions, including Israel bonds, the United Jewish Appeal, and Yeshiva Chaim Berlin. He was born in Bayonne, New Jersey in 1925, and with his two brothers created Barlin Knitting Mills, a major textile manufacturing company. He will be lovingly missed by all who knew him. He is predeceased by his wife Mildred, and is survived by his wife Linda, children Judy and Glenn, Brian and Varda, and Sheldon and Mindy, and his many grandchildren. May his life be a loving memory for all.

FILBIN--Dr. Marie T.,Hunter College deeply mourns the passing of Dr. Marie T. Filbin, Distinguished Professor of Biology, on January 15. Dr. Filbin, who came to Hunter in 1990, was an internationally renowned neuroscientist and a beloved professor, who inspired generations of students. She will be greatly missed by all who knew and worked with her. Jennifer J. Raab, President Hunter College Vita Rabinowitz, Provost Hunter College Shirley Raps, Chair Hunter College Department of Biological Sciences

BRICKMAN--Miriam, age 83, died on January 15, 2014 after a courageous battle with lung cancer. Beloved wife of Harvey for 61 years and sister of Mel. Loving mother of Alan, Neal, Bonnie and Mindy. Cherished grandmother of Adam, Noah, Ben, Elly and Nathan. She had a brilliant mind, a compassionate heart, and a wonderful imagination. She was a determined fighter to the very end for herself and for those who could not fight for themselves. She will be missed terribly by her large extended family and many friends. Memorial service to be held on Friday, January 17 at 12:45pm at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th St., NY, NY.
HOFFMAN--Joan Everett. (January 26, 1391 - December 19, 2013). Joan was a graduate of Wellesley College class of 1952 and former warden of St. Thomas Church.

LEVY--Werner, on January 8th. Loving husband of Gabriele (Gaby). Doting father of Vivian and Ron, Michael and Rosalia. Cherished grandfather of Jeffrey, Jason, Andrea, Alexandra and Paul. Beloved bother of Frank. Brother-in-law to Susie, Steve and Elyse. Services Friday 10am at "The Riverside" 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave.

PARNES--Carol, of Boca Raton, FL, passed away peacefully on January 16th 2014 at the age of 85. Carol was a true lady. She was blessed with unique intuition which guided her to always do what was right and good. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate contributions to The Carol Parnes Memorial Fund, C/O Englewood Hospital and Medical Center Foundation, 350 Engle Street, Englewood, NJ 07631.

SHMERLER--Edwin of Scarsdale, NY on January 13, 2014 at age 94. Beloved son of the late Ethel (Wolinsky) and Maxwell. Adored husband of almost 60 years of the late Paula. Cherished father of Andrew (Tina), Bill (Susan) and Cindy (Ford Levy). Loving grandfather of Erica (AJ), Bari, Kristen, Max and Harry. Honored brother of Walter (Hannah) and the late Irving and Natalie. Great-grandfather of Owen and Maggie. Born in Mt. Vernon, NY, Edwin moved to Scarsdale in 1935 and graduated from Scarsdale High School in 1938. He was also a proud alumnus of the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania, Class of 1942, where he was president of the Kappa Nu fraternity and a member of the golf team. A World War II veteran, Edwin served in the Navy in the Solomon Islands. He was a 70-year partner at Maxwell Shmerler & Co., the CPA firm founded by his father, and a past president of Fairview Country Club. Funeral services Friday, January 17 at 11:30am at Congregation B'nai Yisrael in Armonk, NY. The family will receive visitors at Cindy and Ford's home 2-5 Friday, 6-9 pm Saturday and 12-4 on Sunday. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions to Surprise Lake Camp, 307 Seventh Avenue, New York, NY 10001 or to the "Paula Shmerler Endowed Fund for Alzheimer's Research" at the CNDR, University of Pennsylvania, 3535 Market Street, Suite 750, Philadelphia, PA 19104.

PAULIN--Sven M.D. Ph.D. Pioneer of Coronary Angiography, has Died at 87. (October 18, 1926-January 10, 2014) passed away suddenly and unexpectedly at his home on January 10, 2014. One of the pioneers in modern radiology, Dr. Paulin was highly regarded throughout the world for his work by both the radiology and cardiology communities. At the time of his death, he was Professor Emeritus at Harvard Medical School and had been working regularly in the Department of Radiology at the Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center, as he had for almost a half century. He led a full and active life until this death. Dr. Paulin was born in Bad-Muenster am Stein, Germany, and immigrated to Sweden in 1953 where he met his wife, Birgit, a few years later. In 1970 he immigrated with his family to the United States and became an American Citizen in 1979. He loved the personal and academic freedom that the United States provided him and his family. Dr. Paulin was an avid sports enthusiast, dedicated chess player, voracious reader, and art and oyster lover. In 1951, he graduated from the University of Mainz, Germany with a Doctor of Medicine degree. He then received the degree of Medical License from the Karolinska Institute in Stockholm, Sweden in 1958. This was followed some years later by the degree of Medicine Doctor (equivalent to a Ph.D.) from the University of Gothenburg, Sweden. In 1965, Coronary Angiography was a new field when Dr. Paulin, as a doctoral candidate at the University of Gothenburg, published his dissertation on the subject. His doctoral thesis, "Coronary Angiography A Technical, Anatomic and Clinical Study", written 50 years ago, was recognized as a landmark immediately after publication. Coronary angiography, the graphic demonstration of the coronary arteries in the living patient, is one of the most often practiced invasive diagnostic procedures today. His colleagues at Boston's Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center (BIDMC) say that is in large part due to Dr. Paulin himself. Shortly after the publication of the thesis, Dr. Paulin was invited to study at Stanford by Herbert Abrams, M.D. In 1970, Dr. Paulin became Radiologist-in-Chief at Beth Israel Hospital and was awarded a full Professorship in Radiology, at Harvard Medical School, Boston, Massachusetts. In 1974, he was further honored by being the first recipient of an endowed chair in Radiology by the family of Miriam M. Stoneman and retired from this position in 1994. He continued to work in the department until his retirement from medicine on his 87th birthday in 2013. Dr. Paulin is survived by his wife of 57 years, Birgit, and his four children Susanne, Magnus, Helena and Viveca. In addition five grandchildren, Elizabeth Michael, Magnus, Mattias, Axel and his sister Tosca Roeren and several nieces and nephews survive him. Funeral services will be private; a public memorial will be announced at a later date. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Sven Paulin MD Radiology Research Fund. Checks can be mailed to: Trudy Howard, Office of Development, BIDMC, 330 Brookline Avenue, Boston, MA 02215. For gifts via check, make checks payable to "BIDMC." In the memo section, please annotate that the gift is in memory of Dr. Sven Paulin. For gifts via phone/credit card, contact Trudy Howard at 617-667-3393. Additional updates can be found at www.eatonfuneralhomes.com

RAINER--Barbara, 91, passed away at home after a long illness. An accomplished pianist, a teacher at the High School of Music and Art, she played flute and cello with the Westchester Symphony and chamber music with her friends. With her husband, John Rainer, M.D., she traveled the world. Passions included progressive causes, painting, theatre, movies, mysteries, swimming, tennis, dance, banana cream pie and museums, where she would drive everybody to exasperation inspecting each canvas. A lifelong student, she was a fixture at Columbia and Purchase. Above all, Barbara adored her family. She leaves behind loving sons Jeff and Peter, daughter-in-law Iwona, grandchildren Marta, Jeremy and Alex, and her devoted caregiver Mary. Service 11:00am, January 20th at Ballard-Durand Funeral Home, 2 Maple Avenue, White Plains, NY 10601. Charity donations welcomed in lieu of flowers.

He was 70 years old. He is survived by a brother, Hillel Stavis; a sister, Laurel Stavis; two nephews, Steven Harper and Myles Stavis, and a niece, Lily Jane Stavis. Mr. Stavis was a driving force in the opening of the SVA Theater on West 23rd Street. He was consistently rated by his students as one of the school's most popular and beloved professors. For more information about the memorial ceremony, please visit: http://memorialwebsites.legacy.com/genestavismemorial/ homepage.aspx

YOUNG--E. James, of Sao Carlos, ESP, Brazil, formerly of New York City and Ft. Lauderdale, passed away on January 8, 2014 at age 90. Jim served as a Major in the Army during WWII and was a Vice President of The Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States. He had a long, happy and successful career at "Mother Equitable" where he had many friends with whom he maintained close ties long after he retired. Jim had a wonderful wit and during his "hour of charm" he would regale his friends for hours with funny and poignant stories from his childhood in Vincennes, his military service in Europe and his arrival in NYC. He will be missed by his loving long time companion Roberto Seviero, his brother Paul, nephews, nieces and many friends.

CARDIN--Marlene Bunn McGinnis. Died on November 21, 2013 in New York City after an almost 30 year battle with breast cancer. Marlene was a founder and president of Video Fashion Inc. and Fashion News Worldwide Inc., the first continuous international presentation of video programs devoted to the world of fashion. Her interviews with the fashion industry's legendary figures and the presentations of their aesthetic creations are unique. Marlene was born in Johannesburg, South Africa on June 7, 1943 as Yi-Lin Ho Bunn to a Chinese family that had emigrated from Canton, China. Her grandfather was a founder with Mahatma Gandhi, then a practicing attorney in Johannesburg, of one of the first great anti-colonialist human rights movements. Marlene left the racially oppressive apartheid South Africa for Tanzania and Paris before arriving at 20 years of age in New York with $100 and knowing no one. Marlene soon found employment with the United Nations and afterwards began a long association with the advertising genius George Lois and his firm Lois Holland Callaway. She went on to become the founder and creator of Video Fashion and also Video Ordnance Inc., the first popular visual attempt to bring to the general public an understanding of the international weapons industry with all its implications. Marlene was one of the longer survivors of breast cancer and her treatment at Mt. Sinai Hospital in New York by Dr. Steven Gruenstein and his team of associates broke new ground in the treatment of breast cancer. Marlene leaves her brothers Dudley and William Bunn, a sister Sandra, and her mother June, all of Johannesburg, and her husband, Paul Cardin. A funeral Mass was held at St. Vincent Ferrer Church on November 25, 2013. A memorial service is planned.

KLONSKY--Edward (Eddie) Lloyd, 57. Survived by his beloved wife Arlene, loving mother Ruth, sister Karen, many nieces and nephews and his adored pet Gracie. Memorial Services Frank Campbell, 1077 Madison Ave. 81st, Monday, January 20th at 3:30.

WRIGHT--Harriet, an original Copa Girl, recently died on January 10. Born on April 15, 1917, she swam in the 1939 Billy Rose World Famous Aquacade Fair. While there, Jimmy Durante picked her out and took her to the Copacabana where she spent nine months as a Copa Girl. After that, Harriet hitched rides across the country to California where she swam as an aquabelle in Esther Williams' films, including Bathing Beauty and others. She also had bit parts in movies, such as Gene Kelly's Christmas Holiday. While traveling in California, Harriet met her husband, Don Ruffin Tisdall, a US Air Force pilot. He was ordered to go to Cairo, Egypt as an attache to the US Embassy and was later killed in a plane crash. Her son, Clovis Ruffin, was the youngest designer ever to win the Cody award. He designed the original wrapped dress, T-shirts and T-dresses in 1969. Harriet herself designed costumes for Broadway shows and nightclubs, such as Latin Quarter and Copacabana. She was the author of a memoir and autobiography titled "I'd Do it Again." There will be a memorial service in the near future.

MOSKOWITZ--Claire, January 17, 2014, of Jamaica, NY. Wife of the late Isidore "Jerry" Moskowitz. Mother of Richard (Linda) Moskowitz, Eileen Moskowitz and Nancy (Lester) Eisenberg. Also survived by six grandchildren and one great-grandchild. Platt Memorial Chapels, Cherry Hill, NJ.

SPOKOJNY--Dr. Artur M.,passed on January 7, 2014 in Los Angeles, CA after courageously battling cancer. Artur rests in Safed, Israel with his beloved Rav Berg. He is survived by his bereaved and loving family: wife Melissa, daughters Rachael and Miriam. See Sunday New York Times for complete obituary.

TIRELLI--Rose M.,on January 16, 2014. Former Nurse Practitioner at St. Barnabas Hospital, Bronx, NY. Devoted daughter of the late Michael and Mary Tirelli. Dear sister of Alfonsina Rosinsky, Michael, Frank and Vincent Tirelli. Loving sister-in-law of Marguerite. Proud aunt of three nieces and seven nephews. Family will receive friends at Leo F. Kearns Funeral Home, 61-40 Woodhaven Blvd, Rego Park on Monday from 2-5pm and 7-9pm. Funeral: Tuesday, 10:30am. Interment: St. John's Cemetery.

SIEGEL--Alfred, The staff of the Center for Court Innovation deeply mourns the untimely passing of our dear friend and colleague Alfred Siegel. Over his long career in the field of criminal justice from his years as an Assistant District Attorney in the Bronx, to his tenure as deputy commissioner of New York City's Department of Probation, to his work with the Task Force on Transforming New York State's Juvenile Justice System, to his fifteen years here at the Center Alfred worked tirelessly to make New York a better, safer and more just place for all of us. He approached his work with a unique combination of wisdom, humility, generosity, and humor, and his absence leaves a deep hole in our lives. Alfred, the world is a better place because you were in it. You will be truly missed.

ANDERSON--Jon Stephen, beloved husband, father and brother, passed away January 15, 2014 at Rush Hospital in Chicago, from complications of Multiple Myeloma. He was 77 years old. Jon was born to William and Dorothy Anderson on March 13, 1936, on St. Urbain Street, the main drag of Montreal's immigrant district, home to many writers including Saul Bellow and Mordecai Richler. In 1952, he graduated from Westmount High School, sharing with Leonard Cohen an English teacher who taught them both how to "write tight." Inspired by an uncle, Johnny Walsh, a legendary crime reporter in Montreal, he started in journalism by describing contentious town council meetings for the Sackville Tribune-Post while completing a Bachelor of Arts degree (1955) at Mount Allison University. Before graduating from McGill University Law School in 1959, he reported for the Montreal Gazette, covering everything from theater to political riots. In 1960, he became Montreal bureau chief for TIME, an assignment that triggered a Mafia death threat for his coverage of their local crimes. Transferred by TIME to Chicago in 1963, he contributed to major stories on football star Jim Brown, archaeologist Nelson Glueck and the murder of eight student nurses. He later worked for the Chicago Sun-Times, Chicago Daily News, Chicago Tribune and Second City. In 1991, he earned a Master of Arts degree in non-fiction writing from the University of Iowa. His book, "City Watch: Discovering the Uncommon Chicago," was published by the University of Iowa Press. Survivors include his wife and sweetheart, Pamela Sherrod Anderson, of Chicago; three beloved children, Ashley Prentice Norton of New York, Abra Williams of San Francisco and Anthony Anderson of Los Angeles; seven grandchildren, and a brother, Derek Anderson of Montreal. A son, Jon Gregory Anderson, predeceased him in 1999. In lieu of flowers, memorial gifts may be sent to Rush University Medical Center, Chappell Fund/ Hematology, 1700 W. Van Buren St., Suite 250, Chicago, IL 60612, or the Mayo Clinic, Rochester, MN for multiple myeloma research. A wake will be held Sunday, January 19th, 4-8pm at Saint Gertrude's Church, 1420 Granville Ave., Chicago. A funeral service will take place at St. Gertrude's Monday January 20th at 10am.

FROMSTEIN--Lita. The Palm Beach Country Club expresses its profound sorrow at the passing of its esteemed member, Lita Fromstein, and extends sincere sympathy to her children, grandchildren and other members of her family. William L. Mack, President; Alan Curtis, Secretary

ABRAMS--Leonard S. Beloved and adoring husband of the late Marjorie, the most amazing father to Diane and Michael, Allison and Jeff and the late Stephen, the best Pop-Pop to Alexandra (Chris) and Rachel (Dan) and the late Jennifer and the grandest GG to Jake passed away peacefully on December 18, 2013. Forever in our hearts and remembered as the kindest and most loving man. We will miss you.

LEVINE--Kenneth, on January 17th, 2014 at 83 years. Cherished husband of the late Lenore Levine. Beloved father of Mark (Alice). Loving brother of Selma Kaye (Dave). Adoring grandfather of Sofie Kate. Brother-in-law of Dr. Harvey L. Hecht (Gail). He was a graduate of the University of Connecticut. He was a practicing licensed civil engineer for many years, and he was also the founder and owner of City Skateboards in NYC. He was a big New York sports fan of the Yankees, Rangers and Giants. He spent his summer on the beach in Belle Harbor, NY with his family. Contributions may be made in his name to NY Presbyterian Cornell Division Cardiac ICU. Service is private, immediate family only.

GOLBY--Mark, beloved father, brother, husband, relative, friend and mentor, passed away January the 13th. Memorial Service at Congregation Mount Sinai, Brooklyn Heights, January 19th, noon.

SPERLING--Peter Ridley, of Wellington, Florida died Sunday, January 5, 2014 at the Hospice of Palm Beach County following complications suffered as the result of a serious accident the previous year. Mr. Sperling was born in 1931 in Madison, Wisconsin, the son of the late Jerome Sperling and the late Gertrude Ridley Sperling. His parents soon moved to New Haven, Connecticut where his father began teaching at Yale University and where he spent his youth, attending Worthington Hooker Grade School together with many other "faculty children." He graduated from Phillips Exeter Academy in 1949, Harvard University in 1953, and Yale Law School in 1956, and was a member of the Massachusetts Bar Association. At Yale he founded and was the first Chairman of the Conservative Society of the Law School. Mr. Sperling worked at New England Merchants Bank (now the Bank of New England) as a Trust Officer for nine years until he joined Citibank, N.A. in 1968. During his career at Citibank, he became a Vice President and was also Senior Marketing Director and Deputy Head of the International Private Banking Division until his retirement in 1995. On retirement, he and a close associate, Robbie Meyjes, founded Meyjes-Sperling Associates, a private banking consultancy firm. While residing in Hong Kong in the early 1970's, and for years thereafter, he wrote a monthly financial column for Insight Magazine and spent many hours training Citibank staff in the field of Private Banking. Mr. Sperling is survived by his wife, Edwina W. Van Winkle Sperling of Wellington, FL; his daughter, Ridley Whitehouse Sperling of Pleasantville, NY; and his brother, David Colton Sperling of Nairobi, Kenya.

UROWSKY--Richard. Our beloved brother, cousin and uncle, Richard, passed away on January 14. Richard led a private life and was a man of few words, but his true nature showed through in his unfailing acts of generosity, kindness and support. In times of need, Richard was always there, no questions asked. Our family is still in shock from his untimely passing. He will be missed dearly by all those whom he loved and who loved him.

SIEGEL--Alfred, The staff of the Center for Court Innovation deeply mourns the untimely passing of our dear friend and colleague Alfred Siegel. Over his long career in the field of criminal justice from his years as an Assistant District Attorney in the Bronx, to his tenure as deputy commissioner of New York City's Department of Probation, to his work with the Task Force on Transforming New York State's Juvenile Justice System, to his fifteen years here at the Center Alfred worked tirelessly to make New York a better, safer and more just place for all of us. He approached his work with a unique combination of wisdom, humility, generosity, and humor, and his absence leaves a deep hole in our lives. Alfred, the world is a better place because you were in it. You will be truly missed.

UROWSKY--Richard J. The lawyers and staff of Sullivan & Cromwell LLP mourn the loss of our beloved partner Richard J. Urowsky. Richard died at New York Presbyterian Hospital on January 14, 2014 after a long battle with cancer. He was 67 years old. We regret that Richard was taken from us so soon. Richard is survived by his sister, Ellen, brother-in-law Allen, nephews Andrew and Jonathan, cousins Edward, Norma, Peter and Robert, and many close friends and family. Richard was raised in the Bronx, and graduated from the Bronx High School of Science in 1963. He then attended Yale College, where he was a member of the Elihu Senior Society, secretary of the Aurelian Honor Society, a member of the Elizabethan Club, and an editorial assistant for The Review of Metaphysics. Richard was a philosopher from an early age. After eight straight semesters on the Dean's List and his election to Phi Beta Kappa, Richard graduated from Yale with high honors in 1967. He studied with the great legal philosopher H.L.A. Hart at New College in Oxford University as the C.P. Howland Fellow, receiving a degree in Political Theory and Legal Philosophy. Richard also was a graduate of Yale Law School, where he was an editor of the Yale Law Journal. Following law school, Richard was a law clerk for Justice Stanley Reed of the US Supreme Court. During his tenure at the Court, Richard also spent time working in the chambers of Chief Justice Warren Burger and Justices Potter Stewart and Byron White. Richard returned to New York to begin the private practice of law in 1973. He spent his entire legal career at Sullivan & Cromwell, starting as an associate in the litigation department, and becoming a partner of the firm in 1980. He represented a wide range of clients, from financial services firms to automobile manufacturers to commercial printing companies. Whether the case was large or small, Richard always brought his incisive approach to legal issues to bear. Richard was perhaps best known for leading the defense of Microsoft in several antitrust cases brought against the company during the 1990s by the US government. His command of the enormous factual record developed during a six-month trial and his mastery of a wide range of complex legal subjects during a multi-day oral argument before the en banc US Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit in February 2001 was a sight to behold. Richard was a brilliant lawyer, one who combined a rigorous analytical mind with a sparkling wit. Richard was also a wonderful teacher who was very generous with his time in mentoring younger lawyers. We all learned a lot from him. We were lucky to have had Richard as a friend and colleague for the last 40 years. He was, as one loyal client said upon hearing of his death, "a force of nature and a very good human being." He made us proud of his many accomplishments, but he also made us laugh. We will miss his great intelligence and his subversive sense of humor in equal measure.

YOUNG--E. James, of Sao Carlos, ESP, Brazil, formerly of New York City and Ft. Lauderdale, passed away on January 8, 2014 at age 90. Jim served as a Major in the Army during WWII and was a Vice President of The Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States. He had a long, happy and successful career at "Mother Equitable" where he had many friends with whom he maintained close ties long after he retired. Jim had a wonderful wit and during his "hour of charm" he would regale his friends for hours with funny and poignant stories from his childhood in Vincennes, his military service in Europe and his arrival in NYC. He will be missed by his loving long time companion Roberto Seviero, his brother Paul, nephews, nieces and many friends.

VEEDER--Peter G.,of Pittsburgh, PA, died January 13, 2014. Survived by his wife Sybil P. Veeder and three children. Services were held Saturday, January 18, 2014 in the Third Presbyterian Church, Pittsburgh, PA. Services by John A. Freyvogel Sons, Inc.
ASTROVE--George. 1 year missed and loved everyday. Grampy, Grandpa, Dad & Judy

GEIST--Mike . Top American Fashion Designer of knitted sportswear and inventor born 2/22/22, passed 1/16/13. In the fashion field, he was a pioneer and trendsetter for which he received much acclaim. In World War II, a navigator on downed B17 and ex-POW nine months in Germany. Received Purple Heart and Air Medal. He was a loving husband, father and brother and an inspiration to all who knew him. WRIGHT--Harriet, an original Copa Girl, recently died on January 10. Born on April 15, 1917, she swam in the 1939 Billy Rose World Famous Aquacade Fair. While there, Jimmy Durante picked her out and took her to the Copacabana where she spent nine months as a Copa Girl. After that, Harriet hitched rides across the country to California where she swam as an aquabelle in Esther Williams' films, including Bathing Beauty and others. She also had bit parts in movies, such as Gene Kelly's Christmas Holiday. While traveling in California, Harriet met her husband, Don Ruffin Tisdall, a US Air Force pilot. He was ordered to go to Cairo, Egypt as an attache to the US Embassy and was later killed in a plane crash. Her son, Clovis Ruffin, was the youngest designer ever to win the Cody award. He designed the original wrapped dress, T-shirts and T-dresses in 1969. Harriet herself designed costumes for Broadway shows and nightclubs, such as Latin Quarter and Copacabana. She was the author of a memoir and autobiography titled "I'd Do it Again." There will be a memorial service in the near future.

ZWEIG--Annette, passed on January 14, 2014. Loving mother to Gail and John, Ellen and David; adoring grandmother to Haley, Sophia, Brian and Julia; dear sister and cousin. We will cherish your memory always.

SIEGEL--Irving, Born August 23, 1931. Died December 17, 2013. The Fisher Island Philanthropic Fund Executive Committee sadly mourns the passing of Irving Siegel, our dedicated friend and board member for 20 years. He brought an energy and devotion to each of our philanthropic charities, which support children and at-risk youth within a ten mile radius of Fisher Island. He exemplified philanthropy at its finest. His personal visits to our charitable recipients, his enthusiasm for problem solving, his sensitivity to the challenges of the children we serve, were among the many contributions that will make his absence deeply felt and long remembered. We shall miss him. The family has requested that donations should be directed to the Fisher Island Philanthropic Fund, c/o Eugene Gitin, 7957 Fisher Island Drive, Miami, Florida 33109.

SCHWEITZER--Robert David, D.D.S.,age 83, died suddenly in Ft. Lauderdale, FL on January 14, 2014. He was born on April 1, 1930 in New York City to Jerome and Dorothy Schweitzer. He will always be remembered for his kindness, fairness and generosity to family, friends and those in need. Services will be private.

PAULIN--Sven M.D. Ph.D. Pioneer of Coronary Angiography, has Died at 87. (October 18, 1926-January 10, 2014) passed away suddenly and unexpectedly at his home on January 10, 2014. One of the pioneers in modern radiology, Dr. Paulin was highly regarded throughout the world for his work by both the radiology and cardiology communities. At the time of his death, he was Professor Emeritus at Harvard Medical School and had been working regularly in the Department of Radiology at the Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center, as he had for almost a half century. He led a full and active life until this death. Dr. Paulin was born in Bad-Muenster am Stein, Germany, and immigrated to Sweden in 1953 where he met his wife, Birgit, a few years later. In 1970 he immigrated with his family to the United States and became an American Citizen in 1979. He loved the personal and academic freedom that the United States provided him and his family. Dr. Paulin was an avid sports enthusiast, dedicated chess player, voracious reader, and art and oyster lover. In 1951, he graduated from the University of Mainz, Germany with a Doctor of Medicine degree. He then received the degree of Medical License from the Karolinska Institute in Stockholm, Sweden in 1958. This was followed some years later by the degree of Medicine Doctor (equivalent to a Ph.D.) from the University of Gothenburg, Sweden. In 1965, Coronary Angiography was a new field when Dr. Paulin, as a doctoral candidate at the University of Gothenburg, published his dissertation on the subject. His doctoral thesis, "Coronary Angiography A Technical, Anatomic and Clinical Study", written 50 years ago, was recognized as a landmark immediately after publication. Coronary angiography, the graphic demonstration of the coronary arteries in the living patient, is one of the most often practiced invasive diagnostic procedures today. His colleagues at Boston's Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center (BIDMC) say that is in large part due to Dr. Paulin himself. Shortly after the publication of the thesis, Dr. Paulin was invited to study at Stanford by Herbert Abrams, M.D. In 1970, Dr. Paulin became Radiologist-in-Chief at Beth Israel Hospital and was awarded a full Professorship in Radiology, at Harvard Medical School, Boston, Massachusetts. In 1974, he was further honored by being the first recipient of an endowed chair in Radiology by the family of Miriam M. Stoneman and retired from this position in 1994. He continued to work in the department until his retirement from medicine on his 87th birthday in 2013. Dr. Paulin is survived by his wife of 57 years, Birgit, and his four children Susanne, Magnus, Helena and Viveca. In addition five grandchildren, Elizabeth Michael, Magnus, Mattias, Axel and his sister Tosca Roeren and several nieces and nephews survive him. Funeral services will be private; a public memorial will be announced at a later date. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Sven Paulin MD Radiology Research Fund. Checks can be mailed to: Trudy Howard, Office of Development, BIDMC, 330 Brookline Avenue, Boston, MA 02215. For gifts via check, make checks payable to "BIDMC." In the memo section, please annotate that the gift is in memory of Dr. Sven Paulin. For gifts via phone/credit card, contact Trudy Howard at 617-667-3393. Additional updates can be found at www.eatonfuneralhomes.com

SCHEINMAN--Tom, 86, passed away January 5, 2014. Loving husband to Bonita, his wife of 58 years, devoted father to Laurel, Joanne, Kim and Jessica, and adoring grandfather to Jackson, Koby, Kyle and Griffin. MUSSMAN--Martin, at home on January 13, 2014. Proudly served the Veteran's Administration over 40 years. Beloved husband of Lillian; devoted father of Laurie and John Reische; adored grandfather of Griffin and Danielle. He will be in our hearts forever.

RAINER--Barbara, 91, passed away at home after a long illness. An accomplished pianist, a teacher at the High School of Music and Art, she played flute and cello with the Westchester Symphony and chamber music with her friends. With her husband, John Rainer, M.D., she traveled the world. A lifelong student, she was a fixture at Columbia and Purchase. Above all, Barbara adored her family. She leaves behind loving sons Jeff and Peter, daughter-in-law Iwona, grandchildren Marta, Jeremy and Alex, and her devoted caregiver Mary. KINDER--William F.,a former Director at the management consulting firm McKinsey & Co. in a career spanning four decades, died on Wednesday, January 8 in Oakland, California. He was 82. His son Bill confirmed the death, which came suddenly after a five year bout with Alzheimer's disease. Mr. Kinder was born in Providence, Rhode Island on February 19, 1931, the son of Mildred Fearney and Harold Kinder. He grew up in Waynesboro, Virginia and was educated at Northfield Mount Hermon, Brown University (cum laude, Phi Beta Kappa), and Harvard Business School. He enjoyed stints as a radio announcer and Top-Forty disc jockey for stations such as WTON, WEAN, WHIM between 1950-52. Mr. Kinder served as a Lieutenant in the Navy during the Korean conflict, contributing to the deployment of long range missile detection systems on the Distant Early Warning Line near the Arctic Circle. He married Mary Anne Johnson of Waynesboro in 1956. Their daughter Pam was born in 1957 while Mr. Kinder was stationed in San Diego, California. The family moved to Darien, Connecticut, after Mr. Kinder joined McKinsey & Co.'s New York Office in 1958. Son Bill was born in 1963 in Stamford. Mr. Kinder helped build up the consulting firm's practice in Los Angeles after moving there in 1969. He led numerous consulting engagements with eminent corporate clients in a range of industries including media, automotive, and finance. He was instrumental in building the consulting company's widely respected insurance practice. But he is remembered there most for his unflinching integrity, generous mentorship, contagiously positive attitude and mischievous sense of humor. He retired from McKinsey in 1991, and moved with Mary Anne to Savannah, Georgia to enjoy boating, golf, and southern hospitality. Mary Anne passed away in 2002. In addition to Pam and Bill, Mr. Kinder is survived by his sister Carolyn Carr of Washington, D.C. and six thriving grandchildren: Emily, Matthew, and Charlotte Pik of Darien; and Henry, Jackson and Phoebe Kinder of Berkeley, California. In lieu of flowers, the family is requesting that donations be made to the Cure Alzheimer's Fund at www.curealz.

McGUIRE--John C.,May 6, 1920 - December 21, 2013. John C. McGuire, founder of McGuire Furniture Company, died peacefully in his home in Portland, Oregon on December 21, 2013, with his beloved daughter Jean holding his hand. John's wife Elinor, predeceased him in November 2005. He is survived by his son, Don, and his daughter-in-law Clay, his daughter Jean McGuire Coleman, and her children, Mark, Amanda, Jessie, Perry and Don Robert. He is survived by his sister-in-law Jean Stevenson (Mrs. Donald), his brother-in-law and sister-in-law Wally and Priscilla Stevenson, and his brother-in-law and sister-in-law Rees and Eloise Stevenson. John was born in St. Augustine, Florida on May 6, 1920. With his mother, Jessie Clark McGuire, and his brother, Bill, he spent his childhood in the Boston suburb of Hingham, Massachusetts. He graduated from Hingham High School and attended Northwestern University in Evanston, Illinois. His education was interrupted by the bombing of Pearl Harbor; John enlisted in the Navy. He was sent to flight school at the Naval Air Station in Pensacola, Florida, where he advanced to train new pilots. Also in Pensacola was Elinor Stevenson who was a navigation instructor and the First Assistant to the Commander of Training. John and Elinor met and fell in love, beginning their extraordinary lifetime partnership. Following the end of World War II, John retired from the Navy and began working for the Standard Vacuum Oil Company in the Far East. John returned to the United States and married Elinor at her family home in Portland, Oregon in 1947. John and Elinor settled in San Francisco. John initially found work selling newspaper ads for the San Francisco Examiner where he fortuitously ran into Dwayne White, a friend from the Navy. Dwayne had a warehouse full of rattan furniture which he was having trouble selling. John sold the furniture for him and wanted to order more but Dwayne declined. During his tenure with Standard Oil in the Philippines, John met Dona Maria Aboitiz, the matriarch of the prominent Aboitiz Company, who was making rattan furniture for her own use. John saw the potential of rattan and in 1948 contacted Dona Maria who agreed to produce rattan furniture for him to design and sell. The McGuire Furniture Company was born. Today, Josephine Booth, the daughter of Dona Maria, with her son, Robert Booth, still supply furniture to the McGuire Furniture Company. They became an extended part of the McGuire Family. In 1995, the Philippine Government, under the Presidency of Corizan Aquino, honored John with an award for his leadership in developing the rattan furniture industry in the Philippines. John was the innovator and promoter. Elinor was the accountant and business manager and had design and engineering experience with the Boeing Aircraft Corporation. Together these two entrepreneurs designed furniture for the company. With their patented invention of applying rawhide to bind the rattan and the introduction of color to the rattan, they created the most uniquely designed and fashionable rattan furniture on the market. The McGuire collection grew over the years to include the use of different materials including willow, redwood, teak, special bamboos and Oriental hardwood. With their keen sense of style and design excellence, John and Elinor created furniture which appeared in many of the finest residences, resorts, hotels, clubs, restaurants and even in the Nixon White House and yacht. Town & Country Magazine would write, "A McGuire in the drawing room is on a par with a Rolls in the garage". Some of the first McGuire designs are now part of the permanent Smithsonian Collection at the Cooper-Hewitt Museum in New York City. John and Elinor were leaders in the area of employee relations. They understood that their employees were essential to the success of the company, and they considered them a part of the McGuire Furniture Company family. John possessed a keen interest in others, as was shown to a new young employee Frank Doodha. He befriended and mentored this 15-year-old boy who under his guidance and friendship became President of the McGuire Company after the company was sold to Chicago Pacific in 1986 and John and Elinor retired. The Company is now owned by the Kohler Co. From their first years together, John and Elinor traveled the world promoting their furniture. John met thousands of people during his life and reign as Chairman and CEO of the McGuire Company, many became cherished friends. In their retirement, they continued to travel and visit friends all over the United States, and in London, Munich, Paris, Milan, Rome, Hong Kong, and of course, the Philippines. For each of us who knew John, we knew a man who was vibrant and fun, who had great wit which was formidable, amusing and contagious and who told delightful stories. He loved his family, and was a favorite Uncle to his many nieces and nephews and their husbands and wives and all their children. He was delighted to meet new people. He wrote hundreds of letters to friends throughout his life. How many of us got calls in the early morning as he was up early and ready to make contact! He had an amazing life and we are all enriched to have shared it with him John's family consider themselves remarkably fortunate to have been nurtured by him and he was a proud father of his children and an especially proud grandfather to his grandchildren. A memorial service for John will be held on Friday, February 14, 2014, at 2:00pm at the Trinity Episcopal Cathedral, 147 NW 19th Avenue, Portland, Oregon.

HARLAN--Neil Eugene, 92 years, of Admirals Way, died January 9, 2014, following a period of declining health, at Huntington Commons in Kennebunk. Neil was born June 2, 1921 in Cherry Valley, Arkansas a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Harlan. After graduating from public schools there, he graduated from the University of Arkansas in 1947 with a Bachelor of Science Degree and earned his MBA (1950) and DBA (1956) from Harvard University Graduate School of Business Administration. Mr. Harlan also attended the University of Edinburgh, Scotland, in 1946. In 1969 was awarded an honorary Doctorate of Laws Degree from the University of Arkansas and in 1981 another doctorate from Golden Gate University. Mr. Harlan proudly served his country in the US Army during WW II. He served as Platoon Leader, Company Commander and Battalion Commander of the 8th Armored Division, through the Ardennes, Rhineland, and Central European campaigns. He received an honorable discharge in September 1946 with the rank of Captain. On September 27, 1952 he married Anna Marta (Martha) Almlov of Melrose, Massachusetts. Mr. Harlan's career was long and varied. In 1951, Mr. Harlan was appointed to the faculty of the Harvard Business School where he served as full professor until 1962, when he was appointed the Assistant Secretary of the Air Force by President John F. Kennedy. From 1964 until 1967 he worked at Anderson, Clayton & Company, Houston, Texas in positions including Financial Vice President, Executive Vice President and member of the Board of Directors. From 1967 until 1974 he was a Director of McKinsey & Company. And from 1974 until 1993, Mr. Harlan was with McKesson Corporation serving as Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer, Director and finally as interim Chairman and CEO. Always active in the community and in the business world, Mr. Harlan served in many capacities, including the following: California Commission on Campaign Financing; Board of Trustees of the San Francisco Ballet Association; Trustee of World Affairs Council of Northern California; Board of Directors, Castle Springs, Inc.; National Advisory Board, Little Rock, Arkansas; Vice Chairman, Board of Directors of the National Park Foundation, 1985-1992; Board of Governors, San Francisco Symphony, 1985-1988; California Business Roundtable; Bay Area Council, Inc.; San Francisco Chamber of Commerce; Board of Directors, Envirotech, Inc.; Board of Directors, U.S. Leasing, Inc.; and Board of Directors, Levi Strauss (1984-1985). Mr. Harlan enjoyed salmon fishing as well as playing guitar and piano. He enjoyed golf and was a member at the Webhannet Golf Club, Kennebunk and the Edgecomb Tennis Club in Kennebunk Beach. Neil is remembered and lovingly missed by his wife, Martha; his daughters, Lindsey Beth Harlan of Mystic, CT and Sarah Ellis Harlan Brown of Acton, ME; his son, Neil E. Harlan, Jr.; five grandchildren, Christopher Kingsford, Lindsey Brown, Devon Harlan Gay, Philip K. Brown, IV, and Kirin Harlan Gay; three great- grandchildren, Alissa Long, Gabriel Long and Willow Star Kingsford. Graveside services in Hope Cemetery, Kennebunk, ME will be private. Should friends desire, memorial donations may be made to the Rachel Carson National Wildlife Refuge, 321 Port Road, Wells, Maine, 04090.

LIKER--Blanche Marcus, age 80, died peacefully on September 18, 2013. She lived most of her life in the same house in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, NY. A proud graduate of Hunter College with a Bachelor of Arts degree, she earned a Master's degree in Education from Brooklyn College. She is survived by her devoted husband Daniel and her three loving children: Dr. Mark Liker of Los Angeles and his two children Jakob and Libby; Kenneth Liker of Staten Island and Melissa Tavel of Westchester County, NY, her husband Barry and their two children Ethan and Mollie. She survived being afflicted by polio as a young woman and despite requiring treatment in an iron lung with a prognosis that she would never walk again, she rebounded and succeeded in walking and, in fact, returning to full function. Her entire career was dedicated to helping children with speech and developmental delay, as a long-standing speech pathologist for NYC Public Schools and then in private practice nearly up until the time of her first stroke in December 2012. She had been a healthy vibrant woman who attended synagogue every week and enjoyed spending time with friends and family. She will always be in our hearts and thoughts. In lieu of flowers please send donations to the Hadassah Organization. "Strength and honor are her clothing, she smiles at the future; she opens her mouth in wisdom, and the lesson of kindness is on her tongue."

LITTLEJOHNS--G. Michael, died peacefully January 3, 2014, at Lenox Hill Hospital. For many years Littlejohns was Reuters' legendary veteran chief correspondent at the United Nations. One of the best-connected journalists on the diplomatic scene, he became President of the United Nations Correspondents Association in 1969. After 1989 he wrote for the Financial Times, and later hosted the UN TV show World Chronicle. A mentor to legions of young journalists and celebrated for his humor, wit and generosity of spirit. Much missed by goddaughter Sarah Dallas and his many friends and colleagues around the world. Now with his beloved Wilhelmina Vandermolen, his partner of more than 50 years, who died in 2013.

DEALY--John T.,of Newport, RI, formerly of New York City, Bronxville, NY and Naples, FL, died peacefully January 8, 2014 in Newport Hospital after a long and courageous battle against the effects of MS and Parkinson's Disease. John was the beloved husband of 48 years of Constance (Fagan) Dealy; father of Amanda Dealy (Matthew) Haverstick of Chester Springs, PA and Nicholas F. Dealy of Portsmouth, RI; and the grandfather of Emily, Megan, and Greta Haverstick. He was the brother of: Eileen D. (George) Gillespie of Harrison, NY; James J. FOLGER--Edward George, died November 8, 2013 in Ottawa, Ontario, Canada. In a career spanning two decades in TV and film in New York and Los Angeles, as one of the youngest members ever of the Directors Guild of America, Ed worked as an assistant director with such legends as Alain Resnais and Alfred Hitchcock and on early films by such contemporary icons as Ismail Merchant, George Lucas and Francis Ford Coppola. Subsequently Ed, a true nomad, filmed "Nanook Taxi" and found a new home with the Inuit of Canada's eastern arctic, where he helped foster the fledgling talent that, to this day, run the Inuit Broadcasting Corporation. Ed is survived by his sister Kathleen, and by five children: Paul and Alexei from his marriage to Susan; Mosha and Nikkutai from his marriage to Suvinai; and Napatsi from his marriage to Annie; and a beloved granddaughter Alicia.

GELLER--Joshua. The Geller family is saddened by the loss of our patriarch, Joshua Geller, adoring father, grandfather, and loving husband. ANDY--Katja, dies at 106. Born Kate Aschaffenburg in Cologne, Germany, pianist Katja Andy was a prominent student of the great Edwin Fischer in Berlin. She performed with Fischer on two pianos and traveled through Germany with his chamber orchestra. At the brink of a brilliant career, she escaped from the Nazi regime in 1933. She fled to Paris and subsequently to the United States, where she became an American citizen. In America, she established herself primarily as a teacher, taught at De Paul University in Chicago before moving to Boston, where she joined first the Boston Conservatory, then the New England Conservatory where she received an honorary doctorate in 1987. Katja was loved and respected by her colleagues, family and friends, and many students who remained in touch with her until the end of her life. She was widely admired for her unique and impeccable musicianship. Artists of renown came to play for her to seek her advice. She passed away in New York City on December 30, 2013.

A recipient of the William J. Brennan, Jr. Award by The New Jersey Federal Bar, and the Judge Learned Hand Award. He served as a director of Prudential Financial, Inc., a trustee of the New Jersey Performing Arts Center and as counsel to Congregation B'nai Jeshurun. Donations to: St. Barnabas Medical Center Foundation, 95 Old Short Hills Rd., West Orange, NJ 07052, Attn: The Cancer Center.
