RUSH--Alvin, March 8, 1934 - January 20, 2013. Forever in our hearts. Love, Marilyn and Family

UROWSKY--Richard. Our beloved brother, cousin and uncle, Richard, passed away on January 14. Richard led a private life and was a man of few words, but his true nature showed through in his unfailing acts of generosity, kindness and support. In times of need, Richard was always there, no questions asked. Our family is still in shock from his untimely passing. He will be missed dearly by all those whom he loved and who loved him.

EPSTEIN--Sydell (nee Waldman), died January 17, 2014 in Miami at age 97. She danced into our lives with her high kick, her great piano playing made us all feel good. Predeceased by her husband Cantor Maurice Epstein. Survived by two sons, Martin and Richard Siskind, four grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. We will all miss her.

LOWENBERG--Sidney, My father, Sid Lowenberg, died today. He was 100 years old, turning 101 in June. Most people marvel at a life that spans an entire century for its mere duration, but I marvel at how he lived those 100 years. Born and raised in the Bronx, he met and fell in love with my mother, Beatrice, when he was only 16 years old. He was a smart young man and had dreams of becoming a doctor, but abandoned them before he could finish college so that he could marry and make a life with his one true love --Bea. Their love for each only grew stronger over the years as they began to raise a family. He was determined to give his family a good life, and before long he began a career that encompassed two full time jobs so that he could earn enough money to do so. By day, he worked in the General Post Office in NYC and by night, the educational department at the 92nd St. YMHA. I grew up watching his tireless energy, as he went from one job to the other with only one night and one day off each week. In those few hours each week he somehow managed to teach me life lessons that have molded who I am today. His work ethic was rivaled by no one I have ever known. His innate intelligence and commanding personality enabled him to balance both jobs, gain respect of his peers and friends, and adore his wife and children. His devotion to his family, however, was paramount to everything else. He prided himself on his success and he measured success by who he was as a man, a husband and a father. My brother and I learned about love and family by his example, not by his words. He adored the woman he married and for 78 years of marriage we witnessed their everlasting love affair that never wavered. Growing up in their presence was so awe inspiring that even as a teenage boy I would talk to my friends about my parents being the gold standard for love and marriage. He was my best friend, my champion, my advisor and my mentor. There was nothing that I did not share with him or confide in him--nothing. He was always there when I needed him, always emotionally available and always loved me for who I was without any judgment. He was kind and generous. He was loyal and filled with great integrity. He was strong and tough, but sensitive in an era when sensitivity in men was rare. In short, he was my hero. In the last hours of his life, his aged hand wrapped around my index finger and held on tightly, in the same manner that my five year old little hand once held onto his finger. Our eyes met for that last moment and I smiled at him, thinking, for as long as I can remember, he was the man I had hoped to become. I'm still trying.

LOWENBERG--Sidney,My grandfather died on Saturday following my grandmother three months earlier. He was 100, she was 98. They were married for 78 years. It is impossible to speak of one without speaking of them both. For 38 years they have been Mama and Papa never one without the other. It is hard to imagine life without them now. For all of us, they have been the guiding example for how to live your life. Each time I saw them I would try to analyze what made them have such good fortune in life. They were the most grateful people throughout the day they would remark on their good fortunes. They didn't measure the success of their life by money or stature, but against only what they had their family, their health, their love for each other and their entire family. As their grandchild, I felt loved in a way I have felt by no other. It is said that a grandparent can love their grandchildren in a different way than a parent can. Both mama and papa genuinely loved me unconditionally, thought the world of me, were rooting for me, were genuinely interested in me and whatever I was doing, took the time to always make me feel special and so loved, and made me feel the pleasure I had brought to their lives simply by living my own life. In turn, I tried to let them know as often as I could how much I loved them and how much they meant to me. I will always remember them holding hands on the couch, the warmth of Papa's smile and kindness in his eyes, Mama laughing at Papa, and hearing them say "I love you" to each other a hundred times throughout the day up until the very end. I am fortunate that they lived long enough to meet my son and know him for the first four years of his life. I know that he too, will remember them and carry their love throughout his own life. This is how they live on forever. It is a gift to have known them, my good fortune to have been loved by them, and my duty to try and live up to the legacy they leave behind.Tara Lowenberg
PLEAT--Marvin, died on January 18, 2014. Beloved and devoted husband of Elena. Loving and devoted father of Daniel, Alan, and Benjamin.

TAUBE--Annette Betty, born February 17, 1916, passed away Tuesday, December 3, 2013. Adoring and adored wife of Harry Taube, MD. Beloved mother of Steven and Ozzie Taube, and Susan Taube-Katchor. Generous and caring grandma of Alexis, Andrew, Matthew, James and Sam and great-grandma of Ella and Luca Lucente. Annette will always be remembered as an elegant woman epitomizing all that was good about being a New Yorker. Annette was most passionate about "her" city: its theaters, museums, concert halls and especially its streets. She enjoyed her daily perambulations even in her 90's. Annette was strong, resilient, independent and generous. She will be greatly missed by her family.

SIEGEL--Alfred R.,bornMarch 14 1951 in NYC, diedJanuary 14, 2014. Predeceased by father, R. Lawrence, and mother, Beatrice. Survived by beloved wife, Nancy Levine Siegel, two wonderful sons, Lawrence and Daniel, sister, Alice, aunt, Selma, uncle, Ed- ward, and his wife, Elsie, a niece, nephews and cousins. Graduated from Stuyvesant High School, NYU with Mas-ters and Rutgers Law School. Served various NYC agencies and ended his career as Deputy Director of the Center for Court Innovation where he spent 15 years. Served on Board of Directors for the Riverdale Community Center for 15 years. He was an avid sports enthusiast and a wonderful husband, father, brother, uncle and friend. Beloved by all. Donations: Center for Court Innovation or Riverdale Community Center.

LOWENBERG--Sidney, (June 26, 1913-January 18, 2014) died on Saturday in Boca Raton, FL. His wife, Beatrice, of 78 years pre-deceased him three months ago. He is survived by his sons Andrew and Marc, his grandchildren Adam, Jaimi, Tara and Terrence and his eight great-grandchildren, Morgan, Mia, Reese, Kaley, Travis, Graydon, Dylan and Jake. He loved them all with all his heart. Graveside services will be today at 11am at Beth Moses Cemetery, Farmingdale.

MIDONICK--Millard (Will) Lesser, age 99, died peacefully in his sleep on January 18. Beloved husband of Jill Claster Midonick; adoring brother of Vivian Dicker (deceased); cherished uncle. In a legal career that spanned more than 70 years, he served as judge of both the Family and the Manhattan Surrogate's Court. He was also a co-founder of the Tilden Democratic Club. Will was a force for good in all he did as a friend, mentor, and judge, unfailingly kind and generous-spirited. Services Tuesday 11:45am at "The Riverside" 76th Street at Amsterdam Avenue.

O'MEARA--Jean C.,died age 91 in Portland, ME on January 13. A resident of Hancock Point, ME, she was born in Ellsworth, ME, attended Colby College, and wed Alan Hillman, who died in WWII. She married Dr. Edward S. O'Meara in 1947 and helped him found the Maine Coast Memorial Hospital in Ellsworth. She was also a founding trustee of the Pierre Monteux School. She is survived by five children - Mary E., Ellen K., Edward S., Jr., Dr. John R., and William F. O'Meara and nine grandchildren. She will be deeply missed by family and friends of all ages.

LENNON--Arthur J.,Jr., MD, aged 78, of Bronxville, NY, died peacefully on January 19 surrounded by family and friends. Born in Manhattan, he received his BA at Fordham University, his MD at the College of Physicians and Surgeons and his MPH at the School of Public Health, both at Columbia University. He received his postgraduate education at St Luke's Hospital and was board certified in Internal Medicine, Cardiology and Geriatrics. For over 40 years he was on the staff of St. Luke's Hospital where he was President of the Medical Board and the first to be asked to stay on in this position for two years. He retired as a Senior Emeritus Attending Physician. He was on the staff of the Isabella Geriatric Center for 42 years including 33 years as Director of Medical Services and 23 years as Vice Chairman of the Board. He made great contributions to each through his contemplative leadership and remarkable compassion. He was also Associate Clinical Professor of Medicine at Columbia University, taking special pleasure in passing on his caring bedside manner and his wisdom in the art of physical diagnosis. He was a Captain in the US Army 1962-64 and served in Vietnam. He was known for having a well-timed remark, and had passions for history, sailing, music and the Adirondacks. He is survived by his wife of 45 years, Airlie, his daughter Jean of Durham, NC, his son James (Tori) of Nashville, TN, and three grandchildren. Mass of Christian Burial will be held at St. Joseph's Church in Bronxville on Wednesday January 22 at 11am. The family will receive friends at the Fred H. McGrath & Son, Funeral Home, 20 Cedar St., Bronxville, on January 21 between 7 and 9pm. In lieu of flowers, please send donations in his name to the Isabella Foundation, 515 Audubon Ave., NY, NY 10040.
CHALFIN--Lawrence E.,71, died January 16, 2014. Loving father of Aaron. Memorial: January 26, 2014, 2:30pm. Plaza Jewish Community Chapel: 630 Amsterdam Ave.

GOLDSTEIN--Arnold. (1931 - 2014). Graduated from New York University's School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance. Co-founder of Samson Management, one of New York City's largest owner management firms. Chairman of the board and chairman of the executive committee of the Rent Stabilization Association of New York. Member of the Attorney General's Cooperatives and Condominiums Advisory Task Force. Served as a director of the New York State Managed Long Term Care Advisory Board. Since 1978; served on the board of the Hebrew Hospital Home, Inc., the sixth largest not-for-profit nursing home in New York State, and served as chairman since 1993. He founded the Arlene and Arnold Goldstein Family Foundation, which continues to support various medical and Jewish causes as well as other community and social programs. He leaves behind his loving wife of sixty years, Arlene; three children, Scott, Shari and Michael; six grandchildren, Jackie, Alex, Joey, Calli, Marisa and Jordan, and two great-grandchildren, Samantha and Matthew.

RICHARDS--Arthur V.,of Chappaqua, NY died January 17, 2014 at age 74. Born February 20, 1939 in Brooklyn, NY to Isabel (McCafferty) and James V. Richards. He retired in 1997 as Vice President/General Counsel of the Melville Corporation. He served on the boards of the Retail Council of NY. State and SUNY College at Purchase. He is survived by his wife Nancy, daughter Pamela Smith (Kevin) of Rye, son Arthur (Danae) of Chappaqua and four grandchildren. Funeral services by Beecher Flooks Funeral Home, Inc., Pleasantville, NY.

RIPPS--Julia Gabai, 85, of West Caldwell, New Jersey, on Sunday, January 19th, 2014. Born in Havana, Cuba, widow of the late Norman. Mother of Linda, Amy, Vanessa, and Daniel. Grandmother of Greta, David, Navah, Seffi, and Matan.

McINERNEY--Victoria de Fere, a native of Bay Shore, NY and a resident of Rupert, VT died 18 January 2014 after a courageous battle with lung disease at age 68. She graduated from Rosemary Hall and then Pine Manor College. She is a direct descendant of Rev. John Yongs, the first settler and founder of the town of Southold, NY and of John Proctor, hung as a witch during the Salem, MA witch trials. She is survived by her husband, John, of almost 48 years; their twin sons, John Haven and Paul Proctor; her sister Paulette Van Vranken; niece Karen Maloney; predeceased by her oldest sister, Joscelyn Hill. She would appreciate contributions to the Vermont Chapter of the Nature Conservancy.

TAUBE--Annette Betty, born February 17, 1916, passed away Tuesday, December 3, 2013. Adoring and adored wife of Harry Taube, MD. Beloved mother of Steven and Ozzie Taube, and Susan Taube-Katchor. Generous and caring grandma of Alexis, Andrew, Matthew, James and Sam and great-grandma of Ella and Luca Lucente. Annette will always be remembered as an elegant woman epitomizing all that was good about being a New Yorker. Annette was most passionate about "her" city: its theaters, museums, concert halls and especially its streets. She enjoyed her daily perambulations even in her 90's. Annette was strong, resilient, independent and generous. She will be greatly missed by her family.
ROSEN--Philip, a wonderful friend who was an inspiration to all who knew him. My heartfelt condolences to his loving wife Rita and the entire family. Diane H.
GOLDBERG--Lisa Ellen, who lit the world, still lights our lives. John, Katie, and Jed

ROSEN--Philip, we are so saddened by the loss of our uncle, loving brother of our late mother and grandmother. Our deepest condolences to the entire Rosen family. We love you. Cheryl, Bill, Ian and David
HOFF--Julia, 19 years, and not a day goes by that I don't miss you. Love, Enid

SIEGEL--Alfred R.,bornMarch 14 1951 in NYC, diedJanuary 14, 2014. Predeceased by father, R. Lawrence, and mother, Beatrice. Survived by beloved wife, Nancy Levine Siegel, two wonderful sons, Lawrence and Daniel, sister, Alice, aunt, Selma, uncle, Ed- ward, and his wife, Elsie, a niece, nephews and cousins. Graduated from Stuyvesant High School, NYU with Mas-ters and Rutgers Law School. Served various NYC agencies and ended his career as Deputy Director of the Center for Court Innovation where he spent 15 years. Served on Board of Directors for the Riverdale Community Center for 15 years. He was an avid sports enthusiast and a wonderful husband, father, brother, uncle and friend. Beloved by all. Donations: Center for Court Innovation or Riverdale Community Center.

ROSEN--Philip. Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University records with profound sorrow the passing of our dear friend Philip Rosen. Together with his beloved wife and partner, Rita, Phil was a devoted supporter of the College for more than 50 years and a cherished member of the Einstein family. Benefactors and passionate advocates for Einstein's mission to improve human health, Phil and Rita have used their energies and talents to help the College grow and flourish; our Department of Communications and Public Affairs is named in their honor. Mr. Rosen joined Einstein's Board of Overseers in 1977, served as vice chair, and was honored with the title of Life Overseer. He was also a founding member and a past chairman of the Men's Division and member of its Executive Board. The College recognized the Rosens for their extraordinary service with both its Humanitarian and Lifetime Achievement awards. Mr. and Mrs. Rosen are also each recipients of honorary doctorates from Yeshiva University. Rita is an Executive Vice President of our Women's Division and is a past president. We already miss Phil's presence, and extend our heartfelt condolences to Rita and the entire family. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President

ROSEN--Philip, of New Rochelle, NY passed away on Sunday, January 19, 2014. He is survived by his beloved wife Rita of 66 years, his loving children Phyllis Hadley and Michael Rosen, his sons-in-law Robert Landes and Richard Hadley, his daughter-in-law Stephanie Rosen, and his adoring grandchildren; Brett Raskin, Shaun Raskin-Deutschlander, Weston Deutschlander, Matthew Landes, Alexandra Landes, Jacqueline Landes, Alec Rosen, Kayla Rosen and Sierra Rosen. Sadly, Philip was predeceased by his daughter Wendy Landes on March 14, 2013. Born in the Bronx, on September 1, 1921, to Isadore and Anna Rosen, Philip was an outstanding student which enabled him to gain entrance into the Townsend Harris High School. He won a Merit Scholarship for mathematics and was admitted to Cornell University where he graduated in 1942 with a Bachelor of Science degree in Civil Engineering and a letter in Varsity Crew. Immediately after graduation he worked as an engineer for Stone and Webster while working for the United States government on "The Manhattan Project." During World War II he served his country as a Lieutenant in the United States Navy. After the War, Philip joined his father's masonry contracting business, Isadore Rosen and Sons, constructing many buildings throughout the metropolitan area. In addition to providing masonry services for other developers, Isadore Rosen and Sons went on to develop and build numerous buildings on their own behalf. Although success in business was very important to Philip, the idea of "giving back" and social responsibility were paramount. He felt fortunate to be able to contribute much time and energy to the many causes he believed in. Philip was a benefactor of Technion in Israel, a founder of The Chemotherapy Foundation, a benefactor of New Rochelle Hospital, The Juvenile Diabetes Foundation, The Cystic Fibrosis Foundation, and the Anti-Defamation League of B'Nai Brith. He was active in UJA, Federation of Jewish Philanthropies, and United Way. He was an honorary trustee of Temple Israel of New Rochelle, on the Board of Trustees of the Jewish Braille Institute (JBI), and was the founding member of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine's Young Men's Division. Philip and Rita were honored with the Lifetime Achievement Award, in 2004 and Philip remained a "Life Overseer" on The Board of Overseers of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine. Philip was a man of many hobbies. He loved literature and art, collecting stamps and shells but most of all he loved to ski. He skied well into his 80's and passed on that love to all of his children and grandchildren. Philip had a tremendous zest for life and felt he truly got the opportunity to live his American dream. He was loved by many and will be missed. A funeral service will be held on Wednesday, January 22, 2014 at 11:30am at Temple Israel of New Rochelle, 1000 Pinebrook Boulevard, New Rochelle, NY. Donations in Philip's memory should be made to "The Wendy Walk" (www.wendywalk.com) or to the Albert Einstein College of Medicine Men's Division.

UROWSKY--Richard. Our beloved brother, cousin and uncle, Richard, passed away on January 14. Richard led a private life and was a man of few words, but his true nature showed through in his unfailing acts of generosity, kindness and support. In times of need, Richard was always there, no questions asked. Our family is still in shock from his untimely passing. He will be missed dearly by all those whom he loved and who loved him.

ROSEN--Philip. The members of Brae Burn Country Club mourn the passing of our esteemed founding member, Philip Rosen. Our sympathy is extended to his entire family. Len Shendell, President William Schultz, Secretary

MIDONICK--Millard (Will) Lesser, age 99, died peacefully in his sleep on January 18. Beloved husband of Jill Claster Midonick; adoring brother of Vivian Dicker (deceased); cherished uncle. In a legal career that spanned more than 70 years, he served as judge of both the Family and the Manhattan Surrogate's Court. He was also a co-founder of the Tilden Democratic Club. Will was a force for good in all he did as a friend, mentor, and judge, unfailingly kind and generous-spirited. Services Tuesday 11:45am at "The Riverside" 76th Street at Amsterdam Avenue.

GOLDSTEIN--Arnold. The Officers and Members of the Bronx Realty Advisory Board mourn the passing of a highly respected, outstanding leader who was a friend to New York City and its real estate industry. Arnold served as Chairman of the Rent Stabilization Association for many years. He led by example and humility dedicating himself to making our City a better place to live. Arnold will be greatly missed but remembered by the many lives he touched. Michael Laub, Chairman William Schur, President

FEINBERG--Frank, was a rarity among those considered well-to-do. He had a strong social conscience. He felt for those who were "less-privileged." Frank was proud that because of hard work his brothers and he put in, their business was successful. His dear wife Mildred and he formed a wonderful team and happily supported well-chosen and deserving causes, most of them anonymously. Well-read. It never was easy to win an argument with Frank. Incorrigible but lovable. Frank Feinberg will be missed by countless admirers. Kanti Rai, Great Neck, NY

GOLDSTEIN--Arnold, we mourn the passing of our dear friend and esteemed client Arnold Goldstein. To all who knew him, Arnold was the preeminent real estate investor, community leader and philanthropist; his word was a mighty contract, his handshake was always his bond. To us, we will miss and remember his warmth, humor and wisdom. Our heartfelt condolences Arlene, Scott, Shari, Michael, and their families. Andy Albstein & Goldberg Weprin

FEIL--Phyllis, died peacefully at 86 after a brief illness on January 17, 2014. She rejoins her husband Morris, who died in 2007, and her daughter Susan, who died in 1957. Loving mother of sons Jonathan and Stuart (Susan), and adoring grandmother of Arden and Owen. Born in Brooklyn, raised in Queens, she was a 45-year resident of Westbury, NY and retired in Boynton Beach, FL. She graduated from Far Rockaway High School in 1945 and worked as a graphic artist. She will be remembered for her generosity of spirit, delight in entertaining others, and zest for seeking out objets d'art. Memorial mitzvot may be made to American Lung Association or Planting Fields Foundation. Graveside service Wednesday, January 22, 2014, 1:00pm, New Montefiore Cemetery, West Babylon. Shiva visits that evening at Stuart and Susan Feil.

GOLDSTEIN--Arnold. The Board of Directors, members, and staff of the Rent Stabilization Association mourn the loss of our chairman for over thirty years, Arnold Goldstein. Arnold's leadership, wisdom, and knowledge not only guided the real estate industry through many difficult periods but also led it to attain the outstanding success it is at now. Arnold made New York a better place to live. Arnold will be missed by all who knew him and the many lives he made better. Aaron Sirulnick, Chairman Joseph Strasburg, President

KLEIMAN--David, died Saturday January 18 from Amyloidosis, a rare plasma cell disease. His commitment to a life of integrity, music and learning made him extraordinary. He is survived by wife Kate, parents Irving and Rhoda, brother Barry and Susan, Ross, Lauren, Alex Kleiman, and grandchildren Amelia & Ian Price.

LOWENBERG--Sidney, My father, Sid Lowenberg, died today. He was 100 years old, turning 101 in June. Most people marvel at a life that spans an entire century for its mere duration, but I marvel at how he lived those 100 years. Born and raised in the Bronx, he met and fell in love with my mother, Beatrice, when he was only 16 years old. He was a smart young man and had dreams of becoming a doctor, but abandoned them before he could finish college so that he could marry and make a life with his one true love --Bea. Their love for each only grew stronger over the years as they began to raise a family. He was determined to give his family a good life, and before long he began a career that encompassed two full time jobs so that he could earn enough money to do so. By day, he worked in the General Post Office in NYC and by night, the educational department at the 92nd St. YMHA. I grew up watching his tireless energy, as he went from one job to the other with only one night and one day off each week. In those few hours each week he somehow managed to teach me life lessons that have molded who I am today. His work ethic was rivaled by no one I have ever known. His innate intelligence and commanding personality enabled him to balance both jobs, gain respect of his peers and friends, and adore his wife and children. His devotion to his family, however, was paramount to everything else. He prided himself on his success and he measured success by who he was as a man, a husband and a father. My brother and I learned about love and family by his example, not by his words. He adored the woman he married and for 78 years of marriage we witnessed their everlasting love affair that never wavered. Growing up in their presence was so awe inspiring that even as a teenage boy I would talk to my friends about my parents being the gold standard for love and marriage. He was my best friend, my champion, my advisor and my mentor. There was nothing that I did not share with him or confide in him--nothing. He was always there when I needed him, always emotionally available and always loved me for who I was without any judgment. He was kind and generous. He was loyal and filled with great integrity. He was strong and tough, but sensitive in an era when sensitivity in men was rare. In short, he was my hero. In the last hours of his life, his aged hand wrapped around my index finger and held on tightly, in the same manner that my five year old little hand once held onto his finger. Our eyes met for that last moment and I smiled at him, thinking, for as long as I can remember, he was the man I had hoped to become. I'm still trying.

JACOBSON--Edith, beloved wife of the late Dr. Morton Jacobson, cherished mother of Lesley and Jeffrey Jacobson and their spouses Ron DuBreuil and Caroline Ghertler. Adored grandmother of Micah DuBreuil and Sonya Jacobson. Formerly of Hastings-on-Hudson, NY and Palm Beach, FL. Edith died after a brief illness surrounded by loved ones. Funeral Services at the Edward Dowdle Funeral Home in Dobbs Ferry, NY on Thursday, January 23 at 10am.

FRANKFURT--Daniel, 88, loving and cherished husband of Ruth for 62 years, father of Judith (James R. Oestreich) and Jackie (Mark Cahn), proud grandfather of Jordan and Joey Frankfurt Cahn, brother of Dina Katz, on January 20, 2014. Founding president of Daniel Frankfurt P.C. Engineers & Architects, a New York City firm, following career involvement in projects including the Telstar communications satellite, and the United States space program's testing facility for the Lunar Excursion Module for the 1969 landing on the moon. Dedicated board member and civic leader in Greenburgh township, ARZA/World Union and Westchester Reform Temple. Alumnus of DeWitt Clinton High School, CCNY and Columbia University. His keen mind, calm spirit and warm soul will be sorely missed. Service: Wednesday, January 22 at 11:30am, West-chester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale, NY.

MARX--Walter, 88, of Jackson Heights, Queens (Stuttgart, Germany), Export Agent/ Community Activist/ World Traveler. Died Wednesday, January 15, 2014. Father of Geoff (Elisabeth), devoted Grandfather of Willem and Gemma. Services: Tuesday, January 21, 2014, 11:30am at Riverside Chapel, W. 76 & Amsterdam. Donations in his memory may be made to NYCLU, 125 Broad St, 10004.

GOLDSTEIN--Arnold, The Board and Staff of Hebrew Hospital Home of Westchester, Hebrew Hospital Senior Housing, HHH Homecare, Choices Health Plan and Hebrew Hospital Home Foundation wish to express their profound sorrow on the passing of our Chairman Emeritus Arnold Goldstein on January 19th, 2014. Arnold served as Chairman of the Board from 1993 until 2013, whereupon he continued to serve as a Board member until his death. We will miss his sage counsel, leadership, vision, generosity and wonderful sense of humor for years to come. Our thoughts and prayers go out to his wife Arlene, his children Scott, Shari and Michael and his grandchildren. The Board and Staff of Hebrew Hospital Home

LENNON--Arthur J.,Jr., MD, aged 78, of Bronxville, NY, died peacefully on January 19 surrounded by family and friends. Born in Manhattan, he received his BA at Fordham University, his MD at the College of Physicians and Surgeons and his MPH at the School of Public Health, both at Columbia University. He received his postgraduate education at St Luke's Hospital and was board certified in Internal Medicine, Cardiology and Geriatrics. For over 40 years he was on the staff of St. Luke's Hospital where he was President of the Medical Board and the first to be asked to stay on in this position for two years. He retired as a Senior Emeritus Attending Physician. He was on the staff of the Isabella Geriatric Center for 42 years including 33 years as Director of Medical Services and 23 years as Vice Chairman of the Board. He made great contributions to each through his contemplative leadership and remarkable compassion. He was also Associate Clinical Professor of Medicine at Columbia University, taking special pleasure in passing on his caring bedside manner and his wisdom in the art of physical diagnosis. He was a Captain in the US Army 1962-64 and served in Vietnam. He was known for having a well-timed remark, and had passions for history, sailing, music and the Adirondacks. He is survived by his wife of 45 years, Airlie, his daughter Jean of Durham, NC, his son James (Tori) of Nashville, TN, and three grandchildren. Mass of Christian Burial will be held at St. Joseph's Church in Bronxville on Wednesday January 22 at 11am. The family will receive friends at the Fred H. McGrath & Son, Funeral Home, 20 Cedar St., Bronxville, on January 21 between 7 and 9pm. In lieu of flowers, please send donations in his name to the Isabella Foundation, 515 Audubon Ave., NY, NY 10040.

LENNON--Arthur J.,MD. The Board of Directors and the entire Isabella Geriatric Center community mourn the loss of our dear friend and colleague, Dr. Arthur J. Lennon. Dr. Lennon cared for the residents of Isabella Geriatric Center for 42 years serving first as Director and then as Vice President of Medical Services. He was on the Isabella Board of Directors for 23 years fulfilling the role as First Vice Chairman, a position he held until his death. Throughout his career, Dr. Lennon displayed a remarkable ability to see and respond to the needs of the most vulnerable among us with unerring love and compassion. He was a gifted teacher whose communication skills and commitment to excellence were an inspiration to all who had the benefit of his guidance. As a member of the Isabella Board of Directors, he demonstrated an enduring commitment to the mission and goals of Isabella. Known for his well-seasoned blend of wry wit and love, he will be greatly missed by all. Mark Lipton, PhD, Chair Mark J. Kator, President/CEO

GOLDSTEIN--Arnold. The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society (ATS) are saddened by the loss of Arnold Goldstein of New York, a generous donor to many Jewish causes. Their support includes the Arlene & Arnold Goldstein UAVs and Satellites Center and the Arlene and Arnold Goldstein SAMSON Satellite Project at the Asher Space Research Institute. We offer our heartfelt condolences to Arlene and the entire Goldstein family. American Technion Society Scott Leemaster, President Joel S. Rothman, Chairman of the Board Melvyn H. Bloom, Executive Vice President

GOLDSTEIN--Arnold. You were my friend and mentor. I will dearly miss your advice, counsel and friendship. Thank you for your love and influence on my life. Deepest sympathy to Arlene and the entire Goldstein family. Michael Laub

ACHS--Samuel, MD, MS, FACS February 23, 1919-January 19, 2014. Sam Achs, died peacefully in his home with his wife Sharon by his side. Sam was a gentle man with a remarkable intellect and a quiet, caring manner. He was truly a "good human being", who in his own style was accessible, generous, giving and wise. He is predeceased by his son Robert. He is survived by his wise Sharon, his daughter Naomi, daughter-in-law Jackie, grandchildren Maggie, (Peter) Jake, Rachel, great- granddaughters Ramona, Gloria, niece Eleanor (Howard) brother-in-law Michael (Pat) and dear friends Robin and Joel, and Greg Cunningham. Donations may be sent to: Trinitycarehospice.org

ANGEL--Arline, 90, died at Vassar Brothers Medical Center in Poughkeepsie on December 21 from complications of dementia. Cherished mother of Karen Angel, widow of Dr. Klaus Angel, sister-in-law of Dr. Burt and Ann Angrist, aunt of Laurel Angrist, and grandmother of Anny, Imogen and miniature pinscher Lily Angel. A native New Yorker and near-lifelong resident, social worker, devout birder, guardian of nature, insightful confidante, and loving and devoted mother, she had an unbeatable zest for life and love of humor that will live on in those who loved her. She will be sorely missed.

RUBIN--Jeffrey Mark, 70, beloved husband, father, grandfather, brother, attorney and best friend, died January 21st after a courageous seven year battle with cancer. A lion of a man, he approached every moment of his young life with passion, humor, and adventure. His love for the law was matched only by his love for the sea and its endless horizons, but it was his family in which he found safe harbor. We are thankful for how he taught us to live with gusto and bravery and to value each moment. A world without him is overwhelming, but we take heart that he is within and around us providing the strength we need to go on. We love you forever. He is survived by his devoted family, wife Susan, son Aaron, daughter Lauren and Michael Virk, daughter Diana and Alexander Rus, sister Enid and grandchildren David and Nicholas Rus. Service Thursday, January 23, 2014, 11:15am, at "The Riverside," 76th and Amsterdam.

Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; John S. Ruskay, Executive VP & CEO

TAUBE--Annette Betty, born February 17, 1916, passed away Tuesday, December 3, 2013. Adoring and adored wife of Harry Taube, MD. Beloved mother of Steven and Ozzie Taube, and Susan Taube-Katchor. Generous and caring grandma of Alexis, Andrew, Matthew, James and Sam and great-grandma of Ella and Luca Lucente. Annette will always be remembered as an elegant woman epitomizing all that was good about being a New Yorker. Annette was most passionate about "her" city: its theaters, museums, concert halls and especially its streets. She enjoyed her daily perambulations even in her 90's. Annette was strong, resilient, independent and generous. She will be greatly missed by her family.

Mr. Weitzel was a partner of the law firm of Cummings and Lockwood and a retired Senior Vice President and General Counsel of Texaco, Inc. Bill is survived by his wife, Loretta; son, William C. Weitzel III and wife, Michelle; son Richard S. Weitzel and wife, Christine and two children, Nicole and Ryan; daughter Sarah L. Farrell and husband Richard, their four children, Emma, Richie, Liam and Nora; and son, Andrew K. Weitzel. Calling hours January 23rd, 2014, 11am to 1pm at the Ricker Funeral Home in Lebanon, NH. Service: January 24th, 2014, 9am, at the Plainfield Community Church in Plainfield, NH. Burial will be at the Chase Cemetery in Cornish, NH in the spring. Condolences may be expressed with the family by visiting www.rickerfuneralhome.com

MCLANE--Robert Milligan, a longtime resident of Locust Valley, NY died peacefully at home on January 18. Born February 2, 1930 in New York City, youngest child of Edith Gibb Maxwell and Allan McLane. Mr. McLane graduated from St Paul's School (1948) and from Yale University (1952), then served in the US Navy for two years. His professional career was with Marsh & McLennan Companies, where he retired as a Senior Vice President in 1994. Devoted to family and friends, he was an avid sportsman who enjoyed golf, racquet sports, and upland game hunting. He served on the Boards of Charles Pratt & Co, Good Hope Corporation, Greenpoint Savings Bank, Greenwood Cemetery, Piping Rock Club and on the Vestry at St. John's of Lattingtown. Mr. McLane was predeceased by his wife of 54 years Camilla Merritt McLane and his brother Allan McLane. He is survived by his children Nina Burchfield (Bill) and Robert M. McLane Jr. (Gratia); grandchildren William, Camilla and Jennifer Burchfield, and Robert III, Allison and Nicholas McLane; and his sister Edith Gibb Edson. A memorial service will be held at 11:00am on January 25th at St. John's of Lattingtown in Locust Valley, NY.

MAYER--Peter E. Selfhelp Community Services deeply mourns the passing of Peter Mayer, long time friend, advocate and staunch supporter of Selfhelp's programs for Holocaust survivors. Following in the footsteps of his mother, Irma Mayer, an active volunteer from Selfhelp's earliest days, Peter devoted his time and energy to advancing and promoting our vital mission. Joining him was his beloved wife Reggie, a dedicated Selfhelp Board member for nearly four decades. Peter left an extraordinary legacy for which he will always be remembered. We extend heartfelt sympathy to his wife Reggie, daughters Susan and Nancy, and the entire family. Raymond V.J. Schrag, President Stuart C. Kaplan, CEO

ROSEN--Philip. We have shared a lifetime of many joyous moments and have been there for each other in good times and bad. My heart is full of sympathy for Rita, Phyllis and Michael and the entire Rosen and Landes families. Selma

The Parker Jewish Institute family notes, with great sadness, the passing of Janet Landsberg, beloved wife of Steven, cherished mother and grandmother, and daughter-in-law of Gloria and Jerry Landsberg, benefactors of Parker Jewish Institute for Health Care and Rehabilitation. We extend our sympathy and sincere condolences. Our thoughts and prayers are with the entire Landsberg family. Parker Jewish Institute for Health Care and Rehabilitation Lenny Tanzer Chairman, Board of Trustees Michael N. Rosenblut President and CEO

ROSEN--Philip. JBI International, Inc. (Established in 1931 as The Jewish Braille Institute) deeply mourns the passing of longtime Trustee and Honorary Officer, Philip Rosen. Together with his beloved wife Rita, he was instrumental in supporting some of JBI's most important programs, which today help 35,000 blind and visually impaired children and adults around the world. No one knew better than Mr. Rosen, who developed Macular Degeneration later in life, what a difference JBI could make to the lives of the blind and visually impaired. The Rosen family has been, and still is, an ongoing inspiration to all of us. Our thoughts are with Rita, Phyllis, Michael and their extended families, including the family of the late Wendy Rosen Landes. We will mourn him but we will forever be blessed by his memory. Judy E. Tenney, Chairman of the Board Dr. Ellen Isler, President and CEO Israel A. Taub, Vice President and CFO

ROSEN--Philip, we are so saddened by the loss of our uncle, loving brother of our late mother and grandmother. Our deepest condolences to the entire Rosen family. We love you. Cheryl, Bill, Ian and David

LEWIS--Selma, PhD, 89, died January 18, 2014. Loving wife of Michael Gibeau, sister of Evelyn (deceased) and Mildred/Daisy, mother of Carol, Ellen and Nikki (deceased). doting grandmother, great-grandmother and aunt. Memorial: January 24, 12pm, Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave.

ROSEN--Philip. We at Albert Einstein College of Medicine are deeply saddened by the passing of our dear friend of more than 50 years and esteemed Life Overseer. We have cherished and will sorely miss his friendship, wisdom, passion and creativity. Phil truly exemplified Albert Einstein's credo, that "man is here for the sake of other men--above all for those upon whose smile and well-being our own happiness depends." His exceptional devotion to Einstein and its mission will have an enduring impact on the College of Medicine. Our heartfelt condolences to his beloved wife, Rita, and the entire family. Ruth L. Gottesman, Ed.D. Chair, Board of Overseers Allen M. Spiegel, M.D. The Marilyn and Stanley M. Katz Dean Albert Einstein College of Medicine

ROSEN--Philip, of New Rochelle, NY passed away on Sunday, January 19, 2014. He is survived by his beloved wife Rita of 66 years, his loving children Phyllis Hadley and Michael Rosen, his sons-in-law Robert Landes and Richard Hadley, his daughter-in-law Stephanie Rosen, and his adoring grandchildren; Brett Raskin, Shaun Raskin-Deutschlander, Weston Deutschlander, Matthew Landes, Alexandra Landes, Jacqueline Landes, Alec Rosen, Kayla Rosen and Sierra Rosen. Sadly, Philip was predeceased by his daughter Wendy Landes on March 14, 2013. Born in the Bronx, on September 1, 1921, to Isadore and Anna Rosen, Philip was an outstanding student which enabled him to gain entrance into the Townsend Harris High School. He won a Merit Scholarship for mathematics and was admitted to Cornell University where he graduated in 1942 with a Bachelor of Science degree in Civil Engineering and a letter in Varsity Crew. Immediately after graduation he worked as an engineer for Stone and Webster while working for the United States government on "The Manhattan Project." During World War II he served his country as a Lieutenant in the United States Navy. After the War, Philip joined his father's masonry contracting business, Isadore Rosen and Sons, constructing many buildings throughout the metropolitan area. In addition to providing masonry services for other developers, Isadore Rosen and Sons went on to develop and build numerous buildings on their own behalf. Although success in business was very important to Philip, the idea of "giving back" and social responsibility were paramount. He felt fortunate to be able to contribute much time and energy to the many causes he believed in. Philip was a benefactor of Technion in Israel, a founder of The Chemotherapy Foundation, a benefactor of New Rochelle Hospital, The Juvenile Diabetes Foundation, The Cystic Fibrosis Foundation, and the Anti-Defamation League of B'Nai Brith. He was active in UJA, Federation of Jewish Philanthropies, and United Way. He was an honorary trustee of Temple Israel of New Rochelle, on the Board of Trustees of the Jewish Braille Institute (JBI), and was the founding member of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine's Young Men's Division. Philip and Rita were honored with the Lifetime Achievement Award, in 2004 and Philip remained a "Life Overseer" on The Board of Overseers of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine. Philip was a man of many hobbies. He loved literature and art, collecting stamps and shells but most of all he loved to ski. He skied well into his 80's and passed on that love to all of his children and grandchildren. Philip had a tremendous zest for life and felt he truly got the opportunity to live his American dream. He was loved by many and will be missed. A funeral service will be held on Wednesday, January 22, 2014 at 11:30am at Temple Israel of New Rochelle, 1000 Pinebrook Boulevard, New Rochelle, NY. Donations in Philip's memory should be made to "The Wendy Walk" (www.wendywalk.com) or to the Albert Einstein College of Medicine Men's Division.
ROSEN--Philip, a wonderful friend who was an inspiration to all who knew him. My heartfelt condolences to his loving wife Rita and the entire family. Diane H.

LORIAN--Victor M.D.,on January 20, 2014. Dr. Lorian was a graduate of the University of Bucharest School of Medicine in Romania. After arriving to the United States in 1964, he conducted research in microbiology, concentrating on antibiotics, at the Harvard School of Public Health and later at Bronx Lebanon Hospital Center. He was also a professor of Laboratory Medicine at the Albert Einstein School of Medicine. Among his many publications, he edited five editions of, "Antibiotics in Laboratory Medicine." Beloved husband of Marina. Loved by many extended family members and friends. Visitors may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. on Wednesday from 2-5 and 7-9pm. Funeral Mass at St. Spyridan Greek Orthodox Church in Worcester, Mass on Friday 10:30am.

ROSEN--Philip, was an inspiration and friend of Tau Delta Phi fraternity at Cornell. How proud we all were of his achievements in varsity crew. A friend to me for 73 years. I extend my condolences to lovely Rita and family. Barney

Sullivan, President & Chief Executive Officer Ronald McDonald House New York

ANGEL--Arline, 90, died at Vassar Brothers Medical Center in Poughkeepsie on December 21 from complications of dementia. Cherished mother of Karen Angel, widow of Dr. Klaus Angel, sister-in-law of Dr. Burt and Ann Angrist, aunt of Laurel Angrist, and grandmother of Anny, Imogen and miniature pinscher Lily Angel. A native New Yorker and near-lifelong resident, social worker, devout birder, guardian of nature, insightful confidante, and loving and devoted mother, she had an unbeatable zest for life and love of humor that will live on in those who loved her. She will be sorely missed.

FRANKFURT--Daniel, 88, loving and cherished husband of Ruth for 62 years, father of Judith (James R. Oestreich) and Jackie (Mark Cahn), proud grandfather of Jordan and Joey Frankfurt Cahn, brother of Dina Katz, on January 20, 2014. Founding president of Daniel Frankfurt P.C. Engineers & Architects, a New York City firm, following career involvement in projects including the Telstar communications satellite, and the United States space program's testing facility for the Lunar Excursion Module for the 1969 landing on the moon. Dedicated board member and civic leader in Greenburgh township, ARZA/World Union and Westchester Reform Temple. Alumnus of DeWitt Clinton High School, CCNY and Columbia University. His keen mind, calm spirit and warm soul will be sorely missed. Service: Wednesday, January 22 at 11:30am, West-chester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale, NY.

FRANKFURT--Daniel. The congregation of Westchester Reform Temple mourns the death of a devoted member from its founding generation, a former officer and trustee, and extends sympathy to his bereaved family. Helene K. Gray, President Jonathan E. Blake, Rabbi Jill Abramson, Cantor

GOLDSTEIN--Arnold. The Officers and Members of the Bronx Realty Advisory Board mourn the passing of a highly respected, outstanding leader who was a friend to New York City and its real estate industry. Arnold served as Chairman of the Rent Stabilization Association for many years. He led by example and humility dedicating himself to making our City a better place to live. Arnold will be greatly missed but remembered by the many lives he touched. Michael Laub, Chairman William Schur, President

CAMPION--Jef. The Board of Directors, Volunteers and Staff of Ronald McDonald House New York wish to express our sincere sympathy on the passing of our dear friend, volunteer, and supporter Jef Campion. Jef Campion was a member of the Yonkers Fire Department and volunteer at Ronald McDonald House for twenty years. Sullivan, President & Chief Executive Officer Ronald McDonald House New York

AMORY--Jean Moore, age 92, died peacefully in Vero Beach, FL, on January 17. She was born May 27, 1921 in Bronxville, New York, the daughter of Bertha Stone Moore and Thomas Channing Moore. She attended Miss Porter's School in Farmington, CT. Her first marriage, to Francis B. Trudeau in 1942, ended in divorce in 1959. She later married Harcourt Amory, Jr., on September 15, 1960. He predeceased her in 2006. Jean was the co-owner of an antique shop in NYC, and another in Bedford, NY. She served on the Board of the Blair House Restoration during the Kennedy Administration. She also served on the Board of the Hospital for Special Surgery for over 25 years, and was a member of the City Mission Benefit Board. A devoted mother, Jean is survived by her daughter Jeanne Trudeau Fenn and her husband, Henry Fenn; her son Garry Trudeau and his wife, Jane Pauley Trudeau; her daughter Michelle Trudeau and her husband, Steven Potkin; and her stepdaughter Dita Amory Nickson and her husband, Graham Nickson. She is also survived by six grandchildren and many nieces and nephews, all of whom will greatly miss their beloved Baba. A service in her memory will be held at St. Mark's Church in Vero Beach at 4:00pm on Saturday, January 25. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to: VNA Hospice of Indian River County, 1110 35th Lane, Vero Beach, FL 32960 or St. Mark's Church, P.O. Box 6994, Vero Beach, FL 32961.

ADOLFSEN--Lauren Anne, on January 20, 2014. Beloved daughter of Joyce and Lou Adolfsen. Loving sister of Eric and his wife Lisa, and cherished girlfriend of Stephen Kaye. A graduate of Dalton, Skidmore and Yale. She was the creator of Snack Mountain, as well as a lover of food, music and art, who will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her. Service Thursday 10am, January 23rd at Central Synagogue, 55th St. at Lexington Ave. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Memorial Sloan Kettering.

BERRY--Peter Chamberlain, 60, of New York City, died of a heart attack while running in Central Park on Sunday, January 19. He is survived by his children Shirley Lupton Berry, James Chamberlain Berry and Peter Ward Berry and his former wife, Tav Holmes Berry. Peter is also survived by his mother Nancy Ward Berry, brother Charles G. Berry, and nephews Nicholas, Samuel and Christopher Berry. He was predeceased by his father Rynn Berry, brother Eliot Ward Berry and half-brother Rynn Berry, Jr. Peter graduated from the Buckley School, Groton School, Yale College, Boston University Law School, where he was a member of the Law Review, and NYU Law School's Graduate Tax Program. After a clerkship with Judge Edward R. Neaher of the Federal District Court in Brooklyn, Peter specialized in tax and corporate trust law and helped set up the first exchange-traded fund (ETF) for trading gold. Throughout his life he was a scholar, bibliophile and reader on all subjects, read Latin and ancient Greek for pleasure, and had a deep knowledge of early printed books and fine typography. Peter was a member of the Yale Varsity Squash Team, an A-ranked player in the New York Metropolitan Squash League, a lifelong advanced practitioner of yoga, and a tireless bicycle rider throughout the City. He cared deeply for his family and friends, who sorely miss him. A memorial service will be held at St. James' Church, Madison Avenue and 71st Street, on Monday, January 27 at 4pm followed by a reception. Gifts in Peter's memory may be made to The New York Society Library, 53 East 79th Street, NYC 10075, or The Elizabethan Club of Yale University, 459 College Street, New Haven, CT 06511.

AYERS--Emory D.,85, died peacefully in his home in Stonington, Connecticut on Saturday, January 11, 2014 surrounded by family, friends, and clergy. His death was due to complications from Parkinson's disease. Emory was born December 23, 1928 in Tyus, Georgia, the son of Enoch and Lottie Ayers. He received a Civil Engineering degree from Georgia Institute of Technology in 1950, and was on active duty in the United States Navy from 1950 to 1953. He participated in the Inchon landing during the Korean War and was awarded the Korean Service Medal 5 Stars, United Nations Medal, and the Navy Occupation Medal. He was in the Navy reserves until receiving an honorable discharge in 1961. From 1953 to 1972 Emory was employed by Union Carbide Corporation in Charleston, West Virginia and New York City, and he became executive in charge of Union Carbide's Tin and Tantalum business in Thailand. He earned his MBA from New York University in 1962. He was employed by Theodore Barry Associates from 1972 to 1974 and founded Emory Ayers Associates in 1974, later named Ayers/ Whitmore Associates, New York. He served as Chairman, Interstate Bakeries, Kansas City, in 1984; and founded and served as President of New York Management Consultants from 1985 to 1998 where he worked with top management on strategic issues for companies including Standard Oil, Alyeska Pipeline, and the IBM Personal Computer Group. He also consulted with New York Consulting Partners. Emory retired from consulting in 2003. From an early age Emory was interested in seeking the Divine. He was active in a number of churches during his life including St. Matthews Church, Wilton, Connecticut where he served on the Vestry and became Warden. He studied with Dr. Thomas Hora, Founder of the New York Institute of Metapsychiatry from 1979 to 1995. In 1997 with his wife Susan, Emory founded Avatar Meher Baba Foundation, Inc., dedicated to the teachings of Avatar Meher Baba. Emory joined Calvary Church (Episcopal), in Stonington, Connecticut. Emory was grateful for all the people who were a beneficial presence during his spiritual journey including Rev. Dr. Alfred Tisdale, Rev. Dr. Douglass Lind, Dr. Thomas Hora, and Bhau Kalchuri. Emory's passions included music, sailing, and cycling. He was a long time member of Masons Island Yacht Club, Mystic, Connecticut; and Emory was also a member of The Union League Club, New York, NY; and The Economics Club, New York, NY. Emory is survived by Susan, his wife of 32 years; his brother Fred and his wife Pat; three children from his first marriage to Alice Lowndes Ayers: Daniel and spouse Tony Seguino, Elizabeth Ayers Cabrera, Jonathan and wife Heryun Kim Ayers, and four grandchildren: Alice Marie Cabrera, Kimberly Danielle Ayers, Lauren Juliet Ayers and Margaret Brooke Ayers. A Celebration of Emory's Life will be held at Calvary Church, in Stonington, Connecticut, on Saturday, February 15th at 11am; followed by a reception in the Parish Hall. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation to the charity of your choice in honor of the life of Emory Ayers.

JACOBSON--Edith, beloved wife of the late Dr. Morton Jacobson, cherished mother of Lesley and Jeffrey Jacobson and their spouses Ron DuBreuil and Caroline Ghertler. Adored grandmother of Micah DuBreuil and Sonya Jacobson. Formerly of Hastings-on-Hudson, NY and Palm Beach, FL. Edith died after a brief illness surrounded by loved ones. Funeral Services at the Edward Dowdle Funeral Home in Dobbs Ferry, NY on Thursday, January 23 at 10am.

AGATA--Burton C.,Professor Emeritus, Hofstra Law School, died peacefully at his home in Hudson, NY on January 20th at the age of 85. By his side was his beloved wife of 58 years, Dale. He also leaves behind his son Seth, daughter-in-law Gail, treasured grandson Adam, and dear cousins, nieces, nephews, in-laws and friends. The one tragedy in his life was the loss in 1997 of his beloved daughter Abby, before her and his time. He leaves a legacy of love and achievement. Those wishing to honor his memory may make a donation to the Southern Poverty Law Center in his name.

KAPLAN--Bernard, age 91, of Miami, FL, born in Brooklyn, after a brave 20-year battle with prostate cancer. Educated at Boys High and Brooklyn College; served in the Navy during World War II; worked in the handbag, financial and taxi industries. He lived long enough to see Civil War veterans parade on Memorial Day in his youth, and to use computers in old age. Proudly progressive in his politics, he cheered for Roosevelt at a parade in 1936 and voted for every Democrat for President since then. He was a man of rigorous intellectual honesty, decency and generosity, who identified strongly with the Jewish people. Son of the late Max and Rebecca Kaplan of Brooklyn. Predeceased by his wife, Phyllis, in 1989. Survived by his son, Richard, of Westbury, LI, his grandsons Daniel of Brooklyn; Adam of Bogota, Colombia; and Paul of Chicago, and his close companion of twenty years, Edith Weinberg of Miami. Burial Thursday, New Montefiore Cemetery located in Farmingdale, NY.

GOLDSTEIN--Arnold. You were my friend and mentor. I will dearly miss your advice, counsel and friendship. Thank you for your love and influence on my life. Deepest sympathy to Arlene and the entire Goldstein family. Michael Laub

GOLDSTEIN--Arnold. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Arnold Goldstein, a dedicated philanthropist who leaves behind a legacy of exceptional commitment to the Jewish people. We extend our condolences to Arnold's wife, Arlene; his children, Scott (Lauren), Shari, and Michael (Janice); his grandchildren, Jackie, Alex, Joey, Calli, Marisa, and Jordan; and the entire family. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; John S. Ruskay, Executive VP & CEO

SCHINDEL--Murray. (1920-2014) Died suddenly and peacefully, January 20 at age 93. He was predeceased by his beloved wife of 65 years, Edith, his parents, Anna and Jacob, his sister Ruth, and his brother Irving. Murray is survived by his two nephews, Carl and Mark Stewart and his many friends. Murray served as a 1st Lt. in the U.S. Army during the 2nd World War; he was a lover of the arts, a humanist, and a champion of the rights of the poor and disadvantaged. Funeral services will be at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th St., NY, NY at 11:30am, Sunday, January 26. A memorial service will be held in the near future. For details, contact Carl Stewart at: carlstewartlaw@gmail.com.

WEITZEL--William C.,Jr., age 78, a resident of Cornish, NH, passed away on January 20, 2014 after a long battle with cancer. Mr. Weitzel was a partner of the law firm of Cummings and Lockwood and a retired Senior Vice President and General Counsel of Texaco, Inc. Bill is survived by his wife, Loretta; son, William C. Weitzel III and wife, Michelle; son Richard S. Weitzel and wife, Christine and two children, Nicole and Ryan; daughter Sarah L. Farrell and husband Richard, their four children, Emma, Richie, Liam and Nora; and son, Andrew K. Weitzel. Calling hours January 23rd, 2014, 11am to 1pm at the Ricker Funeral Home in Lebanon, NH. Service: January 24th, 2014, 9am, at the Plainfield Community Church in Plainfield, NH. Burial will be at the Chase Cemetery in Cornish, NH in the spring. Condolences may be expressed with the family by visiting www.rickerfuneralhome.com

WALSH--Joseph, Board of CIVITAS Citizens Inc. mourns the loss of Joseph Walsh, longtime Board member and President from 2008-2010. We will miss his strategic counsel, his love of urban life and desire for excellent architecture. Memorial Mass on Saturday January 25 at 11am, Church of the Sacred Heart Jesus, 457 W 51 St.

STANTON--Walter X.,Jr, formerly of Port Washington, NY, passed away peacefully at Southampton Hospital on January 20, 2014 from complications related to a fall. Walter, known as Ted, was born April 29, 1934 to Walter and Gertrude Kinsley Stanton in the Bronx, NY. He attended Fordham Prep, Fordham College, and Columbia Law School, graduating as a Stone Scholar. Married to Anne Hickey Stanton for over 50 years, he is survived by loving children: Anne, Elizabeth, Tony, Peter, and Christopher and eight cherished grandchildren. Predeceased by brothers Michael K. and Joseph L. Stanton. Reposing at O'Connell Funeral Home, Southampton, Friday, 2-4pm and 7-9pm and a Mass of Christian Burial on Saturday at 10am at The Basilica of the Sacred Hearts of Jesus & Mary. Interment at Sacred Hearts Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to "A Kid's Brain Tumor Cure Foundation" 98 Random Farms Drive, Chappaqua, NY 10514.

LEVINSOHN--Jay Douglas. Born May 7, 1923 in New York City, Jay passed away suddenly January 19, at Cedars Sinai Hospital in LA, surrounded by his loving wife, daughter and son. Jay brightened every day and every room with his smile, easygoing manner, and optimistic view of the world. He grew up in NYC and Rumson, NJ, graduated from Phillips Academy Andover, and Princeton University and served for the US Army during World War II. In 1959, he married the former Joyce Salton, and settled in Tenafly, NJ, where they stayed for 35 years. He spent nearly his entire career in the boys and men's clothing business and was one of the industry's leading and most well-liked figures. Father, husband, grandfather, friend, and role model, he was a kind, gentle and inspirational man, and woke each day with optimism. He is survived by his wife of 55 years Joyce, daughter Sharon, son Ross, daughter-in-law Nicole, and grandchildren Skylar and Jagger.

MCLANE--Robert Milligan, a longtime resident of Locust Valley, NY died peacefully at home on January 18. Born February 2, 1930 in New York City, youngest child of Edith Gibb Maxwell and Allan McLane. Mr. McLane graduated from St Paul's School (1948) and from Yale University (1952), then served in the US Navy for two years. His professional career was with Marsh & McLennan Companies, where he retired as a Senior Vice President in 1994. Devoted to family and friends, he was an avid sportsman who enjoyed golf, racquet sports, and upland game hunting. He served on the Boards of Charles Pratt & Co, Good Hope Corporation, Greenpoint Savings Bank, Greenwood Cemetery, Piping Rock Club and on the Vestry at St. John's of Lattingtown. Mr. McLane was predeceased by his wife of 54 years Camilla Merritt McLane and his brother Allan McLane. He is survived by his children Nina Burchfield (Bill) and Robert M. McLane Jr. (Gratia); grandchildren William, Camilla and Jennifer Burchfield, and Robert III, Allison and Nicholas McLane; and his sister Edith Gibb Edson. A memorial service will be held at 11:00am on January 25th at St. John's of Lattingtown in Locust Valley, NY.
FELD--Isabel. January 23, 2000 14 years of missing your smile, quick wit, laughter and warm heart. Your light still shines. Loved and missed every day. Steph

SAYERS--Ross Verey, M.D.,died December 10, 2013 in Klamath Falls, Oregon at the age of 93. Dr. Sayers was born in New York City and grew up in Rye and Port Chester, NY. He attended George Washington High School. Dr. Sayers was musically gifted and admitted to the Juilliard School of Music at age 16 but opted to attend Columbia University graduating in 1941. Ross is a World War II Veteran having spent time in the Pacific Theatre. Dr. Sayers obtained his M.D. from the University of Louvain Medical School in Belgium. He became fluent in Dutch and French. Dr. Sayers worked in medical research helping launch over 100 FDA approved drugs. Dr. Sayers developed an ophthalmology practice in Madison, Connecticut and continued service to his patients until age 78. He taught for 20 years at the Yale University Medical School. Ross played the organ at many churches in NYC including Carnegie Hall. Ross is survived by three children, a sister, and life partner Carolyn Larson and her children.

RUBIN--Jeffrey Mark, 70, beloved husband, father, grandfather, brother, attorney and best friend, died January 21st after a courageous seven year battle with cancer. A lion of a man, he approached every moment of his young life with passion, humor, and adventure. His love for the law was matched only by his love for the sea and its endless horizons, but it was his family in which he found safe harbor. We are thankful for how he taught us to live with gusto and bravery and to value each moment. A world without him is overwhelming, but we take heart that he is within and around us providing the strength we need to go on. We love you forever. He is survived by his devoted family, wife Susan, son Aaron, daughter Lauren and Michael Virk, daughter Diana and Alexander Rus, sister Enid and grandchildren David and Nicholas Rus. Service Thursday, January 23, 2014, 11:15am, at "The Riverside," 76th and Amsterdam.
RUBIN--Jeffrey. Thank you for a lifetime of love, laughter and friendship. Who you were and what you stood for will live on within the rest of us. Mitchell, Lois, Jesse and Brian
PERLIN--Bernard, 95, died January 14. He was a noted artist with works in major museum collections (see BernardPerlin.com), and was beloved by all who knew him.

RUBIN--Jeffrey. My beloved and dearest friend. You were like a brother to me for over fifty years. You will forever be in my heart and on my mind. Now you are at peace. Our prayers are with Susan, your children Aaron, Lauren and Diana and your two beautiful grandchildren. Love Sandy and Jill
RUBIN--Jeffrey. He was my brother and best friend. We were lucky to have him in our lives. Truly one of a kind. He will be missed beyond words. Bob & Kathryn Bregman Robert & Kate Bregman

SCHAPIRO--Edward, a resident of Union City, NJ was born on August 17th, 1964. He passed away on December 26, 2013. Teddy, his preferred name, graduated from California Institute of the Arts with a degree in Fine Arts. In 1991, he had a well-reviewed one-man art show in Manhattan. However, collectibles were Teddy's passion. His collection is of museum quality. Teddy is survived by his devoted aunt, Susanne Smith, his father, Steve Schapiro, his sister, Taylor Schapiro, his brother, Abba Schapiro, his step-brother, Theophilus Donoghue and his step-mother, Maura Smith. In lieu of flowers please make donations to the Water Project.

LEVY--Mildred Cherin, died January 19, 2014, after a lengthy illness. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Gerald Levy; loving mother of Gerald Joseph Levy, Lanis-Ruth Levy and Nathan Jay Levy; cherished sister of Shirley Cherin Sigler and the late William Sanford Cherin. She will be missed by the many who loved her. In lieu of flowers, donations to UNISEF will be appreciated.

MAYER--Peter, died peacefully at home on January 19, 2014 at the age of 92. Born on December 5, 1921, in Mannheim, Germany, Peter escaped from Nazi Germany in 1936 with his family, and settled in New York. He was married to Reggie, who he loved and adored for 67 years. After retiring from the precious gems business, he devoted his time to volunteer endeavors. He was manager of the New York City Clothing Bank where he solicited donations of new clothing for the homeless. Peter served on the board of Congregation Habonim and was the Chair of the Queens Committee. He was a trustee of the Margaret Tietz Center Nursing Home and for years visited its residents weekly. Peter devoted his life to others. He leaves a legacy of caring for family, friends, temple and community. He is survived by his wife Reggie, two daughters Nancy and Susan (Stephen), and four grandchildren: Jeremy (Heather), Janelle (Joshua), Sarah and Emily. Funeral services will be held at Schwartz Brothers in Forest Hills, on Thursday January 23 at 1pm. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions to Selfhelp Community Services or Congregation Habonim.

GOLDSTEIN--Arnold. Columbia University Medical Center mourns the passing of our great friend and supporter, Arnold Goldstein. The vision and generosity of him and his family have been cornerstones of our Division of Cardiology, most recently with the establishment of the Arnold and Arlene Goldstein Professorship of Cardiology. We offer our condolences to his wife, Arlene; his children, Scott, Shari and Michael; his grandchildren; and the extended Goldstein family. Allan Schwartz, MD Chief, Division of Cardiology Vice Chair, Department of Medicine Mathew S. Maurer, MD Arnold and Arlene Goldstein Associate Professor of Cardiology

CAHN--Robert Frederick, of Boca Raton, Florida and previously of Briarcliff Manor and Searingtown, NY. 76 years old, passed away on January 22, 2014. Beloved husband of the late Bonnie Sorkin Cahn. Devoted father of Adam Cahn and his wife Melissa Waters, and Jody Hirsch and her husband Todd. Cherished grandfather of Jasper and Miles Cahn, and Benjamin and Claudia Hirsch. Dear brother of Arthur Cahn and his wife Shirley. Loving companion of Hedy Mandell. Services Sunday January 26, 2014 at 10:00am at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, NY.

AGATA--Burton C.,Professor Emeritus, Hofstra Law School, died peacefully at his home in Hudson, NY on January 20th at the age of 85. By his side was his beloved wife of 58 years, Dale. He also leaves behind his son Seth, daughter-in-law Gail, treasured grandson Adam, and dear cousins, nieces, nephews, in-laws and friends. The one tragedy in his life was the loss in 1997 of his beloved daughter Abby, before her and his time. He leaves a legacy of love and achievement. Those wishing to honor his memory may make a donation to the Southern Poverty Law Center in his name.

BERRY--Peter Chamberlain, 60, of New York City, died of a heart attack while running in Central Park on Sunday, January 19. He is survived by his children Shirley Lupton Berry, James Chamberlain Berry and Peter Ward Berry and his former wife, Tav Holmes Berry. Peter is also survived by his mother Nancy Ward Berry, brother Charles G. Berry, and nephews Nicholas, Samuel and Christopher Berry. He was predeceased by his father Rynn Berry, brother Eliot Ward Berry and half-brother Rynn Berry, Jr. Peter graduated from the Buckley School, Groton School, Yale College, Boston University Law School, where he was a member of the Law Review, and NYU Law School's Graduate Tax Program. After a clerkship with Judge Edward R. Neaher of the Federal District Court in Brooklyn, Peter specialized in tax and corporate trust law and helped set up the first exchange-traded fund (ETF) for trading gold. Throughout his life he was a scholar, bibliophile and reader on all subjects, read Latin and ancient Greek for pleasure, and had a deep knowledge of early printed books and fine typography. Peter was a member of the Yale Varsity Squash Team, an A-ranked player in the New York Metropolitan Squash League, a lifelong advanced practitioner of yoga, and a tireless bicycle rider throughout the City. He cared deeply for his family and friends, who sorely miss him. A memorial service will be held at St. James' Church, Madison Avenue and 71st Street, on Monday, January 27 at 4pm followed by a reception. Gifts in Peter's memory may be made to The New York Society Library, 53 East 79th Street, NYC 10075, or The Elizabethan Club of Yale University, 459 College Street, New Haven, CT 06511.

FILBIN--Dr. Marie T. The City University of New York deeply mourns the passing of Dr. Marie T. Filbin, Distinguished Professor of Biology at Hunter College/CUNY, and internationally renowned neuroscientist. Her pioneering work was critical to understanding paralysis and the development of drugs to reverse spinal cord injuries. Dr. Filbin will be long remembered as a staunch advocate and mentor for her students. Our deepest sympathies go to her family and friends. Benno Schmidt, Chairperson, CUNY Board of Trustees William P. Kelly, Interim Chancellor Gillian Small, Vice Chancellor for Research

LEE--Samantha. We at NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital and Columbia University Medical Center are deeply saddened by the tragic and sudden loss of our dear friend and colleague Dr. Samantha Lee, who was a first-year resident in our department of anesthesiology. Dr. Lee was at the beginning of her medical career with a future filled with hope and promise when her life was cut short. We miss her and mourn her passing. Our most profound sympathies are extended to her family. Steven J. Corwin, MD, CEO, NY-Presbyterian Hospital Lee Goldman, MD, Dean, Columbia University Medical Center Robert E. Kelly, MD, President, NY-Presbyterian Hospital Margaret Wood, MD, Chair and Anesthesiologist-in-Chief, NY-Presbyterian/Columbia

ADOLFSEN--Lauren. We note with sorrow the passing of our longtime member Lauren Adolfsen and extend sincerest condolences to her bereaved family. Rabbi Peter J. Rubinstein President David B. Edelson Central Synagogue of New York City

GOLDSTEIN--Arnold. We express our sorrow over the loss of our dear friend and client, Arnold Goldstein. Arnold was a true prince among men and a role model in how to conduct business with unyielding honesty and integrity. He was instrumental in building our firm's success and we will forever cherish his friendship and support. We extend heartfelt condolences to his wife, Arlene, to his children, Scott, Shari and Michael, and to his nieces, nephews and grandchildren. May the family take solace in his accomplishments and legacy, and find comfort among the mourners of Zion. Ralph Herzka, Meridian Capital Group, LLC

GOLDSTEIN--Arnold. NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital mourns the passing of Arnold Goldstein. Mr. Goldstein was a dear friend of our institution who, with his wife, Arlene, generously supported cardiology services at NewYork-Presbyterian/ Columbia. His legacy of support includes the Arlene and Arnold Goldstein Surgery Center. Mr. Goldstein was a visionary supporter of medicine who had a passion for improving patient care and advancing research. We extend our deepest condolences to Arlene and his entire family. Steven J. Corwin, MD, CEO, NY-Presbyterian Hospital

KAPLAN--Bernard, age 91, of Miami, FL, born in Brooklyn, after a brave 20-year battle with prostate cancer. Educated at Boys High and Brooklyn College; served in the Navy during World War II; worked in the handbag, financial and taxi industries. He lived long enough to see Civil War veterans parade on Memorial Day in his youth, and to use computers in old age. Proudly progressive in his politics, he cheered for Roosevelt at a parade in 1936 and voted for every Democrat for President since then. He was a man of rigorous intellectual honesty, decency and generosity, who identified strongly with the Jewish people. Son of the late Max and Rebecca Kaplan of Brooklyn. Predeceased by his wife, Phyllis, in 1989. Survived by his son, Richard, of Westbury, LI, his grandsons Daniel of Brooklyn; Adam of Bogota, Colombia; and Paul of Chicago, and his close companion of twenty years, Edith Weinberg of Miami. Burial Thursday, New Montefiore Cemetery located in Farmingdale, NY.

ADOLFSEN--Lauren Anne, on January 20, 2014. Beloved daughter of Joyce and Lou Adolfsen. Loving sister of Eric and his wife Lisa, and cherished girlfriend of Stephen Kaye. A graduate of Dalton, Skidmore and Yale. She was the creator of Snack Mountain, as well as a lover of food, music and art, who will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her. Service Thursday 10am, January 23rd at Central Synagogue, 55th St. at Lexington Ave. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Memorial Sloan Kettering.

DeVRIES--Phyllis Krex, age 92, passed away on January 21st. Adored wife of Philip (deceased), loving mother of Philip Jr, Mary, Jane and Robert. Dear sister of Nina Silverman and Ruth Druxerman. Loving grandmother of Ben, Jennie, Emily, Rebecca and Megan. Great-grandmother of Maddy and Harry. She will be greatly missed by her many friends and family.

LEE--Leslie. The Trustees, Staff and Artists of Signature Theatre mourn the loss of Playwright Leslie Lee. Leslie was a beloved member of the Signature family. His talent, humor and irresistible smile will be deeply missed by all who knew him.
