WARWICK--Arnold S. Born in Brooklyn on October 18, 1931, passed away January 21 in New York City. He lived in Greenwich Village for 60 years - most of it with his late wife, Jane. He is survived by his children, Liadain, Matthew, Samantha, and seven grandchildren.

SNYDER--Marc A.,Marc A. Snyder passed away on January 20, 2014. Marc dedicated his life to helping others, both as a psychotherapist and a devoted father, husband, brother and friend. He will be remembered for his humble wisdom, sharp sense of humor, and sage advice. He is preceded in death by his wife, Susan Krupnick Snyder; father, Maury Snyder; and his mother and father-in-law, Lee and Samuel Krupnick. He is survived by his children, Michael Snyder of Austin, TX and Rachel Snyder of White Plains, NY; sister and brother-in-law, Jessica Josell Wechsler and Steven Wechsler of New York, NY; brother and sister-in-law David Snyder and Maribel Snyder; and mother, Rose Snyder of Miami, FL. He will be laid to rest with his wife in St. Louis, MO. A memorial is scheduled to celebrate Marc's life on Saturday January, 25 from 2:00pm to 5:00pm at Women's Club of White Plains, 305 Ridgeway, White Plains, NY 10605.

TRUSLOW--Sophia LaVerdiere, 68, died on January 21st in Brooklyn, New York. Survived by son Julian LaVerdiere, siblings Elizabeth Russell, Francis Truslow, Frederic Truslow, John Howell, Shirley Caracciolo, and by longtime friend Bruno LaVerdiere. A native New Yorker, she received numerous degrees throughout her life: BFA from Skidmore College and the Penland School, MFA from Boston Museum School, law degree from Boston University, MA in Historical Preservation from Columbia University. Sophy pursued her many passions as a member of the Historic District Council, board member of the New York Marble Cemetery, member of the Woman Flyfisher's Club, and she expressed these passions in the world she lovingly created within her converted firehouse in Boreum Hill. A devoted mother, she was a force of nature whose wit, charm and gusto and whose immediate affection and embrace of all will live on long past her days. She will be profoundly missed by her many friends. Services will be held at 11am on Saturday, January 25th at St. John's Church, 1670 Rte. 25A, Cold Spring Harbor, NY 11724.

SCHINDEL--Murray. (1920-2014) Died suddenly and peacefully, January 20 at age 93. He was predeceased by his beloved wife of 65 years, Edith, his parents, Anna and Jacob, his sister Ruth, and his brother Irving. Murray is survived by his two nephews, Carl and Mark Stewart and his many friends. Murray served as a 1st Lt. in the U.S. Army during the 2nd World War; he was a lover of the arts, a humanist, and a champion of the rights of the poor and disadvantaged. Funeral services will be at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th St., NY, NY at 11:30am, Sunday, January 26. A memorial service will be held in the near future. For details, contact Carl Stewart at: carlstewartlaw@gmail.com.

STANTON--Walter X.,Jr, formerly of Port Washington, NY, passed away peacefully at Southampton Hospital on January 20, 2014 from complications related to a fall. Walter, known as Ted, was born April 29, 1934 to Walter and Gertrude Kinsley Stanton in the Bronx, NY. He attended Fordham Prep, Fordham College, and Columbia Law School, graduating as a Stone Scholar. Married to Anne Hickey Stanton for over 50 years, he is survived by loving children: Anne, Elizabeth, Tony, Peter, and Christopher and eight cherished grandchildren. Predeceased by brothers Michael K. and Joseph L. Stanton. Reposing at O'Connell Funeral Home, Southampton, Friday, 2-4pm and 7-9pm and a Mass of Christian Burial on Saturday at 10am at The Basilica of the Sacred Hearts of Jesus & Mary. Interment at Sacred Hearts Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to "A Kid's Brain Tumor Cure Foundation" 98 Random Farms Drive, Chappaqua, NY 10514.

ZUFALL--Kathryn "Kay", died January 18, 2014, at the age of 87, in The Country Home of Morris Plains, NJ, where she was treated with great kindness. She had had Alzheimer's disease for a few years. In 1990, after doing volunteer work in Peru, she and her husband, Dr. Robert Zufall, started the Dover Free Clinic, providing primary medical care to underserved people in Dover, NJ. It later became the Dover Community Clinic, and then the Zufall Health Center. She was the administrative director of the center for several years. In 1956, along with her brother-in law, Joseph McVicker, she created Play-Doh. Joe had a company which made a doughy wallpaper cleaner. Kay suggested that this could be modeled, rolled out, cut with cookie cutters, and made into a creative children's toy. She and her husband suggested the name 'Play-Doh'. Joe produced and marketed it, and it has since become a worldwide product. Donations may be made in her memory to the Zufall Health Center, 18 West Blackwell Street, Dover, NJ 07801.
KNIFFEN--Robert. July 24, 1926 - Jan. 24, 2012 We miss you as husband, father and grandfather. Love you always. Your family.

SCOTT--Ann Myra (nee Rosen), on January 22, 2014. Wife of the late Carl. Sister of the late Samuel Rosen, the late Irving Rosen, and the late Albert Rosen. Beloved sister-in-law of Gilda Rosen, Michael Scott, and Jeanne Scott. Cherished aunt of Mitchell Rosen, Glenn Rosen, Robert Rosen, Mark Rosen, and Lynne Friedman. Relatives and friends are invited to Graveside Services Sunday 2pm precisely at Roosevelt Memorial Park (sec. B-10) Trevose. www.goldsteinsfuneral.com

REVERE--Thomas Jonathan, 74, of Seven Gates Farm in West Tisbury, on Martha's Vineyard. Known as Jonathan, he was the son of Thomas and Althea Revere of New York City, and is survived by his sister, Lee Revere. Writer and poet, he was at the center of cultural life on the island, noted for his ability to bring together people in the arts with similar interests. His Class Poet at Harvard University, from which he graduated in 1960, at the time of his death he was nearing completion of a novel. He had a deep interest in and encyclopedic knowledge of American literature, as well as music, theatre, and film, while his concern for government transparency led him to spearhead reforms in local government. He was an elected member of the Finance Committee of West Tisbury, and on the Board of Directors of MVTV, where he was also a producer and chronicler of island life. He was known island-wide for his generosity, wit, and constant loyalty. A memorial service is planned for the spring.

We extend our heartfelt condolences to her entire family. Dean R. O'Hare, Kendrick R. Wilson III, Co-Chairs, Board of Trustees Thomas P. Sculco, M.D., Surgeon-in-Chief Louis A. Shapiro, President and CEO, Hospital for Special Surgery
GLASS--Dr. Leonard. We mourn the loss of Dr. Leonard Glass, whose character and goodness touched us all in ways that will last forever. The Scheinfeld Family.

GOLDSTEIN--Arnold, (A.G.) The Solomon Organization wishes to express our sincerest condolences to Arnold's wife, Arlene, children Scott, Shari, Michael and the entire Goldstein Family. Arnold was a great partner, dear friend, and mentor for more than 25 years. A giant in the Real Estate Industry. He will be missed but always remembered. The Solomon Organization Marc S. Solomon Founder

MORGAN--David William, 85, died peacefully at home in Darien, CT January 20, 2014. A dedicated and beloved husband and father, he was surrounded by his wife of 42 years, Mary Louise Fitzsimmons, and children Mallory and David Jr. having battled Primary CNS Lymphoma for 22 months. Born July 6, 1928 in Cleveland, OH to Dr. John Benjamin Morgan and Bertha Amersbach Morgan; he graduated from La Salle University in 1950. Before founding Morgan Communications in 1978, he worked for Catalina Swimwear, Harper's Bazaar, Seventeen, and CBS. He represented the San Fransisco 49ers at the 2000-2006 NFL Drafts. A 32 year resident of Darien, he was active in town politics as elected Constable for 20 years. In 1986 he founded and ran the charity "Bikes For Bed-Stuy" for 13 years. He was a longtime member of the Spring Lake Bath & Tennis Club in NJ. Funeral Mass will be held at St. John Church in Darien on January 25, 2014 at 10:00am. Donations may be made to www.burke.org

KRAUSE--Robert L.,died peacefully on January 23 after a short illness. He was in his 91st year. Survived by his beloved wife Susan, devoted children Janet Krause ("Jatila") van der Veen (Steve Davis), Frederic Krause (Jennifer Moore), Ann Galler (Andy Galler), and Jonathan Laufer (Laura Bucko). Loving grandfather to Benjamin Laufer, Adrienne and Aidan Galler, and Devananda van der Veen. Leader in the Equipment Finance industry. Services Sunday, January 26 at 10am at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, New York.

GOLDSTEIN--Arnold, (A.G.) "Valiant in life and more valiant in death." More than 25 years my Real Estate partner, my dear friend and mentor. A giant in the Real Estate Industry who flew under the radar. Real Estate was our connection but our friendship was the final result. An active philanthropist, he was dearly loved, trusted, respected and admired. His word was his bond. I will deeply miss him and never forget him. Sincerest condolences to his wife, Arlene, children Scott, Shari, Michael and the entire Goldstein Family. Rest in peace, Marc S. Solomon
KRAUSE--Robert L.,Our dearest friend, you will always be in our hearts. Shirley and Bob

EISNER--Professor Elliot W.,passed away peacefully in his home in Stanford, California, on January 10th due to complications from Parkinson's disease. Eisner was born in Chicago, Illinois on March 10, 1933. He taught at Stanford University for 42 years and was the Lee Jacks Emeritus Professor of Education and Art. Eisner was widely recognized as an exceptional teacher and scholar. He authored hundreds of written works and was the recipient of numerous awards, including six honorary doctorates, the Grawmeyer Award and membership in the Royal Society of Arts in the U.K. Elliot Eisner was a man of great vitality who had a broad smile and a great sense of humor. Elliot's aesthetic sensibilities enabled him to see artistic qualities that others often missed. Appreciating those qualities was a daily occurrence for this man who made his life in the arts. Elliot W. Eisner is survived by his wife of 57 years, Ellie, son Steve Eisner, daughter Linda Eislund, son-in-law Eric Eislund, and grandsons Ari, Seth and Drew. A memorial service at Stanford's Graduate School of Education will follow in the coming months. Those who desire to remember and honor Elliot W. Eisner may make contributions to the Elliot Eisner Lifetime Achievement Award Fund at the National Art Education Association, 1806 Robert Fulton Drive, Suite 300, Reston, Virginia 20191.

LEVY--Mildred Cherin, died January 19, 2014, after a lengthy illness. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Gerald Levy; loving mother of Gerald Joseph Levy, Lanis-Ruth Levy and Nathan Jay Levy; cherished sister of Shirley Cherin Sigler and the late William Sanford Cherin. She will be missed by the many who loved her. In lieu of flowers, donations to UNISEF will be appreciated.

BASSECHES--Mark T.,83, of Savannah, GA, formerly of Pleasantville, NY, passed away on January 18, 2014. He is survived by his wife, Janet; two sons, Stuart, (Judy) and Jeffrey (Robbin); a daughter, Julie Booth, (Mark), and four grandchildren.

FRERICHS--Ernest S. 88, of Warren, RI. Co-founder of the Religious Studies Department and the Judaic Studies Program at Brown University; also professor, assistant dean of the College and dean of the graduate school across 42-year career at Brown; lectured widely in Hebrew Bible and the history of Biblical Interpretation across England, Europe and the former Soviet Union; edited, co-edited or authored sixteen books; for 13 field seasons, led volunteer and consortium relationships for the Tel Miqne-Ekron Excavation and Publication Project in Israel. In 1995, became executive director of the Dorot Foundation, a family foundation providing grants and the Dorot Fellowship in Israel to enliven the American Jewish landscape. A native of Tottenville, Staten Island; educated in the public schools of NYC. Sergeant in the U.S. Army's 100th Infantry Division; recipient of the Bronze Star for Battle of the Vosges Mountains. Ordained Elder in the United Methodist Church; served as pastor at Mathewson Street United Methodist Church in Providence, RI prior to joining the faculty of Brown. Noted for such traits as modesty, humility, compassion, and gentleness, his life is best characterized in the title of a festschrift presented to him by friends and colleagues, Hesed ve-Emet (Kindness and Truth). Equally at home in Jewish and Christian circles, he knew no enemy, but gave great encouragement to all, especially those in need, preferring to think of himself as an enabler.

BRODY--Nathaniel. Congregation Rodeph Sholom notes with sorrow the death of our member, Ned Brody, beloved husband of Rita Aizer-Brody. The Brody family are members for over 25 years. We will miss his caring and selfless devotion to his family and community. Our deepest condolences to Rita, their sons, Ab and Jacob and all their dear ones. Robert N. Levine, D.D., Senior Rabbi Karen L. Berman, President

DYE--Nedenia Post, business owner and entrepreneur, died December 22, 2013 in her home in Roatan, Honduras. She was 46. Ms. Dye was born in Santa Monica, CA on November 30, 1967 to parents Peter and Marjorie Durant Dye. She graduated from St. Monica Catholic High School in 1986. Nedenia continued her education and moved to Washington, D.C. in the fall of 1988 to enroll in Mount Vernon College (now George Washington University) where she earned a Bachelor of Arts degree in Communications in 1992. Nedenia was a devoted daughter, sister, niece, cousin and friend who lived her life abundantly. She owned and operated Spa Baan Suerte on the island of Roatan, Honduras where she made her home for the last fifteen years. Nedenia was known for her business acumen and her enormous heart. She enjoyed adventures, music, swimming, helping others and spending time with her friends and family. Anyone who met Nedenia was instantly affected by her palpable enthusiasm for life. She was a pillar of her community in Honduras, and a true humanitarian who gave freely to the underprivileged. Nedenia is survived by her mother Marjorie, her sister Wendy and her brothers Steven, Timothy and John. Nedenia was preceded in death by her father Peter in July 2013. She was the great-granddaughter of Marjorie Merriweather Post. GLASER--Estelle, born May 22, 1936, the daughter of Eleanor and Eugene, beloved mother of Gabrielle, adored grandmother of Nico, mother-in-law of Nick, admired sister of Milton and dear friend to his wife, Shirley, died Saturday, January 18th at the Beth-Israel Hospice in Manhattan after a long and courageous battle against heart-disease and asthma. She had worked for many years as a social worker for the Department of Human Resources in New York City, and was widely respected for her role in helping the poor and disadvantaged. She is also survived by a number of caring cousins, nieces and nephews.

Arnold was a true prince among men and a role model in how to conduct business with unyielding honesty and integrity. He was instrumental in building our firm's success and we will forever cherish his friendship and support. We extend heartfelt condolences to his wife, Arlene, to his children, Scott, Shari and Michael, and to his nieces, nephews and grandchildren. May the family take solace in his accomplishments and legacy, and find comfort among the mourners of Zion. Ralph Herzka, Meridian Capital Group, LLC

O'DONNELL--Charles F.,Ph.D. Bronxville, NY, age 75, on January 23, 2014. Dr. O'Donnell was a professor, dean, scholar, esteemed colleague and, upon retirement, professor emeritus at Iona College, New Rochelle, NY where he served for forty-seven years, but what he cherished most was his family: his wife of 46 years, Mary (Hehir); son, Charles, Jr., his wife, Stacey; daughters, Keara Gordon, Caitlin Greatrex, their spouses Len and Peter, and his seven grandchildren Emma, Neil, Maggie, Patrick, Anne, Andrew, and Dean; sisters Mary Ann O'Donnell, Noreen Leonard, her husband, James; brothers (predeceased) twin Robert, Alexander, Patrick, their spouses - Joan and Judy, and his thirteen nieces and nephews. A son of Mary (Larkin) and Patrick O'Donnell (predeceased), he grew up in the Bronx, NY, graduated summa cum laude from Iona College and received his M.A. and Ph.D. in economics from Fordham University. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son, Funeral Home, Bronxville, NY, 2pm to 4pm and 7pm to 9pm Monday. Mass of Christian Burial, St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville, on Tuesday, January 28th at 10am. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Friends of Br. Devlin, c/o Iona College, 715 North Avenue, New Rochelle, NY 10801.

ADAM--Alexander Jay 11/84 1/25/07 Darling Al, It has been seven years since you lost your cruel battle with Ewings Sarcoma. We will always remember the extraordinary grace and courage with which you faced your painful illness and death. How we miss funny, charming, complicated, talented, handsome you! How we wish we could see what you were up to now, and laugh at your exploits and cheer your successes. We are doing what we can to honor your dear memory awards at Princeton for "the most talented undergrad with the worst GPA", the Alex Adam Foundation to support emerging artists. You would be so happy to know that we are living the dream you envisaged as you lay dying: we live and work in a brownstone in Harlem, surrounded by our fellow artists. Alas, how we wish you could be with us. Love, Mom, Dad, Nick and Dash www.alexadamfoundation.com www.arts78.com
COHEN--Harris David. 1/25/67 - 8/13/85. Our large family will always be one short. Love, Unkie, Amy and Gaby

MARTINEZ--Mark Viatori, died peacefully on Thursday January, 23, 2014 surrounded by loving family. He was 41 years old. He was a father, husband, son, brother, friend, accomplished builder, sea captain, big wave surfer, philanthropist, saltwater fisherman, snowboarder, soccer and hockey player. He is survived by his wife, Uli (Ulrike) De Vreese Martinez, his daughters, Juliana De Vreese Martinez, 7, and Esmee Nicolina Martinez, 4, his parents, Antonia Viatori Martinez and Albert A. Martinez, his step-father, Friedrich (Fritz) Pangratz, his sister, the Honorable Stefanie A. Martinez, brother-in-law, Sergeant Steve Garcia, nieces, Isabela Martinez Thibodeau and Sofia Martinez Thibodeau, nephews, Nicolas Martinez and Maximilian Martinez, great-aunt Magali Leiseca, aunts, Maria Ryan, Joanna Martinez, Sister Maria Viatori, OCD, Nancy Anne Viatori, and uncles, Wilfred Martinez, Maximilian Viatori and Robert Ryan. Mark was recognized by colleagues, friends and family members for his honest nature and can-do attitude. There was never an obstacle that Mark didn't meet with a smile and tackle with vigor, determination and grace. His unique style and presence, especially in the face of challenges others would have shied away from, distinguished him as an individual. Doing good by doing right was his way. Mark was defined by generosity and fierce loyalty. Mark invested 100% of himself into everything he committed to - his family, friends, sports and business. Family was paramount for Mark. Mark was a resident of both Manhattan and Southampton, NY. He was born in Rochester, NY on November 7th, 1972. Mark grew up in Rumson, NJ where he attended Rumson Country Day School, Rumson Fair Haven High School and ultimately matriculated to UNC Wilmington, where he was a member of the Chi Phi fraternity. Professionally, Mark built upon the foundation that his father created when he assumed responsibility of Interior Management, Inc (IMI). He had a specific vision for the company, focused on quality workmanship and culture, and has grown the business into Manhattan, the Hamptons, and New Jersey's foremost construction and renovation partner. A Memorial Visitation will be held at Frank E. Campbell at 1076 Madison Ave. Monday January 27th from 4pm-9pm. A Memorial Mass will be held at The Church of St. Ignatius Loyola at 980 Park Ave. on Tuesday January 28th at 4pm. In lieu of flowers the family is requesting donations to Habitat for Humanity.

GOLDSTEIN--Arnold, (A.G.) "Valiant in life and more valiant in death." More than 25 years my Real Estate partner, my dear friend and mentor. A giant in the Real Estate Industry who flew under the radar. Real Estate was our connection but our friendship was the final result. An active philanthropist, he was dearly loved, trusted, respected and admired. His word was his bond. I will deeply miss him and never forget him. Sincerest condolences to his wife, Arlene, children Scott, Shari, Michael and the entire Goldstein Family. Rest in peace, Marc S. Solomon

KRIMENDAHL--H. Frederick II.,died peacefully in New York City on Tuesday, January 21st, 2014. Fred was chairman of Petrus Partners, Ltd., a real-estate investment firm in New York, which he founded in 1992. His investment banking career began in 1953, when he joined the firm of Goldman Sachs & Co., becoming a partner in 1962. Fred served on the Management Committee at Goldman Sachs from 1975 until 1987, when he became a Limited Partner. After the firm became public in 1999, Fred became a Senior Director. While working at Goldman Sachs, he developed the Firm's 370,000 square foot European headquarters in London. Fred was also a Director and past President for ten years of the Philharmonic Symphony Society of New York, a Director Emeritus of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, a Founding Member of the James Madison Council of the US Library of Congress, a Director of the Bridgehampton Chamber Music Associates, and a Trustee of The Ohio State University Foundation. In addition, Fred has been a director of eight publicly traded corporations. Fred graduated from Ohio State University and the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration, and he served in the US Air Force as a lieutenant. He is survived by his wife, Emilia. Two daughters, Elizabeth and Nancy Krimendahl, and a grandson, Teddy Krimendahl, survive from his marriage to Connie, who predeceased him. Guy and Gray Harley, his stepsons, also survive Fred. A Memorial Service will be held on Monday, April 7th at 3:00pm at St. James' Church in New York followed by a reception at the Knickerbocker Club. In lieu of flowers, gifts in Fred's name may be sent to the Philharmonic Symphony Society of New York.

KRIMENDAHL--H. Frederick II. The New York Philharmonic deeply mourns the passing of H. Frederick Krimendahl II. A devoted and beloved Board member since 1976 (one of the longest tenures in our history), he was President of the Board 198996, traveled with the Orchestra around the world, served on numerous committees, and was a subscriber for more than four decades. We remember Mr. Krimendahl as a steady advisor dedicated to the Philharmonic and extend sincere condolences to his wife, Emilia Saint-Amand; daughters; stepsons; and grandson. SHACKTER--Susan, It is with deep sadness but also a comforting sense of peace that we inform you of Susan Shackter's passing, January 21, 2014. New York City has lost one of its most loyal and enthusiastic fans. A lover of the arts, literature and the theater, Susan took full advantage of everything the city had to offer. The Morningside Neighborhood will miss a familiar couple: Susan and Eric, her love and companion of 44 years. Susan retired in 2011 from the New York State Department of Labor where she taught classes for almost 45 years. She also volunteered at many New York museums and recently received an award from the American Museum of Natural History for almost 4000 hours of volunteer work. Eric and Julie would like to thank Irene Zola and LILY for their help in finding Susan's caregivers Kathleen, Kerrie and Katy. Only because of their loyalty, patience, skill, compassion and love was Susan able to stay in her apartment in peace and comfort as she wished. We would also like to thank MJHS hospice care, especially Susan's aide Nadine who kept us laughing, while sharing her knowledge and empathy. A loving thank you to all the doormen at 395 for their caring, compassion and friendship over the years. Condolences can be sent to Eric Hankam 395 Riverside Drive Apt 1B NY, NY 10025. Donations can be made in Susan's name to LILY, Life Force in Later Years, a neighborhood volunteer organization that works with elders to keep them healthy and in their own homes as long as possible. Life Force in Later Years, P.O. Box 250402, New York, New York 10025. Website- L-I-L-Y.org click donate.

CARDOZO--Benjamin M.,of New York City, died peacefully on January 19th at his Westport, CT home. He was a lawyer, a WWII veteran, and a philanthropist. Born in Manhattan in 1915, he graduated from Dartmouth College, Class of 1937, and NYU Law School. He served with the Moreland Commission, with the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration in Europe, and with the Justice Dept in Washington, D.C. He practiced law for over sixty years at his family law firm, Cardozo & Cardozo, formerly Cardozo & Nathan. He is survived by his best friend and wife, Barbara (nee Schaffer), his brother, Dr. Richard Cardozo, his daughters, Enid Cardozo (Ed Lamon), Ellen Sonsino (Isaac Sonsino), five grandchildren, and a great-grand-daughter. Services were private. Donations in his memory to Dartmouth College are appreciated.

ZUFALL--Kathryn "Kay", died January 18, 2014, at the age of 87, in The Country Home of Morris Plains, NJ, where she was treated with great kindness. She had had Alzheimer's disease for a few years. In 1990, after doing volunteer work in Peru, she and her husband, Dr. Robert Zufall, started the Dover Free Clinic, providing primary medical care to underserved people in Dover, NJ. It later became the Dover Community Clinic, and then the Zufall Health Center. She was the administrative director of the center for several years. In 1956, along with her brother-in law, Joseph McVicker, she created Play-Doh. Joe had a company which made a doughy wallpaper cleaner. Kay suggested that this could be modeled, rolled out, cut with cookie cutters, and made into a creative children's toy. She and her husband suggested the name 'Play-Doh'. Joe produced and marketed it, and it has since become a worldwide product. Donations may be made in her memory to the Zufall Health Center, 18 West Blackwell Street, Dover, NJ 07801.

WEISS--Irwin, born January 23, 1921, son of Max and Anna, beloved husband of over 65 years to Naomi, loving father of Laurie Berke-Weiss (Brian Berke), Sara Weiss (Dr. Lawrence Wasser) and Barbara Finnerty (John Finnerty), proud grandfather of Rachel, Alex, Louis, Jason, Lindsay and Haley, brother of Dr. Nathan Weiss (Joann Weiss) and Thelma Ross, died peacefully January 23rd surrounded by his family. A decorated WWII Army Air Corps navigator, former restaurateur, lawyer and accountant, Irwin was beloved by many for his insatiable interest in the world and quick wit. A lifelong New Yorker, Irwin loved travel, literature, food, crosswords and other puzzles, cultural expeditions, amateur photography, and Bing Crosby, and he was generous in sharing his interests with others and serenading them.
