WARWICK--Arnold S. Born in Brooklyn on October 18, 1931, passed away January 21 in New York City. He lived in Greenwich Village for 60 years - most of it with his late wife, Jane. He is survived by his children, Liadain, Matthew, Samantha, and seven grandchildren.

TRUBIN--Sybil, passed away on November 3, 2013 at the age of 88 after a long bout with COPD. The last surviving daughter of Bernard "Barney" and Jennie Trubin and sister of Ruth and Charlotte Trubin, Sybil grew up in Rye, NY, where her father, a self-taught contractor built homes and apartments, named streets after his daughters and bought property including a gully which early on became known locally as "Barney's Folly" but eventually became the land where the New England Thruway and the Cross Westchester Parkway intersect. Sybil majored in political science at the University of Wisconsin and was the president of the university theatrical group, the Wisconsin Players. Her first job in 1947 as a go-fer on the Broadway production of "Brigadoon" resulted in her being hired by its star, Marion Bell, and Marion's composer husband, Alan Jay Lerner. She later worked as a talent agent, at the production office of the City Center of Music and Drama, and at the production office of renowned Shakespearean actor and producer Maurice Evans. When in 1954 Sybil went on to produce her first season at the Cherry Lane Theater in New York City, the New York Times referred to her as "a young lady from Rye." That "young lady", with her partners Robert Merriman and Warren Enters with whom she shared life long friendships, produced five shows at the Cherry Lane and won the first Tony ever awarded to an off-Broadway organization for its presentations of among others, "The Way of the World" and "Thieves Carnival". In the mid 50's Sybil began her long association with stage and television director/producer George Schaefer, and in 1959 when George formed his own production company, Compass Productions, Sybil became its Vice President of Business Affairs - for over a decade, first as a talent consultant or in charge of casting and then supervising all business matters for Compass, Sybil was instrumental in the production of over 30 award-winning Hallmark Hall of Fame and other television productions. After the closing of Compass Productions, during the late 70's and early 80's, Sybil became Vice President of Business Affairs for Quinn Martin's QM Productions, one of the largest independent suppliers of dramatic television series at the time, including "Streets of San Francisco" and "Barnaby Jones", and later held the same position at Lorimar before retiring in 1987. Following her retirement, Sybil, a life long and passionate political liberal volunteered at the office of California State Senator and Assembly person Tom Hayden and at the Santa Monica Public Library. At the request of George Schaefer, Sybil came out of retirement to supervise the clearance and arrange for the television syndication and first home video release of ten of the classic Hallmark Hall of Fame shows which had been produced during the "Golden Age of Television". Sybil was a renaissance woman - interested and knowledgeable in business, politics, the arts and almost everything else, incredibly organized and efficient, with unlimited energy, enthusiasm and optimism. Her abiding belief in fairness and justice kept the words "no" and "can't" out of her vocabulary. She graduated from college when few women attended college; she went back to college to get trained as an accountant when few women became accountants; she was the head of business affairs at television production companies when few women were involved in television business affairs or production--and she did so with an accounting background when business affairs was almost exclusively the province of lawyers. Sybil will be remembered for her ability to light up any gathering and her gift for enduring friendships--they don't make them like Sybil any more. "Aunt Sybil" as she was affectionately called is survived by her nieces and nephews, Jennifer (and Charles) Graham, Liz (and Lance) Sussman, Bruce (and Anne) Zeller, Peter (and Nickie) Zeller, Bernie (and Joyce) Bogrow, Jan (and John) Fleder and Michael (and Moira) Bogrov and their families, by her surrogate niece and nephew, Jeanna Michaels and Steve Katz, and by friends all over the country.

SHACKTER--Susan, It is with deep sadness but also a comforting sense of peace that we inform you of Susan Shackter's passing, January 21, 2014. New York City has lost one of its most loyal and enthusiastic fans. A lover of the arts, literature and the theater, Susan took full advantage of everything the city had to offer. The Morningside Neighborhood will miss a familiar couple: Susan and Eric, her love and companion of 44 years. Susan retired in 2011 from the New York State Department of Labor where she taught classes for almost 45 years. She also volunteered at many New York museums and recently received an award from the American Museum of Natural History for almost 4000 hours of volunteer work. Eric and Julie would like to thank Irene Zola and LILY for their help in finding Susan's caregivers Kathleen, Kerrie and Katy. Only because of their loyalty, patience, skill, compassion and love was Susan able to stay in her apartment in peace and comfort as she wished. We would also like to thank MJHS hospice care, especially Susan's aide Nadine who kept us laughing, while sharing her knowledge and empathy. A loving thank you to all the doormen at 395 for their caring, compassion and friendship over the years. Condolences can be sent to Eric Hankam 395 Riverside Drive Apt 1B NY, NY 10025. Donations can be made in Susan's name to LILY, Life Force in Later Years, a neighborhood volunteer organization that works with elders to keep them healthy and in their own homes as long as possible. Life Force in Later Years, P.O. Box 250402, New York, New York 10025. Website- L-I-L-Y.org click donate.
RUBIN--Jeffrey. He was my brother and best friend. We were lucky to have him in our lives. Truly one of a kind. He will be missed beyond words. Bob & Kathryn Bregman Robert & Kate Bregman

SHULMAN--Mary Gordon, devoted wife of author Max Shulman for 24 years, until his death in 1988, larger-than-life mother, step-mother, grandmother and great-grandmother, died peacefully at age 95 on January 22, 2014, at her apartment in New York City. Mary was a wonder. A woman of intelligence, self-reliance, humor and unique style, she changed for the better the lives of all who knew her, but especially those of her daughter, Melodie Bryant, and her step-children, Dan, Bud, Peter and Martha Shulman. There will never be another like her. She will be missed. One of six children, Mary is survived by her sister Katie Wilson and her brother Teddy Gordon, along with her daughter, her four step-children, eight grandchildren and numerous greatgrandchildren. Burial will be at Hillside Memorial Cemetery in Los Angeles and there will be a memorial service on February 16 in New York City.

SVED--John Russell, passed peacefully on Saturday, January 11th, 2013. He was born in New York in 1930 to Dr. Alexander Sved and Irene Oppenheim Sved. John graduated from the University of Detroit with a degree in mechanical engineering, and was a pioneer in the pursuit of environmentally friendly ways to reduce industrial carbon emissions. John was married only once, to Therese Brown. They had two children. He is survived by his beloved sister, Erda Matheson; his children, Pamela and James; his grandchildren, Lana, Ivy, Abigail, and Cooper; and his dear cousins of the Sved and Oppenheim families. After a small, family memorial, John's final resting place will be his parents' farm in Becket, Massachusetts.

SHANAHAN--Dr. Dolores M. On the evening of January 8, 2014, Dr. Dolores Marie Shanahan, 83, of Fort Salonga, NY, died peacefully surrounded by members of her loving family. Dolores went to her rest after a long battle with Alzheimer's disease. Dolores, the daughter of Frank Yoerg and Rose Ann Mooney, was born on January 4, 1931 in Queens, NY, the eldest of three children. She was raised in St. Albans, NY, graduating from St. Catherine of Sienna School, St. Agnes Academic High School in Rockville Centre, and St. Joseph's College in Brooklyn, NY, and received an MS in Guidance & Counseling from Fordham University. For many years, Dolores served in the Commack Public School system in Commack, NY, where she was Director of Special Education and Curriculum Director for the school district with a student body of 9,000. As a young mother and while teaching in Commack, Dolores continued her education and went on to earn her Ph.D. in Child Psychology from St. John's University. Dolores was known as a dedicated professional, keenly interested in the development of each and every child. She touched many lives on Long Island with her kind, thoughtful, brilliant mind that was always looking to advance education by offering alternative methods of teaching so that each child could learn. Dolores was a national pioneer in education in the early 1970's, introducing computers into every classroom and teaching the school district the benefits of technology for learning. In 1977, she created Project CAL (Computer Accelerated Learning), a pilot program to measure the effectiveness of using computers in an elementary learning environment that led to the district-wide implementation of a comprehensive computer-learning program. She also wrote about and promoted the use of computers for special needs education. Dolores lectured at conferences all around New York State about the program she had developed for Commack Public Schools. Many school systems from across the US visited Commack to learn how to develop a similar model. Dolores had many intellectual and creative interests, was a published poet, an avid gardener and traveled extensively throughout the world. She was actively involved with many adult education committees at her parish, Our Lady Queen of Martyrs Roman Catholic Church in Centerport, NY, and taught English as a second language to women immigrants with the Dominican Sisters of Amityville, NY, at their Motherhouse. Throughout her life, Dolores remained an active, outgoing and loving woman. She enriched the lives of countless students, parents, teachers and school administrators. She will be sorely missed by her family and those whose lives she brightened on Long Island and in NYC. Dolores was predeceased by her husband, William J. Shanahan, and her sister Rose Ann. She is survived by her husband, Francis X. O'Shea; a daughter, Jeanne Shanahan, of Hoboken, NJ; a son, William Jr., of Nissequoque, NY; grandsons, Connor and Christopher Langer, also of Hoboken; and one brother, Frank Yoerg, and his wife Kathy of Williamsburg, VA. There will be no calling hours. A memorial service will be planned in the future at Our Lady Queen of Martyrs Church, Centerport, NY. Services entrusted to Riotto Funeral Home (riottofh.com), Jersey City.

SPOOR--Janet Spain, left this world in Salt Lake City, UT on January 18, 2014. Gracious, beautiful and loving, Janet was born in New York City to Dr. Will Cook and Grace Jones Spain on October 19, 1926. She attended Smith College where she graduated in 1948 with a Bachelor of Arts degree. On a weekend trip to Dartmouth College, she met the love of her life, William Howard Spoor. They were married in New York City on September 23, 1950 and embarked on what was to become an extraordinary life. Their first years were spent together in New York City and Chappaqua, NY where they began their family. In 1962, Bill was transferred to Minneapolis, MN by his employer The Pillsbury Company. There, they thrived for over forty years. They put down strong roots and became pillars of their community. When Bill was elected Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of The Pillsbury Company in 1973, he was widely quoted as saying that Janet "Was the perfect wife and partner for this endeavor." The two of them went hand in hand in everything they did. Janet was devoted to her family and friends and believed strongly in giving to others. Our mother loved people. She had an amazing memory for names, faces, places and events that was present until the day she died. She was elegant in both her manner and style. Genuinely kind and thoughtful, she was also generous to a fault. She loved to laugh, had a big, soft heart and a beautiful, engaging smile. She was an outstanding cook and threw large, elegant parties and served delicious food she made herself. She adored all animals and spoiled her pets (as well as her children) terribly. In order to be closer to their children and grandchildren, Janet and Bill moved to a hilltop in Salt Lake City where they enjoyed the peace and tranquility of the Wasatch Range with views of the city below. She delighted in feeding the deer and birds that flocked to her gardens. Her grandchildren were her pride and joy and they all benefited from her love and devotion. She was a member of numerous boards including The Center for the Study of The Presidency, University of Minnesota Nursing Foundation, Planned Parenthood of Minnesota and The Madeline Island Music Camp where she was honored by the establishment of the Janet Spain Spoor Scholarship Program. She is survived by her husband William H. Spoor, her children Melanie Grace Spoor, Cynthia Field Spoor (Douglas Howard), William Lincoln Spoor (Sarah), six grandchildren: Charles Spoor Howard, Anna Grace Howard, Blakely Madison Spoor, Savannah Spain Spoor, William Walker Spoor and Lincoln Campbell Spoor; her sister Joann Spain Rasmussen of Walton, NY and numerous nieces and nephews who loved her dearly. She had an immense impact on all who knew her and will be missed beyond words. With deepest gratitude to Dr. Anne Pendo, Becky Christensen, Claire Anderson, Lesila Kolomalu, Sue Christopherson, Dr. Jane MacPherson and the staff at Quality Solace Services. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation to the charity of your choice. A gathering of close friends and family is planned for a later date.
SVERDLOVE--Frieda, 98. Teacher and Scottish Country dancer. Friend to all. Loved by her family. Died peacefully at home in New Jersey.

ROSEN--Philip, of New Rochelle, NY passed away on Sunday, January 19, 2014. He is survived by his beloved wife Rita of 66 years, his loving children Phyllis Hadley and Michael Rosen, his sons-in-law Robert Landes and Richard Hadley, his daughter-in-law Stephanie Rosen, and his adoring grandchildren; Brett Raskin, Shaun Raskin-Deutschlander, Weston Deutschlander, Matthew Landes, Alexandra Landes, Jacqueline Landes, Alec Rosen, Kayla Rosen and Sierra Rosen. Sadly, Philip was predeceased by his daughter Wendy Landes on March 14, 2013. Born in the Bronx, on September 1, 1921, to Isadore and Anna Rosen, Philip was an outstanding student which enabled him to gain entrance into the Townsend Harris High School. He won a Merit Scholarship for mathematics and was admitted to Cornell University where he graduated in 1942 with a Bachelor of Science degree in Civil Engineering and a letter in Varsity Crew. Immediately after graduation he worked as an engineer for Stone and Webster while working for the United States government on "The Manhattan Project." During World War II he served his country as a Lieutenant in the United States Navy. After the War, Philip joined his father's masonry contracting business, Isadore Rosen and Sons, constructing many buildings throughout the metropolitan area. In addition to providing masonry services for other developers, Isadore Rosen and Sons went on to develop and build numerous buildings on their own behalf. Although success in business was very important to Philip, the idea of "giving back" and social responsibility were paramount. He felt fortunate to be able to contribute much time and energy to the many causes he believed in. Philip was a benefactor of Technion in Israel, a founder of The Chemotherapy Foundation, a benefactor of New Rochelle Hospital, The Juvenile Diabetes Foundation, The Cystic Fibrosis Foundation, and the Anti-Defamation League of B'Nai Brith. He was active in UJA, Federation of Jewish Philanthropies, and United Way. He was an honorary trustee of Temple Israel of New Rochelle, on the Board of Trustees of the Jewish Braille Institute (JBI), and was the founding member of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine's Young Men's Division. Philip and Rita were honored with the Lifetime Achievement Award, in 2004 and Philip remained a "Life Overseer" on The Board of Overseers of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine. Philip was a man of many hobbies. He loved literature and art, collecting stamps and shells but most of all he loved to ski. He skied well into his 80's and passed on that love to all of his children and grandchildren. Philip had a tremendous zest for life and felt he truly got the opportunity to live his American dream. He was loved by many and will be missed. A funeral service was held on Wednesday, January 22, 2014. Donations in Philip's memory should be made to "The Wendy Walk" (www.wendywalk.com) or to the Albert Einstein College of Medicine Men's Division.

MELADY--John C. (Jack), died December 21, 2013 in Sun City, AZ. Born in Brooklyn, NY in 1930. He attended Mt. St. Joseph's High School, Baltimore, MD, Carnegie Tech and received a degree form Manhattan School of Music. Accomplished musician performed in USAF Band, original orchestra of Hello Dolly, recorded with Clancy Brothers playing Irish Harp, and played in numerous European and Manhattan Supper Clubs. Pre-deceased by his parents, Pauline and John F. Melady (City Hall AP reporter during Wagner years), and his brother, Ralph L. Melady, (Assistant New York City Corporation Counsel).

NADLER--Allen. OHR ZARUAH LA TZADIK (a light shines on the righteous). On January 12, 2014 Allen Nadler, beloved partner of Jeff Donnelly and much loved father of Susannah and Reena Nadler, unexpectedly passed away. Allen's warmth, generosity, and zest for living was evident to all who knew him, and his passion for adventure was legendary. Jeff came into his life in the past ten years and filled him with a happiness that was a blessing. Reena and Susannah, the center of his world, received his constant and unconditional love. After attending Dartmouth College, Allen had a successful career on Wall Street, highlighted by his time at Goldman Sachs as a securities analyst and at Drexel Burnham as an investment banker. Following his retirement, Allen taught high school math through New York City Teaching Fellows. He was a beloved member of the Upper West Side Jewish Community, a past President of Ansche Chesed Congregation and, more recently, an active member of the Jewish community in Fort Lauderdale. Allen forged and kept friendships from every phase of his life, and his many friends, along with his family, will miss him terribly. Contributions in memory of Allen may be sent to AIDS Walk NY/Rita's Team, 2801 N. Pine Island Rd. Bldg 72 #
PAVLOUNIS--Peter, April 10, 1956 - January 24, 2014. Loving husband, father, son, brother and friend. May your memory be eternal.
ROBINSON--Keith J.,composer-animator, died December 29th, in New York. Surviving daughters Becky, Jenny and Kathy.

QUINLAN--Joseph P. on January 24, 2014. Retired principal, New York City Department of Education. Past president of the St. Patrick's Society of Brooklyn and the Men's Club of Bay Ridge. Beloved husband of Maureen (nee Tiedemann). Loving father of Eileen Quinlan, Elizabeth McMurray (Patrick), and the late Erin Patricia Quinlan. Proud grandfather of Ryan, John, and Maeve. Visiting Monday 7-9pm and Tuesday 2-4 and 7-9pm at Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 4th Ave., Brooklyn. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday 10:30am at Our Lady of Angels R.C. Church. In lieu of flowers, donations to Bishop Kearney High School, Erin Quinlan Scholarship Fund, 2202 60th St., Brooklyn, NY 11204.

MEYER--Fred J. Fred J. Meyer, 82 of Old Greenwich, CT passed away peacefully at his home on December 27, 2013 after a long courageous battle with prostate cancer. Mr. Meyer was born in Walenstadt, Switzerland and is survived by his wife Marie-Noelle of 38 years; three sons from a first marriage, Jay, Marc and Michael; grandson Abel-Lucien; brother Urs P. Meyer; and sister Brigitte Perna of Switzerland. Mr. Meyer graduated cum laude with an M.S. in geology from the Swiss Federal Institute of Technology in Zurich, Switzerland and an MBA from Harvard Business School, Boston, MA. Mr. Meyer had a successful business career in diverse industries and retired as Chief Financial Officer of Omnicom Group in 1999. He also served on many boards, including The Sacred Heart University and Earthjustice. Mr. Meyer had a rich life full of interests; he was a strong athlete and held the Swiss record in shot put in the 1950's. His kind, generous and discreet spirit manifested in innumerable ways. Mr. Meyer will be missed by his family, friends and associates from all walks of life. A memorial service will be held at the First Congregational Church, Sound Beach Avenue, in Old Greenwich, CT on Saturday March 8, 2014, at 2pm. In lieu of flowers donations can be sent to MSKCC, ATTN: Howard Scher/Prostate Cancer Research, 353 E. 68th St, New York, NY, 10065.

PAYSON--Elaine. The Maimonides Medical Center community mourns the loss of Elaine Payson, beloved sister-in-law of Martin D. Payson, esteemed Chair of the Medical Center's Board of Trustees. We extend our deepest condolences to the entire Payson family. Funeral and Shiva will be private. The Board of Trustees, Pamela Brier, President and CEO, and the staff of Maimonides Medical Center

ROMANOFF--Maya, It is with great sadness that the Maya Romanoff Corporation announces the loss of Founder and Chief Creative Officer Maya Romanoff. Maya, 72, died peacefully at his suburban Chicago home on January 15. His wife and business partner, Joyce, was at his side, along with his loving family. Maya, born Richard Romanoff in 1941, was an original, from the name he used in the 1970s-- Multifarious Maya--to the company he built. His firm produces handcrafted wallpaper in the tradition of British designer William Morris, often incorporating tactile materials like glass beads and seashells. The work is created by artisans at a studio factory in Skokie, Illinois, and at mills around the world. Flagship showrooms are in New York and Chicago. Maya was diagnosed with Parkinson's disease at age 49, but never stopped pushing his company to grow. Joyce became president in 2002, and her children and his niece have assumed leadership roles. This month, a biography about Maya entitled "Multifarious: Maya Romanoff's Grand Canvas," was published by CityFiles Press. "The world is both ugly and beautiful, and art makes things more one or the other," Maya wrote. "I'm on the side of the angels." Now at rest, he truly is. Survived by brother Robert (Heddie), stepdaughters Andrea Berkowitz (David) and Jennifer Block (Peter), stepson Michael Gutwaks (Mandy) and six grandchildren. Donations to Rehabilitation Inst. of Chicago, 345 E. Superior, Chicago, IL 60611.

MEYER--Fred J. The staff and Board of Trustees of Earthjustice express our profound sorrow and deepest sympathies to the family for the loss of our great friend and longtime Trustee Fred Meyer. Fred was a rock and source of great wisdom, fidelity, clarity and constancy of vision, accountability, perception, humor, compassion and worldly acumen and knowledge. He spoke his mind, but always with tact and a smile and the purpose of providing constructive guidance. He was devoted to the organization and its mission, which he served and supported unstintingly from 1999 - 2011, and was a shining reminder that we will succeed by avoiding narrow visions and by being bold and inclusive. Fred was a friend and will be missed by all.

O'DONNELL--Charles F.,Ph.D. Bronxville, NY, age 75, on January 23, 2014. Dr. O'Donnell was a professor, dean, scholar, esteemed colleague and, upon retirement, professor emeritus at Iona College, New Rochelle, NY where he served for forty-seven years, but what he cherished most was his family: his wife of 46 years, Mary (Hehir); son, Charles, Jr., his wife, Stacey; daughters, Keara Gordon, Caitlin Greatrex, their spouses Len and Peter, and his seven grandchildren Emma, Neil, Maggie, Patrick, Anne, Andrew, and Dean; sisters Mary Ann O'Donnell, Noreen Leonard, her husband, James; brothers (predeceased) twin Robert, Alexander, Patrick, their spouses - Joan and Judy, and his thirteen nieces and nephews. A son of Mary (Larkin) and Patrick O'Donnell (predeceased), he grew up in the Bronx, NY, graduated summa cum laude from Iona College and received his M.A. and Ph.D. in economics from Fordham University. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son, Funeral Home, Bronxville, NY, 2pm to 4pm and 7pm to 9pm Monday. Mass of Christian Burial, St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville, on Tuesday, January 28th at 10am. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Friends of Br. Devlin, c/o Iona College, 715 North Avenue, New Rochelle, NY 10801.

OLSON--Miriam Meltzer. Born to Jacob and Rebecca Meltzer on December 24th, 1933, in the Bronx, NY, Miriam Meltzer Olson died, peacefully in her sleep, on January 22nd at her home in North Truro, Massachusetts after suffering for many years with Alzheimer's disease. An accomplished and passionate Social Worker, Miriam's professional years included work at Yale Psychiatric Institute and Colombia University and teaching at Fordham, then Temple University in Philadelphia. She graduated from the City College of New York, then received her Master's degree from Case Western Reserve in Cleveland and her Doctorate from Hunter College in Manhattan. A Fulbright Scholar, her professional publications include essays on women's health and women in social work and an edited book, Women's Health and Social Work: Feminist Perspectives. Predeceased by her sister Cecile Meltzer, Miriam is survived by her husband Toby Olson, her two sisters, Evelyn Stark (her husband Melvin) and Betty Meltzer, and numerous nieces and nephews on both sides of the family. Donations in Miriam's name may be sent to United Communities of Southeast Philadelphia, Houston Center, 2029 S. 8th St., Philadelphia, PA 19148 www.ucsep.org.

NOYES--Adele. Cherished mother, grandmother, great-grandmother, aunt, teacher and friend peacefully passed away on January 18th, her mother Rose's birthday. Her love that touched so many will be in our hearts forever. Donations in her memory may be made to Dayscape Senior Activity Center, 4800 West Hillsboro Blvd; #

ROSENBERG--Harold, 99 years young, old blue eyes, died peacefully at home in Lake Worth, FL. Former resident of Lido Beach, NY. Devoted husband, father, golf champion, former co-owner of Eastern Chain Works, Mr. Fix-it, music lover and passionate photographer. Kind, humble and adored. He is survived by his wife Rose, daughters Jane Stein (Rick), Gale Bayer (Stephen) and Liz Rosenberg Citron (Phil). Grandfather to John (Gilian), Kate (Adam), Maggie and Johanna Stein, Kim (John Henry) and Jesse Bayer (Dori), great-grandfather to Cole and True Hilliker, Ruby Bayer and John Stephen Olthoff.

HOSTEIN--Clifford J.,87 years, died January 23, 2014. He is survived by Rollie, his wife of 57 years; his children, Ellen and Jay Auster and Lisa Hostein and Joel Oshtry; and grandchildren, Zachary, Leah and Jeremy Auster, and Ezra and Sam Oshtry. Services 12 noon Sunday at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY.
KRIMENDAHL--Fred. The Ohio State University Foundation mourns the passing of our Director, Fred Krimendahl, and extends our sympathies to Emilia and family.

McGOVERN--Eugene. Peter, Eileen, Debora, and Suzanne Lehrer pay tribute to the memory of Gene McGovern, a friend, business partner, godfather, mentor, and life inspiration who passed away too soon for someone with such a zest for life. Gene left a lasting impression on all whom he encountered, someone who wasted very few words, lived life on his own terms, had a remarkable sense of humor, and was utterly devoted to family and those lucky enough to be considered his true friends. His bigger-than-life stature, swagger, and Stetson hat belied a razor sharp mind and adaptability to situations and circumstances be it reconstructing the Statue of Liberty, managing the construction of EuroDisney, building Canary Wharf in London, baling hay on his beloved Castle Rock Ranch in Wyoming, or lavishing attention on his horde of grandchildren during visits to their homes and at his home in Boca Raton. Gene lived many lives in one lifetime. He was determined from a young age to be the best at whatever he did and in that he more than succeeded. For Peter Lehrer, who first met Gene McGovern on a construction jobsite 45 years ago and in whom he found a kindred spirit to create together one of the largest, most influential and innovative construction management firms worldwide, the art of friendship was perfected throughout whatever trials and tribulations came their way. As such, Gene was admired and appreciated by the rest of the Lehrer family as well. To Lisa, and to Phyllis, Eric, Danny, Derek, P.J., and all the family, we extend our heartfelt condolences.

KRIMENDAHL--H. Frederick II. The New York Philharmonic deeply mourns the passing of H. Frederick Krimendahl II. A devoted and beloved Board member since 1976 (one of the longest tenures in our history), he was President of the Board 198996, traveled with the Orchestra around the world, served on numerous committees, and was a subscriber for more than four decades. We remember Mr. Krimendahl as a steady advisor dedicated to the Philharmonic and extend sincere condolences to his wife, Emilia Saint-Amand; daughters; stepsons; and grandson. Alan Gilbert, Music Director; Gary W. Parr, Chairman; Matthew VanBesien, Executive Director; New York Philharmonic Musicians, Board, and Staff

LEVIN--Monte. At age 96 on January 23rd. Industrial designer, husband and companion, father, grandfather and great-grandfather. Service Monday January 27, 11:30 at Riverside Chapel, Amsterdam and 76th

KALLINS--Beatrice J.,Born in 1924 in Brooklyn, NY. Bea lived in Roslyn Estates, Long Island, Jupiter, Florida, and San Francisco. She died peacefully in San Francisco on November 28, 2013 surrounded by her family. Married to Edward Kallins for 70 years. He and their son Neil preceded her in death. She is survived by their two daughters, Marilyn Kallins and Maureen MOMO Kallins and her three grandchildren Kati Kallins, Chazz and Jack Gretsch. Bea's humor, style and strength will live on in the hearts of all who knew her. A memorial will be held on Thursday, April 3, 2014 at 3:30pm at the Jewish Home of San Francisco, 302 Silver Ave. In lieu of flowers please send donations to The Jewish Home of San Francisco.

MARTINEZ--Mark Viatori, died peacefully on Thursday January, 23, 2014 surrounded by loving family. He was 41 years old. He was a father, husband, son, brother, friend, accomplished builder, sea captain, big wave surfer, philanthropist, saltwater fisherman, snowboarder, soccer and hockey player. He is survived by his wife, Uli (Ulrike) De Vreese Martinez, his daughters, Juliana De Vreese Martinez, 7, and Esmee Nicolina Martinez, 4, his parents, Antonia Viatori Martinez and Albert A. Martinez, his step-father, Friedrich (Fritz) Pangratz, his sister, the Honorable Stefanie A. Martinez, brother-in-law, Sergeant Steve Garcia, nieces, Isabela Martinez Thibodeau and Sofia Martinez Thibodeau, nephews, Nicolas Martinez and Maximilian Martinez, great-aunt Magali Leiseca, aunts, Maria Ryan, Joanna Martinez, Sister Maria Viatori, OCD, Nancy Anne Viatori, and uncles, Wilfred Martinez, Maximilian Viatori and Robert Ryan. Mark was recognized by colleagues, friends and family members for his honest nature and can-do attitude. There was never an obstacle that Mark didn't meet with a smile and tackle with vigor, determination and grace. His unique style and presence, especially in the face of challenges others would have shied away from, distinguished him as an individual. Doing good by doing right was his way. Mark was defined by generosity and fierce loyalty. Mark invested 100% of himself into everything he committed to - his family, friends, sports and business. Family was paramount for Mark. Mark was a resident of both Manhattan and Southampton, NY. He was born in Rochester, NY on November 7th, 1972. Mark grew up in Rumson, NJ where he attended Rumson Country Day School, Rumson Fair Haven High School and ultimately matriculated to UNC Wilmington, where he was a member of the Chi Phi fraternity. Professionally, Mark built upon the foundation that his father created when he assumed responsibility of Interior Management, Inc (IMI). He had a specific vision for the company, focused on quality workmanship and culture, and has grown the business into Manhattan, the Hamptons, and New Jersey's foremost construction and renovation partner. A Memorial Visitation will be held at Frank E. Campbell at 1076 Madison Ave. Monday January 27th from 4pm-9pm. A Memorial Mass will be held at The Church of St. Ignatius Loyola at 980 Park Ave. on Tuesday January 28th at 4pm. In lieu of flowers the family is requesting donations to Habitat for Humanity.

LEE--Leslie. The Funeral for playwright Leslie Lee will be held at Saints Memorial Baptist Church in Bryn Mawr, PA, Saturday, February 1, 10am, viewing 8am-10am. Memorial Service, Signature Theatre New York City, TBA.

HYMAN LEVEY--Pelda B.,75, beloved mother of Richard H. Levey and daughter-in-law Astrida Valigorsky, devoted sister of Pamela Rosario, aunt of Andrea and Jose DeJesus, and great-aunt of Isabela and Joaquin DeJesus. Remembered for her wit, honesty, and engaging personality, coupled with her personal charm and elegance, as well as her facility with words, which she used both in her career in advertising and in a wide spectrum of personal writing. A devoted reader of the New York Times' obituary pages.

JAGENDORF--Daniel Zachary Samuel, 49, of Brooklyn, NY, died in his sleep, unexpectedly, on January 20, 2014. The cause was sleep apnea. Born September 6, 1964 in Baltimore, MD, he was the son of Andre and Jean Jagendorf. He is survived by his parents; by his wife, Patricia; his sisters, Suzanne and Judith; five nieces, three nephews, three great-nieces and three great-nephews, and many friends. He was one of the initiators of the Fringe Festival, and ever since an adjudicator for plays to be performed. He designed and built scenery and props for many off-Broadway plays and operas. Working for the Spaeth Corp., he fabricated props and back-drops for the Christmas store windows of Macy's, Lord and Taylor, and Saks Fifth Avenue.

LAUMAN--Richard H.,on January 21, 2014, beloved husband of the late Joane Albright Lauman; dear father of Richard H. Lauman, Jr. and Thomas G. Lauman; dear grandfather of Richard H., III, Elizabeth, Paige, Kayleigh and John T. Lauman; devoted brother of Ginger (nee Lauman and Eugene Cullen and the late Margo (nee Lauman) and Jack Clynes. Mr Lauman was a graduate of the class of 1950 of Villa Nova University. Friends may call at the Cathedral of Mary our Queen on Saturday, February 1st from 11am to 12 Noon at which time a Funeral Mass will be offered. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be made to Stella Maris Hospice, 2300 Dulaney Valley Rd. Timonium, MD 21093. Services by the family-owned Mitchell-Wiedefeld Funeral Home Inc.

KRIMENDAHL--H. Frederick II.,died peacefully in New York City on Tuesday, January 21st, 2014. Fred was chairman of Petrus Partners, Ltd., a real-estate investment firm in New York, which he founded in 1992. His investment banking career began in 1953, when he joined the firm of Goldman Sachs & Co., becoming a partner in 1962. Fred served on the Management Committee at Goldman Sachs from 1975 until 1987, when he became a Limited Partner. After the firm became public in 1999, Fred became a Senior Director. While working at Goldman Sachs, he developed the Firm's 370,000 square foot European headquarters in London. Fred was also a Director and past President for ten years of the Philharmonic Symphony Society of New York, a Director Emeritus of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, a Founding Member of the James Madison Council of the US Library of Congress, a Director of the Bridgehampton Chamber Music Associates, and a Trustee of The Ohio State University Foundation. In addition, Fred has been a director of eight publicly traded corporations. Fred graduated from Ohio State University and the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration, and he served in the US Air Force as a lieutenant. He is survived by his wife, Emilia. Two daughters, Elizabeth and Nancy Krimendahl, and a grandson, Teddy Krimendahl, survive from his marriage to Connie, who predeceased him. Guy and Gray Harley, his stepsons, also survive Fred. A Memorial Service will be held on Monday, April 7th at 3:00pm at St. James' Church in New York followed by a reception at the Knickerbocker Club. In lieu of flowers, gifts in Fred's name may be sent to the Philharmonic Symphony Society of New York.
HOSTEIN--Clifford. In loving memory of our cherished friend of 62 years. Irreplaceable. Grayce Perlbinder Barbara & Mike Feldman

McGOVERN--Eugene, age 72, passed away suddenly on January 22 in New York City. Gene was a resident of Boca Raton, FL, and Cody, WY. Gene was born in Manhattan on January 27, 1941 to Julie and Frank McGovern. He was a builder extraordinaire and the co-founder of Lehrer McGovern, Inc. in 1979, which grew to become one of the largest and most respected construction companies in the world. The company later merged into Bovis Ltd and, subsequently, Lend Lease. Gene's remarkable career as a leader in the construction industry spanned 50 years, and he was responsible for some of the largest and most visible projects ever constructed, such as Petronas Towers in Kuala Lumpur, Euro Disney in Paris, Canary Wharf in London, the renovation of the Statute of Liberty and Ellis Island and hundreds of monumental undertakings. A man of imposing presence and personality, he innovated techniques that revolutionized the construction industry. Gene not only led and managed thousands of workers, but took the time to train and personally mentor hundreds of people. Besides taking time to build a company, Gene was one of the founding members of the most important trade association in New York, CAGNY. After a long career in the United States, Gene ventured to Europe and Asia in the late 1980's and 1990's to create and manage companies and projects and adapted to all cultures and challenges he faced. No project or task was ever too complicated. Gene was one of the three arbitrators in settling the disputes at Ground Zero, and later was responsible for helping to steer the September 11 Memorial and Museum project to a timely completion. Gene, with his trademark cowboy boots and ever-present cigar, left memorable impacts on every life he touched, and created a legacy that will live on. With a dry sense of humor and absolute candor, Gene made things happen when he was on the scene, and the impossible became possible. Unquestionably, he was truly bigger than life, and a giant in the world of construction. Gene leaves behind his wife Lisa, his former wife, Phyllis, and four children, Eric (Donna), Danny (Tessa), Derek (Gina) and PJ (Allan) and 13 grandchildren; Ryan, Jordan, Christopher, Danielle, Phillip, Colton, Katie, Tyler, Garrett, Dillion McGovern and Gene, Maxx and PJ Middleton, and two sisters Lorna Mion and Patti Hahn and one brother Brian. McGovern and 4 dogs, Roscoe, Brie, Bogey & Ginger. A true patriarch in every sense, as a family man, father, and grandfather devoted to his family. We will miss him and cherish the time we knew him. Visitation will be at Frank E. Campbell's Funeral Home at 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, New York, NY on Monday, January 27th 2014 with visitation between 2-5pm and 7-9pm with a celebration of Gene's life at 4pm. Telephone: 212-288-3500 Donations should be made to Coastal Carolina JDRF in his honor.

HUNTER--Holland, an expert on Russian transportation policy and professor emeritus of economics at Haverford College, died Saturday January 18th of pneumonia at The Quadrangle in Haverford, Pennsylvania. He was 92 years old. Dr. Hunter grew up in Geneva, Illinois, the son of real estate developer Harry Holland Hunter and Hester Hunter, advertising copywriter. He graduated from the Fountain Valley School in Colorado and received his B.S. in Economics from Haverford College in 1943. After obtaining an M.A. in 1947 and a PhD in 1949 from Harvard University, both in Economics, he returned to Haverford College where he taught economics for the rest of his career. Dr. Hunter specialized in transportation policy in the Soviet Union. The author of numerous books and articles, he did research for the Brookings Institute, the National Science Foundation, the Russian Research Center, and other organizations. He was an active member of Haverford Friends Meeting and sat on the boards of the Haverford Friends School and the Baldwin School. He also engaged actively with other local organizations and political groups including the Democratic Party. In 1945, he married Helen Taft Manning, professor of economics at Bryn Mawr College. Dr. Hunter is survived by his children Timothy Hunter, Christine Hunter, and Ann Hunter, eight grandchildren, and three great-grandchildren. A funeral service will be held at the Haverford Friends Meeting followed by a reception and interment on Sunday February 16th, 3pm. Instead of flowers, donations may be made to the American Friends Service Committee (afsc.org). www.chadwickmckinney.com

KIERSTEAD--Dr. Nancy Carrick Romer (nee Hewlett), Passed away peacefully aged 86, on December 21st 2013. Nancy, was widowed in 1990 and is survived by her two daughters (and sons-in-law), Anna Romer (Bruce Jacobson) and Marisha Romer (Eric Katz), her son (and daughter-in-law) Jan Edward Romer (Catherine Romer); one granddaughter, Sophie Helene Romer; five grandsons, Andy and Charlie Romer, David and Peter Jacobson, and Gregory Romer; two step-grandchildren, Alyssa and Chase Katz and by her beloved niece Nancy Kronenberg and nephew Stephen Hewlett. Nancy was born February 19, 1927 in Schenectady NY, daughter of Dr. Clarence Wilson Hewlett and Mary Stephens Carrick. Nancy earned a BFA in Art History from Cornell ('49). Already a skilled pianist, she was one of only two female Chimes Masters and later donated a bell to the Cornell Chimes Tower bearing the family name. Nancy attended University of Michigan for her Masters in Education. It was there she met and married her Lithuanian born husband Andrzej Tadeusz Romer, in 1952. They had three children: Jan Edward (1953) Anna Louise (1954) and Marisha Helena (Maia) in 1965. Nancy then got her PhD in Educational Psychology from the University of Connecticut. Nancy's father, Dr. Clarence Wilson Hewlett, had a doctorate from Johns Hopkins and was a renowned physicist and inventor. Dr. Hewlett created the first ever solar cell while working for General Electric. An environmentalist and member of the Quaker Society of Friends, Nancy was an early activist promoting alternative energy. She designed and oversaw construction of the first two solar powered homes in the State of Connecticut in 1973 and 1978. Nancy's career as a tenured professor and clinical psychologist spanned three decades. She was also a published writer, ("The Green Ribbon," 1998) creator of hand made books, a keen quilter, figure skater, artist, knitter, sculptor, and potter. She also lavished her skills and energy donating time to help counsel troubled children and families without the means to hire professional counselors. Apart from being a wonderful aunt, mother and grandmother, her passions were the New York Times crossword puzzle, folk music, dancing and sailing. She spent her later years sailing her boat on long and challenging trips with her husband and soul mate Henry Andrew Kierstead, who sadly died of cancer aged 67, only 10 years after their marriage. A memorial meeting is being held on Saturday, March 1st, 3pm at Berkhamsted Quaker Meeting, High St., Berkhamsted, Hertfordshire, HP4 3EG, England. All welcome.

LEVINSOHN--Jay Douglas. Born May 7, 1923 in New York City, Jay passed away suddenly January 19, at Cedars Sinai Hospital in LA, surrounded by his loving wife, daughter and son. Jay brightened every day and every room with his smile, easygoing manner, and optimistic view of the world. He grew up in NYC and Rumson, NJ, graduated from Phillips Academy Andover, and Princeton University and served for the US Army during World War II. In 1959, he married the former Joyce Salton, and settled in Tenafly, NJ, where they stayed for 35 years. He spent nearly his entire career in the boys and men's clothing business and was one of the industry's leading and most well-liked figures. Father, husband, grandfather, friend, and role model, he was a kind, gentle and inspirational man, and woke each day with optimism. He is survived by his wife of 55 years Joyce, daughter Sharon, son Ross, daughter-in-law Nicole, and grandchildren Skylar and Jagger.

DAVIES--Michael. Devoted son of the late Bernard and Julia Davies. Beloved husband of Leslie Davies. Loving brother of Yvonne Tropp and Charlette Krane. Doting stepfather to Jessica Pell. Services Monday, January 27, 10:30am, Larchmont Temple, Larchmont, NY.

GILMOUR--Joan Thompson (Stehli), 79, of South Tamworth, NH and Naples, FL, died January 18 after a short illness. She leaves three children, Pam Hearne, Kitty Scharf, and Hunt Stehli, and four beloved grandchildren.

DYE--Nedenia Post, business owner and entrepreneur, died December 22, 2013 in her home in Roatan, Honduras. She was 46. Ms. Dye was born in Santa Monica, CA on November 30, 1967 to parents Peter and Marjorie Durant Dye. She graduated from St. Monica Catholic High School in 1986. Nedenia continued her education and moved to Washington, D.C. in the fall of 1988 to enroll in Mount Vernon College (now George Washington University) where she earned a Bachelor of Arts degree in Communications in 1992. Nedenia was a devoted daughter, sister, niece, cousin and friend who lived her life abundantly. She owned and operated Spa Baan Suerte on the island of Roatan, Honduras where she made her home for the last fifteen years. Nedenia was known for her business acumen and her enormous heart. She enjoyed adventures, music, swimming, helping others and spending time with her friends and family. Anyone who met Nedenia was instantly affected by her palpable enthusiasm for life. She was a pillar of her community in Honduras, and a true humanitarian who gave freely to the underprivileged. Nedenia is survived by her mother Marjorie, her sister Wendy and her brothers Steven, Timothy and John. Nedenia was preceded in death by her father Peter in July 2013. She was the great-granddaughter of Marjorie Merriweather Post. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be given to the George Washington University's EJS Women's Leadership Program for a fund honoring Nedenia. Online at http://giving.gwu.edu/ or mail to: George Washington University, Division of Development, 2100 M Street NW, Suite 310, Washington, D.C. 20052. There will be a Memorial Service April, 12, 2014, 2:00pm at George Washington University, Mount Vernon Campus, Post Hall, 2100 Foxhall Road, Washington, DC 20007.

FENNER--James, of Bridgeport, CT, age 90. Retired Economics Professor, University of Bridgeport. WWII Army veteran. Survived by nieces Laura Slusher of San Leandro, CA, and Lenore Lupie of Tarrytown, NY, and brother-in-law Richard Levy of East Rockaway, NY. Predeceased by sister Marion Levy.

GLASER--Estelle, born May 22, 1936, the daughter of Eleanor and Eugene, beloved mother of Gabrielle, adored grandmother of Nico, mother-in-law of Nick, admired sister of Milton and dear friend to his wife, Shirley, died Saturday, January 18th at the Beth-Israel Hospice in Manhattan after a long and courageous battle against heart-disease and asthma. She had worked for many years as a social worker for the Department of Human Resources in New York City, and was widely respected for her role in helping the poor and disadvantaged. She is also survived by a number of caring cousins, nieces and nephews.

GARDNER--Helen L.,Rochester, January 16, 2014 at age 92; formerly of New York, NY. Predeceased by her husband Richard B. Gardner, her parents Edward and Nettie Lonsdale; her brothers Edward M. and James B. Lonsdale; two stepsons Richard R. Gardner and John D. Gardner. Survived by her stepdaughter Diane Gardner Premo (Edward) and three grandchildren, Katherine, Margaret and James Premo of Rochester; nieces Mary Baker, Helen Forbes and Margaret Lonsdale; nephews Edward and James Lonsdale; many great-nieces and nephews and many friends. A native of Kansas City, Missouri, Helen worked for more than 40 years as the Supervisor of the Central Pass Bureau of Trans World Airlines in New York City. She moved to Rochester to be closer to family and loved living here. A memorial service will be held on Monday, February 17 at 10:30am at Briarwood, St. John's Meadows, 1 Johnsarbor Drive, Rochester, NY 14620. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions can be made to Citymeals-on-Wheels, 355 Lexington Avenue, New York, NY 10017, citymeals.org. To share a memory of Helen or send a condolence to the family visit www.anthonychapels.com.

GEIGER--Dr. Arnold, on Friday, January 17, at dusk, Dr. Arnold Geiger "Cap", Pop and "The Fish Doctor" - of Martha's Vineyard, slipped the mooring for his final voyage. He lived a rich and full 95 years. He was pre-deceased by his loving wife; Ruth Geiger. Arnold was born August 11, 1918, in New York City, attended New York University, and then the University of Pennsylvania College of Dentistry. Following a Surgical Internship at Harlem Hospital in 1941, Arnold embarked on a life-long career in dentistry. In 1950 he began a private Orthodontic practice in Manhattan and Port Chester, NY, finally retiring in 1995. Along the way, he taught dentistry at Columbia University, gave lectures at various institutions and was active in state and national dental associations. He co-authored a text book which was required reading at universities and translated into six languages. Over a career that spanned 45 years, Arnold improved the lives and smiles of countless patients. That was the professional side of "Pop". The other side was a crusty fisherman, at home on his beloved boat, the Noe-pe, in pursuit of stripers, blues, fluke, and lobster. He and Ruth first brought the family to Martha's Vineyard in 1961 for a two-week holiday - it immediately became a second home. As much as Dad loved fishing and his boat, Ruth preferred gardening in the rich earth of the Vineyard. Dad became quite the gardener himself. I'll always admire my father for the ease with which he wore this duality: medical professional in New York, and man of the land and sea on the Vineyard. Even when alone on his boat, surrounded by only sun, wind and ocean, he would smilingly receive a radio hail from Ruth just checking that he was well and the fish were biting. When Dad retired, he and Mom settled on the Island. Arnold was a life-long campaigner against racial, gender and class prejudice, and the proliferation of nuclear weapons. He loved music and the performing arts, Mexican painting and sculpture, and his many friends. Arnold also loved his dogs a Golden Retriever was always a constant companion. Pop was charming and warm; universally admired by people he met. He was also calm and logical a reassuring presence for his patients, and a source of sound advice for his family as we navigated the storms of life. With his quiet intelligence, high standards, and unwavering ethics, he has always been -- and always will be -- the family's moral compass. Arnold is survived by his children Julie Geiger; William and wife Donna Geiger; David Nathanson, wife Kathy McKeough, and their son Samuel; and Adam Geiger, wife Colette Beaudry and sons Addison and Aidan. All of us owe a special thanks to Sheryl Enos, CNA who cared for Dad with professionalism, love and compassion in his final months. Dr Geiger was a gentleman; a prince among men. His wish for his children was simple, but profound: a long and happy life. He led by example. Donations can be sent to Overlook CARE, 88 Masonic Home Rd, Charlton, MA 01507. Adam Geiger

GOLDSTEIN--Arnold, (A.G.) The Solomon Organization wishes to express our sincerest condolences to Arnold's wife, Arlene, children Scott, Shari, Michael and the entire Goldstein Family. ESKENAZI--Irving Leon, 83, of Bedford, NY passed away peacefully on January 23, 2014 after a long illness. He was a rare, generous, wise, loving and devoted husband, father and friend. GUTTER--Ruth Rubenstein, longtime resident of Great Neck, NY died peacefully on January 16, 2014. She was in her 91st year.

BOSCH--Albert C.,PhD, January 15, 1934 January 17, 2014. The Bosch family mourns the loss of their beloved patriarch of Bedford, NY and Boynton Beach, FL, who filled their lives with love, music, science and laughter. An educator by nature and vocation, he brought wisdom about human anatomy and physiology to all who shared his passion for helping humankind. Albert is survived by his wife of 57 years, Marie Adele; two children and their spouses, William and Brenda Bosch of Great Falls, VA, and Vivienne and Alexander Deligtisch of New Canaan, CT; and five grandchildren: Allison, Margaret, Caroline, Lauren and Nicholas. A private service was held on January 22nd and there will be a memorial service in celebration of his life. Those wishing to make a contribution in his name may do so to the Caramoor Center of Music and Arts in Katonah, NY. Services by Cassidy Flynn Funeral Home Inc., Mt. Kisco, NY, (914) 666-4840.

BRODY--Nathaniel (Ned), died peacefully surrounded by family on January 22, 2014. Rita, Ab, Abby and Eli, Jacob, Lauren, Arthur, Robin and Arlene will miss his love and presence in our lives. Contributions to Mt. Sinai Palliative Care Unit.

BROKAW--Howard Pyle, 97, died on December 20, 2013. Brokaw lived an active, dedicated life of two careers, first with E.I. DuPont de Nemours Co., of Wilmington, Delaware, and then in conservation - of nature and of his grandfather, Howard Pyle's, legacy as an illustrator and author. Brokaw was born October 2, 1916, in Wilmington, to Roberts W. Brokaw and Phoebe Churchman Pyle, daughter of Howard Pyle. He grew up in Newark, New Jersey, and attended Newark Academy, The Hotchkiss School, and Princeton University, graduating magna cum laude and Phi Beta Kappa and earning degrees in Chemical Engineering. He married Mary Ann Taylor (Dede) in 1942. Brokaw worked for DuPont from 1939 to 1976, holding various positions in manufacturing and marketing, finishing his career as Director of Marketing for the Industrial Fibers Division. He lived in Penn's Grove, New Jersey; Old Greenwich, Connecticut; Akron, Ohio; and, mainly, in Wilmington. From childhood, he was interested in birds and familiar with Pyle's work. While traveling for DuPont he birded in many parts of the U.S. and other countries. Encouraged by Andrew Wyeth, Brokaw began collecting Howard Pyle's paintings, pen and ink drawings, and books. Retiring at 59, birding and Pyle became serious conservation vocations. Brokaw led, raised money for, or otherwise served: the Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia, American Bird Conservancy, National Audubon Society, International Council for Bird Preservation, Delaware Nature Society, Delaware Museum of Natural History, World Wildlife Fund-US, American Ornithologists" Union, Roger Tory Peterson Institute, Hawk Mountain Sanctuary Association, Delmarva Ornithological Society, Delaware Wild Lands, Forward Lands, RARE Center for Tropical Conservation, Asa Wright Nature Center, President's Council on Environmental Quality, U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Urban Wildlife Refuge Advisory Committee, Mid-Atlantic Environmental Law Center, Brandywine Museum and Conservancy, Princeton University, The Studio Group, and Delaware Humanities Council. Howard and Dede were often out-of-doors, traveling to nearby and remote areas of the US and 55 countries. Most notable were trips Brokaw helped lead for science and conservation in Central and South America and surveys of environmental programs in India. Howard and Dede contributed their collection of Pyle's works, including more than 100 paintings and drawings, to the Brandywine River Museum, Chadd's Ford, Pennsylvania. Brokaw wrote on Pyle and wrote, edited or was otherwise indispensable to the production of Wildlife and America, Delaware's Outstanding Natural Areas and Their Preservation, and Birds of Delaware. Dede died in January 2013. Brokaw is survived by his children: Thomas Clarkson Taylor Brokaw, of Kennett Square, Pennsylvania; Nicholas Van Liew Brokaw, of San Juan, Puerto Rico; Jeffrey Johnson Brokaw, of Vancouver, British Columbia; Clotilda Brokaw Heimbuch, of Pittsburgh; eight grandchildren; and one great-grandchild. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to any of the organizations listed above. For online condolences, please visit Chandler Funeral Homes & Crematory chandlerfuneral home.com 302.478.7100.

BERGANE--Vilma F.,age 96, died peacefully on January 22, 2014. A lifetime New Yorker, Ms. Bergane served as Vice President and Secretary of Book of the Month Club from 1977 until her retirement in 1984. Her entire career was spent in publishing. She joined Doubleday in 1941 as a file clerk and, over the years, learned all aspects of the business. She joined McCall's in 1969, where she helped launch the Cook Book Club and other bookselling projects. When the Cook Book Club was sold to the Book of the Month Club, she moved with it. At BOMC, she was the Manager of three book clubs and supervised various departments. She enjoyed helping launch the Quality Paperback Book Club by persuading editors and publishers to allow their paperback trade books to be offered in this new club. She was elected to YWCA Academy of Women Achievers in November 1983. In her retirement, she enjoyed traveling throughout the world. Other interests including gardening at Fire Island, reading, needlepoint, theater and music. She volunteered in Pediatrics at New York Hospitals for 16 years. Kendal on Hudson, a continuing care retirement community in Sleepy Hollow, NY, was her home from 2005 until her death. She is survived by her godchild, Vilma O'Brien.
CARDOZO--Benjamin. We mourn the death of our cherished member and extend deepest sympathies to his family. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York

DELMAN--Myron, The family of Myron Delman remembers and celebrates his achievements and contributions to their lives over the 100 years of his life. Born in Poland in 1913, Myron arrived in New York in 1948 after surviving the Holocaust in Europe. Having learned shoemaking as a young man, he turned his creativity, craftsmanship, sense of design, and prodigious talent for understanding the production process to the local leather goods industry, quickly rising to the position of Vice-President for Production at Gail Leather Products. Gail became Coach Leatherware, where Myron was instrumental in the growth and development of that now-legendary firm. He was always grateful for the support he received from Coach's founder, Miles Cahn, without which he could not have been so successful. Although he spent long hours at work, in the world of his family Myron was a devoted father and husband. His children fondly remember weekend days with him, playing in Riverside Park, enjoying exhibits and films at the Museum of Natural History, or fishing in the Catskills. His wife, a homemaker, remembers an excellent provider who loved to dance. (This is not to say he did not take time out for his not-to-be-missed poker game with the guys!) Myron is survived by his wife Ruth, his sons Charles, a mathematics professor, and Joel, an industrial designer, and his stepson Paul, an entrepreneur.

BENGELSDORF--Herbert, MD, 88, of Hastings-on-Hudson, NY. He died of cancer January 21, 2014. He was born in Manhattan in 1925, the son of Sara Bronstein Bengelsdorf and Simon Bengelsdorf. He grew up in Brooklyn and finished one year at Cornell University before he was drafted into the Army infantry. After the war he graduated from Cornell and entered Chicago Medical School in 1949. He trained as a neurologist but a required course in psychiatry so intrigued him that he changed his specialty. He had a private practice, worked at Metropolitan Hospital in Manhattan, and taught psychiatry at New York Medical College. In 1979, as director of psychiatry at the Westchester County Medical Center, he began an outreach effort to find and treat patients before they required admission. His "Crisis Team" treated family members and co-workers in addition to the "identified patient," an approach that was adopted by other hospitals. Dr. Bengelsdorf retired in 1990. After the death of his first wife, Grace Wenett, he married Evelyn Isaac. He loved this merged family, which included his son, Peter, daughter-in-law, Emily, grandson, Tobias and his wife, Basia; stepdaughter, Emily Isaac and her partner, David Tumblety; stepdaughter, Rachel Isaac Hager and her husband, Jeremy; and step-granddaughters Sophie and Betty Hager. His sister, Annette LeWinter, died in 2012. He loved his profession and his many interests, such as music, literature and writing letters to the Editor of the New York Times, 14 of which were published. A memorial service will be held at Edwards Dowdle Funeral Home, Dobbs Ferry, NY, 11am Friday, January 31.

CARDOZO--Benjamin M.,of New York City, died peacefully on January 19th at his Westport, CT home. He was a lawyer, a WWII veteran, and a philanthropist. Born in Manhattan in 1915, he graduated from Dartmouth College, Class of 1937, and NYU Law School. He served with the Moreland Commission, with the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration in Europe, and with the Justice Dept in Washington, D.C. He practiced law for over sixty years at his family law firm, Cardozo & Cardozo, formerly Cardozo & Nathan. He is survived by his best friend and wife, Barbara (nee Schaffer), his brother, Dr. Richard Cardozo, his daughters, Enid Cardozo (Ed Lamon), Ellen Sonsino (Isaac Sonsino), five grandchildren, and a great-grand-daughter. Services were private. Donations in his memory to Dartmouth College are appreciated.

CARCANAGUES--Jacques Soho pioneer, passed away in New York City on January 13th. He will be greatly missed by his friends and family throughout the world. Our dear Jacques was born on August 22nd 1937 in Paris, France. After a stint in the French Foreign Service in Brazil, Central America, and Tunisia his adventurous spirit took him to New York City in the early 1970's where he established himself. From his loft he started his legendary business with ethnographic art from Asia, Central America and North Africa. Jacques Carcanagues Gallery became a landmark destination for 40 years in the heart of Soho. His artifacts were sold in museum shops and galleries around the world. The last location on Greene Street closed it's doors February 2013. He lived his work. With a discerning eye he traveled the world to hand select every piece. His exotic global vision, curiosity and passion for collecting both ethnographic and contemporary art created new trends and fashions, but the soul of the business was about spiritual artifacts of many cultures. He will be heart-fully remembered for his unique humor, quick intelligence, his love of beauty and music and his laughing eyes. He is survived by his life partner Sergio Francescon, his sisters Nicole Tirard of Paris, Marie-Claire Chantriaux of Aix-en-Provence, France, and loving nieces and nephews. He will be greatly missed by his family and many friends. His remains will be interred in Paris. There will be no funeral service. A private memorial will be held in the future. In lieu of flowers make a prayer of your choice.

CHABON--Dr. Ada, on January 23, 2014. Physician at Beth Israel Medical Center for many years. Beloved wife of Dr. Richard J. Stenger. Loving mother of Brenda Chabon, PhD and Arthur D. Chabon. Cherished "ita" to Issac Samuel Chabon and Jacob Harrison Chabon.

DeVRIES--Phyllis Krex, age 92, passed away on January 21st. Adored wife of Philip (deceased), loving mother of Philip Jr, Mary, Jane and Robert. Dear sister of Nina Silverman and Ruth Druxerman. Loving grandmother of Ben, Jennie, Emily, Rebecca and Megan. Great-grandmother of Maddy and Harry. She will be greatly missed by her many friends and family.

BERGMANN--Dr. Martin, The Psychoanalytic Research and Development Fund mourns the death of its esteemed member, Dr. Martin Bergmann. Dr. Bergmann was a long-standing member of the Fund and its Board of Directors. He was a champion of psychoanalysis, an original thinker who contributed a great deal to the Fund's study of psychoanalytic topics. All of us benefited enormously from his enthusiastic participation in the Fund's activities and publications. Our thoughts are with his wife, Maria and his son Michael and his family. We will miss him greatly. Harold Blum MD, President Henry Nunberg MD, Professional Director

COHEN--Norman B.,87, of San Diego, CA died January 18 after a long illness. He is survived by his wife of 62 years, Roberta, daughters Leslie Lemberg and Linda Goldman (Harris) and grandchildren Nathan, Ross, Kate and Jonathan. A native New Yorker and apparel industry executive, Norman was a graduate of Horace Mann and Yale, and served as a Marine in the Korean War. Adored for his quick wit, easy-going manner and intelligence, he will be missed by everyone who knew him.

BARNIE--Doris C.,The New York Society for Gastrointestinal Endoscopy mourns the passing of our beloved colleague Doris Barnie, RN. Doris was a nursing pioneer in gastroenterology and champion of excellence in patient care. Her exceptional energies were tirelessly applied to the continuing education of nurses and associates in gastroenterology. For many years, she directed the GI nurses and associates component of the NYSGE annual postgraduate course, which has been named in her honor. Recently, Doris received a Lifetime Achievement Award from the Society of Gastroenterology Nurses and Associates, having previously served as a Regional Society President. She is much loved and will be long remembered.

ACHS--Samuel, MD, MS, FACS February 23, 1919-January 19, 2014. Sam Achs, died peacefully in his home with his wife Sharon by his side. Sam was a gentle man with a remarkable intellect and a quiet, caring manner. He was truly a "good human being", who in his own style was accessible, generous, giving and wise. He is predeceased by his son Robert. He is survived by his wise Sharon, his daughter Naomi, daughter-in-law Jackie, grandchildren Maggie, (Peter) Jake, Rachel, great- granddaughters Ramona, Gloria, niece Eleanor (Howard) brother-in-law Michael (Pat) and dear friends Robin and Joel, and Greg Cunningham. Donations may be sent to: Trinitycarehospice.org
AGATA--Burton C. We will miss his humor, intellect and loving friendship through all these years. "Your voice forever stilled." The Schmertz Family

AHLUWALIA--Inderive (Andy) Singh, 58 years old, passed away on January 23, 2014. Andy was devoted to his family and is survived by his wife Nancy Silverman, children Harrison Samir and Jillian Rachna Ahluwalia, brother Pradeep Singh Ahluwalia and sister-in-law Mary Ahluwalia, his large extended family of aunts, uncles, in-laws, nieces and nephews and predeceased by his parents Jagjit and Balwant Singh Ahluwalia. Andy had a 29 year battle with a rare thyroid cancer that he handled with grace, courage and dignity. He dealt privately with his disease and lived a full life with his family and friends. He had a great sense of humor and zest for life. Andy had an incredible work ethic and positive attitude which was recognized by each of the companies he worked for as well as those he developed as an entrepreneur. The Memorial Service will be held at Lesko & Polke Funeral Home, 1209 Post Road, Fairfield, CT at 2pm Friday, January 31st followed by a gathering of friends and family. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made in memory of Inderive Ahluwalia to support Thyroid and Endocrine Cancer Research at Massachusetts General Hospital, with checks made out to MGH (Inderive Ahluwalia in the memo line) and sent c/o MGH Development Office, 100 Cambridge Street, Suite 1310, Boston, MA 02114. For travel directions or to sign his guest register please visit LeskoPolkeFuneralHome.com

ABBE--Kathryn, photographer, died peacefully at her home in Brookville, NY, on January 18 at age 94. Born in Brooklyn, she graduated from Pratt Institute in 1941 and began a 70-year career as a professional photographer. Her subjects included fashion icons, children, personalities, and artists. Her photographs are in the permanent collections of the Akron Museum of Art, the Brooklyn Museum, Guild Hall Museum, the International Center of Photography, and the Metropolitan Museum of Art. She was co-author of two books on her favorite subjects of twins and photography. She was pre-deceased by her husband, photographer and antiques dealer James Abbe, Jr. (1912-1999). Known to her family as Fuffy, she was an inspiration and a mentor for young artists, including students at Friends Academy, where she served as trustee. She also served as clerk of Jericho Friends Meeting. She is survived by her twin sister, Frances McLaughlin-Gill, a daughter, Lucinda Abbe, her sons, Thomas Abbe and Eli Abbe, a stepson, James Abbe III, a niece, Leslie Gill, and five grandchildren. Memorial donations can be made to Quaker United Nations Office, www.quno.org To send condolences, visit oysterbayfuneralhome.com
