NADLER--Allen. OHR ZARUAH LA TZADIK (a light shines on the righteous). On January 12, 2014 Allen Nadler, beloved partner of Jeff Donnelly and much loved father of Susannah and Reena Nadler, unexpectedly passed away. Allen's warmth, generosity, and zest for living was evident to all who knew him, and his passion for adventure was legendary. Jeff came into his life in the past ten years and filled him with a happiness that was a blessing. Reena and Susannah, the center of his world, received his constant and unconditional love. After attending Dartmouth College, Allen had a successful career on Wall Street, highlighted by his time at Goldman Sachs as a securities analyst and at Drexel Burnham as an investment banker. Following his retirement, Allen taught high school math through New York City Teaching Fellows. He was a beloved member of the Upper West Side Jewish Community, a past President of Ansche Chesed Congregation and, more recently, an active member of the Jewish community in Fort Lauderdale. Allen forged and kept friendships from every phase of his life, and his many friends, along with his family, will miss him terribly. Contributions in memory of Allen may be sent to AIDS Walk NY/Rita's Team, 2801 N. Pine Island Rd. Bldg 72 #

TOVER--Sylvia, granddaughter of Yonah Schimmel, beloved cousin of Sylvia (Bobbe) Sadosky and Adele Frischling. Friend to students/ faculty at Julliard. "Loved lemons, turn them into lemonade."Delly and Cuppy

WEIL--Inga Frenkel, MD, Sister to Helga Brinitzer. Loving mother of the late Lawrence Weil. Grandmother of Jacob, Lydia, and Amanda Weil. Great grandma to Zirk Weil. Immigrating from Germany in 1938, she practiced medicine and psychiatry for over 50 years. Deceased at age 99.

KRIMENDAHL--H. Frederick II, The Bridgehampton Chamber Music Festival sadly mourns the loss of our dear friend and long time board member, Fred Krimendahl. Fred was enthusiastically encouraging, extremely generous, and always supportive. We will miss his unfailing gentle kindness and send our heartfelt sympathy to Emilia and the family. Kenneth S. Davidson, Chairman Marya Martin, Artistic Director

LEVIN--Monte. At age 96 on January 23rd. Industrial designer, husband and companion, father, grandfather and great-grandfather. Service Monday January 27, 11:30 at Riverside Chapel, Amsterdam and 76th

IERVOLINO--Thea Petschek, artist and philanthropist, passed away on Friday, January 24, 2014, in Riverdale, New York, at the age of 89. She was preceded in death by her husband Antonio Iervolino, and by her siblings Charles, Max, and Thomas Petschek. A graduate of Vassar College and of Parsons School of Design, Thea was a skilled potter and painter and for many years taught those skills and origami as a volunteer in New York City Public Schools on the lower East Side. She was a generous life-long donor to International House New York where she lived for two years after college. Among other gifts, she donated a music practice room to that institution. She also was an important donor to the Juilliard School of Music where she, along with her siblings and cousins, established the annual Juilliard William Petschek Recital Award in honor of her uncle. She loved all the arts and vigorously supported arts programming on public television Channel 13 and public radio station WQXR. From an early age, she was an avid photographer. Attending the Berlin Olympic Games in 1936 with her father, she took a picture of Jesse Owens receiving the Gold Medal. Six decades later, she presented that historic photograph to the mayor of Atlanta, Georgia, during that city's Olympic Games. She will be fondly remembered by the many people in all walks of life whom she befriended and helped, as well as by her nieces, nephews, grandnieces and grandnephews to whom she was always unfailingly attentive and generous.

KRAMER--Bernice Weissberg, (Meme) of Sarasota, FL and Cliffside Park, NJ, died on January 25th, 2014. Daughter of the late Rubin and Minnie Denmark. She was predeceased by her husband Stanley Weissberg and daughter Elyse Weissberg Spero (of blessed memory). Wife of Robert Kramer. Devoted mother of Fonda and Jeff Lowe, Bruce Zev and Elissa Weissberg and Ted Spero. Loving grandmother of Ryan and Lauren, Matthew, Sonny, Hannah, Shlomo, Navah and Azari, Michal and Tamar. Loving great-grandmother of Eli. We were all blessed by her unconditional love and singular focus on her family.

LEE--Leslie. The Funeral for playwright Leslie Lee will be held at Saints Memorial Baptist Church in Bryn Mawr, PA, Saturday, February 1, 10am, viewing 8am-10am. Memorial Service, Signature Theatre New York City, TBA.

McGOVERN--Eugene, The Offices and Directors of the Contractors Association of Greater New York (CAGNY) extend our deepest sympathies to the family of Gene McGovern, one of the original five founders of our Association. Gene had a profound influence on NYC's construction industry and on the lives of the young men and women he generously mentored. He will be sorely missed.

MOUNDROS--Mary Eva, passed away at home on January 25, 2014. Mary is survived by her mother Elizabeth Orphanides, brother John Moundros, wife Aspasia and two sons James and Evan. Visitation will be held at Riverside Chapel at 180 West 76th St on January 28th from 2-5pm and 7-9pm. Funeral services will be held at The Annunciation Greek Orthodox Church at 302 West 91st on January 28th at 10:00am. Donations welcome to the Lighthouse for the Blind, the ASPCA or Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center. Mary held a Master's Degree in English and taught for over 30 years in the public high school system. She was highly intelligent, witty, entertaining, well-traveled and up on world news. Always an educator and passionate about reading, Mary never went a day without reading the New York Times from cover to cover. God bless you Mary. Heaven is blessed with another angel. May you rest in peace.

SHULMAN--Mary Gordon, devoted wife of author Max Shulman for 24 years, until his death in 1988, larger-than-life mother, step-mother, grandmother and great-grandmother, died peacefully at age 95 on January 22, 2014, at her apartment in New York City. Mary was a wonder. A woman of intelligence, self-reliance, humor and unique style, she changed for the better the lives of all who knew her, but especially those of her daughter, Melodie Bryant, and her step-children, Dan, Bud, Peter and Martha Shulman. There will never be another like her. She will be missed. One of six children, Mary is survived by her sister Katie Wilson and her brother Teddy Gordon, along with her daughter, her four step-children, eight grandchildren and numerous greatgrandchildren. Burial will be at Hillside Memorial Cemetery in Los Angeles and there will be a memorial service on February 16 in New York City.

McELROY--Donna Renee, born in Philadelphia on March 7, 1965, the beloved wife of Joseph F. McElroy, died Jan uary 23, at St. Barnabas Hospital in the Bronx from a rare lymphoma. Donna studied at Girl's High, followed by Temple and the Air Force Reserves. Donna was an award-winning artist. She co-founded the agency Corporate Performance Artists. She is survived by her husband, stepson Ethan McElroy, mother Lillian McCray, sisters Dionne McCray and Lisa Kidd, brother Don McCray, and many loving family members.

MARTINEZ--Mark Viatori, died peacefully on Thursday January, 23, 2014 surrounded by loving family. He was 41 years old. He was a father, husband, son, brother, friend, accomplished builder, sea captain, big wave surfer, philanthropist, saltwater fisherman, snowboarder, soccer and hockey player. He is survived by his wife, Uli (Ulrike) De Vreese Martinez, his daughters, Juliana De Vreese Martinez, 7, and Esmee Nicolina Martinez, 4, his parents, Antonia Viatori Martinez and Albert A. Martinez, his step-father, Friedrich (Fritz) Pangratz, his sister, the Honorable Stefanie A. Martinez, brother-in-law, Sergeant Steve Garcia, nieces, Isabela Martinez Thibodeau and Sofia Martinez Thibodeau, nephews, Nicolas Martinez and Maximilian Martinez, great-aunt Magali Leiseca, aunts, Maria Ryan, Joanna Martinez, Sister Maria Viatori, OCD, Nancy Anne Viatori, and uncles, Wilfred Martinez, Maximilian Viatori and Robert Ryan. Mark was recognized by colleagues, friends and family members for his honest nature and can-do attitude. There was never an obstacle that Mark didn't meet with a smile and tackle with vigor, determination and grace. His unique style and presence, especially in the face of challenges others would have shied away from, distinguished him as an individual. Doing good by doing right was his way. Mark was defined by generosity and fierce loyalty. Mark invested 100% of himself into everything he committed to - his family, friends, sports and business. Family was paramount for Mark. Mark was a resident of both Manhattan and Southampton, NY. He was born in Rochester, NY on November 7th, 1972. Mark grew up in Rumson, NJ where he attended Rumson Country Day School, Rumson Fair Haven High School and ultimately matriculated to UNC Wilmington, where he was a member of the Chi Phi fraternity. Professionally, Mark built upon the foundation that his father created when he assumed responsibility of Interior Management, Inc (IMI). He had a specific vision for the company, focused on quality workmanship and culture, and has grown the business into Manhattan, the Hamptons, and New Jersey's foremost construction and renovation partner. A Memorial Visitation will be held at Frank E. Campbell at 1076 Madison Ave. Monday January 27th from 4pm-9pm. A Memorial Mass will be held at The Church of St. Ignatius Loyola at 980 Park Ave. on Tuesday January 28th at 4pm. In lieu of flowers the family is requesting donations to Habitat for Humanity.

FIEDLER--Carolyn, on January 25th, 2014. Beloved wife of the late Morton. Devoted mother of Marjorie Samuels and Patricia Kardaras. Cherished grandmother of Alexandra Kardaras Scharfstein. Graveside services will be held Thursday, January 30, 2014 at Beth Shalom Cemetery Pittsburgh, PA.

FLEISIG--Carrie, died January 25th 2014. Beloved wife of Louis Fleisig. Beloved Mother of Neal and Elizabeth Fleisig. Grandmother of Eric, Daniel and Joseph Fleisig. Loved by family and friends, will be missed by all. Edwin L. Bennett Funeral Homes, 824 Scarsdale Avenue Scarsdale, NY 10583. 914-725-1137 www.elbennettfuneralhomes.com

CARDOZO--Benjamin M.,of New York City, died peacefully on January 19th at his Westport, CT home. He was a lawyer, a WWII veteran, and a philanthropist. Born in Manhattan in 1915, he graduated from Dartmouth College, Class of 1937, and NYU Law School. He served with the Moreland Commission, with the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration in Europe, and with the Justice Dept in Washington, D.C. He practiced law for over sixty years at his family law firm, Cardozo & Cardozo, formerly Cardozo & Nathan. He is survived by his best friend and wife, Barbara (nee Schaffer), his brother, Dr. Richard Cardozo, his daughters, Enid Cardozo (Ed Lamon), Ellen Sonsino (Isaac Sonsino), five grandchildren, and a great-grand-daughter. Services were private. Donations in his memory to Dartmouth College are appreciated.

Bergmann--Martin S. (1913-2014). We deeply mourn the passing of Martin S. Bergmann, a friend and esteemed member of The Contemporary Freudian Society (CFS) and the psychoanalytic community-at-large. He was a consummate teacher, author, a luminary, and an inspiration to generations of psychoanalysts. We all were heartened by his optimism. He will be sorely missed. Our hearts go out to his family, friends, and the many patients whose lives he so profoundly touched. Marsha Levy-Warren, PhD President, The Contemporary Freudian Society

GOWING--Richard W.,on January 24, 2014. Beloved uncle of Jonathan Hitchon. Devoted brother of Ned, John, Thomas and Robin. Cherished friend of Glen Chernigoff. He will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. Friends may call Wednesday, January 29, 2014, 2-5pm and 7-9pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st. Mass of Christian Burial on Thursday, January 30, at 10am. St. Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Ave at 84th St.

BERGANE--Vilma F.,age 96, died peacefully on January 22, 2014. A lifetime New Yorker, Ms. Bergane served as Vice President and Secretary of Book of the Month Club from 1977 until her retirement in 1984. Her entire career was spent in publishing. She joined Doubleday in 1941 as a file clerk and, over the years, learned all aspects of the business. She joined McCall's in 1969, where she helped launch the Cook Book Club and other bookselling projects. When the Cook Book Club was sold to the Book of the Month Club, she moved with it. At BOMC, she was the Manager of three book clubs and supervised various departments. She enjoyed helping launch the Quality Paperback Book Club by persuading editors and publishers to allow their paperback trade books to be offered in this new club. She was elected to YWCA Academy of Women Achievers in November 1983. In her retirement, she enjoyed traveling throughout the world. Other interests including gardening at Fire Island, reading, needlepoint, theater and music. She volunteered in Pediatrics at New York Hospitals for 16 years. Kendal on Hudson, a continuing care retirement community in Sleepy Hollow, NY, was her home from 2005 until her death. She is survived by her godchild, Vilma O'Brien.

GINSBURG--Carolyn, passed away on January 24th at the age of 68. She is survived by her loving husband Allan, who always called Carolyn "the love of his life." This Valentine's Day would have marked their 45th wedding anniversary. She also leaves behind five children, Stephanie, Kenny (Gail), Jeffrey (Melissa), Greg (Zora), and Ashley; and six grandchildren, Ryan, Eric, Mitchell, Heather, Jared and Isabel Rose. An accomplished model, ever generous and philanthropic, she will be remembered as a beautiful woman, both inside and out. Carolyn had a passionate spirit, a heart of gold, and an unconditional love for her family and friends. She will be truly missed by all. The funeral will be held Monday, January 27th, 11:30am at Gutterman & Musicant, 402 Park Street, Hackensack, NJ .

GARDNER--Helen L.,Rochester, January 16, 2014 at age 92; formerly of New York, NY. Predeceased by her husband Richard B. Gardner, her parents Edward and Nettie Lonsdale; her brothers Edward M. and James B. Lonsdale; two stepsons Richard R. Gardner and John D. Gardner. Survived by her stepdaughter Diane Gardner Premo (Edward) and three grandchildren, Katherine, Margaret and James Premo of Rochester; nieces Mary Baker, Helen Forbes and Margaret Lonsdale; nephews Edward and James Lonsdale; many great-nieces and nephews and many friends. A native of Kansas City, Missouri, Helen worked for more than 40 years as the Supervisor of the Central Pass Bureau of Trans World Airlines in New York City. She moved to Rochester to be closer to family and loved living here. A memorial service will be held on Monday, February 17 at 10:30am at Briarwood, St. John's Meadows, 1 Johnsarbor Drive, Rochester, NY 14620. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions can be made to Citymeals-on-Wheels, 355 Lexington Avenue, New York, NY 10017, citymeals.org. To share a memory of Helen or send a condolence to the family visit www.anthonychapels.com.

LESSER--Vicki, 75 died peacefully on Sunday, January 26th surrounded by family at her home in Stamford, CT. Born in New York City she attended The Dalton School and Syracuse University. Her passion for art, ballet, animals and her garden was boundless. ROSE--Anne T.,The playwrights, board and staff of New Dramatists mourn the death of Anne T. Rose. We are heartbroken at the loss of this extraordinary woman, who dedicated years of service to our playwright community and the theatre at large. The indefatigable Anne taught us many important lessons about philanthropy and life; how to work tirelessly for a cause and how to be a true friend. We will miss her profoundly for her strength, wisdom, humor and thoughtful dedication to our mission and the many people who make our work possible. Isobel Robins Konecky, President; Seth Gelblum, Chairman.

Bergmann--Martin S. (1913-2014). We deeply mourn the passing of Martin S. Bergmann, a friend and esteemed member of The Contemporary Freudian Society (CFS) and the psychoanalytic community-at-large. He was a consummate teacher, author, a luminary, and an inspiration to generations of psychoanalysts. We all were heartened by his optimism. He will be sorely missed. Our hearts go out to his family, friends, and the many patients whose lives he so profoundly touched. Marsha Levy-Warren, PhD President, The Contemporary Freudian Society

ERCKLENTZ--Enno W.,Jr., died peacefully in the presence of his immediate and loving family on January 24, 2014 after a short illness and just three days shy of his 83rd birthday. The son of Enno and Hildegard Ercklentz, who came to this country in the 1920's, Enno was born in New York City. At the age of 10, he found himself stranded with his parents and siblings in Japan at the outbreak of WWII, and attended St. Joseph's College in Yokohama. In 1947, the family was repatriated to Germany, where, he served as a civilian in the US Army in Frankfurt, Germany. In 1950 they returned to New York City, where Enno graduated in 1951 from the Collegiate School and in 1954 with a Bachelor of Arts from Columbia University. He then went on to earn a law degree from Harvard Law School in 1957. A highly regarded international corporate lawyer, Enno maintained an active legal practice up until his death. His acclaimed two-volume study entitled "Modern German Corporate Law," is still in use as a reference work. Enno served for many years as the Chairman of the Deutsche Schule in White Plains, NY. For his contributions to the school, he was awarded the Cross of the Order of Merit by the Federal Republic of Germany. A devout Catholic, he was honored to become a part of the Order of the Teutonic Knights. An exceptional human being, he was charming, urbane, a marvelous conversationalist and a true gentleman. Anyone who met Enno fell in love with his contagious smile and laughter. His kind and polite manner belied a sharp and witty intellect. His knowledge and passion for music, history, geography and travel was encyclopedic, the result of a voracious reading habit and a brilliant mind. He was and always will be remembered as someone special. Enno was a devoted father to his two lovely and loyal daughters, Cornelia Ercklentz and Stephanie Ercklentz Coleman, and a doting and proud grandfather "Opi" to Devon, Blake and Kendall Coleman, to whom he affectionately referred as his "little pups." He is survived by his daughters and grandchildren, his son-in-law, Chase Coleman, his sister Hildegard Mahoney, his brother and sister-in-law, Alexander and Margild Ercklentz, his former wife and best friend Mai Hallingby Harrison, his sister-in-law, Eevi Truumees, as well as seven nieces and nephews. There will be a private funeral mass for the immediate family and a celebration of his life is planned for the Spring. The Family requests that in lieu of flowers, donations in memory of Enno W Ercklentz, Jr. may be mailed to: the Philharmonic Symphony Society of New York, c/o New York Philharmonic, Avery Fisher Hall, 10 Lincoln Center Plaza, New York, NY 10023 or the Bladder Cancer Advocacy Network, 4915 St. Elmo Avenue, Suite 202, Bethesda, Maryland 20814.

KRIMENDAHL--H. Frederick II, The Bridgehampton Chamber Music Festival sadly mourns the loss of our dear friend and long time board member, Fred Krimendahl. Fred was enthusiastically encouraging, extremely generous, and always supportive. We will miss his unfailing gentle kindness and send our heartfelt sympathy to Emilia and the family. Kenneth S. Davidson, Chairman Marya Martin, Artistic Director

EPSTEIN--Reva Mae Paul, a true lady, beloved wife of the late Seymour S. Epstein and cherished mother of Ellen and Paul, passed peacefully on January 27, 2014. A tireless volunteer with over eighty years of public service showing compassion and kindness to others as past Sisterhood Vice-President and in other official capacities of the Westchester Reform Temple, Life member and former officer of Brandeis University, Democratic Westchester Country Volunteer Chairwoman, Heathcote School Fun Day Chairwoman, founding fundraiser for Lincoln Center, countless causes including the Mount Sinai Medical Center, Make A Wish, and National Academy Reva Paul Prize, with a crowning legacy being instrumental in establishing the Discover America program with the Lyndon B. Johnson White House to assist tourism and a pilot launch predating for what is now NYC & CO. The next time you follow a color-coded line at an airport or hospital you can think of Reva for helping you to find your way. One of the few women stockbrokers in the nineteen sixties; then at an age when most retire, turned her love of art into culinary confections. Reva's talent spawned an industry's new dawn on the lost genre of sugar art. Reva dearly loved her friends and family and was truly grateful for all the kindnesses she received in her lifetime and the good wishes from many in her last days. She requested no funeral service and only wanted to send her love to all those with whom she spent happy times. Elegant, corn flower blue eyed Reva Mae younger than springtime and always young at heart, a glamour girl, Grande Dame, fashion plate, sportswoman, master chef, artist, hostess, animal lover, friend, aunt, cousin, daughter, wife, and mother extraordinaire, you taught us to walk through the storms with our heads held high, to walk on the sunny side of the street, put on a happy face and dream. Your love made our world go round. Since you're gone and won't be ours again, we'll remember when it was a party just to be near you. Together, wherever we go, we'll be loving you always. We had the very best when we got you for a mother. We only wish we could do it all over again. We will forever be your team. It has been the highest honor and greatest privilege to be your children. You lived an honorable life setting an example for all who follow. Reva has now joined her beloved Seymour in spiritual eternity with their two hearts now resting as one. You will always be the first star we see at night. Feel the hugs and give one to Daddy.

CLAPP--Stephen, The Juilliard School community deeply mourns the passing of Stephen Clapp, the school's dean from 1994 to 2007, a member of our violin faculty since 1987, and dean emeritus. His work as a soloist, chamber musician, and orchestral player represented the highest standards of the institution. We will miss his engaging smile and caring personality. LEVIEN--Robert Ernst, 90, passed away peacefully at home with family January 28, 2014. Princeton graduate, WWII naval veteran. Civil Engineer in private practice for 60 years. Friend and mentor to many. He leaves behind his beloved wife of 69 years Anita (Daniels), son Kenneth, daughter Cary, daughter-in-law Debra and son-in-law Bill, granddaughters Andrea and Katherine. POSNER--Ruth Lee, nee Glass, died January 27 at age 88. Ruth is survived by Norman, her husband and best friend, from whom she was inseparable for 67 years, by children Henry, Michael, and Lillian, daughters-in-law Virginia and Andria, and grandchildren Rachel, Alyssa, and Joshua. Ruth graduated from Temple University where she met Norman, then in medical school. They married in 1947 and raised their family in New Rochelle. Ruth was active in Project Hope and Women's American ORT. Ruth was devoted to friends, adored her family, and loved to be surrounded by loved ones. Ruth's worth was "far above jewels." Donations in her memory to Beth El Synagogue, New Rochelle, NY. Shiva at Ruth and Norman's home until Monday, February 3.

RIEZENMAN--Michael J.,on January 27, 2014. Graduate of MIT, Electrical Engineer for Grumman Aerospace, Long Island, and then a writer for several electronic magazines, ending up at IEEE Spectrum Magazine, where his main focus was electronic and hybrid vehicles. His many interests included Gilbert & Sullivan, Sherlock Holmes, Rex Stout's Nero Wolf and traveling. He is survived by his loving wife, Paula, whom he met while on jury duty, mother Selma, sister Barbara and her husband Rick, nephew Marc, stepdaughters Stacey Campbell and Jill Kittredge, two grandsons Richard Jones and Weston Campbell, and a host of adoring friends and family including his neighborhood and high school friends, "The Bensonhurst Boys". Services Wednesday, 11:15am at "The Riverside," 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

WEINBLATT--Charlotte Redlener Adelman, age 91, died in New Rochelle on January 28, 2014. Born and raised in New York City, Charlotte had a highly successful 35 year career as a teacher. A rare combination of intelligence, great insight and a deep abiding affection for family characterized her personality and overall life view. She was a magnificent woman of grace and caring who, never succumbing to self-pity, endured many tragedies and the loss of some of the people she loved most (cousins, her only sister, Helen, her beloved husband, Jerry Weinblatt and a cherished grandson, Jason). Through everything, as she often proclaimed with love and laughter, "I am the matriarch!" To say she will be missed is to understate the impact of her loss in the lives of her family members and many close friends. She is survived by three sons, Irwin Redlener, his wife Karen, Neil Redlener and his partner Deanna, Eric Redlener, his wife Gloria, grandchildren David, Michael, his wife Ania, Stephanie, Jesse, his wife Kari, Rachel, her wife Thea, Jenna, her husband Nasir, Sasha, Jacob, and great-grandchildren Caleb, Mia, Naomi, Aaron, Olivia, Ben, Eloise, Solomon and Lily, daughter-in-law Pam and granddaughters-in-law, Judith and Sheareen. After Charlotte died, her sons found a box filled with poems, instructions (like, literally, don't forget to dress warmly, don't fight over possessions, be kind to each other, value family above all else), newspaper articles she wanted us to read after she was gone, legal papers, her life chronology. She was determined to leave her mark, her counsel and her love with all of us, long after she left the living world. Per Mom's wishes, in lieu of flowers, friends and family are encouraged to consider donations to the Children's Health Fund accessible at www.childrenshealthfund.org.

STACOM--Matthew John, 95, died peacefully on January 25, 2014 in Aventura, Florida. Born and raised in Long Island City, Matthew was fiercely proud of his New York roots. His father, Matthew, was a builder of private homes and commercial properties and his mother, Helen, was a homemaker. He and his surviving brother, Ray, had an active and happy childhood. Matthew was a graduate of Xavier High School and received a Bachelor of Arts degree from Lehigh University in 1941. After serving as a lieutenant in the U.S. Navy during World War II, he obtained a Masters in business administration from New York University in 1948. Known to his friends and family as "MJ", as a bachelor, Matthew was well known for his good looks and impeccable dress. He was a man about town in New York City and a two-time winner of the New York Sun's Most Eligible Bachelor award. During his 67 year career at Cushman & Wakefield, Inc. (C&W), MJ played an integral role in the development, sale, and leasing of commercial properties in major cities throughout the U.S. Rising rapidly through the ranks at C&W, he held the title of number one sales professional year after year and was eventually promoted to Vice Chairman. He was a long-time Member of the Board of Directors and prominent shareholder in C&W and was intimately involved in the firm's sale to, and buy-back from, RCA. MJ's career accomplishments include representation of a who's who of America's finest corporations, developers, and owners, including HBO, Ebasco Service, Inc., and others too numerous to name. His crowning glory was the sale of two square blocks in downtown Chicago to Sears, Roebuck and Company. This led to the development of what was then the world's tallest building Sears Tower - for which Stacom served as the exclusive leasing and management agent. During his career, MJ also served on innumerable committees within the Real Estate Board of New York, including the Municipal Affairs and Civil Rights Committees. In 1962 and 1963 he won REBNY's Most Ingenious Sales award. MJ also served as Chairman of the Sales Brokers Committee and became the third Chairman of the Young Men's / Women's Real Estate Association of New York. An avid tennis player and swimmer, MJ truly enjoyed the outdoors. He was the beloved father of six children who he raised with his late wife, Claire Murphy, in Greenwich, CT. MJ was an active community member and strong supporter of the Greenwich Historical Society and Greenwich Library. His was a founding family of the Whitby School and he was extremely active at Greenwich Academy and Brunswick School, from which his children graduated. MJ was also an active member of numerous clubs including The Greenwich Country Club, The University Club, The Metropolitan Club, where he served on the Board of Governors, and the Fisher Island Club in Miami. The family patriarch, MJ hosted family gatherings and celebrations with gusto. He treasured the role of provider, storyteller, and family man. He adored his children and grandchildren, and enjoyed telling them unique tales of his life. After the death of Claire, MJ met and married Lesta Summerfield in 1983. They enjoyed a glorious life together which led from Manhattan to Fisher Island and, finally, to Aventura, Florida. Matthew is survived by his beloved wife, Lesta, his brother Ray, and his beloved children and their families, including his daughter Pat; daughter Stacy and her husband Eric Ossorio and their children Willem, Kane and Beau; daughter Tara and her husband Arthur Diedrick; daughter Darcy and her husband Chris Kraus and their children Amber and Teal; son Matthew, and daughter Beau and her husband Daniel Gerson and their children Claire and Asher. Matthew is also survived by his beloved stepdaughters and their families, including Marianne and her husband Rick Dornfeld and their children Paul and Micah; Paulette and her husband Richard Landes and their children Andrew and Jane; and Melissa and her husband Chris Gough and their children Alexander and Cameron. In lieu of flowers, the family would sincerely appreciate donations be made to The Stacom Family Speaker Series at MJ's alma mater, Lehigh University. MJ and four of his children attended Lehigh and the school meant a great deal to him. To do so, please visit Http://mylehigh.lehigh.edu/ donate and indicate your gift is "in memory of Matthew J. Stacom." A celebration of his life will be held for family and friends at The Metropolitan Club on Friday, February 21st at 10am.

STACOM--Matthew J. The governors, members and staff of the Real Estate Board of New York mourn the passing of Matthew Stacom, distinguished real estate broker and father of REBNY governor Darcy Stacom and REBNY member Tara Stacom. Matthew served as a Vice Chairman at Cushman & Wakefield and was involved in developing the Sears Tower. Matthew was an active REBNY member for over 67 years and was recognized by his peers when they awarded him The Most Ingenious Deal of the Year award in 1962 and 1963. We express our sincere condolences to his wife Lesta, his daughters Darcy and Tara, and the entire Stacom family. Rob Speyer, Chairman Steven Spinola, President

KLADOPOULOS--Dr. Nicholas, on January 27, 2014, was born in Istanbul, Turkey on April 23, 1926. He played soccer at Fenerbahce and served as a Lieutenant in the Turkish army. Nicholas was a born scholar and studied Theology at Halki and received his doctorate from the University of Thessaloniki. Nicholas held the position of Director of Education for the Greek Orthodox Archdiocese of North and South America until his retirement in 1999. He was a beloved and dedicated husband to Mary Georgia; father to Chris, Theodore and Katherine Megdanis; father-in-law to Maria and Dr. Ernest Megdanis; grandfather to George, Nicholas, Angelica, Nicholas and Georgia. Reposing at the Frederick Funeral Home of Flushing, Northern Blvd. at 193rd Street. Visiting Hours Thursday 2-5 and 7-9pm. Visitation will also be available at Cathedral of the Holy Trinity Church on Friday from 10:00am - 11:00am. Funeral Service Friday Archdiocese Cathedral of the Holy Trinity Church at 11:00am. Interment Flushing Cemetery.

CLAPP--Stephen, The Juilliard School community deeply mourns the passing of Stephen Clapp, the school's dean from 1994 to 2007, a member of our violin faculty since 1987, and dean emeritus. A person of exceptional artistry, impeccable character, and deep sensitivity, he was admired by us all as an artist and as a human being. His work as a soloist, chamber musician, and orchestral player represented the highest standards of the institution. We will miss his engaging smile and caring personality. We send our deepest condolences to his beloved wife, Linda, his children, Amy, Peter, and Andrew, and his entire family. Bruce Kovner, Chairman Joseph W. Polisi, President Ara Guzelimian, Provost and Dean

ARNETT--Harvey, passed away on Sunday, January 26, 2014. He was surrounded as always by his family and friends. LEMLE--Gertrude B. We note with sorrow the passing of our longtime member Gertrude B. Lemle and extend sincerest condolences to her bereaved family. Rabbi Peter J. Rubinstein President David B. Edelson Central Synagogue of New York City

LEVIEN--Robert Ernst, 90, passed away peacefully at home with family January 28, 2014. Princeton graduate, WWII naval veteran. Civil Engineer in private practice for 60 years. Friend and mentor to many. He leaves behind his beloved wife of 69 years Anita (Daniels), son Kenneth, daughter Cary, daughter-in-law Debra and son-in-law Bill, granddaughters Andrea and Katherine. Predeceased by son Andrew. Funeral service: Friday, 9:45am, Riverside Nassau North Chapels, 55 No. Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his memory to the Long Island Alzheimer's Foundation (LIAF), Port Washington, NY.

SHAPIRO--Beatrice, age 98, passed peacefully on January 28th. A brilliant woman who will be sorely missed.

KRIMENDAHL--H. Frederick. The Board of Governors, Members and Staff of Deepdale Golf Club deeply regret the passing of our esteemed member and friend, H. Frederick Krimendahl. Our deepest sympathy is extended to the bereaved family. D. Dixon Boardman, President

SPRAGUE--Elsie Youngman Hull, age 67 of Washington DC and Manchester, MA. Died at the University of Maryland Hospital after seven years with multiple myeloma. She attended Brearley School, and then Bennett College. She received a BA at the Corcoran School of Art and then a Masters in film from American University in Washington. Elsie painted and sculpted for many years and exhibited in multiple galleries in Washington. In the late 1970's, she "discovered" photography. In 1983, she was a founding member of PRISMA, a Washington photographic group. She was fascinated with technique, and worked in multiple formats with cameras that ranged from modern to primitive. She did multiple shows and trips, and published three books of photographs detailing her travels, particularly to Cuba. With a simple camera, she did wedding books in black and white attempting to capture the spirit of the event rather than its details. She traveled widely and her pictures reflected that adventurous spirit; two weeks before her death, she was in Aruba. Her travels also included trips to India to meet the Dalai Lama and to Brazil to meet John of God. An early marriage to Harry Hull III ended in divorce. She is survived by her husband, James Sprague; her daughters, Celina and Julia; and her brothers, William and Robert Youngman. A memorial service will be held Wednesday, February 5 at 11:00am at Christ Church, Georgetown, 31st and O NW, Washington, DC. Contributions in lieu of flowers, can be made in Elsie's name to the University of Maryland Greenebaum Cancer Center, 110 S Paca St, 9th floor Baltimore, MD 21201.

RAPHAEL--Melvyn, of Forest Hills, NY on January 28, 2014. Beloved husband of the late Susan Raphael. Adored father of Russell and Stefanie Wallach; Allison and Ray Lauenstein. Devoted grandfather of Ben, Rachel, Sophie and Hannah. Dear brother of Deborah Blum. Loved uncle of Jonathan Blum and Barbara Spindel; Belinda Blum and Eric Wallach. Services will be held on Friday January 31, 2014 at 10:30am at Schwartz Brothers-Jeffers Memorial Chapel, Forest Hills, NY.

SEEGER--Peter, age 94. Taught us, "My job is to show folks there's a lot of good music in this world and if used right it may help to save the planet." He was one of our greatest and inspirational teachers. May his many lessons continue to transform us. Peter and Russell Neufeld

REICHMAN--Steven H.,died at his home in Haverford, PA, on January 27 at the age of 70 after suffering complications from a lung infection. Born in Washington Heights and raised in Flushing, Steve graduated from Stuyvesant High and Brooklyn Poly (Polytechnic). A metallurgist by trade, he worked for companies in Utica, NY, Portland, OR, Pittsburgh and Exton, PA, where he recently retired from Timet Corp., a manufacturer of Titanium. Steve was a Renaissance man; his interests were as varied as his travels: golf, food, reading, music, hiking. But most of all, he enjoyed sharing life with his life partner and soul-mate, Susan Schweitzer. Besides Susan, he is survived by a son, Aaron, a brother, James, and three grandchildren. Two other sons, Jeremy and Alexander, pre-deceased him. Services were private.

SPIERER--Henry, passed peacefully Tuesday, September 28, 2014 at age 79, known to many as "Hank" the Madison Avenue intimate apparel legend for 50 years. He was a generous and loyal friend and will be greatly missed. He is survived by his loving wife Elena, caring daughters Ivy and Lili, wonderful son Danny, devoted sons-in-law Marc and John, and treasured grandchildren Emily, Jake and Matthew. Services: The Riverside, West 76th and Amsterdam on Friday, Januray 31st at 11:30am.

JAMIESON--Francis A. November 8, 1904 - January 30, 1960. After more than half a century we still miss your wit, laughter, wisdom and warmth, and wish you could have known your 7 grandchildren and their families, many of whom have qualities that remind us of you. Joan-Ellen, Margot and Fran

She is survived by her loving husband of 55 years, Paul; son Steven, daughter Robin; son-in-law Charles; granddaughters Samantha and Alexis and her sister Harriet, as well as nieces and nephews, all of whom she dearly loved.

STACOM--Matthew. The Officers and Directors of the Realty Foundation of New York mourn the passing of Matthew Stacom. Matthew was a giant in the real estate industry, paving the way for future generations of real estate professionals. His knowledge of the inner workings and his dedication to each and every deal are legendary. We send heartfelt condolences to Tara, a vice president of the foundation and to Darcy on the loss of their father. Tara and Darcy continue the Stacom legacy into the future. We send our thoughts and prayers to the entire Stacom family. May you rest in peace Matthew. H. Dale Hemmerdinger, Chairman Jeffrey R. Gural, President

HIRSCH--Robert Henry, 88, of Sarasota, died peacefully in his sleep on Monday morning January 27, 2014. He was born to the late Clarence and Ruth Hirsch, May 29, 1925, in Kansas City, MO. Robert graduated from Pembroke Country Day School in 1941 and received a BS in Engineering from the University of California Berkeley in 1944, graduating early to serve in the Navy in World War II. He married the late Pamela Hirsch in 1987, and they lived together in Westport, CT. and New York City, before relocating to Sarasota in 1992. Robert was a businessman and owned a chain of women's clothing stores in Fairfield County, CT, Brooks Hirsch until he retired in 1992. He was passionate about making a difference in the lives of his customers, employees and their families. He also served on the board of Westport Bank and Trust and Fairfield University. He was active with several local charities and foundations including The Nature Center of Westport and The Van Wezel Center of Sarasota. Robert was an active member of Birchwood Country Club, Bird Key Yacht Club and the Longboat Key Club. He was an avid golfer and tennis player. He loved architecture and was inspired by the work of Frank Lloyd Wright and the mid century movement. He also loved to travel, especially to his favorite destinations - the South of France and Paris. Although he spent his final years in Florida, his favorite place always remained Westport, CT, enjoying the summer sounds of the water and slurping his beloved Blue Point oysters from his hometown. Robert is survived by three children: Sydney Bellinger, of Rye, NY; Leslie Becker, of Winter Park, FL; and Robert Hirsch, of Austin, TX. He also is survived by three grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, the family is requesting that donations be made out to the Van Wezel Center for the Performing Arts. A service will be held at 10:30am Friday at Harding Funeral Home. Burial will be held at 11:15 at Willow Brook Cemetery.

BERGMANN--Martin. The Contemporary Freudian Track of The New York University Postdoctoral Program in Psychoanalysis mourns the loss of Professor Martin Bergmann, one of the leading scholars and practitioners in the field of psychoanalysis, beloved colleague, mentor, teacher and friend. We extend deepest sympathies to his wife, Maria Bergmann, son, Michael Bergmann and his grandson. Professor Bergmann died on January 22, 2014, just before his 101st birthday. Until the end, he kept a full schedule of students, patients, supervisees and writing. We witnessed his awe inspiring, creative odyssey through the latter part of his life. In addition to his treatment of patients and his teaching, especially of Freud, his prodigious contributions to the field included the areas of The History of Psychoanalysis, Nazism, Romantic Love, The Oedipus Complex, Psychoanalysis in Old Age and Shakespeare. Martin was passionate about teaching, independent and original thinking, new ideas and the uniqueness of each patient. He eschewed orthodoxy and fanaticism. He combined a formidable intellect with a sense of personal importance to patients and students. He was instrumental in preserving Freud's legacy but did so in a critical and intimate way. Martin was born in Prague, Czechoslovakia on February 15, 1913. He moved to Palestine when he was seven years old where his father, Hugo Bergmann became a world renowned scholar at the Hebrew University. He emigrated to the United States to study genetics. There he became interested in psychology. He served as a psychologist in the U.S. army and came to New York to pursue psychoanalysis. A memorial service will be held in the spring. Therese Rosenblatt, PhD For the Contemporary Freudian Track NYU Postdoctoral Program in Psychoanalysis

KLEIN--Margaret Kennedy. Born February 4, 1950 in Orange, New Jersey. Died January 18, 2014 in New York City. Never complaining or feeling sorry for herself, Margaret battled cancer for 15 years. Margaret was the youngest of three children of the late Mary Eddy Klein and Walter C. Klein. She grew up in Maplewood and Short Hills, NJ and graduated from Kent Place School in Summit, NJ and Wellesley College, her mother's alma mater, where she majored in art history. Margaret was a pioneering woman in finance and had a successful 20-year career at Chase Manhattan Bank, holding 16 positions in five banking divisions on four continents, including assignments in London, Panama City and Johannesburg. Her last position was Division Executive/Managing Director of the Special Loan Division, where she was responsible for Chase's global non-real estate-related troubled loan portfolio. Margaret ultimately left Chase to become CEO/CFO of a near-bankrupt oil distribution company in Connecticut, which she restructured and brought back to life. While Margaret was astute financially and a strong negotiator, her main priorities were family and friends. She had scores of very good friends on many continents, since she had a love for adventure and travelled widely from an early age to all parts of the globe. She kept in close touch with her family and friends and developed special relationships with their children. Margaret enjoyed the fact that her apartment in New York was a welcoming way-station for visitors from everywhere. Margaret was passionate about women's rights, education, international affairs, environmental conservation and the arts and, through the family foundation she headed, supported many philanthropic organizations, including Trickle Up (an organization helping women around the world escape extreme poverty), Planned Parenthood, the American Museum of Natural History, Wellesley College and Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute. Margaret is survived by her brother John E. Klein of Washington, D.C. and by her niece and nephew Jennifer Klein Seaman and Thomas Eddy Klein of New York City. She was pre-deceased by her brother Walter C. (Terry) Klein, Jr. Margaret is also mourned by her eight god-children. A memorial service for Margaret will be held at St. James' Episcopal Church, 865 Madison Avenue (at 71st Street), New York City on February 25 at 3:00pm. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in Margaret's memory to Trickle Up or to Planned Parenthood of New York City.

BRAVIN--Ira, age 83, passed away in his home on January 24th. Ira was the founder, publisher and writer of the New York Connection, a trade publication to the textile industry. After working in marketing at WWD, Ira and his wife embarked on a publication of their own, believing that present day trade publications had limitations. His wish was to enhance communication between the textile and manufacturing worlds. His goal was to encourage daring business people with common interests and problems, to find one another. This innovative magazine, with its unique textile registry, published for 25 years. Ira's family remembers his warmth towards all he knew; his affection for his Brooklyn days; his keen interest in General Semantics; his Fire Island summers; his piano playing; his dancing; his love of traveling to France with his wife; and above all his great sense of humor. He is survived by his wife Jean, daughter Karin, and grandchildren Charlotte and Jackson. He will be sorely missed. A memorial will be planned for the spring.

FIORITO--Dolores. The Lauder family and The Estee Lauder Companies are deeply saddened by the passing of our beloved former colleague, Dolores Fiorito. Dolores worked with our Company from 1978 to 1996 where she became the field sales manager for the Estee Lauder brand. She passed away on January 28 in New York City after a short illness. Dolores is survived by her son Michael Fiorito, daughter-in-law Patrice Fiorito and grandchildren Harlin and Jade of Las Vegas; and by her daughter Rona Fiorito and grandchild Jesse of New York and Boston, respectively. Our thoughts are with her family and many friends.

BLACHER--Richard. The members of the NY Psychoanalytic Society & Institute mourn the loss of our esteemed member, Dr. Richard Blacher. A devoted colleague for 50 years, he will be dearly missed. We extend our condolences to his family. Ian D. Buckingham, MD, President

FERRERA--Stephen, Grammy-award winning record producer. Survived by his loving wife Camilla, children Grace Sophia and Guy Alexander. Parents Gaetano and Olga Ferrera, sisters Jayne Schmitz and Deborah Baldwin. A Memorial service will be Monday, February 3rd, 4pm at "The Riverside," 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to: Lung Cancer Research at MSKCC, 300 East 66th St., NYC 10065.
HUMBACH--William. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of William Humbach, associated with The New York Times from May 16, 1951 until retiring on November 1, 1986.

KLADOPOULOS--Dr. Nicholas, on January 27, 2014, was born in Istanbul, Turkey on April 23, 1926. He played soccer at Fenerbahce and served as a Lieutenant in the Turkish army. Nicholas was a born scholar and studied Theology at Halki and received his doctorate from the University of Thessaloniki. Nicholas held the position of Director of Education for the Greek Orthodox Archdiocese of North and South America until his retirement in 1999. He was a beloved and dedicated husband to Mary Georgia; father to Chris, Theodore and Katherine Megdanis; father-in-law to Maria and Dr. Ernest Megdanis; grandfather to George, Nicholas, Angelica, Nicholas and Georgia. Reposing at the Frederick Funeral Home of Flushing, Northern Blvd. at 193rd Street. Visiting Hours Thursday 2-5 and 7-9pm. Visitation will also be available at Cathedral of the Holy Trinity Church on Friday from 10:00am - 11:00am. Funeral Service Friday Archdiocese Cathedral of the Holy Trinity Church at 11:00am. Interment Flushing Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, the family is requesting donations to be made to the Office of Institutional Advancement, Hellenic College Holy Cross, Attn: Dr. Nicholas Kladopoulos Memorial Fund, 50 Goddard Avenue, Brookline, MA 02445. Donations can also be made at www.hchc.edu.

PRITT--Solomon, of Margate, FL, passed away peacefully Tuesday night, January 28, at age 93 after a long illness. A longtime resident of New York City, where he was born and raised, in 1990 Sol moved with his wife Sylvia to Margate, FL, where he continued to work as a buyer and salesman until age 87. He was greatly beloved by family, friends and co-workers for his humor, compassion, zest for life and good heart. Sol was widely regarded as a pioneer and legend in the novelty, magic and costume industry. After running his own manufacturing/import business for many years, he joined New York-based Franco-American Novelty Co., another manufacturer and importer, in the late 1960s as its head buyer and salesman. He traveled the world in search of novelty and costume items that would add laughter and fun to our lives. During World War II, Sol was stationed at Guam in the United States Air Force and flew 27 missions in the Pacific theatre as a bombardier until the War ended, earning several medals for bravery. Sol leaves behind his wife Sylvia; sisters Doris Herstone and Ruth Greenberg; sons Michael Garry and wife Maureen, and Steve Buttolph and wife Sandi; stepchildren Gail Stone, David Stone and wife Peggy, and Deborah Elster and husband Alan; three grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. Funeral is scheduled for Friday, January 31, at 1:45pm at the Star of David Memorial Gardens Cemetery and Funeral Chapel, North Lauderdale, FL. Donations in Sol Pritt's name can be made to the Jewish Federation of Broward.

The last of her generation, Harriet maintained her grace until the end. Services will be held Sunday, February 2, 11:30am at Frank E Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st Street, New York City.

WEISS--Rhoda. Beloved wife of the late Harry Weiss, mother of Kenny and Mike Weiss, grandmother of Josh, Bessie, Nick and Casey and great grandmother of Mason, Audrey and Ricky. Formerly of Bayside, NY. Rhoda died peacefully amidst her family on January 18. She is in our hearts forever.
SCHWEDE--William J. and Robert J. We shared the same birthday all three of us. Miss you William, and Robert, my identical twin, more and more each day. Your loving brother, Raymond

GLASSMAN--Esther, Died peacefully in the company of her family on January 29, 2014 at the Hebrew Home in Riverdale, NY. Born on New Year's Day 1933 to Charles and Gussie Roth in Brooklyn, NY, Esther was able to build an instant bond of friendship with everyone she met. Most important to her were the things she was able to do for others. Esther is survived by her siblings, Harriet Montag and Michael Roth, and by her children Neil, Sheldon and Beth. She was predeceased by her husband Julius Glassman and companion Sidney Schoenbrun. Esther is also mourned by her four grandchildren and the many whose lives she has touched. Donations in her honor may be made to the American Cancer Society or the American Heart Association. A memorial service will be held graveside at the old Montefiore Cemetery, 121-83 Springfield Boulevard, Queens, NY at 11:00am on Friday, January 31, 2014.

JACOBSONJanet C.,age 57, peacefully, on January 23rd. Loving wife, daughter, sister, aunt, stepmother, grand-stepmother, and friend to legions. A multi-lingual expert in international film finance known for her keen trend spotting, negotiation skills, irreverence, wit, style, and indomitable spirit, beating the odds with a rare form of cancer that ultimately claimed her life. She never let her illness define her; rather she used it to transform her life and live it to the fullest. She moved fast, enjoying novelty and challenge. Born in New York City and raised in Burlington Vermont and Westchester County, she graduated Cornell University (Phi Beta Kappa) and Columbia Law School (Harlan Stone Fiske Scholar). She began her career as an Assistant District Attorney in the New York County office of Robert Morgenthau, moving next to the law firm of Frankfurt, Garbus, Klein & Selz where she began her specialization in entertainment law. Subsequently she was in-house counsel at Balthazar Pictures, then Scala Productions Ltd., establishing herself in European film acquisition, development, and related activities involving parties such as Miramax and Canal Plus. The bulk of her career was spent at Hallmark Entertainment/RHI Entertainment structuring production finance, tax incentives and co-production arrangements and liaison work with producers, distributors and broadcasters in the television industry. During this period she pioneered film production finance in Hungary and other Eastern European countries. Ultimately she founded Film Borders, Inc., a legal and financial consulting firm for film and television clients. She is survived by her husband, James H. Wildman, former managing partner of the King & Spalding law firm and founding partner of its New York City office; her father and step-mother, Dr. Julius H. and Mrs. Joan L. Jacobson, her sisters, Jeannie, and Wendy (Andrew H. Miller), her brother, William (Beth R. Jacobson), nieces, Annalise and Sara, nephews, Max and Jackson Miller, step-sons, James Wildman, Jr. (Suby), and Andrew Wildman (Caroline), and step-grandchildren, Wake, Henry, Eli, Ellie, Hall, and Tate. Her mother, Beverly Jacobson, pre-deceased her in 2009, and her youngest brother, David, in 2003. Friends may call Tuesday, February 4 from 3-8pm at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St. Funeral will be private with memorial service in the spring. In lieu of flowers, donations in Janet's memory to Dana-Farber Cancer Institute (www.dfci.org/give), or Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center (https://www. mskcc.org/giving/giftintro. html)

LUNIN--Lois F.,89. Widow of David Becker. Stepmother of Dan Becker (Martha Toll) and Sue Becker (Faith Baum); grandmother of Lila, Naomi, Zoe and Jamie. Frontierswoman in the field of information science, and talented fiber artist. Memorial service Sunday, noon February 2, Kol Rina, 60 Valley Street, South Orange, NJ.

KATZ-DOFT--Rebecca Madeline, 35, of Atlanta, GA died on January 30, 2014, after a long battle with a debilitating illness. She passed away peacefully in her home surrounded by the people who loved her most. It is how she would have wanted it. Rebecca was born in Port Washington, NY on February 6, 1978 in the middle of a blizzard that shut down roads, and died during a snow and ice storm that shut down Atlanta. In between, she received her B.A. from Emory University and attended graduate school at the Rollins School for Public Health at Emory, before being forced to take leave for medical reasons. She was a staunch advocate for disability services and for providing equal access and opportunities to everyone - regardless of their disability. Over the course of her long illness, she touched many lives with the spirit and enthusiasm she brought to everyday and everyone she met. Rebecca is survived by her parents, Alexander Katz and Ellen Doft; brother, David Katz-Doft; sister-in-law, Emily Chamberlin; niece, Sophia Katz; grandparents, Elliot and Frances Doft; and her cats: Sam, Ike and Mamie. The family gives a special thanks to the men and women who helped care for Rebecca during her final months, and helped her have the peace and dignity she deserved. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to Weinstein Hospice, 3150 Howell Mill Road NW, Atlanta, GA 30327, www.weinsteinhospice.org or the Hewlett Chapter of Hadassah: www.hadassah.org

BRAVIN--Ira, age 83, passed away in his home on January 24th. Ira was the founder, publisher and writer of the New York Connection, a trade publication to the textile industry. After working in marketing at WWD, Ira and his wife embarked on a publication of their own, believing that present day trade publications had limitations. His wish was to enhance communication between the textile and manufacturing worlds. His goal was to encourage daring business people with common interests and problems, to find one another. This innovative magazine, with its unique textile registry, published for 25 years. Ira's family remembers his warmth towards all he knew; his affection for his Brooklyn days; his keen interest in General Semantics; his Fire Island summers; his piano playing; his dancing; his love of traveling to France with his wife; and above all his great sense of humor. He is survived by his wife Jean, daughter Karin, and grandchildren Charlotte and Jackson. He will be sorely missed. A memorial will be planned for the spring.

BERGMANN--Martin. It is with much sadness that we have learned of the recent death of Martin Bergmann. Dr. Bergmann was a tireless friend to psychoanalysis and to his many colleagues at NYPSI, in New York and in the US. We extend our condolences to his family. Ian D. Buckingham, MD, President, New York Psychoanalytic Society & Institute

LAGER--Robert B.,of Princeton Junction, NJ on January 30, 2014. Retired proprietor of Dale Electronics (Dale Pro Audio). Beloved husband of Naomi; devoted father of Debra (Kevin) Ward, Marcia (Alan) Stein and Julia Lager-Mesulam and Steven Mesulam; cherished grandfather of Leah, Zack, Jake, Mitchell, Eli and Ari. Services Sunday 10am at Orland's Ewing Memorial Chapel, 1534 Pennington Road, Ewing, NJ. Burial at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY

FONNER--Edwin, Jr.,on January 26, 2014. He was born in Denver, CO on December 5, 1948 and is survived by his spouse of 42 years, Maribeth Ann, and his son Clifford Edwin. He was raised in an Air force family and lived in Japan, Germany, and many locations across the United States. Ed earned multiple degrees: BA in Psychology from the University of Texas, Austin, 1972; MPH, 1976, University of Texas Health Science Center, Houston; MBA, 1979, University of Houston; and Doctor of Public Health (DrPH), 1979, University of Texas Health Science Center. His professional endeavors included: studies in clinical psychology, Chicago; six years in retail stock brokerage, Houston; branch money management and brokerage operations (Paine Webber and Rotan Mosle); investment research; and municipal debt underwriting, Denver and New York City. Ed was with Voluntary Hospitals of America's capital unit and clinical/financial information system (NYC and Irving, TX, 1987 to 1988). Ed directed research and information systems at the Catholic Health Association, St. Louis, 1989 to 1995. Ed helped start the Kansas Health Institute and was Executive Director of the Kansas Governor's Public Health Improvement Commission. He helped form a health insurance purchasing pool for small business and served as grant writer and evaluator to the Manhattan, KS Community Health Council, Project Access. He won three Robert Wood Johnson Foundation grants. He was Director of Outreach at the Kansas University School of Medicine. More recently, Ed was the Executive Director and Board member for the Kansas Health Insurance Association. He was the Executive Director for the California Society of Thoracic Surgeons (STS) and the Virginia Cardiac Surgery Quality Initiative (VCSQI). He started the web site: HealthDataForum.com and served on the STS Adult Cardiac Surgery Database Taskforce. He assisted the Kansas Insurance Department's Affordable Care Act initiatives and wrote the business plan for the Kansas Health Cooperative loan (2010 and 2012). Ed completed over 25 published articles and posters for scientific sessions. Ed's athletic accomplishments: Nolan High School, varsity basketball, football, and track teams. He won All-District and All-State honors in basketball and his team won All-District in his senior year, 1966. He placed first in the District high jump and high hurdles in 1966. Ed was a runner and competitive athlete most of his adulthood. He completed over 10 "century rides," three five-kilometer swims, multiple half-marathons, two marathons, and 70 triathlons after age 50, including IronMan Louisville in 2007 and 2008. Ed's Key Learnings: be self-made; bring out the best in people; have pure intention; and listen. "With his loving wife and esteemed son, there was nothing in his life wanting."

LEVIEN--Robert. The Levien Family mourn the passing of our Uncle Bob. A distinguished architect, engineer and esteemed Princeton graduate. Our deepest sympathy to Anita, Kenneth, Cary and their families.

JACOBSONJanet C.,age 57, peacefully, on January 23rd. Loving wife, daughter, sister, aunt, stepmother, grand-stepmother, and friend to legions. A multi-lingual expert in international film finance known for her keen trend spotting, negotiation skills, irreverence, wit, style, and indomitable spirit, beating the odds with a rare form of cancer that ultimately claimed her life. She never let her illness define her; rather she used it to transform her life and live it to the fullest. She moved fast, enjoying novelty and challenge. Born in New York City and raised in Burlington Vermont and Westchester County, she graduated Cornell University (Phi Beta Kappa) and Columbia Law School (Harlan Stone Fiske Scholar). She began her career as an Assistant District Attorney in the New York County office of Robert Morgenthau, moving next to the law firm of Frankfurt, Garbus, Klein & Selz where she began her specialization in entertainment law. Subsequently she was in-house counsel at Balthazar Pictures, then Scala Productions Ltd., establishing herself in European film acquisition, development, and related activities involving parties such as Miramax and Canal Plus. The bulk of her career was spent at Hallmark Entertainment/RHI Entertainment structuring production finance, tax incentives and co-production arrangements and liaison work with producers, distributors and broadcasters in the television industry. During this period she pioneered film production finance in Hungary and other Eastern European countries. Ultimately she founded Film Borders, Inc., a legal and financial consulting firm for film and television clients. She is survived by her husband, James H. Wildman, former managing partner of the King & Spalding law firm and founding partner of its New York City office; her father and step-mother, Dr. Julius H. and Mrs. Joan L. Jacobson, her sisters, Jeannie, and Wendy (Andrew H. Miller), her brother, William (Beth R. Jacobson), nieces, Annalise and Sara, nephews, Max and Jackson Miller, step-sons, James Wildman, Jr. (Suby), and Andrew Wildman (Caroline), and step-grandchildren, Wake, Henry, Eli, Ellie, Hall, and Tate. Her mother, Beverly Jacobson, pre-deceased her in 2009, and her youngest brother, David, in 2003. Friends may call Tuesday, February 4 from 3-8pm at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St. Funeral will be private with memorial service in the spring. In lieu of flowers, donations in Janet's memory to Dana-Farber Cancer Institute (www.dfci.org/give), or Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center (https://www. mskcc.org/giving/giftintro. html)

LAZAR--Eliot. We at NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital are deeply saddened by the passing of our dear friend and beloved colleague Dr. Eliot Lazar. Words cannot fully express our sense of loss and our profound sorrow. Eliot began his brilliant career with us in 2000 as Vice President for Medical Affairs, and at the time of his passing was Senior Vice President and Chief Medical Officer for Quality. His formidable skills shaped our quality and patient safety initiatives and allowed NewYork-Presbyterian to be recognized as a national leader in quality. He leaves a legacy that ensures each patient receives the highest-quality, most compassionate care in the safest environment. An extraordinary leader, clinician, educator, administrator, husband and father, he set an example of integrity, humility, and commitment to excellence. We will always remember him. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Becky, his children, and his entire family. Frank A. Bennack, Jr., Chairman of the Board Steven J. Corwin, MD, CEO Robert E. Kelly, MD, President NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital

PARNES--Harriet, of New York, NY died peacefully of natural causes in her home on January 29th, 2014 at the age of 98. The last of her generation, Harriet maintained her grace until the end. Services will be held Sunday, February 2, 11:30am at Frank E Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st Street, New York City.

SHORT--Nancy Jean Fulop, 72, On Monday, January 20, 2014, Nancy Jean Fulop Short died unexpectedly at New York Hospital after a long fight with the side effects and complications resulting from the re-emergence of thyroid cancer. Born on January 5, 1942, she was the only child of George Edward Fulop and Elizabeth Helen (Meruse) Fulop. Nancy was raised in Toledo, Ohio, first in its Birmingham neighborhood until her family moved to the Point Place neighborhood in the late 1940s. Eventually, she moved to New York City to practice law and into Lincoln Plaza Tower, an apartment building overlooking Lincoln Center and Central Park, where she lived from 1976 until her death. She was the wife of William P. Short III, whom she married in 1978, and the mother of Bradford W. Short, who was born in 1979. Both survive her. Until she became ill, she was an active member of the Certificate of Appropriateness Committee of Landmark West as well as of her building's co-op board. She was a parishioner of the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, where she also served as a lector. She was especially fond of reading at the Easter Vigil and Christmas Eve Masses. After she retired, she was a student at the New York School of Interior Design ("NYSID"), where she was pursuing an associate degree in interior design. Her hope was to graduate from NYSID and work in the interior design industry. Nancy worked for Bowne & Co. Inc., first as Editor of its Legal Publishing Division from 1997 to early 2003 and then as Editor of Bowne's securities compliance resource, SecuritiesConnect, from 2003 to late 2005. Before working at Bowne, she was Publications Manager of securities publications at Matthew Bender. Nancy had more than 30 years experience in securities law. She practiced as a corporate and securities attorney in New York for ten years at Skadden, Burns Summit and Warshaw Burstein and as an assistant professor of corporate finance and securities law at Rutgers School of Law-Camden for four years. She was awarded a J.D. degree from The University of Toledo - College of Law, where she was first in her class, and an LL.M. degree from Yale Law School. She was a graduate of St. Ursula Academy and Mary Manse College, both located in Toledo. She was valedictorian of her class at St. Ursula and was awarded the Bishop's Cross. At Mary Manse College, she graduated summa cum laude. Nancy taught high school art as well as English literature in the Toledo school system before starting her legal career. There will be a viewing on Monday, February 3, 2014 from 2:00-5:00pm followed by an evening viewing from 7:00-9:00pm at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, at 81st and Madison Avenue, New York, New York. A funeral mass will be held at noon, Tuesday, February 4, 2014, at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola at 84th and Park Avenue, New York, New York. Following the service, interment will be at (First) Calvary Cemetery, Queens, New York. In lieu of flowers, friends are encouraged to make memorial contributions to Celiac Disease Center at Columbia University or NYSID, where an academic prize will be created for lawyers who leave the legal profession to pursue studies in interior design. Additional information on each program may be obtained by e-mailing cb2280@columbia.edu or sfingleton@nysid.edu, respectively, using Nancy Short in the subject line.

SPRAGUE--Elsie Youngman Hull, age 67 of Washington DC and Manchester, MA. Died at the University of Maryland Hospital after seven years with multiple myeloma. She attended Brearley School, and then Bennett College. She received a BA at the Corcoran School of Art and then a Masters in film from American University in Washington. Elsie painted and sculpted for many years and exhibited in multiple galleries in Washington. In the late 1970's, she "discovered" photography. In 1983, she was a founding member of PRISMA, a Washington photographic group. She was fascinated with technique, and worked in multiple formats with cameras that ranged from modern to primitive. She did multiple shows and trips, and published three books of photographs detailing her travels, particularly to Cuba. With a simple camera, she did wedding books in black and white attempting to capture the spirit of the event rather than its details. She traveled widely and her pictures reflected that adventurous spirit; two weeks before her death, she was in Aruba. Her travels also included trips to India to meet the Dalai Lama and to Brazil to meet John of God. An early marriage to Harry Hull III ended in divorce. She is survived by her husband, James Sprague; her daughters, Celina and Julia; and her brothers, William and Robert Youngman. A memorial service will be held Wednesday, February 5 at 11:00am at Christ Church, Georgetown, 31st and O NW, Washington, DC. Contributions in lieu of flowers, can be made in Elsie's name to the University of Maryland Greenebaum Cancer Center, 110 S Paca St, 9th floor Baltimore, MD 21201.

SMOLEV--Richard, Gifted lawyer, published author, loving husband and devoted father and grandfather. After battling ALS for more than two years, Richard Smolev passed away on January 25, 2014 at age 65. A New York State Regent Scholarship graduate of Columbia University, Richard obtained his JD from Chicago's Northwestern University Law School. He began his career as a litigator before focusing on bankruptcy law, first as an attorney at Wiseman, Smolev and Solow, then at Sachnoff and Weaver, before joining Kaye Scholer as a Founding Partner of the Chicago office in 2000. Recognized by Best Lawyers in America, and recipient of a 2011 International Law Office (ILO) Client Choice Award, Richard focused on the insolvency aspects of leveraged and operating leases, and routinely worked with Kaye Scholer's structured finance and real estate securitization practices in their financing and capital markets transactions. Richard continued working at Kaye Scholer for a year after his diagnosis, retiring at the end of 2012. But rather than give in to his disease, Richard decided to pursue his lifelong passion for creative writing full-time. He achieved literary success quickly, when, in July 2012, Academy Chicago Press published his first novel, Offerings, about a female Wall Street executive who must prove her worth by putting together an unconventional IPO for a small games maker whose most valuable, but unknown, asset may be a painting stolen from a Jewish family as they fled Austria after the Nazi invasion. His second book, In Praise of Angels, a historical novel about the Reconstruction Era, was published a year later. Richard's decision to pursue a second career as a writer, even as his illness became more debilitating, and the joy he took in his family, inspired many who knew him. Noted for his wry wit, vast intellect and pragmatic approach to complex problems, Richard lived and died on his own terms. A resident of Bucks County, Pennsylvania, he is survived by his wife Nancy Alessi, sons Michael and David, grandchildren Lily, Ella, Jake and Bode, brother Dr. James Smolev and sister Carole Smolev Landau. While no funeral services will be held, family members request that donations be made in Richard's memory to the ALS Association's Greater Philadelphia Chapter.
