SARACEVIC--Blanka Regina, passed away on January 18, 2014 in Glenview, IL. She was 81. She was a wife, mother, sister and grandmother, loved by all. She earned a graduate degree and worked as a children's librarian in Ohio and New Jersey. She is survived by her husband of 55 years, Tefko, her daughter Aida, her son Alan and her sisters, Vesna and Zeljka. Services to be held at Wade Memorial, Cleveland, OH, February 16.

WEISS--Ronald Whitman, 1939-2014. Real estate executive. Beloved husband of Ellen, father to Hilary, Carolyn and Chris, grandfather of five. Service Wednesday, February 5, 11am Congregation Kol Ami in White Plains, NY.
SUNSHINE--Rita, January 24th. Beloved wife of Melvin, cherished mother of Elyse and Francine, loving grandmother of Ian, sister of Bernyce.

KILBURN--Victoria Tyner, of New York City, Greenwich, CT and Key Largo, FL passed away on January 16, 2014 in Key Largo, FL. Her late husband was H. Thomas Kilburn, Jr. of New York City and Greenwich, CT. Victoria is survived by Sandra Heath, her sister; Christopher Tyner, her brother, and Tory Curtis, her niece. Victoria was a graduate of the Lawrence School, the Garrison Forest School and Villa Mercedes (Florence, Italy). She was a member of the Ocean Reef Club, the Anglers and Racquet Clubs in Key Largo, FL and the Belle Haven Yacht Club in Greenwich, CT. A Celebration of her Life for family and friends will be held at the Belle Haven Yacht Club in Greenwich, CT on June 1, 2014 at 5:30pm. In lieu of flowers, please send a contribution to Camphill Special School, 1784 Fairview Road, Glenmoore, PA, 19343, for the new Early Childhood Learning Center.

LAVNER--Jules, of Woodland Park, NJ sadly died on January 30. He is survivied by his beloved wife Gerry, dear son James (Christina) wonderful grandchildren Julianna and Jack, sister Sheila (Manny). Daughter Ronna predeceased her loving father. Funeral Tuesday, February 4, 12 noon at Jewish Memorial Chapel, Clifton, NJ.

FRIEDMAN--Dr. Raymond, of Palm Beach, Florida and Lenox, MA, died peacefully on January 20 just weeks before his 92nd birthday. As a research chemist, Dr. Friedman held positions in research and management at Westinghouse Research Laboratories, Atlantic Research Corporation and Factory Mutual Insurance Corporation of Norwood, MA., from which he retired as Vice President of Research. His many professional and academic honors include positions of leadership with the Combustion Institute, the American Chemical Society of Fuel Chemistry, the International Association for Fire Safety Science, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration and the National Academy of Science. Ray was also a member of the Cosmos Club. Known for his keen wit and analytical mind, Ray enjoyed classical music at the Society of the Four Arts in Palm Beach and Tanglewood in the Berkshires. The eclectic nature of Ray's intellect is reflected in the wide range of his publications. He is the author of the definitive text on fire prevention as well as other publications including The Foreseeable Future. Ray and his adored best friend and wife of 68 years, Myra, enjoyed traveling to all parts of the world. Besides his beloved wife, Ray leaves behind a galaxy of devoted cousins in Pittsburgh, a brother, Irving Friedman of Williamsburg, Virginia and friends who will never forget his loyalty kindness, patience and love. Funeral services were handled by Avatar Cremation Services of North Palm Beach.

KATZ-DOFT--Rebecca Madeline, 35, of Atlanta, GA died on January 30, 2014, after a long battle with a debilitating illness. She passed away peacefully in her home surrounded by the people who loved her most. It is how she would have wanted it. Rebecca was born in Port Washington, NY on February 6, 1978 in the middle of a blizzard that shut down roads, and died during a snow and ice storm that shut down Atlanta. In between, she received her B.A. from Emory University and attended graduate school at the Rollins School for Public Health at Emory, before being forced to take leave for medical reasons. She was a staunch advocate for disability services and for providing equal access and opportunities to everyone - regardless of their disability. Over the course of her long illness, she touched many lives with the spirit and enthusiasm she brought to everyday and everyone she met. Rebecca is survived by her parents, Alexander Katz and Ellen Doft; brother, David Katz-Doft; sister-in-law, Emily Chamberlin; niece, Sophia Katz; grandparents, Elliot and Frances Doft; and her cats: Sam, Ike and Mamie. The family gives a special thanks to the men and women who helped care for Rebecca during her final months, and helped her have the peace and dignity she deserved. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to Weinstein Hospice, 3150 Howell Mill Road NW, Atlanta, GA 30327, www.weinsteinhospice.org or the Hewlett Chapter of Hadassah: www.hadassah.org

KUHN--Edward, 85, of Huntington, NY died peacefully on January 31, 2014. Esteemed nuclear physicist; WWII veteran; devoted family man; haiku poet; lover of classical music, the arts and The New York Times. Beloved husband of 55 years of Judy, devoted father of Donna (Dr. Samuel) Pesin , cherished grandfather of Elyssa (Jeff) Kotzen and Jennifer Pesin, adoring great-grandfather of Skylar Kotzen. Services privately held.

POSNER--Ruth Lee, nee Glass, died January 27 at age 88. Ruth is survived by Norman, her husband and best friend, from whom she was inseparable for 67 years, by children Henry, Michael, and Lillian, daughters-in-law Virginia and Andria, and grandchildren Rachel, Alyssa, and Joshua. Ruth graduated from Temple University where she met Norman, then in medical school. They married in 1947 and raised their family in New Rochelle. Ruth was active in Project Hope and Women's American ORT. Ruth was devoted to friends, adored her family, and loved to be surrounded by loved ones. Ruth's worth was "far above jewels." Donations in her memory to Beth El Synagogue, New Rochelle, NY. Shiva at Ruth and Norman's home until Monday, February 3.

PECK--Helen, of Scarsdale, NY died peacefully on January 27th. She was predeceased in death by her beloved husband Milton and son Joseph. She is survived by her daughter, Mary Ellen Rogers (Peter); son, Robert Peck (Paula); grandchildren, Micheala, Tain, Alex Kendrick (Scott); and great-grandsons Cooper and Parker. She was greatly loved and will be missed by all who knew her for her kindness, sharp wit and wonderful presence.

FONNER--Edwin, Jr.,on January 26, 2014. He was born in Denver, CO on December 5, 1948 and is survived by his spouse of 42 years, Maribeth Ann, and his son Clifford Edwin. He was raised in an Air force family and lived in Japan, Germany, and many locations across the United States. Ed earned multiple degrees: BA in Psychology from the University of Texas, Austin, 1972; MPH, 1976, University of Texas Health Science Center, Houston; MBA, 1979, University of Houston; and Doctor of Public Health (DrPH), 1979, University of Texas Health Science Center. His professional endeavors included: studies in clinical psychology, Chicago; six years in retail stock brokerage, Houston; branch money management and brokerage operations (Paine Webber and Rotan Mosle); investment research; and municipal debt underwriting, Denver and New York City. Ed was with Voluntary Hospitals of America's capital unit and clinical/financial information system (NYC and Irving, TX, 1987 to 1988). Ed directed research and information systems at the Catholic Health Association, St. Louis, 1989 to 1995. Ed helped start the Kansas Health Institute and was Executive Director of the Kansas Governor's Public Health Improvement Commission. He helped form a health insurance purchasing pool for small business and served as grant writer and evaluator to the Manhattan, KS Community Health Council, Project Access. He won three Robert Wood Johnson Foundation grants. He was Director of Outreach at the Kansas University School of Medicine. More recently, Ed was the Executive Director and Board member for the Kansas Health Insurance Association. He was the Executive Director for the California Society of Thoracic Surgeons (STS) and the Virginia Cardiac Surgery Quality Initiative (VCSQI). He started the web site: HealthDataForum.com and served on the STS Adult Cardiac Surgery Database Taskforce. He assisted the Kansas Insurance Department's Affordable Care Act initiatives and wrote the business plan for the Kansas Health Cooperative loan (2010 and 2012). Ed completed over 25 published articles and posters for scientific sessions. Ed's athletic accomplishments: Nolan High School, varsity basketball, football, and track teams. He won All-District and All-State honors in basketball and his team won All-District in his senior year, 1966. He placed first in the District high jump and high hurdles in 1966. Ed was a runner and competitive athlete most of his adulthood. He completed over 10 "century rides," three five-kilometer swims, multiple half-marathons, two marathons, and 70 triathlons after age 50, including IronMan Louisville in 2007 and 2008. Ed's Key Learnings: be self-made; bring out the best in people; have pure intention; and listen. "With his loving wife and esteemed son, there was nothing in his life wanting."

HUMBACH--William W.,passed away peacefully Thursday, January 23rd. Devoted father, husband of his adored late wife, Millie, doting grandfather. During his thirty five year career at the New York Times he worked as a reporter, as an editor on the National Desk, and assistant to the Executive Editor and Publisher. He was a World War II Navy Veteran. Phi Beta Kappa, Summa cum laude graduate from New York University. Boston Red Sox fan and expert crossword puzzle solver (always done in ink.) A lover of books and music. Famous for his puns and unconventional sense of humor and encyclopedic memory. Survivers include daughters Annie and Miriam and grandson Matthew. Family and friends gathering for a tribute in his honor, Sunday, February 9th at the home of the Kessler Family, 38 Russet Lane, Huntington, NY. 12:00pm to 5:00pm.

HEYMAN--Anne. The Officers, Board, and staff of The American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee (JDC) mourn with profound sadness the untimely passing of Anne Heyman, beloved wife of Seth Merrin, and daughter-in-law of longtime JDC Board Member Edward Merrin. An accomplished lawyer and esteemed global philanthropist, Anne was deeply involved in a variety of Jewish and humanitarian causes in North America, Israel, Africa, and the former Soviet Union. As the Founder and Board Chair of the renowned Agahozo-Shalom Youth Village (ASYV) in Rwanda, Anne's boundless generosity, unbridled enthusiasm, and passionate dedication ensured a future for young Rwandans, many of them genocide orphans. We were proud to be her partner in ASYV's formative stages and to continue to support the village with Jewish Service Corps volunteers today. These young Jewish adults like all of us were awed by Anne's extraordinary leadership and the timeless example she set as a global citizen and unparalleled Jewish role model. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Ed and Vivian Merrin; Anne's beloved husband Seth and their children Jenna, Jonathan, and Jason; and to their entire family. May Anne's memory be for a blessing, and may all those whose lives were touched by Anne embrace the principles that guided her life and work: tikkun halev - repairing the heart - and tikkun olam - repairing the world. Penny Blumenstein President Dr. Irving A. Smokler Chairman of the Board Alan H. Gill Chief Executive Officer

JACOBSON--Janet. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Janet Jacobson, beloved daughter of Dr. Julius H. Jacobson and step-daughter of Mrs. Joan L. Jacobson, both dedicated philanthropists who help strengthen the fabric of the New York Jewish community. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Julius and Joan; Janet's husband, James H. Wildman; sisters, Jeannie and Wendy; brother, William; her step-grandchildren; and the entire family. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; John S. Ruskay, Executive VP & CEO

KOVALESKI--Manya. Beloved and cherished wife of Fred, mother of Serge and mother-in-law of Jo, passed away on January 23, 2014. Born in Cairo, Egypt to parents who left Russia during the Bolshevik Revolution, Manya was a true internationalist blessed with extraordinary beauty, grace and a deep sense of compassion. She was a socially sought-after member of every community in which she lived. As part of Cairo's exclusive social milieu in the 1950's, she was often in the company of members of the Royal family, and King Farouk himself often enjoyed greeting her with the few Russian words he knew. Manya was a loving, inspirational mother whose guiding philosophy was that "life is beautiful" and "out of everything bad, comes something good." Educated at the Lycee Francais and English Mission College, she was conversant in six languages: French, English, Russian, Italian, Greek and Arabic. Following her marriage to Fred, this sophisticated and highly intuitive woman played a big role in furthering her husband's career as an international business executive. Over the span of nearly 20 years, his assignments took them to Cairo, Beirut, Khartoum, Yemen, Cape Town and Sydney. During their stay in Khartoum, the Station Chief for the CIA learned that Manya was a polyglot and recruited her to translate the tapes of wire-taps done on the Soviet Embassy. Manya was also witness to two revolutions overthrowing Sudanese governments. In Cape Town, Manya gave birth to her beloved son, Serge, who then spent several of his early years in Sydney. Once again, Manya showed her flair for fashion and was the subject of articles and pictorial features in such publications as Vogue magazine, Women's Wear Daily and the Sydney Morning Herald. Manya also had a talent for interior decorating, creating chic and comfortable homes for her family in the Point Piper section of Sydney and on Manhattan's Park Avenue, where she lived for more than four decades. Manya was a true socialite, hosting lavish dinners for friends and always attracting an eclectic mix of guests. Special among them was Oleg Cassini, the renowned fashion designer who became a life-long friend. Mr. Cassini, recognizing Manya's sense of style, proposed she join him in a new retail venture in which she would be the fashion director. As tempting as it was for Manya, she was a devoted mother to Serge, who was around 10 at the time, and declined the offer. During her many years abroad, Manya enjoyed memberships in a number of exclusive clubs including The Gezira Sporting Club (Cairo), The American University Alumni Club (Beirut), Rondebosch Tennis Club (Cape Town), White City Tennis Club and The American National Club (Sydney). In New York City, she belonged to the dining club, Doubles. Manya was also an extraordinary mother to two other children, from a previous marriage: Claudine, who passed away in 2007, and Pierre, who lives in France.

LAZAR--Eliot. We at NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital are deeply saddened by the passing of our dear friend and beloved colleague Dr. Eliot Lazar. Words cannot fully express our sense of loss and our profound sorrow. Eliot began his brilliant career with us in 2000 as Vice President for Medical Affairs, and at the time of his passing was Senior Vice President and Chief Medical Officer for Quality. His formidable skills shaped our quality and patient safety initiatives and allowed NewYork-Presbyterian to be recognized as a national leader in quality. He leaves a legacy that ensures each patient receives the highest-quality, most compassionate care in the safest environment. An extraordinary leader, clinician, educator, administrator, husband and father, he set an example of integrity, humility, and commitment to excellence. We will always remember him. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Becky, his children, and his entire family. Frank A. Bennack, Jr., Chairman of the Board Steven J. Corwin, MD, CEO Robert E. Kelly, MD, President NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital

HEYMAN--Anne,We mourn the tragic death of Anne Heyman, a leader in the fight against genocide and creator of a powerful program to support genocide orphans in Rwanda. Anne joined forces with American Jewish World Service (AJWS) in the earliest days of the fight against genocide in Darfur, persuading the entire organized American Jewish community to rally against genocide on the National Mall in Washington, DC. Anne's bold brilliance and warm heart will be missed by all of us at AJWS. We send our deepest condolences to the entire Merrin-Heyman family. American Jewish World Service Kathleen B. Levin, Chair of the Board Ruth W. Messinger, President Robert E. Bank, Executive Vice President

IERVOLINO--Thea Petschek, artist and philanthropist, passed away on Friday, January 24, 2014, in Riverdale, New York, at the age of 89. She was preceded in death by her husband Antonio Iervolino, and by her siblings Charles, Max, and Thomas Petschek. A graduate of Vassar College and of Parsons School of Design, Thea was a skilled potter and painter and for many years taught those skills and origami as a volunteer in New York City Public Schools on the lower East Side. She was a generous life-long donor to International House New York where she lived for two years after college. Among other gifts, she donated a music practice room to that institution. She also was an important donor to the Juilliard School of Music where she, along with her siblings and cousins, established the annual Juilliard William Petschek Recital Award in honor of her uncle. She loved all the arts and vigorously supported arts programming on public television Channel 13 and public radio station WQXR. From an early age, she was an avid photographer. Attending the Berlin Olympic Games in 1936 with her father, she took a picture of Jesse Owens receiving the Gold Medal. Six decades later, she presented that historic photograph to the mayor of Atlanta, Georgia, during that city's Olympic Games. She will be fondly remembered by the many people in all walks of life whom she befriended and helped, as well as by her nieces, nephews, grandnieces and grandnephews to whom she was always unfailingly attentive and generous.

REICHMAN--Steven H.,died at his home in Haverford, PA, on January 27 at the age of 70 after suffering complications from a lung infection. Born in Washington Heights and raised in Flushing, Steve graduated from Stuyvesant High and Brooklyn Poly (Polytechnic). A metallurgist by trade, he worked for companies in Utica, NY, Portland, OR, Pittsburgh and Exton, PA, where he recently retired from Timet Corp., a manufacturer of Titanium. Steve was a Renaissance man; his interests were as varied as his travels: golf, food, reading, music, hiking. But most of all, he enjoyed sharing life with his life partner and soul-mate, Susan Schweitzer. Besides Susan, he is survived by a son, Aaron, a brother, James, and three grandchildren. Two other sons, Jeremy and Alexander, pre-deceased him. Services were private.

HEYMAN--Anne. The Agahozo-Shalom Youth Village (ASYV) and its Board, staff, students and network of advisors in the United States, Israel and Rwanda mourn the passing of our founder, dear friend and inspiration, Anne Heyman. We extend our deepest sympathies to her husband, Seth Merrin; their three children, Jason, Jenna, and Jonathan; her entire immediate and extended family; and her 750 "grandchildren" in Rwanda. Her intelligence, drive, and compassion for vulnerable youth will be an inspiration for generations. Board of Directors, staff and students

JACOBSONJanet C.,age 57, peacefully, on January 23rd. Loving wife, daughter, sister, aunt, stepmother, grand-stepmother, and friend to legions. A multi-lingual expert in international film finance known for her keen trend spotting, negotiation skills, irreverence, wit, style, and indomitable spirit, beating the odds with a rare form of cancer that ultimately claimed her life. She never let her illness define her; rather she used it to transform her life and live it to the fullest. She moved fast, enjoying novelty and challenge. Born in New York City and raised in Burlington Vermont and Westchester County, she graduated Cornell University (Phi Beta Kappa) and Columbia Law School (Harlan Stone Fiske Scholar). She began her career as an Assistant District Attorney in the New York County office of Robert Morgenthau, moving next to the law firm of Frankfurt, Garbus, Klein & Selz where she began her specialization in entertainment law. Subsequently she was in-house counsel at Balthazar Pictures, then Scala Productions Ltd., establishing herself in European film acquisition, development, and related activities involving parties such as Miramax and Canal Plus. The bulk of her career was spent at Hallmark Entertainment/RHI Entertainment structuring production finance, tax incentives and co-production arrangements and liaison work with producers, distributors and broadcasters in the television industry. During this period she pioneered film production finance in Hungary and other Eastern European countries. Ultimately she founded Film Borders, Inc., a legal and financial consulting firm for film and television clients. She is survived by her husband, James H. Wildman, former managing partner of the King & Spalding law firm and founding partner of its New York City office; her father and step-mother, Dr. Julius H. and Mrs. Joan L. Jacobson, her sisters, Jeannie, and Wendy (Andrew H. Miller), her brother, William (Beth R. Jacobson), nieces, Annalise and Sara, nephews, Max and Jackson Miller, step-sons, James Wildman, Jr. (Suby), and Andrew Wildman (Caroline), and step-grandchildren, Wake, Henry, Eli, Ellie, Hall, and Tate. Her mother, Beverly Jacobson, pre-deceased her in 2009, and her youngest brother, David, in 2003. Friends may call Tuesday, February 4 from 3-8pm at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St. Funeral will be private with memorial service in the spring. In lieu of flowers, donations in Janet's memory to Dana-Farber Cancer Institute (www.dfci.org/give), or Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center (https://www. mskcc.org/giving/giftintro. html)

LEMLE--Gertrude B.,died peacefully at home on January 28th at age 92. Beloved wife of the late Leo. Loving and proud mother of Laura and Robert. Dear mother-in-law of Roni. Devoted grandmother of Zach, Joanna, Ariel, David and Noah.

MARBACH--Diane, 91, passed peacefully on January 17, 2014. She will forever be remembered for her loving and vivacious personality, her generosity, and tireless dedication to her "woman-owned" business she pioneered in the food industry. Your loving family, Eddie, Danielle, Rebecca, Andrew, Sarah, and Liz.

HERTZOG--Arlene, of Teaneck, NJ, passed away at age 91 on January 30, 2014. She is survived by her son, David; her daughter-in-laws, Rosalind and Karen; her grandchildren, Adam and Lauren; and her great-grandchildren, Chloe, Emily and Lily. Contributions, in lieu of flowers, may be made to the Harold Hertzog Scholarship at the University of Pennsylvania, 3615 Market Street, Philadelphia, PA 19104, Attention: Jean-Marie Kneeley.

KNUTH--Charles Joseph, a chemical engineer who worked on the Manhattan Project, then as a research chemist for Pfizer, Inc., until he became Director of Patents for Pfizer International, died at his home in Manhasset Long Island on January 5. He was 89. The son of a mailman, Dr. Knuth was born in Queens in 1924. He attended Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute (now the Polytechnic Institute of New York University), from which he was drafted after receiving his Bachelor's Degree, returning for his doctorate after World War II. Sent to army specialized training at Ohio State University, he was suddenly, and with some secrecy, transferred to Oak Ridge, Tennessee, then to Los Alamos, New Mexico, to work on purifying enriched fissionable materials for the atomic bomb. While completing his doctoral research, Knuth was supported by a Pfizer fellowship, and upon graduation, he joined their research division in Brooklyn. His many discoveries were patented by Pfizer, and, after he had repeatedly rewritten the draft applications prepared by the patent specialists, he was offered a position in the Legal Division, eventually becoming Director of Patents. Patent work gradually became a job not of writing but of testifying at infringement cases: Knuth took well to the role of expert witness and helped Pfizer to win considerable infringement damages. But the hectic challenges of constant litigation prompted Knuth to take early retirement in 1987, when he took up a new career as a book-discussion leader at the Manhasset Public Library. These annual courses were extremely popular: they went on for eighteen years. Charles took great pains in selecting each year's "syllabus" and was able to enjoy literature, really his first love, in a life that had been dedicated to polymer chemistry and the abstruse byways of patent law. Dr. Knuth was married for 49 years to the former Nancy Addor, who predeceased him in 2001. He is survived by four daughters, Deborah Knuth Klenck of Hamilton, New York; Penelope Knuth of Santiago, Chile; Nancy Thompson of North Bay, Ontario; and Jane Patukas of Lancaster, Pennsylvania, and six grandchildren. The funeral was held January 15 at St. Mary's Manhasset. Memorial donations can be directed either to The Polytechnic Institute of New York (Eleanor Fallon, Dir., Donor Relations, 15 Metro Tech Center, Brooklyn NY 11201; www.poly.edu/giving) or The Manhasset Public Library (Debbie Dellis-Quinn, Program Director, 30 Onderdonk Ave, Manhasset, NY 11030; delldeb@aol.com).

HEMENWAY--Russell D.,died peacefully at home on January 30, 2014. He was 88. Russ Hemenway was, for more than fifty years, a true warrior spirit in American politics, combating the power of the radical right from the days of Joe McCarthy to the contemporary influences of extreme conservatism. From 1966 until his death, he was the National Director of the National Committee for an Effective Congress, founded in 1948 by Eleanor Roosevelt. He was the father of campaign finance disclosure reform in the early 70's. He was born on March 24, 1925, in Leominster, MA, to Bess and Alan E. Hemenway. He graduated from Dartmouth College in 1949 and continued his education at The Institut d'Etudes Politiques in Paris. Hemenway served in the Navy during World War II aboard the heavy cruiser USS Pittsburgh. He married Catherine Casey in Paris in 1951, and was widowed by her in 1999. Their daughter, Anne Hemenway, survives him. He is also survived by a son, Brent G. Hemenway, two grandsons, Alexander and Maverick Douglas, a sister, Joyce H. Brown, a son in law, John H. Wilson, a daughter in law, Christina Morales Hemenway, and five nieces, Elesse T. Brown, Valentine L. Judge, Phoebe Legere, Jane L. Jackson, and Alison L. Fraser. Mr. Hemenway was pre-deceased by his sister, Winifred Ledger and his brother, Richard Hemenway. A service will be held on February 14 at 2pm at St Thomas Church, 1 W 53 St. NYC. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to The NY Public Library. Links to obituaries can be found at: www.dapsonchestney.com

PRICKETT--William, an attorney and longtime resident of Wilmington, DE, died on January 30, 2014, at age 88. He is survived by his wife of 20 years, Caroline Johnstone duPont Prickett. His older sister, Elise Prickett Deans, and his younger brother, Harry deBoeck Prickett, predeceased him. He is survived by his three children, William Loening Prickett, Priscilla Prickett Kraft and Dr. Annie Prickett Renzetti, and his five grandchildren. Before retiring in 2008, he was Prickett Jones & Elliott's senior member. The firm was founded in 1888 by his grandfather. He received a BA from Princeton University and his LL.B. from Harvard Law School in 1954. He served in the US Navy during WWII and the US Marine Corps in Korea. Among his many legal successes, he was the prevailing lead counsel in several landmark corporate cases, including Weinberger vs. UOP, Smith vs. Van Gorkom, and In re Tri-Star Pictures, Inc. Litigation. He was a founding member of the Brandywine River Museum, and was the first President of the Wilmington, DE Grand Opera House. A Memorial Service will be held on Saturday, March 1st at 11:00am at the Lower Brandywine Presbyterian Church, in Centerville, DE. For online condolences and full obituary, please visit Chandler Funeral Homes & Crematory chandlerfuneralhome.com 302.478.7100

MILLON--Dr. Theodore, Leading Personality Theorist and psychologist, died on January 29, 2014, at his home in Greenville Township, NY, after a remarkable life. Dr. Millon was the author of over 25 books and the developer of numerous highly regarded diagnostic inventories including the MCMI. He was a key member of the DSM-III task force and of the DSM-IV's workgroup on personality disorders. Dr. Millon was a Senior Scientific Scholar Emeritus at the Institute for Advanced Studies in Personality and Psychopathology, having served previously over a fifty year sequence of professorial appointments at Lehigh, University of Illinois, University of Miami and Harvard. He received over twenty lifetime achievement awards, including APF's Gold Medal for Lifetime Achievement in Applied Research, APA's Distinguished Award for Applied Psychological Science, as well as its 2000 Presidential Citation. Ted was born in Manhattan on August 18, 1928 to Abner and Mollie (Gorkowitz) Millon. He was raised in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn where he graduated from Lafayette High School in 1945. He earned his BA from the City College of New York '49 and his PhD from the University of Connecticut '52 and later received an Honorary Doctorate from the Free University of Brussels '94. He had a keen interest in art and was a man of many talents and interests. He loved acting and singing and was a painter, sculptor and collector of art. Dr. Millon was a classical music aficionado, followed professional sports and studied physics as a hobby. In 1952 he married Renee Baratz. Although he was an admirable scholar, his role as a husband, father and grandfather was just as important to him. He was a kind, loving and generous man who cared deeply for his family. He is predeceased by his parents. In addition to his wife, he is survived by his children, Diane Bobb (Allen) of Greenville, NY; Dr. Carrie Millon of Pinecrest, FL; Andy Millon of Brooklyn, NY; Adrienne Hemsley (Martin) of White Plains, NY; a niece Linda Shultz (David), a nephew David Grabel, his grandchildren, Alyssa Boice (Rory), Katherine Sinsabaugh (Joseph), Molly Niedbala, Olivia Niedbala, Elizabeth Levin, Matthew Hemsley, Annie Hemsley, William Hemsley and five great-grandchildren. He will not only be missed by his family, but by the many colleagues and students whose lives he influenced. His legacy was far reaching and will carry on. The family would also like to thank his caregivers, Leila Agustin and Elizabeth Grennille, for extending his life and bringing him great comfort. Services will be held at Temple Sinai, 75 Highland Ave, Middletown, NY; on Sunday, February 2nd at 1pm. In lieu of flowers, those wishing to make a donation may do so to the Central Park Conservancy, Attn: Adopt-A-Bench, 14 East 60th Street, New York, NY 10022. Please write "Theodore Millon Bench" in the memo line. Or call 212-310-6617.

GINSBURG--Carolyn, passed away on January 24th at the age of 68. She is survived by her loving husband Allan, who always called Carolyn "the love of his life." This Valentine's Day would have marked their 45th wedding anniversary. She also leaves behind five children, Stephanie, Kenny (Gail), Jeffrey (Melissa), Greg (Zora), and Ashley; and six grandchildren, Ryan, Eric, Mitchell, Heather, Jared and Isabel Rose. An accomplished model, ever generous and philanthropic, she will be remembered as a beautiful woman, both inside and out. Carolyn had a passionate spirit, a heart of gold, and an unconditional love for her family and friends. She will be truly missed by all.

HART--Margo Waldron, of Montrose, NY and formerly of Irvington, NY, died on January 15, 2014. She was born on December 1, 1950 in Portland, OR to Jerome and Agnes Waldron. A woman of exceptional intellectual curiosity, she graduated from Oregon State University with a BA in Slavic Studies. She later received a Masters in History and MBA from the University of Virginia and a Masters of Library Science from Columbia University. Not surprisingly, her professional career was robust and far-ranging. At different times in her life, Margo worked as a licensed real estate broker, marketing director at a publishing firm, admissions officer, corporate trainer, research librarian, consultant, communications director, and talent manager at an investment bank. She loved Broadway, reading, "Star Trek" and singing. She leaves behind a devoted son, Josh, and a brother, Howard. Donations in Margo's memory should be sent to: Reading Is Fundamental, PO Box 33728, Washington DC 20033.

BRONSTEEN--Earl, 88, Boca Raton, FL.,died peacefully at his home with the love of his life, Judith, at his side. Earl's life was one of integrity, love, creativity and accomplishment. He was a Yale graduate, where he was a star athlete. He served in WWII. He was the CFO for a public company. He loved his three sons, their wives, nine grandchildren, brother and family. Over the past 30 years Earl emerged as a prolific artist and writer. His irreverent perspective and famously dry humor interpreted the human experience in an approachable yet thought provoking manner. We will miss him.

DUBOFSKY--Robert. January 31, 2014 at the age of 74. Our friend and esteemed colleague Bob will be greatly missed by all of us who had the honor of knowing him. Bob was extremely successful in life and as smart as they come, hardworking and charismatic. Our loving sympathy goes out to his wife Betsy, his children Ned and Nancy and their spouses Lyndsay and Stephen. Bob also leaves behind four beautiful grandchildren, Casey, Charlie, Michael and Matthew who were the light of his life. All of the members of our families are devastated by this loss. With profound sadness, The Blumencranz and Wilkins Families

DUBOFSKY--Robert L.,The Board of Governors and the Members of Glen Oaks Club express our deepest sorrow at the passing of Robert, our esteemed member of 54 years and past member of the Board of Governors and extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife, Betsy and his entire family. Board of Governors Michael Mann, President

DUBOFSKY--Robert, Our family is heartbroken by the sudden loss of Bob, our dear friend for over 60 years. Our families' love and friendship has spanned four generations. Our lives will never be the same without him. Our deepest, heartfelt condolences to Betsy, Ned, Lindsay, Nancy, Stephen, Casey, Charlie, Matthew and Michael. Lorraine Sosnow-Aaron, Horowitz and Beer Families

CAPPA--Linda, passed away suddenly on January 29, 2014 after battling a rare disease. She was 76 years old. Linda was a loving wife to Arthur and devoted mother to James, Susan, and daughter-in-law Ellen. She was also a beloved grandmother to Justin and Emily, brother to Burt, sister-in-law, aunt and cousin. Linda retired with the NYC Board of Education as a teacher and then worked as an administrator in special education. The family intends to have a memorial service and celebration of her extraordinary life, date to be determined.

BERGMANN--Martin. The Contemporary Freudian Track of The New York University Postdoctoral Program in Psychoanalysis mourns the loss of Professor Martin Bergmann, one of the leading scholars and practitioners in the field of psychoanalysis, beloved colleague, mentor, teacher and friend. We extend deepest sympathies to his wife, Maria Bergmann, son, Michael Bergmann and his grandson. Professor Bergmann died on January 22, 2014, just before his 101st birthday. Until the end, he kept a full schedule of students, patients, supervisees and writing. We witnessed his awe inspiring, creative odyssey through the latter part of his life. In addition to his treatment of patients and his teaching, especially of Freud, his prodigious contributions to the field included the areas of The History of Psychoanalysis, Nazism, Romantic Love, The Oedipus Complex, Psychoanalysis in Old Age and Shakespeare. Martin was passionate about teaching, independent and original thinking, new ideas and the uniqueness of each patient. He eschewed orthodoxy and fanaticism. He combined a formidable intellect with a sense of personal importance to patients and students. He was instrumental in preserving Freud's legacy but did so in a critical and intimate way. Martin was born in Prague, Czechoslovakia on February 15, 1913. He moved to Palestine when he was seven years old where his father, Hugo Bergmann became a world renowned scholar at the Hebrew University. He emigrated to the United States to study genetics. There he became interested in psychology. He served as a psychologist in the U.S. army and came to New York to pursue psychoanalysis. A memorial service will be held in the spring. Therese Rosenblatt, PhD For the Contemporary Freudian Track NYU Postdoctoral Program in Psychoanalysis

CHEN--Chun S.,MD, died after complex illness at Cornell Medical Center on January 28, 20l4. He was a beloved husband, son, brother and uncle. Dr. Chen was a renowned scholar, teacher, and friend to all who knew him. Dr Chen was widely published in his academic field. He was an assistant professor of neurosurgery at the Mount Sinai Medical Center, and an invited lecturer in his field throughout the world. Dr. Chen was an indefatigable surgeon and physician who was educated in Brazil and the United States. Those of us who knew him in and out of the Mount Sinai Medical Center consider ourselves better for the experience. Rebecca Nachamie, MD

ELKIND-VAN GELDER--Margaret, died of cancer on January 30, 2014 at the age of 52. Beloved wife of Todd Van Gelder, adoring mother to Eric and Will Van Gelder and loving sister to Elisabeth and Sam Elkind, she was predeceased by her parents, Charlotte and Morton Digby Elkind. Born in Brooklyn, NY, she attended Packer, Spence, Wesleyan and Bank Street and had various jobs in the education field before moving to Brookeville, MD where her primary focus was her family and her many friends from every stage of her life. Memorial: Saturday, February 15th at noon, The Inn at Brookeville Farms, 19501 Georgia Ave., Brookeville, MD.

FELDMAN--Eugene, 86, died peacefully at home in Brooklyn, January 31; beloved husband of 58 years of Anne, devoted father to Simon, Nancy and Josh (Nancy), cherished grandfather of Howie, Rachel, Jacob, Clara and Rose. Services at Temple Beth Elohim, 145 8th Ave., Monday, February 3rd, at 10am.

DAVEY--Ian, was born in Woking, England on April 30, 1945 to Edward and Jessie Davey. He began his insurance industry career as a teenager at Lloyd's of London. In 1973, he came to New York intending to spend two years, but this became his home. He passed away on January 27, 2014 from heart disease. He is survived by his wife Diane, and three children, Ian and his wife Kimberly, Clarice, Peter, granddaughter Eva, and sister, Janet Tyler. His children were the most important part of his life. Aside from a successful career in business, he was passionately devoted to the Chelsea Football Club, equestrian show-jumping, cycling and running. Ian loved animals, especially his dogs. The Memorial Service will be held on Friday, February 7th, at 3:00pm at St. Andrews Episcopal Church, 419 South St., New Providence, NJ. Memorial contributions can be made to the American Heart Association.

DUBOFSKY--Robert, High Ridge Country Club acknowledges with sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Robert Dubofsky. We extend our deepest sympathy to his beloved wife, Betsy, and their family. Stuart Albrecht, President Robert D. Lang, Secretary

ERCKLENTZ--Enno W.,Jr., died peacefully in the presence of his immediate and loving family on January 24, 2014 after a short illness and just three days shy of his 83rd birthday. The son of Enno and Hildegarde Ercklentz, who came to this country in the 1920's, Enno was born in New York City. At the age of 10, he found himself stranded with his parents and siblings in Japan at the outbreak of WWII, and attended St. Joseph's College in Yokohama. In 1947, the family was repatriated to Germany, where, he served as a civilian in the US Army in Frankfurt, Germany. In 1950 they returned to New York City, where Enno graduated in 1951 from the Collegiate School and in 1954 with a Bachelor of Arts from Columbia University. He then went on to earn a law degree from Harvard Law School in 1957. A highly regarded international corporate lawyer, Enno maintained an active legal practice up until his death. His acclaimed two-volume study entitled "Modern German Corporate Law," is still in use as a reference work. Enno served for many years as the Chairman of the Deutsche Schule in White Plains, NY. For his contributions to the school, he was awarded the Cross of the Order of Merit by the Federal Republic of Germany. A devout Catholic, he was honored to become a part of the Order of the Teutonic Knights. An exceptional human being, he was charming, urbane, a marvelous conversationalist and a true gentleman. Anyone who met Enno fell in love with his contagious smile and laughter. His kind and polite manner belied a sharp and witty intellect. His knowledge and passion for music, history, geography and travel was encyclopedic, the result of a voracious reading habit and a brilliant mind. He was and always will be remembered as someone special. Enno was a devoted father to his two lovely and loyal daughters, Cornelia Ercklentz and Stephanie Ercklentz Coleman, and a doting and proud grandfather "Opi" to Devon, Blake and Kendall Coleman, to whom he affectionately referred as his "little pups." He is survived by his daughters and grandchildren, his son-in-law, Chase Coleman, his sister Hildegarde Mahoney, his brother and sister-in-law, Alexander and Margild Ercklentz, his former wife and best friend Mai Hallingby Harrison, his sister-in-law, Eevi Truumees, as well as seven nieces and nephews. There will be a private funeral mass for the immediate family and a celebration of his life is planned for the Spring. The Family requests that in lieu of flowers, donations in memory of Enno W. Ercklentz, Jr. may be mailed to: the Philharmonic Symphony Society of New York, c/o New York Philharmonic, Avery Fisher Hall, 10 Lincoln Center Plaza, New York, NY 10023 or the Bladder Cancer Advocacy Network, 4915 St. Elmo Avenue, Suite 202, Bethesda, Maryland 20814.

FOLTZ--Richard, song writer and musician, stage manager, actor, printer, Reevaluation Counseling teacher/ leader/ family worker and dear friend died January 25 at the Jewish Home, Manhattan. Always the gentle southerner, Richard was born rural, May 28, 1942, in Woodstock, Virginia and moved to New York in 1966. Richard involved himself in many aspects of the theater and was proud to have worked with the original NYC production of Boys in the Band in 1968. He was a founding member of the Chelsea Gay Association in 1978 and part of Out Music in the 1980's. In 1996 he cooperatively created and produced the CD "Richard Foltz, A Songwriter's Christmas", a collection of his original Christmas songs or as he described it "New songs for the old holiday." Richard is survived in the South by his loving sister and brother-in-law, Barbara and Mike Woods; niece Abbey Woods Stoddard; his brother, Gary Foltz; and his three nephews, grandnieces and nephews and many cousins. He is tenderly remembered by his partner, Eric Canepa and a wide NYC community of beloved friends, co-counselors and professional associates. He was buried January 31 in the Foltz family plot in Woodstock. A future NYC memorial gathering is planned. For information, contact Frank at frankire@aol.com or Diane at dbsonde@earthlink.net.

BRAVIN--Ira, age 83, passed away in his home on January 24th. Ira was the founder, publisher and writer of the New York Connection, a trade publication to the textile industry. After working in marketing at WWD, Ira and his wife embarked on a publication of their own, believing that present day trade publications had limitations. His wish was to enhance communication between the textile and manufacturing worlds. His goal was to encourage daring business people with common interests and problems, to find one another. This innovative magazine, with its unique textile registry, published for 25 years. Ira's family remembers his warmth towards all he knew; his affection for his Brooklyn days; his keen interest in General Semantics; his Fire Island summers; his piano playing; his dancing; his love of traveling to France with his wife; and above all his great sense of humor. He is survived by his wife Jean, daughter Karin, and grandchildren Charlotte and Jackson. He will be sorely missed. A memorial will be planned for the spring.

ACKERBERG--Robert C. The family of Robert C. Ackerberg sadly announces his passing on January 27, 2014. He was 79. Bob was, for almost 30 years, a Professor at Polytechnic Institute of New York and was the co-author of an article cited many times over for its introduction of a mathematical phenomenon that came to be known as Ackerberg - O'Malley resonance. A flutist, Bob co-founded the Massapequa Philharmonic Orchestra in 1983 and was its President from its inception until his passing. He will be remembered for his curiosity, humor and devotion to his family. Bob is survived by his long-time companion of 28 years, Cecele Miller; his children Daniel Ackerberg and Anna Garsten; his son-in-law Bryan Garsten; his grandchildren, David and Max Garsten, Marco Angelucci-Ackerberg and Stephanie and Michael Dalton; his stepchildren Dena Miller and Ellen and Bob Dalton; and his former wife, Sylvia Lipnick. Donations in memory of Robert C. Ackerberg can be made to the Massapequa Philharmonic Orchestra at PO Box 52, Massapequa Park, NY 11762-0052.
DUBOFSKY--Robert, Dear Betsy, Ned and Nancy, there was no one like Bob. His friendship and loyalty were unbounding. Joanne Bross

FERRERA--Stephen, Grammy-award winning record producer. Survived by his loving wife Camilla, children Grace Sophia and Guy Alexander. Parents Gaetano and Olga Ferrera, sisters Jayne Schmitz and Deborah Baldwin. A Memorial service will be Monday, February 3rd, 4pm at "The Riverside," 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to: Lung Cancer Research at MSKCC, 300 East 66th St., NYC 10065.

DUBOFSKY--Robert L.,age 74, passed away suddenly on January 31, 2014. We are deeply saddened by the passing of our hero. Words cannot fully express our sense of deep loss, profound grief, or how much he is missed by his family. We are extremely grateful for the very special bond we shared and consider it a blessing to have had his guidance, wisdom and love. He touched so many people's lives with his compassionate generosity, magnanimous heart and larger than life smile. Graduated from Boston University with a Bachelors of Business degree and served as a trustee for several years. Had an illustrious career in the insurance industry. Enjoyed spending time with family and friends in Great Neck, Aspen and Palm Beach. Loving husband to Betsy, devoted father to Ned (Lindsay), and Nancy (Stephen), adoring grandfather to Matthew, Michael, Casey and Charlie, and loving brother to Simmy (Robert). Services 11am Monday at Temple Israel of Great Neck, 108 Old Mill Road.

DUBOFSKY--Robert, one of our oldest and dearest friends, left us on January 31, 2014. He was a true gentleman and a genuine human being. We cherish all the years of laughs, fun and great experiences our two families had together. Our deepest condolences to Betsy, Nancy, Ned and all the family. Marion, Jerry, Jodi and Andrew Sussman
FAWCETT--John R.,77, died January 22, 2014. Survived by life partner, Helen-Ann Comstock, children Roger, Scott, Travis and Nancy Pietrorazio, two grandchildren, brother.

BROEKSMIT--William Shaw, 58, died January 26 in London. He is survived by his loving wife of nearly 30 years, Alla Broeksmit; his son, Valentin Gregory Broeksmit; two daughters, Alessa Murray Broeksmit and Katherine Shaw Broeksmit; his mother, Jane Broeksmit; his sister, Laura Broeksmit Downing; and brothers Peter, John, Samuel, and Robert Broeksmit. His family and all whose lives he touched will miss him profoundly. Bill was born in 1955 in Chicago, the son of the late Rev. John Shaw Broeksmit, Jr. and Jane Murray Broeksmit. He was raised in Illinois and graduated from Lake Forest Academy in 1973 and from Claremont McKenna College in 1977. He earned an MBA at Northwestern University's Kellogg School of Management in 1982. He started his banking career with Continental Illinois National Bank in Chicago. He held senior positions at Merrill Lynch and Deutsche Bank in New York and London and had recently retired from Deutsche Bank. He was a visionary financial executive and an inspiring mentor, considered to be among the finest minds in the fields of risk and capital management. Those who loved him most will remember him by his devotion to his family, brilliance, humility, eloquence, deep laugh, and love of cooking. Bill had a curiosity about all aspects of life, reading and traveling widely and relishing conversation with family and friends old and new. He was a compass, and his guidance cannot be replaced. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, February 8th, at 3pm at The Brick Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue at 91st Street. Memorials may be given to the National Institute of Mental Health.

DUBOFSKY--Robert, Our deepest sympathy to our dear friend Betsy and her devoted children, Ned and Nancy. The circle of friendship and love we have can never be broken. Nanci, Stuart, Brooke, Emily and Robert
DUBOFSKY--Robert, Bob, your love of life will live on in our hearts. You will be missed today and always. Our deepest sympathy and love to Betsy, Nancy and Ned, and their entire family. Lois and Bob

BODMAN--Elizabeth Sims Calvert, July 14, 1923 - January 19, 2014, died peacefully at Noble Horizons in Salisbury, CT. Elizabeth, known to all as "Bunny," was a Manhattan resident from 1962 to 2012. A fixture on New York's social scene, Bunny was known for her extensive collection of designer hats. Her greatest loves were Paris and a good party. Bunny was a native of Spartanburg, SC. She graduated from the Brownmoor School in Santa Fe, NM. Between 1954 and 1975, Bunny was married to Edward D. Bodman, a Manhattan investment banker and philanthropist. She is survived by her daughter, Beaufort Bodman Butler and three grandchildren. An interment is planned in Spartanburg. In lieu of flowers, gifts may be made to the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

DUBOFSKY--Robert. January 31, 2014. The employees of BWD (Blumencranz, Wilkins and Dubofsky) are stunned and deeply saddened by the loss of our friend and colleague. Bob was a driving force at BWD and will be deeply missed by all. Bob and his son Ned joined BWD more than two decades ago and worked with many of us over the years. We can't imagine BWD without Bob. Our heartfelt sympathy goes out to his wife Betsy, to his son and partner Ned and wife Lyndsay, and all of Bob's family.

MILLER--Herbert Kenneth, April 5th, 1921 - February 1, 2014 died at Kendal House, Sleepy Hollow, New York. Herbert earned his PhD in biochemistry from Columbia University and was a Professor at Manhattan College. He is survived by his wife of 70 years, Audrey Miller; two children, Emily Zeigler of Beaver Creek, Colorado, and Jonathan Miller of Cambridge, Massachusetts; and two adult grandchildren, Abigail Miller of Brooklyn, NY, and Benjamin Miller of Boston, Massachusetts. His family and friends will remember him for his intelligence, sense of humor and charm. Donations in his memory may be sent to Temple Israel of Northern Westchester, 31 Glengary Road, Croton-on-Hudson, NY 10520.

SHORT--Nancy Jean Fulop, 72, On Monday, January 20, 2014, Nancy Jean Fulop Short died unexpectedly at New York Hospital after a long fight with the side effects and complications resulting from the re-emergence of thyroid cancer. Born on January 5, 1942, she was the only child of George Edward Fulop and Elizabeth Helen (Meruse) Fulop. Nancy was raised in Toledo, Ohio, first in its Birmingham neighborhood until her family moved to the Point Place neighborhood in the late 1940s. Eventually, she moved to New York City to practice law and into Lincoln Plaza Tower, an apartment building overlooking Lincoln Center and Central Park, where she lived from 1976 until her death. She was the wife of William P. Short III, whom she married in 1978, and the mother of Bradford W. Short, who was born in 1979. Both survive her. Until she became ill, she was an active member of the Certificate of Appropriateness Committee of Landmark West as well as of her building's co-op board. She was a parishioner of the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, where she also served as a lector. She was especially fond of reading at the Easter Vigil and Christmas Eve Masses. After she retired, she was a student at the New York School of Interior Design ("NYSID"), where she was pursuing an associate degree in interior design. Her hope was to graduate from NYSID and work in the interior design industry. Nancy worked for Bowne & Co. Inc., first as Editor of its Legal Publishing Division from 1997 to early 2003 and then as Editor of Bowne's securities compliance resource, SecuritiesConnect, from 2003 to late 2005. Before working at Bowne, she was Publications Manager of securities publications at Matthew Bender. Nancy had more than 30 years experience in securities law. She practiced as a corporate and securities attorney in New York for ten years at Skadden, Burns Summit and Warshaw Burstein and as an assistant professor of corporate finance and securities law at Rutgers School of Law-Camden for four years. She was awarded a J.D. degree from The University of Toledo - College of Law, where she was first in her class, and an LL.M. degree from Yale Law School. She was a graduate of St. Ursula Academy and Mary Manse College, both located in Toledo. She was valedictorian of her class at St. Ursula and was awarded the Bishop's Cross. At Mary Manse College, she graduated summa cum laude. Nancy taught high school art as well as English literature in the Toledo school system before starting her legal career. There will be a viewing on Monday, February 3, 2014 from 2:00-5:00pm followed by an evening viewing from 7:00-9:00pm at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, at 81st and Madison Avenue, New York, New York. A funeral mass will be held at noon, Tuesday, February 4, 2014, at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola at 84th and Park Avenue, New York, New York. Following the service, interment will be at (First) Calvary Cemetery, Queens, New York. In lieu of flowers, friends are encouraged to make memorial contributions to Celiac Disease Center at Columbia University or NYSID, where an academic prize will be created for lawyers who leave the legal profession to pursue studies in interior design. Additional information on each program may be obtained by e-mailing cb2280@columbia.edu or sfingleton@nysid.edu, respectively, using Nancy Short in the subject line.

HEYMAN--Anne. The Officers, Board, and staff of The American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee (JDC) mourn with profound sadness the untimely passing of Anne Heyman, beloved wife of Seth Merrin, and daughter-in-law of longtime JDC Board Member Edward Merrin. An accomplished lawyer and esteemed global philanthropist, Anne was deeply involved in a variety of Jewish and humanitarian causes in North America, Israel, Africa, and the former Soviet Union. As the Founder and Board Chair of the renowned Agahozo-Shalom Youth Village (ASYV) in Rwanda, Anne's boundless generosity, unbridled enthusiasm, and passionate dedication ensured a future for young Rwandans, many of them genocide orphans. We were proud to be her partner in ASYV's formative stages and to continue to support the village with Jewish Service Corps volunteers today. These young Jewish adults like all of us were awed by Anne's extraordinary leadership and the timeless example she set as a global citizen and unparalleled Jewish role model. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Ed and Vivian Merrin; Anne's beloved husband Seth and their children Jenna, Jonathan, and Jason; and to their entire family. May Anne's memory be for a blessing, and may all those whose lives were touched by Anne embrace the principles that guided her life and work: tikkun halev - repairing the heart - and tikkun olam - repairing the world. Penny Blumenstein President Dr. Irving A. Smokler Chairman of the Board Alan H. Gill Chief Executive Officer

HEYMAN--Anne, a wife, mother, philanthropist and social justice activist, died Friday at the age of 52. The cause was from complications sustained from a horse riding accident during a jumping competition at the Palm Beach International Equestrian Center in the town of Wellington. Born in South Africa to Sydney and Hermia Heyman, Anne Heyman was the second of four children and raised in Capetown. A born Zionist, athlete and go-getter from an early age, Anne was involved in the Jewish Zionist Youth Movement Habonim and just about every sport offered at her school. One day she picked up a table tennis paddle to learn to play and the next year she became the champion. This was an early indication of the extraordinary woman she would become. Her family moved to America when she was 15 and she immediately became active in Young Judaea. Through it, she participated in a year-long trip to Israel after High School. During the second week of the program, she met Seth Merrin, the man who would become her husband. Following the year in Israel, Anne returned to the United States where she attended and graduated from the University of Pennsylvania in 1982. After another year in Israel, Anne returned to the US to attend George Washington Law School where she became editor of the Law Review. In 1984 she transferred to Columbia Law School and graduated in 1985. Anne began her career shortly after as a corporate lawyer at Kronish Lieb Weiner and Hellman. Two years later she became an Assistant District Attorney in Manhattan, prosecuting white-collar crime. Seth and Anne marriedon August 17, 1986. They had three beautiful children - Jason Liav, Jenna Chen and Jonathan Gavriel. After Jonathan was born in 1994, Anne left her job as a lawyer to devote her time to her family. As a full time mother, Anne exposed her kids to every museum, concert and activity throughout New York City where they lived. The family also traveled the world in the summer where Anne would create activity books for the kids describing the history of the location with fun facts contained in coloring pages, word scrambles and crossword puzzles. Anne and Seth's connection to Israel remained strong and they raised their children with Hebrew as their first language, requiring Anne's parents to take Hebrew lessons so that they could communicate with their grandchildren. It was while at home with the kids that Anne began her next career as an activist, a philanthropist, and a light unto nations. As with everything Anne did, she did it with incredible passion and involved her entire family. Anne became involved in Dorot, a Manhattan based organization that mobilizes thousands of volunteers to provide food, service, and companionship to the elderly. In a short time, Anne joined the board and became its chairman. Anne also worked with Rabbi Jeff Summit at Tufts University Hillel to create an ongoing lecture series called "Moral Voices" that invites college youth to get involved and take action against social injustices and moral causes around the world. The program has since been expanded to other campuses. It was during the first year of the program in 2005 where the featured speaker was a famous genocide survivor. During this event Anne began to understand the severity of the orphan problem created by the Rwandan genocide in 1994 and was inspired to take action. Anne connected the challenge to the similar one Israel faced following the second World War. After the Holocaust, Israel created youth villages that housed, fed, clothed, and educated orphans in order to recreate a family environment of love and safety to help heal. Anne's vision was to adopt the "youth village" model and bring it to Rwanda. Not knowing anyone in Rwanda or anything about the country in no way deterred Anne. What she didn't know she learned, whom she had to know, she met. And what resulted would change the world. Anne raised millions of dollars and recruited an international team from Rwanda, Israel and the United States which included a partnership with Chaim Peri and Yemin Orde, a youth village near Haifa, to make her vision a reality. In August 2007, Anne broke ground for The Agahozo-Shalom Youth Village and in 2008, the village officially opened its doors to its first class of 125 students. Named by Anne's daughter Jenna, "Agahozo" is the Kinyarwanda word meaning "a place where tears are dried" and Shalom is the Hebrew word for peace. Students of the village are provided with new family structures, complete with resident "House Mothers, Brothers and Sisters." They are also given a world class education and are introduced to extracurricular activities including art, music, and sports. As part of their education, Anne made sure each child was taught the value of "Tikun Olam" the obligation every person has to try and repair the world and students find ways to contribute to the greater community on a weekly basis. Among the students, Anne was affectionately known as "mom" or "grandmother." Anne believed in transformation, and often reminded the students that "if you see far, you will go far." Each student knew that the future of Rwanda was on their shoulders, that they were being trained to be the country's future leaders, its greatest hope and each student rose to the challenge. By the time the first class graduated in 2013, the village was home to 500 students. Anne's efforts have been recognized globally.

KRAKOWSKI--Elli, Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of our devoted member and Sisterhood Trustee Elli Krakowski, matriarch of the family, who with her beloved husband, Trustee Israel Krakowski, of blessed memory, instilled a love of Torah, Israel and remembrance of the Shoah into the hearts of their children, Harry (Andrea) Krakowski and Lili Stawski, our devoted members. Sincere condolences to them, grandchildren Ariella, Jay, Ilana, Rachel, Sarah, Sophie and Leah, and sister Shirley. May they find comfort among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Herman Hochberg, President

DUBOFSKY--Robert L.,age 74, passed away suddenly on January 31, 2014. We are deeply saddened by the passing of our hero. Words cannot fully express our sense of deep loss, profound grief, or how much he is missed by his family. We are extremely grateful for the very special bond we shared and consider it a blessing to have had his guidance, wisdom and love. He touched so many people's lives with his compassionate generosity, magnanimous heart and larger than life smile. Graduated from Boston University with a Bachelors of Business degree and served as a trustee for several years. Had an illustrious career in the insurance industry. Enjoyed spending time with family and friends in Great Neck, Aspen and Palm Beach. Loving husband to Betsy, devoted father to Ned (Lindsay), and Nancy (Stephen), adoring grandfather to Matthew, Michael, Casey and Charlie, and loving brother to Simmy (Robert). Services 11am Monday at Temple Israel of Great Neck, 108 Old Mill Road.

HEYMAN--Anne, a wife, mother, philanthropist and social justice activist, died Friday at the age of 52. The cause was from complications sustained from a horse riding accident during a jumping competition at the Palm Beach International Equestrian Center in the town of Wellington. Anne is survived by her devoted husband Seth, her loving children Jason, Jenna, and Jonathan, her adoring parents Sydney and Hermia Heyman, her siblings Justin, Dan, and Lauren, her cat Mal, her dog Chewy, her horses Fandango, Alex, and Gillie, and her 750 "grandchildren" in Rwanda. We have lost an incredible daughter, wife, mother, and humanitarian hero. The funeral for Anne Heyman has been scheduled for Monday, February 3rd at 12 noon at B'nai Jeshurun, 257 West 88th Street (between Broadway and West End Avenue). Afterward, the graveside ceremony will be held at Sharon Gardens Cemetery, 273 Lakeview Avenue, Valhalla, NY 10595. The family will be sitting Shiva at the Merrin home located at 155 West 70th St, New York, NY, Apt. 16A during the following times: Monday 6 - 8pm, Tuesday 12 - 3pm, 5-8pm, Wednesday 12 - 3pm, 5-8pm, Thursday 12 - 3pm, 5-8pm, Friday 12 - 3pm. Prayer services are as follows: Shachris (morning) Minchah/Maariv (afternoon/evening) Tuesday 7:30am, 5:00pm, Wednesday 7:30am, 5:00pm. In lieu of flowers, it is the family's wishes that donations be made to Anne's life changing project - the Agahozo-Shaom Youth Village (ASYV).
DUBOFSKY--Robert, We offer our deepest condolences to his beloved wife Betsy, his children Ned and Nancy and the entire Dubofsky family. Ornella and Bob

DUBOFSKY--Robert L.,It is difficult to think of our world without our wonderful brother, brother-in-law, uncle and great-uncle. He will always be in our hearts. Simmy and Robert Atkins Elizabeth Atkins and Samuel Chiche Emily and Jeffrey Rosenfeld

DUBOFSKY--Robert. We are devastated and saddened by Bob's sudden passing. We send our deepest condolences to Betsy, Ned, Lindsey, Nancy, Stephen the grandchildren and to Simmy and Robert. We will always remember Bob as a warm, fun-loving family man, and true friend, and he will be in our hearts forever. The Granoff Family
DUBOFSKY--Robert, We mourn the sudden passing of Bob. Bob was a dear friend and mentor. He touched the lives of so many. Our deepest sympathy to Betsy, Ned and Nancy. Michael Finkelstein and Family

DUBOFSKY--Robert L. "Duby", When I was one year old my family moved to Great Neck and there You were in the house across the street. We then became close friends for Seventy-four years. We shared many experiences together which included our birthday lunches for the last fifty years. You will remain in my heart forever. Bob Weiss

BROEKSMIT--William Shaw, 58, died January 26 in London. He is survived by his loving wife of nearly 30 years, Alla Broeksmit; his son, Valentin Gregory Broeksmit; two daughters, Alessa Murray Broeksmit and Katherine Shaw Broeksmit; his mother, Jane Broeksmit; his sister, Laura Broeksmit Downing; and brothers Peter, John, Samuel, and Robert Broeksmit. His family and all whose lives he touched will miss him profoundly. Bill was born in 1955 in Chicago, the son of the late Rev. John Shaw Broeksmit, Jr. and Jane Murray Broeksmit. He was raised in Illinois and graduated from Lake Forest Academy in 1973 and from Claremont McKenna College in 1977. He earned an MBA at Northwestern University's Kellogg School of Management in 1982. He started his banking career with Continental Illinois National Bank in Chicago. He held senior positions at Merrill Lynch and Deutsche Bank in New York and London and had recently retired from Deutsche Bank. He was a visionary financial executive and an inspiring mentor, considered to be among the finest minds in the fields of risk and capital management. Those who loved him most will remember him by his devotion to his family, brilliance, humility, eloquence, deep laugh, and love of cooking. Bill had a curiosity about all aspects of life, reading and traveling widely and relishing conversation with family and friends old and new. He was a compass, and his guidance cannot be replaced. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, February 8th, at 3pm at The Brick Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue at 91st Street. Memorials may be given to the National Institute of Mental Health.

DUBOFSKY--Robert, Bob - My dear friend for more than 40 years, insurance advisor and business partner. Our monthly lunch dates at S&W- hamburger - 2 glasses of wine and good conversation. Will miss all the great times we shared together but cherish all the wonderful memories. Goodbye my friend. Bob Morrow
DUBOFSKY--Robert. Our hearts are breaking for Betsy and your family. Rest in peace dear friend. Barbara and David

DUBOFSKY--Robert. January 31, 2014. The employees of BWD (Blumencranz, Wilkins and Dubofsky) are stunned and deeply saddened by the loss of our friend and colleague. Bob was a driving force at BWD and will be deeply missed by all. Bob and his son Ned joined BWD more than two decades ago and worked with many of us over the years. We can't imagine BWD without Bob. Our heartfelt sympathy goes out to his wife Betsy, to his son and partner Ned and wife Lyndsay, and all of Bob's family.

ELKIND-VAN GELDER--Margaret, died of cancer on January 30, 2014 at the age of 52. Beloved wife of Todd Van Gelder, adoring mother to Eric and Will Van Gelder and loving sister to Elisabeth and Sam Elkind, she was predeceased by her parents, Charlotte and Morton Digby Elkind. Born in Brooklyn, NY, she attended Packer, Spence, Wesleyan and Bank Street and had various jobs in the education field before moving to Brookeville, MD where her primary focus was her family and her many friends from every stage of her life. Memorial: Saturday, February 15th at noon, The Inn at Brookeville Farms, 19501 Georgia Ave., Brookeville, MD.

DUBOFSKY--Robert. January 31, 2014 at the age of 74. Our friend and esteemed colleague Bob will be greatly missed by all of us who had the honor of knowing him. Bob was extremely successful in life and as smart as they come, hardworking and charismatic. Our loving sympathy goes out to his wife Betsy, his children Ned and Nancy and their spouses Lyndsay and Stephen. Bob also leaves behind four beautiful grandchildren, Casey, Charlie, Michael and Matthew who were the light of his life. All of the members of our families are devastated by this loss. With profound sadness, The Blumencranz and Wilkins Families

FREIDES--Barbara Greene, long time resident of Larchmont, NY, passed away peacefully February 1st, 2014. She was 78 years old. Barbara was born to Henry and Augusta Greene on November 25th, 1935, in Brooklyn, NY before moving to Kew Garden Hills and then Forest Hills for her teenage years and young adult years. She then settled in Mamaroneck and then Larchmont, NY. She was predeceased by her husband, Jack Freides, whom she married November 23rd, 1961. He died on March 1st, 2006. She is survived by her loving sister Sybil Goldman; sons Drew Freides and Randy (Judy) Freides; along with her two cherished grandchildren, Rebecca and Adam Freides. She was first and foremost a devoted wife and mother, but also worked as an accountant for over 50 years, until she retired only last year. Her passion was traveling the world, which took her to almost every continent. Contributions in lieu of flowers, can be made to the Westchester Jewish Center, 175 Rockland Ave, Mamaroneck, NY 10543.

DUBOFSKY--Robert. We are saddened by the loss of our long time friend, a pillar of the community. Our thoughts and prayers are with Betsy, Ned and Lindsay, Nancy and Stephen. Levien and Scheinman Families

DUBOFSKY--Robert. We have lost a very dear friend. We will miss your warmth, kindness, generosity and friendship. Our fond memories of you will forever be in our hearts. Sincerest condolences to Betsy, Ned, Nancy, and the entire family. Marilyn, Steve, Lauren and Josh

DUBOFSKY--Robert, one of our oldest and dearest friends, left us on January 31, 2014. He was a true gentleman and a genuine human being. We cherish all the years of laughs, fun and great experiences our two families had together. Our deepest condolences to Betsy, Nancy, Ned and all the family. Marion, Jerry, Jodi and Andrew Sussman

DUBOFSKY--Robert L. We mourn the loss of our dear friend Bob, admired by all for his loyalty, generosity and kindness. Our deepest, heartfelt sympathy and love to Betsy, Ned, Lindsay, Nancy, Stephen, Matthew, Michael, Casey and Charlie. Joanne and Michael

WOLLAN--Eugene. The partners of Mound Cotton Wollan & Greengrass mourn the loss of our brilliant and esteemed colleague. In his 60 years with the firm that bears his name, Gene was mentor to three generations of our attorneys in insurance, reinsurance, and legal writing. Aptly described as "dean of the reinsurance bar" and "one of the best reinsurance arbitrators in the business," Gene was named one of the five leading reinsurance lawyers in the U.S. and among the best in the world. He authored the treatise Handbook of Reinsurance Law, and was co-author with his Mound Cotton colleagues of portions of other leading insurance and reinsurance texts. He also found time to write regularly for numerous professional periodicals and was Editor of the ARIAS quarterly, a Contributing Editor of The John Liner Review, and a member of the Editorial Board of Risk Management Reports. Gene also served many insurance associations and committees as an officer and member. He graduated with honors from Harvard College, Harvard Law School, and the U.S. Army Command and General Staff College and proudly served as a colonel (ret.) in the U.S. Army Reserve JAG. Gene led a remarkable life, and we will never forget him. We extend our condolences to his wife of 36 years, Marjorie, and to his children, stepchildren, and grandchildren. Contributions may be made to: Weill Cornell Heart Failure Center in memory of Eugene Wollan for Fellowship support, c/o Sylvia Gottlieb, Perkin Heart Failure Center, Weill Cornell Medical Center Division of Cardiology, 520 East 70th St., Starr 443, NY, NY 10021 Fax: 212-746-6665.

HEYMAN--Anne. Young Judaeans around the world are shocked and deeply saddened by the passing of Anne Heyman, friend and fellow alumna. Anne met her husband on Year Course and raised three children who were active in the movement. She was a Young Judaean through and through. Anne's life remains emblematic of the power and passion of Young Judaea. She committed her life to tzedek and tikkun olam; founding the Agahozo-Shalom Youth Village for children orphaned by the Rwandan genocide. We will continue to support Anne's vision by sending groups of students to volunteer at the youth village for years to come. Anne's amazing passion, keen sense of justice, and seemingly infinite energy to engage the world in the healing of broken communities make her a role model to all she touched. Thanks to Anne's support, encouragement, and constant calls for improvement, Young Judaea will continue to burn brighter as we fulfill our mission to engage all in repairing the world.

PLACHTA--Helen Beizer, 92, of Hartford, CT and Fresh Meadows, NY, passed away on February 2, 2014. Beloved mother of Leslie (Sabine) and Deborah (Alan); grandmother of Miriam, Daniel, and Benjamin. Predeceased by her cherished older sister and three brothers. Helen had to forgo college after her father's unexpected death when she was only twelve. After her husband Aaron's early death she returned to school to get a GED, Phi Beta Kappa college degree, and an MLS, working as head of periodicals at the library of the New York Academy of Medicine until her late 70s. We are all very proud of her and will miss her.

MASLOW--Carol Rosenthal. Feisty, loyal, strikingly elegant, bold, blonde and irreverently witty, best friend of husband Arthur, daughter of Doris and Eddie and mother of Toni and Mark, died on February 2nd after a sudden battle with cancer at the age of 78. Loving and generous, Carol will also be dearly missed by her extended family including Cindy, Lizzie and Gerry, Thom and Cheryl, her siblings and their spouses Ellen, Peter and Beth, Pat and Larry, and grandchildren Noah, Morgan, Sara, Brian, Caroline, Rachel and Hannah. Born in 1935 to Edward and Bea Rosenthal, who died due to complications from childbirth, Carol was raised by Eddie and Doris on the Upper West Side of Manhattan and graduated from The New Lincoln School and continued onto Connecticut College for Women. Married to Steven J. Ross at the age of 19, Carol moved back to New York earning her BA from Finch College. Carol raised daughter Toni, artist, restaurateur and mother of Noah and Sara, and son Mark, music producer, husband of Cindy and father of Morgan, Brian and Caroline. Carol went back to school as an adult. Demonstrating what became defining characteristics of determination and perseverance Carol earned her Masters of Social Work from NYU in 1984. Carol was committed to improving the lives of others. After earning her Masters, Carol worked with the homeless at Manhattan State Psychiatric Hospital. Later she became a Trustee of Beth Israel Hospital. Carol had an over 35 year affiliation with the Ackerman Family Institute serving in a multitude of roles from video technician to Chairman of the Board. It was at the Ackerman Institute that Carol met Arthur Maslow and over the ensuing years they fell in love, married in 1979, and remained soul mates for 34 years. Celebrating life's milestones with her children, grandchildren and extended family was one of Carol's greatest joys. For many years Nantucket became a wonderful second home filled with sunsets, gardening and adventures with Arthur's "fleet." Later years were split between Manhattan and Jupiter Florida interspersed with frequent exotic trips abroad. Laughter abounded as Carol punctuated every interaction with her wry one-line observations that cut right to the essence. Carol's life will be honored by family and friends at a memorial service Wednesday, February 5th at 10:00am at the Stanley Kaplan Penthouse at Lincoln Center 165 W. 65th Street, 10th Floor. Donations in Carol's memory may be made to the Carol R. Maslow Charitable Trust c/o Jewish Communal Fund, 575 Madison Avenue, Suite 703, New York, NY 10022.
MASLOW--Carol. Our loving sister, who has always been there for all of us. We will deeply Miss You, and Forever Love You. Love, Ellen, Beth, Peter, Pat and Larry
