MAYERS--Frank K.,91, died peacefully at his home in Boynton Beach, FL, February 1, 2014. Frank and his wife, actress Virginia Lee Curtis Mayers, who predeceased him, were long-time New York City residents. Born 1922 in Cleveland, OH, Frank was the son of inventor and shoe salesman, Horace Mayers, and Lucille Shaw Mayers. He grew up in Rocky River, OH. During WWII he interrupted his college studies to become a pilot in the Army Air Corps and flew a B-24 bomber based in Italy. In 1947 he graduated from the University of Pennsylvania. He earned his MBA from Harvard Business School in the illustrious class of 1949. In the early days of television, he worked at McCann Erickson selling advertising time. He later joined Foote, Cone & Belding as an account executive, working on many famous ad campaigns including "Does she or doesn't she? Only her hairdresser knows for sure." He joined Clairol as Executive Vice President and was named President in 1967. He later rose to President and then Chairman of the Products Division of Bristol-Myers. He retired in 1983. He is survived by his son Michael Mayers, daughter-in-law Lynn Dougherty, and two grandchildren, Jackson Mayers and Nora Mayers, all of Topanga, CA. Frank was active for many years in the Madison Square Boys and Girls Clubs, serving as Trustee and President of the Board of Directors. The family requests donations to this charity in lieu of flowers. He will be deeply missed.

BURKE--Edmund "Ned", 47 of Fairfield, CT, beloved husband of Michele (Carpentier) Burke passed away Thursday, January 30, 2014, after an eight year battle with brain cancer. Ned was born November 23, 1966 in Hartford and raised in Wethersfield, the son of Edmund and Gertrude (Carroll) Burke of Pocasset, MA. He graduated from Xavier High School in 1985, Fairfield University in 1989 and received his MBA from Fordham in 1999. Ned had a fifteen year career in Corporate Communications/ Investor Relations with AIG in New York City. Ned had a love of sports, especially golf and the Boston Red Sox and found great joy in bringing friends together. He will always be remembered for his devotion to his wife and children. Besides his wife and parents, Ned is survived by his children, Michael and Mia Burke of Fairfield and a brother, Jonathan Burke of Avon, CT. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated Saturday, February 8 at 10am directly at the Church of the Incarnation, 544 Prospect Street, Wethersfield, CT. Burial will be private. Calling hours are Friday, February 7, from 3-7pm at the D'Esopo Funeral Chapel, 277 Folly Brook Blvd., Wethersfield, CT. Donations in Ned's memory may be made to The Jimmy Fund, C/O Dana-Farber Cancer Institute, P.O. Box 849168, Boston, MA 02284-9168 or to Xavier High School, Attn: Advancement Office, 181 Randolph Rd., Middletown, CT 06457. For on-line expressions of sympathy please visit www.desopo.com.

EGOL--Marilyn, June 3, 1941 - January 13, 2014. Daughter to the late Beatrice and Norman Egol, twin sister of the late Morton Egol, sister-in-law to Nancy Egol, sister of David Egol. Marilyn was a loving daughter, sister and aunt to her nieces and nephews. Marilyn's passion was the ballet and her career in public relations in the ballet and other performing arts spanned decades. She was known to family, friends and colleagues for her charming wit and her cultured intellect. Marilyn will be greatly missed.

GAMBY--Werner, 98, died at home on February 2nd, surrounded by four generations of loving family. Born in Hamburg, Germany, he survived a concentration camp and in 1940 arrived penniless in New York. He started out pushing carts on 7th Ave and soon became a pioneer in the textile industry, founding W. Gamby and Co., which became one of the largest textile importers in the U.S. A pillar in the industry, he forged close and lasting relationships throughout the world. He embodied the American Dream and his generosity enabled others to realize it as well. Known for his eager anticipation of all that came next, he loved planning meals, trips and family visits. He will forever be our patriarch. Werner is finally reunited with his wife Vera, the love of his life for 75 years. He is survived by his son Peter (Julie) Gamby, daughters Dorothy (Ira) Kovel and Monica (Lee) Evslin, and he was the proud grandfather of Kimberly, Andrea, Jeffrey, Tanya, Noah, Nathaniel and Luke and the great-grandfather to Nicolas, Jackson, Zeke, Lola, Max, Violet, Isaac, Atticus, Alia and his caregiver Nino.

Pressure is on the singer Carly Rae Jepsen as she inherits the lead role in “Rodgers & Hammerstein’s Cinderella” on Broadway.
Researchers say they have developed an electrical conductor that is highly flexible and transparent, a combination that could help usher in flexible flat-screen televisions and smartphones.
Under an unusual agreement, the Dallas Museum of Art will become the long-term custodian of one of the most important collections of Islamic art in private hands.
The percussionist Steven Schick used a panoply of instruments, including his body, at the Miller Theater.
“I Call My Brothers,” by the Swedish playwright Jonas Hassen Khemiri, sends an Arab-American to Times Square soon after suspicious explosions.
Scientists are learning more about the brain activity underlying male aggression.
Broken Bells, Toni Braxton and Babyface, and the Haden Triplets have new albums.
About 28,000 riders took New Jersey Transit to the game at MetLife Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J., and more than 33,000 used it to leave.
In “An Officer and a Spy,” the novelist Robert Harris looks at the Alfred Dreyfus affair through a fictional lens.
Patina Miller appeared at the Allen Room as part of Lincoln Center’s American Songbook series.
Genetic testing of embryos raises unsettling ethical questions that trouble advocates for the disabled and have left some doctors struggling with what they should tell their patients.
The playwright Christina Masciotti puts together a father and college-age daughter in the gentle comedy “Adult” at Abrons Arts Center.
To dress Alpine venues of the Sochi Games in white has required the help of science, a lot of machines and a little luck.
As part of a closely watched unionization drive, workers in Chattanooga will decide next week whether to join the United Automobile Workers.
“This England,” a program of four works performed by the American Symphony Orchestra, seeks to revisit some less-performed compositions.
The Children’s Aid Society is selling a school on the Upper East Side, marketing it as a potential single family townhouse, with plans to use that money to build a modern school in the Bronx.
The British drama, perfect counterprogramming by PBS, was the second-most-watched show on Sunday night with 6.8 million viewers, a 3 percent rise from last year.
Mark Thompson, now president and chief executive of The New York Times Company, testified that he had never “knowingly misled” Parliament over the project’s progress.

A majority of the betting public counted on a storybook ending to quarterback Peyton Manning’s magical season, and it lost big as a result.
Storms and warmer temperatures are killing the chicks of Magellanic penguins, while extreme weather and a shrinking habitat are taking a toll on monarch butterflies.

Once a mostly Democratic cause, government-funded preschool has been embraced by both parties outside Washington, with Republican governors pushing some of the biggest increases in preschool spending.
Dr. Frank Netter’s mother insisted he go into medicine, but he met her halfway, following his passion for art and becoming possibly the world’s best-known medical illustrator.
A recent video purported to prove that adding an infinite series of natural numbers gives you a smaller answer than you might think, raising compelling questions about the entire notion of infinity.
Senior officials are trying to assemble a new financial package intended to ease the way for the formation of a new government.
Just days before the start of the Winter Olympics in Sochi, there are unfinished hotels, half-finished stores and a mall where the only shop that is open and thriving is a Cinnabon.

While rummaging through a collection of keepsakes before moving from New Jersey to Washington, out popped a red flag and memories to go with it.
Statistics exclude segments of the industry that have grown in recent years, and a proposed rule that would require more accuracy remains delayed.

Fiat Chrysler Automobiles is keeping its new logo simple and to the point.

Nascar again shuffles rules for end-of-season Chase for the Championship; five men are inducted into the Nascar Hall of Fame.

Top contenders in both nations failed to get enough votes on Sunday to win outright, in contests that tested the power of incumbent parties.

The Qaeda leadership said it was no longer connected to the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria, which has asserted an increasingly important role in the Syrian conflict.
An announcement from Al Qaeda’s leadership posted on jihadist websites said it is no longer associated with the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria.
Stocks on Wall Street stocks slumped on Monday, with the S.&P. 500 hitting its lowest level since October, after weaker-than-expected data on the factory sector.

Ben S. Bernanke has joined the Brookings Institution, where he will write a book about his time at the Federal Reserve and contribute to an initiative on government economic policy.
Winter Olympics officials made changes to the slopestyle course after Torstein Horgmo of Norway crashed on the rail portion and broke his collarbone.

A Chinese survey released Monday showed that growth in the country’s service sector slowed to a five-year low in January.

ROGERS--Louise Gordon, 91, artist, sailor, died peacefully on February 2nd. Daughter of the late Charles Gordon and Edna Krause Gordon, she was predeceased by her beloved husband Harry Peter, son Gordon, sisters Jane and Sara and brother Henry. A Manhattan resident, she spent many summers in Cutchogue, Long Island. An award-winning painter, illustrator of children's books, she was a member of the Pen & Brush Club and The Art Students League. She was a long-time member of the City Island Yacht Club. She attended Smith College and is an alumna of Elmira College. In 1970, with neighbors, she was instrumental in gaining early landmark designation for a row of mid-19th century row houses, including hers, in Chelsea. She is survived by nieces and nephews, her cherished Victoria Leacock Hoffman, grandson Harry Hoffman, and many dear friends. Memorial service to be announced.

ORTENBERG--Art. The Wildlife Conservation Society mourns the death of businessman, philanthropist and conservationist Art Ortenberg. Art, and his late wife, Liz Claiborne, will be remembered as great champions for wildlife and wild places and for the people whose lives are sustained by them. As our colleagues and donors, they helped to launch and sustain our efforts around the globe. For decades, Art and Liz catalyzed conservation actions to benefit some of the world's most iconic species and places. Their leadership in conserving species like elephants, tigers, and jaguars, and their dedication to wild lands in places like Montana, Argentina's Patagonia, and East Africa, were legendary. Their legacy will continue through the work of the Liz Claiborne and Art Ortenberg Foundation, which is a timeless tribute to their passion and beliefs.

PROCKOP--Elinor S.,of Philadelphia, died peacefully from the effects of cancer on Sunday, February 2nd, 2014. Born Elinor Sacks in New York on May 16th, 1930, Ellie attended Radcliffe College and then earned a PhD in experimental psychology from Harvard University in the 1950's before marrying Darwin Prockop and settling with him in Philadelphia. In 1972, Darwin, Ellie and their two young children moved to Princeton, NJ, where Ellie became advisor to premedical students at the university. Darwin and Ellie moved back to Philadelphia in 1986. To the end Ellie remained comfortable in the home she loved, in the company of her family. She is survived by Darwin, their daughter Susan and her wife Kristie Gordon (of New York City), a son David and his wife Hope and their children Molly and Lyle (of Groton, MA). A memorial service will be held at a later date.

ZILENZIGER--Rodman J.,85, former longtime resident of Scarsdale, New York and Vero Beach, Florida died on February 2, 2014. Born October 10, 1928 in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, his family settled in Bala Cynwyd, Pennsylvania. Mr. Zilenziger was also a graduate of Pennsylvania Military College (PMC) as well as having served as a 1st Lieutenant in the Korean War in the 2nd infantry regiment and received the Bronze Star. Mr. Zilenziger was the founder and past president of Rodman Publishing Corporation, a business-to-business trade magazine publishing corporation located in Ramsey, NJ. Mr. Zilenziger married Roxane Shugart Zilenziger who passed away in 2010. They were married for 53 years. They held memberships in the Fox Meadow Tennis Club of Scarsdale, New York, the Shenorock Shore Club of Rye, New York, as well as The Moorings Club of Vero Beach, Florida where they enjoyed playing tennis, platform tennis, and golf. Mr. Zilenziger was also a member of the Hitchcock Presbyterian Church in Scarsdale, New York and was a volunteer fireman in Scarsdale for many years. Survived by his three children; Gaye Geiger (Scott), of New Canaan, CT., Susan Maier (Rich) of Ho-Ho-Kus, NJ, and Rodman Zilenziger Jr. (Jennifer) also of Ho-Ho-Kus, and eleven grandchildren: Daniel, Sarah, Caitlin, Taylor, Rodman, Lindsay, Kevin, James, Claire, Katherine, and Anna. Private Service to be held Hitchcock Presbyterian Church, 6 Greenacres Avenue, Scarsdale, NY 10583. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the National Parkinson's Foundation.

MAYERS--Frank K.,91, died peacefully at his home in Boynton Beach, FL, February 1, 2014. Frank and his wife, actress Virginia Lee Curtis Mayers, who predeceased him, were long-time New York City residents. Born 1922 in Cleveland, OH, Frank was the son of inventor and shoe salesman, Horace Mayers, and Lucille Shaw Mayers. He grew up in Rocky River, OH. During WWII he interrupted his college studies to become a pilot in the Army Air Corps and flew a B-24 bomber based in Italy. In 1947 he graduated from the University of Pennsylvania. He earned his MBA from Harvard Business School in the illustrious class of 1949. In the early days of television, he worked at McCann Erickson selling advertising time. He later joined Foote, Cone & Belding as an account executive, working on many famous ad campaigns including "Does she or doesn't she? Only her hairdresser knows for sure." He joined Clairol as Executive Vice President and was named President in 1967. He later rose to President and then Chairman of the Products Division of Bristol-Myers. He retired in 1983. He is survived by his son Michael Mayers, daughter-in-law Lynn Dougherty, and two grandchildren, Jackson Mayers and Nora Mayers, all of Topanga, CA. Frank was active for many years in the Madison Square Boys and Girls Clubs, serving as Trustee and President of the Board of Directors. The family requests donations to this charity in lieu of flowers. He will be deeply missed.

ROSS--Robert B.,age 89 of Ridgewood NJ, passed away suddenly but peacefully on January 31, 2014 at his new home in Falls Church, VA. He practiced law for over 60 years and was the founding partner of Katz&Ross. Robert received a BA in 1946 at Harvard College and earned an MBA from Harvard Business School and JD from Harvard Law School. He was a WWII Veteran in the US Navy, Chairman of The Schools Committee of the Harvard Club of NYC for 30 years, an avid tennis player at Upper Ridgewood Tennis Club and continued to play tennis into his 89th year. SHALITA--Alan R.,MD. The Board of Directors of the American Skin Association (ASA) mourn the loss of Alan R. Shalita, MD, distinguished teaching professor and chair of dermatology at SUNY Downstate Medical Center, who passed away on Sunday, February 2, 2014. A pioneer in the treatment of acne, Dr. Shalita was recognized nationally and worldwide for his skills as a clinician, researcher, and educator in dermatology. Since 1975, Dr. Shalita had been chief of dermatology for both SUNY Downstate's University Hospital of Brooklyn and the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation's Kings County Hospital Center, and a consultant in dermatology services for the Brooklyn campus of the VA New York Harbor Healthcare System. He was also associate dean for graduate medical education and clinical affairs at Downstate. Dr. Shalita was a dedicated member of ASA and had served on its Education Council. Over his two decades of loyal service to ASA, Dr. Shalita played an integral part in supporting ASA's mission to fight skin disease and to promote skin health to the nation's children. His immeasurable impact in dermatology has been felt by the physicians he mentored and the patients he treated over a remarkable career. He will be sorely missed as a beloved member of our community! Howard P. Milstein, Chairman of the Board American Skin Association

SHALITA--Alan R.,M.D. The SUNY Downstate Medical Center community deeply mourns the passing of Alan R. Shalita, MD, Distinguished Teaching Professor Emeritus and chair of the Department of Dermatology. A pioneer and internationally known expert in the treatment of acne, Dr. Shalita was recognized worldwide for his skills as a clinician, researcher, and educator. Since 1975 he had been chief of dermatology for both University Hospital of Brooklyn and Kings County Hospital Center, and consultant in dermatology services for the Brooklyn VA Hospital. He served as president of the American Dermatological Association and the Association of Professors of Dermatology, and, for four years, deputy secretary general of the World Congress of Dermatology. In 2013, Dr. Shalita was awarded the Gold Medal, the highest honor of the American Academy of Dermatology, in recognition of his service to the specialty. We extend our deepest sympathies to his family, colleagues, and friends. John F. Williams, MD, EdD, MPH, President Ian L. Taylor, MD, PhD, Dean, College of Medicine

MASLOW--Carol. The Board of Directors of the Robert Mapplethorpe Foundation notes with sadness that its supporter and colleague Carol Maslow passed away. GALLAGHER--James Joseph, Of Vero Beach, FL, passed away on February 1, 2014 after a brief battle with cancer. He was 77 years young. Mr. Gallagher, best known as "Jim," was born on August 29 in the Bronx, and raised in Elmhurst, Queens, where he attended Resurrection Ascension Grammar School. He graduated from Xavier High School in Manhattan in 1954, and attended the University of Mississippi. Baseball was Jim's first love and profession, and he played for the New York Giants, New York Yankees, and Kansas City Athletics organizations. When his pitching coach walked to the mound and told him it was "time to figure out what he was going to do for a living," he did just that, joining the then-burgeoning outdoor advertising industry as an account representative for NOAB. Thus began a 45-year career in advertising that included a stint at J. Walter Thompson in New York, New Orleans and Detroit, and culminated in 33 years as president of his own firm, Gallagher Group, Inc., from which he retired in 2005. In retirement, he and his wife of 54 years, Ann, relocated from Manhattan to Vero Beach, FL, and took up residence at Orchid Island Golf & Beach Club. Jim was an avid reader, golfer and grandfather. He enjoyed baseball, fine cuisine, movies, theatre, travel, his beloved New York Giants, Mets, and Rangers, people everywhere, a good martini, a good laugh and a good story not necessarily in that order. He was an immensely gregarious and curious man who genuinely engaged with everyone he met, regardless of their station in life, and charmed all with his ready wit. He was deeply loyal and generous to his friends and family, and in contrast to his larger-than-life personality, had a notorious soft spot for babies and cats. He was a member of the Metropolitan Club, a 35-year member of Sleepy Hollow Country Club in Scarborough, NY, and a member of both Orchid Island Golf and Beach Club and Quail Valley Golf and River Clubs in Vero Beach, FL. He served on numerous boards and committees of the many clubs and organizations he supported and was extremely active in the Xavier High School Alumni Association. Jim is survived by his wife, Ann (nee Corbin); his daughter Maura Wilson (Thomas) of Darien, CT; son Matthew (Fabrisa) of Matamoras, PA; son Thomas of Beacon, NY; grandchildren Liam Wilson of Darien, CT, Christian, James and Anna Maria Gallagher of Matamoras, PA; sister Maureen Vlack, of Edison, NJ; and many nieces and nephews. Services will be held Thursday, February 6, 2014 at 2pm at Holy Cross Catholic Church in Vero Beach, FL, followed immediately by a reception at Orchid Beach Club. A funeral Mass and Memorial Service will be held in March at the Church of St. Francis Xavier in New York City, followed by a reception at Sleepy Hollow Country Club and interment at Sleepy Hollow Cemetery in Sleepy Hollow, NY. SHALITA--Dr. Alan R. We are deeply saddened by the passing of our Chairman, Dr. Alan R. Shalita, Distinguished Teaching Professor of Dermatology, SUNY Downstate Medical Center, Brooklyn. He has fundamentally changed the lives of countless students and residents in Brooklyn, New York, and around the world. He steadfastly supported and nurtured his faculty and staff and played a major leadership role in our Medical Center. He was a man with a good heart and soul, who was a legend in his own time. He will be deeply missed. Faculty and Staff, Department of Dermatology, SUNY Downstate Medical Center

SHALITA--Dr. Alan R. passed away peacefully on Sunday, February 2nd. He was surrounded by his family: his wife Simone, his sister Barbara Samuelson, his brother-in-law John Samuelson, his nephews Charles and Richard Samuelson, and David Baum. Dr. Shalita was a distinguished Professor of Dermatology and longtime Chairman of the Department of Dermatology at SUNY Downstate. He was revered by all the doctors he trained over almost 40 years. He will be mourned by his daughter Judith, his grandson Daniel Marmour (son of Dr. Shalita's daughter, the late Deborah Marmour), and Daniel's siblings Maia, Yonaton, Ariela, Rafael, and Yehuda, Daniel's parents David and Sharon Marmour and his niece Jennifer Baum. Services will be held on Friday, February 7, 2014 at 12pm at Temple Shaaray Tefila 250 East 79th Street. Contributions in his memory can be made to the Alan R. Shalita M.D. Endowment Chair at SUNY Downstate Medical Center.

STUZIN--Gerald J. 76, February 3, 2014. Beloved husband of Marie deCorse, father of Nina & Gary Vincoff, grandfather of Zoe & Sophie. St. Johns University Professor. Donations may be made to the Yiddish Book Center.

KOEGEL--William F. Bill Koegel, a resident of Somers, New York and Vero Beach, Florida, died on February 3rd in Florida. He was 90. After seven years living outside of Chicago (long enough to become a lifelong Cubs fan), he grew up in Bronxville, New York and proudly attended Williams College, in the class of 1944 (but actually graduating in September 1946 due to service in the First Army of the United States in Europe in the Second World War). After graduating from the University of Virginia Law School in 1949, he joined the New York law firm of Dwight, Royall, Harris, Koegel & Caskey, where he spent his entire professional life, retiring in 1989 as a senior partner and head of the litigation department (the firm then being known as Rogers & Wells). From 1952 to 2007, he resided in Scarsdale, New York where he was active in a range of civic affairs. In 1946 he married Barbara Bixler, whom he had met in 1941 while she was attending Smith College. She died in 1968. In 1969 he married Ruth Swan Boynton, who died in 1983. In 1984 he married Irene Lawrence, who survives him. Also surviving him are: his older sister, Ruth Macreery; his two sons: John Koegel of New York City (and his wife Lesley) and Robert Koegel of Rochester, New York (and his wife Mary); and six step-children: Whitney Boynton, Thomas Boynton, Barbara Hinman, Beverly Orser, Geoffrey Lawrence and Amelia Kelly. He is also survived by four grandchildren, seven step-grandchildren, three great-grandchildren, one great-step grandchild, and seven nieces and nephews. His generous, loving spirit will remain in the hearts of everyone who has been fortunate enough to know him. A service will be held at the Hitchcock Presbyterian Church, located at 6 Greenacres Avenue in Scarsdale, New York on Saturday, February 15 at 2pm. He will ultimately rest with predeceased family members at the Amawalk Hill Cemetery in Yorktown Heights, NY.

BONVILLAIN--Ruth, 99, died peacefully at her home in New Malborough, MA, on February 3, 2014 where she resided with her daughter Nancy. She was born January 1, 1915 in New York City. Ruth worked for the Jewish Family Service in Brooklyn for many years before opening her own therapy practice in 1970. She continued her work until the young age of 92.

LAZAR--Eliot. The New York Academy of Medicine (NYAM) mourns the passing of our valued colleague and friend. A longtime NYAM Fellow, Dr. Lazar served as Chair of the Committee on Admission and Membership for over a decade and as a NYAM Trustee. The staff and Board of NYAM extend our condolences to the entire Lazar family. Dr. Jo Ivey Boufford, President

LENTNER--Dr. Howard H.,died February 5, 2014 at age 82. He was born in Detroit, MI, graduated from Miami University and earned his PhD in Political Science from Syracuse University. He loved to teach at all college levels and developed long-lasting relationships with many students. He taught and held various positions of academic leadership at Case Western Reserve University (Ohio) McMaster University (Ontario) Baruch College and the CUNY Graduate School. He was a respected and widely published author in his field. Howard was married to M. Nancy (Taylor) Lentner from 1958 to 1983. He is predeceased by their oldest daughter, Tarah (1977.) He is survived by his sister Audrey Lentner, son J Lentner, daughter-in-law Joanne and grandsons Christopher and Andrew; and daughter Leseh Lentner and grandchildren Samantha, Mya, Jaheim and Aliyah. Howard had passions for painting, tennis, cooking and the performing arts. He leaves behind a legacy of love and commitment to those in need and will be missed every day. Contributions may be made to the U.S. Fund for UNICEF, 125 Maiden Lane, New York, NY

ORTENBERG--Arthur. NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital mourns the passing of Art Ortenberg, a brilliant friend of the hospital. Deeply committed to patient- and family-centered care and erudite communication, Art established the Liz Claiborne Center for Medical Humanism at NewYork-Presbyterian in tribute to his late wife. The center educates health care professionals on palliative care and medical humanism. Art's careful and selective generosity and broad vision for supporting society's best interests have touched the lives of countless patients and their families. We extend our deepest condolences to his partner, Cathy Horyn, children, Neil and Nancy Ortenberg, stepson, Alexander Schultz, sister, Gloria Ortenberg Farber, and his entire family. Frank A. Bennack Jr. Chair Herbert Pardes, MD Vice Chair Steven J. Corwin, MD CEO NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital

RUSSEK--Lillian, 101 years old, died on February 5, 2014. Beloved wife of the late Herman. Devoted mother of Andrea and Norman Fells, Steffie and Norman Schneider and Richard and Lynn Russek. ORTENBERG--Art. The Wildlife Conservation Society mourns the death of businessman, philanthropist and conservationist Art Ortenberg. Art, and his late wife, Liz Claiborne, will be remembered as great champions for wildlife and wild places and for the people whose lives are sustained by them. As our colleagues and donors, they helped to launch and sustain our efforts around the globe. For decades, Art and Liz catalyzed conservation actions to benefit some of the world's most iconic species and places. Their leadership in conserving species like elephants, tigers, and jaguars, and their dedication to wild lands in places like Montana, Argentina's Patagonia, and East Africa, were legendary. Their legacy will continue through the work of the Liz Claiborne and Art Ortenberg Foundation, which is a timeless tribute to their passion and beliefs.

HIRSCH--Shay Yandell. June 8, 1947 to February 3, 2014. A beloved mother, wife, grandmother, social worker, friend, marathon runner, skier, writer, advocate, hiker, traveler, defender of the vulnerable and cancer warrior, passed away peacefully at home, surrounded by family, on February 3rd. Shay grew up in Boise, Idaho, where she was a 1965 graduate of Boise High School. Her childhood in the American West sparked a lasting love of nature. She entered a career in social work after graduating from Whitman College in 1969, and she devoted her life to others. In 1973, she married Greg Scrivner; the couple's two sons, Ian and Sean, were born in Alaska. After living in France, Ireland, Colombia, and New Jersey, Shay returned to Boise, where she became the director of YWCA's shelter for battered women, now called the Women's and Children's Alliance. At the 1988 New Jersey Waterfront Marathon, George Hirsch, who had met Shay only the day before at a marathon expo, and who was irrevocably lovestruck, ran through the crowded field of a race for which he had not registered until he found her. They ran the remaining 21 miles together, and they married the next year. Shay relocated to New York City, but the Hirsches maintained strong ties to Idaho, and they kept a home in Sun Valley. For the past eleven years, Shay wrote eloquently of her fight against multiple myeloma, an incurable blood cancer. Through two stem cell transplants and through more recent encounters with myelodysplastic syndrome and acute myeloid leukemia, Shay faced wave after wave of indignities with dignity and grace. She ended each post about her cancer battle by saying "Onward!" She embraced every part of life as an adventure, even the difficult ones. The impact of Shay's life is "incalculably diffusive," as George Eliot once wrote. Shay's memory will be held closely in the hearts of her husband, George A. Hirsch, the chairman of the New York Road Runners; her son Ian Scrivner and spouse Cinzia Dinoi; her son Sean Scrivner and partner Rachel Teannalach; her stepsons David and William Hirsch; her father Robert Yandell, brother Robert Yandell, and brother John Yandell and spouse Julie Yandell; her grandchildren Anjali Hirsch and Rhys Scrivner; and her nephews Christopher and Nicholas Yandell. A celebration of Shay's life will be held in March.

BERGER--Stanley, 87 years old of Greenwich, CT. Predeceased by his first wife, Sylvia and his son, Andrew. Survived by his beloved wife Frances Berger, his devoted children Jeff and Lynn Berger, Elisabeth and Gary Schonfeld, Sam and Cathy Berger and Charles Berger, his adoring grandchildren Natalie Berger, Samantha DeCandia, Jesse and Michael Berger, Zach, Matthew and Sam Schonfeld, his loving great- grandchildren Landon Piagentini and Christian DeCandia, his dear sisters Sheila Kane and Bernice Billig. Service 12:30pm Thursday at Gutterman and Musicant, 402 Park Street, Hackensack, NJ.
HIRSCH--Shay. We are so fortunate to have known you. There will never be another treasure like Shay Hirsch. Valerie and Paul

SAVETSKY--Dr. Lawrence. The Columbia University Department of Otolaryngology/Head & Neck Surgery mourns the passing of our dear friend and colleague, Dr. Lawrence Savetsky. Larry was a member of our department for over 40 years and was renowned for the excellence of his care of adults and children; the chair and lectureship in Pediatric Otolaryngology is named in his honor. We extend our condolences to the Savetsky family: Gudrun, his wife of 55 years; his children Eric and Elke, and their spouses Ann and Andrew; and his beloved grandchildren Lauren and Justin. Dr. Joseph Haddad Jr., Interim Chairman

STUURMAN--Margaret C.,of Glen Cove, NY, formerly of Laurel Hollow, NY, passed away February 5, 2014. Predeceased by her husband, John H.G. Stuurman III, sister Catherine Shea and son, J. Pieter Stuurman. Loving mother of Susan Stuurman Affuso and Linda A. Stuurman. Devoted grandmother of Elizabeth P. Affuso and Benjamin P. Affuso. Margaret was former President of the Oyster Bay Historical Society and a former trustee of the Raynham Hall Museum in Oyster Bay, NY. She loved her family and friends and enjoyed painting, reading, traveling, antiques and animals. A Funeral Mass will be held at St. Dominic's Chapel, 93 Anstice Street, Oyster Bay, NY on Saturday, February, 8 at 10:30am. Interment: Holy Road Cemetery, Westbury, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Last Hope Animal Rescue, P.O. Box 7025, Wantagh, NY 11793.

REICH--R. Donald, died on February 3, 2014 of complications from Parkinson's disease. Born in Yonkers, NY in 1921, he was raised by his mother, Alma Shannon, and graduated from Gorton High School, Dartmouth College and Harvard Law School. Donald served as a Naval Officer in World War II, later becoming the President of Airco, Inc., an industrial gas producer, and Vice Chairman of Orion Capital, an insurance holding company. He and his wife Constance Verrill Reich raised their family in Brooklyn Heights, NY, and Ridgewood, NJ, retiring to Redding, CT. Donald spent as much time as he could at Point O' Woods, Fire Island, a community he cherished. He is survived by Connie, his wife of 59 years; his son, Dr. D. Bradford Reich (and wife Patricia Pierce) of Brookline, MA; his son Christopher V. Reich (and wife Eleanor Paschal), of Purchase, NY; and his five grandchildren, Christopher, William, George, Anna and Eleanor. A service will be held at Rye Presbyterian Church, 882 Boston Post Road, Rye, NY at 11am on Saturday, February 15th. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to the Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research, Grand Central Station, PO Box 4777, NY, NY 10163.

RICHARDSON--Rita (nee Griswold), a long time resident of Darien, CT, died February 4, 2014, aged 90. Wife of the late George "Rick" Richardson, loving mother to Debbie Thomas of Melbourne, Australia and George O. Richardson, III of New Canaan, CT. CALI--John J. A true gentleman, husband to Rose, father, Philanthropist, successful businessman and a dear friend. Missed by all. Rest in peace. Murray and Joanne and the Breidbart Family

HIRSCH--Shay Yandell. June 8, 1947 to February 3, 2014. A beloved mother, wife, grandmother, social worker, friend, marathon runner, skier, writer, advocate, hiker, traveler, defender of the vulnerable and cancer warrior, passed away peacefully at home, surrounded by family, on February 3rd. Shay grew up in Boise, Idaho, where she was a 1965 graduate of Boise High School. Her childhood in the American West sparked a lasting love of nature. She entered a career in social work after graduating from Whitman College in 1969, and she devoted her life to others. In 1973, she married Greg Scrivner; the couple's two sons, Ian and Sean, were born in Alaska. After living in France, Ireland, Colombia, and New Jersey, Shay returned to Boise, where she became the director of YWCA's shelter for battered women, now called the Women's and Children's Alliance. At the 1988 New Jersey Waterfront Marathon, George Hirsch, who had met Shay only the day before at a marathon expo, and who was irrevocably lovestruck, ran through the crowded field of a race for which he had not registered until he found her. They ran the remaining 21 miles together, and they married the next year. Shay relocated to New York City, but the Hirsches maintained strong ties to Idaho, and they kept a home in Sun Valley. For the past eleven years, Shay wrote eloquently of her fight against multiple myeloma, an incurable blood cancer. Through two stem cell transplants and through more recent encounters with myelodysplastic syndrome and acute myeloid leukemia, Shay faced wave after wave of indignities with dignity and grace. She ended each post about her cancer battle by saying "Onward!" She embraced every part of life as an adventure, even the difficult ones. The impact of Shay's life is "incalculably diffusive," as George Eliot once wrote. Shay's memory will be held closely in the hearts of her husband, George A. Hirsch, the chairman of the New York Road Runners; her son Ian Scrivner and spouse Cinzia Dinoi; her son Sean Scrivner and partner Rachel Teannalach; her stepsons David and William Hirsch; her father Robert Yandell, brother Robert Yandell, and brother John Yandell and spouse Julie Yandell; her grandchildren Anjali Hirsch and Rhys Scrivner; and her nephews Christopher and Nicholas Yandell. A celebration of Shay's life will be held in March.

DITTMER--Frances. The Trustees, National Council, and staff of the Aspen Art Museum mourn the tragic loss of AAM Board of Trustees member Frances "Frannie" Dittmer, an inspiring and energetic philanthropist, a close friend of the museum, and a tireless and enthusiastic donor to and supporter of the arts. The AAM cannot overstate the profound impact she has had on all of us and our institution. We know that her laughter will ring through the galleries of our new building. Our heartfelt condolences to her family for their loss. John Phelan and Paul Schorr, Co-Presidents of the Board of Trustees; Toby Devan Lewis and Pam Alexander, Co-Chairs of the National Council; Heidi Zuckerman Jacobson, Nancy and Bob Magoon CEO and Director

duPONT--Genevieve, The Officers and Directors of the Garden Club of America express great sorrow on the death of their former president Mrs. Nicholas R. duPont and extend their sincere sympathy to her family and friends. Her leadership furthered the mission of the organization, and she was a true inspiration to all who knew her.

LOCKSLEY--Gordon, private art dealer, contemporary art collector and bon vivant, passed away quietly in Fort Lauderdale, Florida on February 1, 2014. He was 84. Mr. Locksley is remembered for his keen wit and wry sense of humor, his thoughtful generosity and devotion to friends, family and the art world. He is survived by his spouse, Wayne Boeck and long time partner George Shea. Mr. Locksley was born in Chicago, Illinois on August 27, 1930 to Sheila and William Locksley (Lukowitz). Gordon's father worked in pharmaceutical sales for Max Factor and instilled a love of fragrances and their histories in his young son. His grandparents, Isadore and Ella Lukowitz, came from Poland, emigrating before World War II and were renowned for their bakery, which provided Chicago residents with their famous onion rye bread. As a teenager, Gordon developed a love of opera, through weekly radio programs and later, a passion for Broadway musicals. Surrounded by his mother and aunts, Gordon was tutored in the art of cooking and acquired a passion for fine dining and entertaining, which lasted throughout his life. As a young man, Mr. Locksley lived briefly in Columbus, Ohio and then moved to Minneapolis, where he arrived on a bus in a snowstorm, wrapped in an opera cape.and in 1954 met Dr. George Shea, a professor of Japanese language and literature at the University of Minnesota. Together they opened the Red Carpet Beauty Salon and College, where Gordon styled hair, and where he eventually began selling art, first on the salon walls and then in a private space which came to be known as Locksley Shea Gallery, one of the leading spaces for contemporary art in Minneapolis, in the 1960s and 70s. The Locksley Shea Gallery hosted exhibitions by many of the leading names in contemporary art; Christo, Andy Warhol, Donald Judd, Brice Marden, Ellsworth Kelly and Robert Rauschenberg all came for the opening night party of their exhibitions. Legendary parties; Christo wrapped two nude models in cellophane one night, Warhol and his entourage arrived by limousine, there were outrageous costume parties with live bands, multiple bars, dancing and gogo dancers. Gordon was a partner in Sutton Place, the first gay bar in Minneapolis. He and his attorney, Elliot Kaplan, worked tirelessly with local licensing authorities and the city council to create higher visibility for gay rights and equality. In 1974, following a downturn in the art market, a historic snowstorm and a notably large piece of business, Gordon and George Shea departed Minneapolis for Rome, Cannes and Paris where they lived until 1994, when they returned to the US and settled into an A. Quincy Jones designed estate, which was featured in the movie "Oceans Eleven," in Palm Springs. In 1998, Mr. Locksley met Wayne Boeck and moved to Fort Lauderdale, Florida, where they were married in November 2013. Selections from the Locksley Shea Art Collection are currently on view at the Minneapolis Art Institute. Mr. Locksley's ashes will be scattered on the mountainside above Palm Springs, California. There will be no memorial service.
LOCKSLEY--Gordon. We have lost a most special and unique friend. His intelligence, humor and thoughtfulness will always be with us. Colombe Nicholas Leonard Rosenberg

ASH--Paul J.,on February 5, 2014, age 84. Beloved husband of Cobi. Cherished brother of Marcia and Jerome. Adored uncle to many nieces and nephews. Loving son of the late Rose and Sam Ash. President of Sam Ash Music Corp. and philanthropist. A memorial service to be announced.

KOBREN--Jack, 90, died Thursday, February 6. Born in Brooklyn, NY. The son of the late Saul and Sophie. Jack was a decorated Veteran of the United States Army receiving the Bronze star for Valor and two purple hearts during WWII. After the War he was a self-employed fur/clothing manufacturer, Designs by Jack Kobren in New York City. He was predeceased by his loving wife Doris and his son Alan. He is survived by his son Spencer (Yvette) of Calabasas, CA, and his grandson Maxwell of Bethesda, MD. He also leaves behind a brother Sam of Long Island, NY. Services will be held at 2:45pm, Friday, February 7 at the Sanctuary of Abraham and Sarah, 735 Forest Ave., Paramus, New Jersey. Services under the direction of Louis Suburban Chapel 13-01 Broadway, Fair Lawn, New Jersey.

HIRSCH--Shay Yandell. June 8, 1947 to February 3, 2014. A beloved mother, wife, grandmother, social worker, friend, marathon runner, skier, writer, advocate, hiker, traveler, defender of the vulnerable and cancer warrior, passed away peacefully at home, surrounded by family, on February 3rd. Shay grew up in Boise, Idaho, where she was a 1965 graduate of Boise High School. Her childhood in the American West sparked a lasting love of nature. She entered a career in social work after graduating from Whitman College in 1969, and she devoted her life to others. In 1973, she married Greg Scrivner; the couple's two sons, Ian and Sean, were born in Alaska. After living in France, Ireland, Colombia, and New Jersey, Shay returned to Boise, where she became the director of YWCA's shelter for battered women, now called the Women's and Children's Alliance. At the 1988 New Jersey Waterfront Marathon, George Hirsch, who had met Shay only the day before at a marathon expo, and who was irrevocably lovestruck, ran through the crowded field of a race for which he had not registered until he found her. They ran the remaining 21 miles together, and they married the next year. Shay relocated to New York City, but the Hirsches maintained strong ties to Idaho, and they kept a home in Sun Valley. For the past eleven years, Shay wrote eloquently of her fight against multiple myeloma, an incurable blood cancer. Through two stem cell transplants and through more recent encounters with myelodysplastic syndrome and acute myeloid leukemia, Shay faced wave after wave of indignities with dignity and grace. She ended each post about her cancer battle by saying "Onward!" She embraced every part of life as an adventure, even the difficult ones. The impact of Shay's life is "incalculably diffusive," as George Eliot once wrote. Shay's memory will be held closely in the hearts of her husband, George A. Hirsch, the chairman of the New York Road Runners; her son Ian Scrivner and spouse Cinzia Dinoi; her son Sean Scrivner and partner Rachel Teannalach; her stepsons David and William Hirsch; her father Robert Yandell, brother Robert Yandell, and brother John Yandell and spouse Julie Yandell; her grandchildren Anjali Hirsch and Rhys Scrivner; and her nephews Christopher and Nicholas Yandell. A celebration of Shay's life will be held in March.

BONHEUR--Hooshang, PhD, of New York, passed away on January 29, 2014 with his family by his side. He was a man who had a lifelong passion for learning and stood by his principles with conviction and without fail. He had a gentle warmth that could easily be heard in his voice, felt in his touch and seen in his smile. An accomplished clinical psychologist, he dedicated his professional career to his work as a forensic psychologist at the Supreme Court of the City of New York. Most important to him, he was a devoted and loving father to Jennifer and Craig, an adored grandfather to David and Adam, a cherished brother, uncle, cousin and friend. He was the man who taught us to "always do what you know and feel to be right" and emphasized how important it is to "make sure you leave this world a little better than how you found it". He most certainly did just that. His legacy will live on in all who knew him. Thank you Baba Hooshie, for enriching our lives every day and for being the man you'll forever be in our hearts.

PERL--Otto. Beloved husband of over 70 years to Susanne, proud father of Lawrence, Monica, and Martin. Cherished "Papa" of Michael, Ze'ev, Elyse, Michal, Doron, Leia, Daniel, and Ella. Born in Vienna in 1915, Otto survived Dachau and Buchenwald, immigrated to the US in 1940, and served in US Army counterintelligence at Camp Ritchie. He created a world-renowned custom tailoring business on East 64th St. that served captains of industry and such cultural luminaries as Leonard Bernstein, Joe DiMaggio, and Luciano Pavarotti. Contributions in his memory can be made to HIAS.
PIERSON--Howard, 91, of Framingham, MA formerly of N. Babylon, NY. Died February 6, 2014. For full obituary visit www.stanetsky.com

DENNIS--Victoria Ann, on February 5, 2014, loving mother of Nathan and Simon, and wife of Brian Lehrer, passed away. Vicki was a remarkable woman who cared deeply about and for people--as a social worker, engaged citizen, activist, friend, neighbor, and family member. She was a leader in the Spark program for substance abuse prevention in the New York City High Schools, a PTA president, volunteer at the Food Bank for New York City. She will be missed by all who had the privilege of knowing her. She is also survived by her siblings Donovan, Karen, Raymond and George, and their families; in-laws Ruth and Arthur, Warren and Judith; her extended family and many dear friends. Visitation will be take place at the Weigand Bros. Funeral Home, 49 Hillside Ave. Williston Park N.Y. Sunday from 1pm to 5pm. Funeral Service Monday 10am at the funeral Home. Interment to follow at Cypress Hills Cemetery. In lieu of flowers send donations to the Food Bank for New York City.

ZUBAY--Geoffrey Louis. Professor Geoffrey Louis Zubay, who pioneered early studies on gene expression after the discovery of the double helical structure of DNA and genetic code, died on February 5 in West Palm Beach, FL, where he and his wife resided since 2011. He was 82 years old. The cause of death was cardiac arrest. Born in Chicago November 15, 1931, Dr. Zubay had a very precocious youth and graduated from the University of Chicago with an A.B. in Philosophy at the age of seventeen. He received an M.A. in Physical Chemistry from the University of Chicago in 1952, and a Ph.D. from Harvard University in 1957. He completed three years of post-doctoral study at Kings College of the University of London, and the Rockefeller Institute in New York. Dr. Zubay then established his own lab at the Biology Department of Brookhaven National Laboratory on Long Island in 1961. Three years later Dr. Zubay was recruited to Columbia University where he remained for 41 years. During his tenure at Columbia, Dr. Zubay's lab became renowned for the development of several cell-free systems for examining the expression of genes. This was during a time of great interest in gene expression following elucidation of the structure of DNA and genetic code. In addition to a long distinguished scientific research that included more than 160 publications, Dr. Zubay wrote a widely employed textbook in Biochemistry that survived four editions. He also wrote a Genetics textbook published in 1987. In his later career, his research interests shifted to the origins of life and prebiotic chemistry. This direction led to another text Origins of Life on the Earth and in the Cosmos, for which there were two editions published by Academic Press. In the aftermath of 9/11, Dr. Zubay compiled, along with othercontributing authors Agents of Bioterrorism: Pathogens and their Weaponization published by Columbia University Press. Athletically gifted, Dr. Zubay enjoyed playing basketball with colleagues, swimming daily on the University campus, and relaxed playing poker with friends. After retirement, Dr. Zubay and his wife relocated to San Diego, CA where he served for three years as a visiting research scholar at the Scripps Institute of Oceanography in La Jolla. Dr. Zubay is survived by his wife of 47 years, Bongsoon, his son Geoffrey Pyong, Director of Neurosurgery Department at Memorial Hermann The Woodlands Hospital in Houston, TX, his daughter-in-law, Erin, and three grandchildren, Ryan, Abby, and Geoffrey Mitchell.

ORTENBERG--Arthur. Art, a great pal for 45 years. A one of. I will miss you. Love, Martin Tandler

SHALITA--Alan, M.D. Dr. Shalita was an eminent dermatology scholar and distinguished Chief and mentor to hundreds of dermatology residents. He was also a wonderful and caring friend, who overcame great personal tragedy, always comporting himself with great cheer while inspiring others to achieve their potential. Dr. Shalita's contributions to the advancement of dermatology and patient care are iconic, and he will be missed tremendously. We will miss him most as a dear friend and colleague. Jonah Shacknai Mitchell Wortzman Eugene Gans
MAYERS--Frank. Thanks, Frank. My loving mentor, you took a kid from the Bronx and gave him a life he never expected. Norman Kosarin

ORTENBERG--Art. The Wildlife Conservation Society mourns the death of businessman, philanthropist and conservationist Art Ortenberg. Art, and his late wife, Liz Claiborne, will be remembered as great champions for wildlife and wild places and for the people whose lives are sustained by them. As our colleagues and donors, they helped to launch and sustain our efforts around the globe. For decades, Art and Liz catalyzed conservation actions to benefit some of the world's most iconic species and places. Their leadership in conserving species like elephants, tigers, and jaguars, and their dedication to wild lands in places like Montana, Argentina's Patagonia, and East Africa, were legendary. Their legacy will continue through the work of the Liz Claiborne and Art Ortenberg Foundation, which is a timeless tribute to their passion and beliefs.

PLACHTA--Helen Beizer, 92, of Hartford, CT and Fresh Meadows, NY, passed away on February 2, 2014. Beloved mother of Leslie (Sabine) and Deborah (Alan); grandmother of Miriam, Daniel, and Benjamin. Predeceased by her cherished older sister and three brothers. Helen had to forgo college after her father's unexpected death when she was only twelve. After her husband Aaron's early death she returned to school to get a GED, Phi Beta Kappa college degree, and an MLS, working as head of periodicals at the library of the New York Academy of Medicine until her late 70s. We are all very proud of her and will miss her.

OSTROVSKY--Everett Serge, April 18, 1924 February 7, 2014. A gift to all who knew him. Eternally young, he never lost sight of the simple joys in life or abandoned his childlike wonder. A PhD graduate of the Sorbonne, author of five books, and student of Jean Piaget, his work as a clinical psychologist was marked by great humanity, empathy and insight. He is survived by his loving wife of 47 years Michaela, two daughters Ruti and Nina, grandchildren Carla, Jason, Leor and Yael, and great-grandson Leo.

MORGAN--Col. Tom Graham, On January 22, 2014, of Falls Church, VA died after a short battle with cancer. Tom was a devoted and loving husband of Kenneth Youngert for 27 years and formerly of Margaret Ann Morgan. He was a dedicated and supportive father of Elizabeth Morgan of Boston and Cricket Sutton of Seattle. He is also survived by two precious grandsons, Casey and Garrett and his two beloved dogs, TG and Scooter. Tom earned his Bachelor's degree from Cornell University and later went on to earn his Law degree from Albany Law School and his Masters in Law from George Washington University. Col. Morgan served in the United States Army for 4++ years and remained in the Army Reserve for 23 years. He worked for 38 years as Associate Deputy General Counsel for the Department of Defense at the Pentagon. He retired in 2005 but continued as an expert consultant for the DOD. Col. Morgan was awarded the Meritorious Service Medal for service with the Military Personnel Law Team. Tom was hard working, generous and kind. He had a genuine love of life and others (and dancing). He will be remembered for his warm heart, infectious smile and vivacious personality. Tom will be missed by many but his legacy will live on through all those who loved him. Tom's memorial service will be held on Monday, February 17, 2014 at 11am at St. John's Episcopal Church, 3240 O St NW, Washington, DC. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Make A Wish Foundation.

PERL--Otto. Beloved husband of over 70 years to Susanne, proud father of Lawrence, Monica, and Martin. Cherished "Papa" of Michael, Ze'ev, Elyse, Michal, Doron, Leia, Daniel, and Ella. Born in Vienna in 1915, Otto survived Dachau and Buchenwald, immigrated to the US in 1940, and served in US Army counterintelligence at Camp Ritchie. He created a world-renowned custom tailoring business on East 64th St. that served captains of industry and such cultural luminaries as Leonard Bernstein, Joe DiMaggio, and Luciano Pavarotti. Contributions in his memory can be made to HIAS.

REICH--R. Donald, died on February 3, 2014 of complications from Parkinson's disease. Born in Yonkers, NY in 1921, he was raised by his mother, Alma Shannon, and graduated from Gorton High School, Dartmouth College and Harvard Law School. Donald served as a Naval Officer in World War II, later becoming the President of Airco, Inc., an industrial gas producer, and Vice Chairman of Orion Capital, an insurance holding company. He and his wife Constance Verrill Reich raised their family in Brooklyn Heights, NY, and Ridgewood, NJ, retiring to Redding, CT. Donald spent as much time as he could at Point O' Woods, Fire Island, a community he cherished. He is survived by Connie, his wife of 59 years; his son, Dr. D. Bradford Reich (and wife Patricia Pierce) of Brookline, MA; his son Christopher V. Reich (and wife Eleanor Paschal), of Purchase, NY; and his five grandchildren, Christopher, William, George, Anna and Eleanor. A service will be held at Rye Presbyterian Church, 882 Boston Post Road, Rye, NY at 11am on Saturday, February 15th. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to the Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research, Grand Central Station, PO Box 4777, NY, NY 10163.

SCHNEIDER--Stanley H.,Following loving goodbyes with family, beloved wife Sue and children Becky and Evan, Stanley H. Schneider, a longtime resident of Larchmont, NY passed away on February 7, 2014. Funeral service Monday, February 10 at 10:00am at Larchmont Temple. Interment at Mt. Eden Cemetery.

TAGLIARINO--Margaret Ann "Peggy" 66, of West Cornwall, CT (formerly of New York City) peacefully passed on February 5th after complications of a stroke. Peggy's enthusiasm, laughter and love will be survived by her mother Mrs. A.L. Levine (Blanche), her sister Elizabeth Horowitz (Betsy), her niece Emily Horowitz, her nephew Daniel Horowitz and many dear friends. We miss you as no words can describe. As per Peggy's wishes a memorial celebration of her life will be held in the spring.

TOMLINSON--Karl E.,MD, 86, Psychiatrist, longtime resident of Manhattan, died peacefully on December 27, 2013 in Winter Park, FL, surrounded by loved ones. His daughter Anne-Marie Jones MD, his son-in-law William E. Jones MD, granddaughters Abigail and Megan of Winter Park; sisters Paulette Richardson of Holiday, FL. and Monica Camacho of Brooklyn, NY, along with several nieces, nephews and friends, mourn their loss. His older sister Hyacinth Stephenson is deceased. A memorial service will be held at 11am, March 17, 2014, St. George's Church, East St., Kingston, Jamaica.

ZACKS--Gordon, age 80, passed away peacefully surrounded by family on February 1, 2014. Preceded in death by his wife of 57 years, Carol Sue Zacks; parents, Aaron Zacks and Florence Zacks Melton; and brother, Barry Zacks. Survived by his daughters, Cathy (Michael) Gildenhorn and Kim Zacks; grandchildren, Edward and Elissa Gildenhorn and Ariela Zacks. Gordon graduated from Bexley High School and the Ohio State University. He was Chairman of the Board of RG Barry Corporation. Gordon was a business executive, leadership authority, continuing education advocate and author. He helped strengthen leadership in America and Israel that was Pro-American, Pro-Israel, Pro-human rights and Pro-Democracy. Beloved husband, father, brother, grandfather and trusted friend. He will be missed by all who were blessed to be a part of his life. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Florence Melton Adult Mini School, Attn: Betty Sobelman, 95 Revere Dr. Suite F, Northbrook, IL 60062. Online guestbook at www.epsteinmemorial.com

SAVETSKY--Dr. Lawrence. The Columbia University Department of Otolaryngology/Head & Neck Surgery mourns the passing of our dear friend and colleague, Dr. Lawrence Savetsky. Larry was a member of our department for over 40 years and was renowned for the excellence of his care of adults and children; the chair and lectureship in Pediatric Otolaryngology is named in his honor. We extend our condolences to the Savetsky family: Gudrun, his wife of 55 years; his children Eric and Elke, and their spouses Ann and Andrew; and his beloved grandchildren Lauren and Justin. Dr. Joseph Haddad Jr., Interim Chairman

Williams and son Taylor Williams, three brothers and three grandchildren. Condolences may be sent to the family at www.henryfuneralhome.net.

ZELANKA--Rhoda, died January 25th at age 77. A loving wife, mother, grandmother, sister, niece, aunt and friend. She is survived by Jack, Kerry, Joyce, Ivy, Kyle and Luke, Harvey, Doris, many cousins, nieces and nephews. Loved and lived. Will be missed by those that loved her and there were many.

SHEA--Ronald A. on February 7, 2014. Beloved husband of Dolores nee Aguiar. Devoted father of Ronald S. WEINER--Richard, (May 10, 1927 - January 29th, 2014) was one of the true pioneers in the public relations field. His work to launch the Cabbage Patch Kids as well as other contributions led him to win the Public Relations Society of America Gold Anvil for lifetime achievement, among his many awards. He was the author of 23 books, including Webster's New World Dictionary of Media and Communications and Professional's Guide to Public Relations. His most recent passion was the topic of gossip including a book and an October, 2013 TED Talk. In addition to his career, family and friends meant the world to Dick. He was married to Chick Weiner for fifty-seven years. He is remembered as an excellent husband, father, grandfather, great-grandfather and a friend to many.
